DOC.HEAD: Snow & Ice Move East After Battering Colorado And Wyoming
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `In Colorado ...' to RESTORE dropped word `agent'; picks up 5th graf, `The agent ...'.
DOC.TEXT: A storm packing snow and freezing rain moved eastward across the northern Plains on Wednesday after walloping Wyoming and Colorado with their worst winter storm in years. About 130 miles of Interstate highway remained closed in Wyoming late Wednesday night, and nearly 4,000 state employees in Cheyenne who were told to stay home Tuesday were given Wednesday morning off. More than 300 miles of highway in the state were closed earlier. The storm dumped up to 50 inches of snow in parts of northern Colorado and shut down travel from the Denver area to southeastern Wyoming. In Colorado, a blizzard delayed an agent with the U.S. Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms who was driving to Crested Butte to investigate a bank explosion that killed 13 people. His car skidded on an icy highway and rolled over. The agent escaped injury, and his fellow investigators dubbed him ``Crash.'' In central Iowa, about 60,000 customers of Iowa Power lost electricity Wednesday night due to an ice storm, which snapped tree limbs, bringing down power lines. More than half the households in the Des Moines area were without power, Iowa Power spokesman John McCarroll said. More than 200 businesses and virtually all of the schools in metropolitan Denver, Colorado Springs and many northern Colorado communities remained closed Wednesday or opened late. The fierce storm, driven by winds up to 50 mph, was blamed for at least one traffic death in Colorado, and some highways were still closed and littered with stuck and stalled vehicles Wednesday morning. U.S. Highway 36 between Denver and Boulder resembled a parking lot Tuesday night, according to the State Patrol. At Denver's Stapleton International Airport, nearly all airlines voluntarily stopped flying Tuesday, forcing about 2,000 travelers to spend the night at the terminal. During the height of the storm Tuesday, the Wyoming Highway Patrol closed a number of roads, including about 200 miles of Interstate 80 from the Nebraska border to Rawlins, and about 200 miles of I-25 from the Colorado border north to Casper. By Wednesday afternoon, only a 110-mile stretch of I-25 had been reopened from Wheatland to Casper. Colorado authorities closed I-25 and I-70, the two major thoroughfares through metropolitan Denver, and I-76 to the northeast, virtually closing off the city. Most were reopened Wednesday, but I-25 remained closed from Fort Collins north to the Wyoming state line. At midday Wednesday, snow still fell from central South Dakota to western Nebraska, southeastern Wyoming and northern Colorado. Freezing rain extended from north-central and eastern South Dakota to southeastern Minnesota and much of Iowa. Rain fell to the south and east from Texas to parts of Illinois. Hundreds of vehicles slid into ditches in Iowa, and many rural schools were closed. Many schools in southeastern South Dakota also closed. Snowfall in Colorado varied widely: 50 inches on Mount Evans, 44 inches in Coal Creek Canyon near Boulder and 3 inches at Colorado Springs. Denver received 11.3 inches. Snowplows were out early and in force in Cheyenne, trying to clear side streets and some main roads that were buried under 16 inches of snow, the most to fall on the city since a storm in April 1984 dumped 18 inches, according to the National Weather Service. The cleanup was expected to get easier Thursday, when temperatures were expected to soar into the 50s. ``That's one of the pluses of having the storms here in Wyoming in March and April,'' said meteorologist Jack Daseler. ``The sun's up at a higher angle, it warms up quicker after (the storms), and it's not so bad. It's not like getting one the last week of December when the snow stays around for six or seven weeks.'' In Linden, Texas, a 30-year-old employee of the state Highway Department was killed Wednesday when a lightning bolt struck a hoisted steel beam and electrified a chain he was holding, authorities said. Linden is about 150 miles east of Dallas.

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: ``The Bunny Hop'' has been banned on the Granbury Queen Riverboat for fear the bouncy swing number will capsize the dinner-cruise ship. The 74-foot paddlewheeler began bouncing around wildly on Lake Granbury, near Fort Worth, one night last year. Owner Gary Miller left the pilot house and rushed toward the main deck. ``I couldn't figure it out until I looked downstairs and saw these people doing `The Bunny Hop,''' he said. The boat band still takes requests, but ``The Bunny Hop'' is verboten, Miller said this week.

An opposum with a punky orange hairdo has museum officials stumped. Orange opossums are unheard of among experts, the museum staff said Monday. ``We're sure she hasn't been dyed or anything like that,'' said Holly Coovert, an assistant curator at the Dayton Museum of Natural History. ``She's just orange.'' ``We're trying to figure it out,'' said Tom Hissong, the curator of education. ``All our veterinarians can figure is it's a genetic defect.'' The year-old opossum, known only as ``O.P.,'' was donated by a family who raised her from infancy. ``They found two in the same litter that were orange,'' Ms. Coovert said. ``One got loose later, and the family dog munched it.'' Hair samples from the possum have been sent for analysis to state wildlife experts.

DOC.HEAD: No Voting Early, No Voting Often, Poles Learn Government Chicago-Style
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: This city whose political scandals have made national headlines is teaching the tricks of the trade to Polish officials seeking an American model for restructuring their government. What might sound like a joke to some is part of a program aimed at helping Poland implement democratic reforms in local government after nearly half a century of Communist rule. ``Of all the problems Chicago has had with its reputation _ much of it deserved _ as a place that has problems governmentally and politically, it also has a lot of plusses,'' said Paul Green, a political scientist at Governors State University in suburban University Park. ``And if you want to see where the game's really played for keeps, why go to someplace where they eat quiche?'' Despite the Communist-led government's stunning defeat in last June's elections, ``local government still remains in the hands of the Communist apparatus,'' said Robert Repel, an aide to Mayor Richard M. Daley Supporters of democracy hope to change that in elections set for May. So three Polish reformers have come to the United States to learn how democratic local governments operate. Chicago, one of several cities on their U.S. tour, was chosen because it's Warsaw's sister city and has more Poles than any city outside of Warsaw, Repel said. The reputation for crooked politics in the Windy City (so named because of long-winded politicians of old) was ``not at all'' among topics discussed, Repel said Tuesday, the final day of the Poles' two-day stop in Chicago. The city instead gathered local authorities in various facets of governing _ including finance, trade, crime and the courts _ to share their expertise with the visitors. ``I'm certain that they are aware of all of the good things about Chicago and all of the bad things about Chicago, but we're not talking about political scandals, we're talking about some governmental issues,'' Repel said. But scandals often have been an issue in Chicago. A century of Democratic machine politics made influence-peddling and patronage seem like part of the system. In recent years, as federal prosecutors have cracked down on public corruption and reform has replaced machine politics, dozens of crooked city officials have been sent to jail. One probe, code-named Operation Greylord, exposed the largest judicial corruption scandal in the nation's history. Some 70 judges, lawyers and other court personnel were convicted of bribery and related charges. ``We still have crooked local politics, it's just that the politicians aren't as adept at stealing as they once were,'' Chicago Tribune columnist Mike Royko said in a telephone interview. That may be. Still, the Poles' visit coincided with a primary election campaign that recently has been enlivened by FBI tapes of an alleged mobster saying he had helped engineer Daley's election last year as well as made payoffs to the Cook County Republican chairman. Neither charge has been proved. But most Poles know virtually nothing about Chicago's political reputation, said Wlodzimierz Kocon, one of the visitors. Kocon is a director at the Foundation in Support of Local Democracy, a Warsaw-based group that is training candidates for elections. ``Neither our economy nor our social system can change wthout assistance'' from the United States and cities like Chicago, Kocon said in a meeting with city officials Monday. Afterward, he politely declined to discuss Chicago's reputation, but noted, ``We both have to learn from each other, as much as we can.'' And Chicago could be a good teacher, the sardonic Royko observed: ``We've gone from a very closed form of government to a very open form of government and party loyalty is no longer a prerequisite for a majority of city jobs ... and I assume (the Poles) want to make party loyalty an unnecessary element. So this is really a very good training ground.''

DOC.HEAD: Milan's Fun Fashions Forget the Working Girl
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The message coming down the Milan runway for the fall-winter 1990-91 is so clear it risks becoming monotonous. Short skirts and shorts, long jackets, parkas and duffel coats, these are the staples of next winter's moda Milanese. In recent seasons, Italian designers have presented a varied wardrobe for the modern woman who likes to make up her own style. Not this time. Most blatant is the total absence of below-the-knee hemlines. The new length plays around the thigh in mini-skirts and bermuda shorts. Anything longer looks positively dowdy, like the Basile skirts, which _ mind you _ were several inches above the knee. For those who can't bear to bare their knees, the designers present lots of pants, but they are all in stretch-fabric or knit, also only flattering on a fortunate few. The alternative is to run around all day in evening gowns, the only garment to safely cover the body from hip to ankle. And even in this department, the selection is limited with many evening outfits as short by night as by day. The new skirt is worn with a long jacket either slightly shorter than the skirt or even with it. Sometimes the jacket is tailored, at others it is free and swaying to create a bell shape that is repeated in the wide sleeve. The other big theme of these collections is the parka or duffel coat complete with hood, more often than not trimmed in fur _ ecological plush that is, real skins are definitely out of fashion. Copying from functional ski wear many of the coats have draw string waists or hemlines to keep out winter chills. Even staid Genny and Basile, who showed their fall-winter styles on Tuesday, opted for the short hemline and sporty parka look, leaving their career girl clients in a bind. Genny showed a series of tailored suits in prim and proper flannel that would have been great for the office if the hemline and the jacket had not converged eight inches above the knee. Her trouser styles were pencil slim or pert bermudas _ both not ideal for a long working day. Cozy parkas with a huge fur trimmed hood, were ideal for weekend fun, but not a night out with the boss. Basile did keep the hemline down to only a couple of inches above the knee, but he concentrated more on sportswear than city life with plaid bermuda shorts, riding jackets and loads of gaily colored duffel coats.

DOC.HEAD: Increased Immigration to Israel Stirs Arab Concerns
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: The flood of Soviet immigrants into Israel has roused fears among Arabs that the Jewish state will shun peace efforts and seek more land for a rapidly growing population. They also worry about the improved East-West relations that made the increased flow possible, and about the political revolution in Eastern Europe. ``I don't think we've faced a more serious matter since the 1930s,'' when a massive Jewish immigration to Palestine took place, Foreign Minister Marwan Kassem of Jordan told the weekly Star newspaper last month. At least 300,000 Soviet Jews are expected to reach Israel in the next few years because of the Kremlin's relaxed emigration rules. They now arrive at the rate of about 1,200 a week. That will alter the Palestinian demographic equation that, because of a higher birth rate, they eventually would outnumber Jews in Israel as well as the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. The emigration issue is only one consequence of the new detente, which many Arabs believe seriously undermines their strategy against Israel. Such long-time radical allies of Moscow as Syria and Libya already feel the cooling in Moscow caused by political liberalization and are edging back to the Arab mainstream. In what used to be the Soviet bloc, democratic governments are replacing the rigid Communist regimes that backed the Arabs. Some of the new governments have renewed relations with Israel, which their predecessors broke in 1967. These developments have spurred efforts to forge a new Arab unity. There is talk of reviving a military alliance of Iraq, Syria and Jordan on Israel's borders. Kassem compared the mass Soviet emigration to 1948, when Israel was born and hundreds of thousands of Palestinians fled to Jordan, Syria, Lebanon and Egypt. Yasser Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, and Secretary-General Chedli Klibi of the Arab League called the immigration a ``catastrophe.'' Kuwait's Cabinet said it was ``flagrant aggression.'' About 1 million Jews have applied to leave the Soviet Union and Israeli officials say they expect about 300,000 to arrive in the next three years. Israel's Jewish population now is about 4 million. In a statement to Israel radio last month, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said: ``Arabs oppose all immigration. ... For them, the immigration of Soviet Jews to Israel is a sign of defeat ... in their war against the state of Israel and Zionism.'' Arabs see the mass influx as creating a stronger Israel less willing to make peace on terms Arabs consider acceptable. ``Israel already stands as the major military power in the area, so any increase ... is bound to worry us,'' said Kamel Abu Jaber, a political scientist at the University of Jordan. ``We know there are something like 3 million Soviet Jews. We're talking about the first stage of 1 million arriving. When will the other 2 million arrive? Where will be the next jump?'' He and other Arab analysts believe the latest wave of immigration also could: _ Bring new Jewish settlers to the West Bank, Gaza Strip and Golan Heights, all of which Israel captured in 1967. The return of those lands is a key element in all Arab peace plans and most others. ``This influx will make Israel more instransigent in denying Palestinian rights to regain their lands,'' the United Arab Emirates said. _ Increase Israeli pressure on Palestinians in the occupied lands to move to Jordan, which could threaten the stability of a nation bordering the two most important oil states, Saudi Arabia and Iraq. King Hussein of Jordan said that fits what he described as plans of Israeli hard-liners to make Jordan a substitute Palestinian state. _ Deal another blow to the hope millions of Palestinians have of returning to their homeland or creating a Palestinian state in the West Bank and Gaza. ``Our own refugees, who have spent most of their lives scattered around the world without a home, have the priority over Soviet Jews to return to their homeland, Palestine,'' said a petition signed by 85 members of the Palestine National Council, which acts as the PLO legislature. _ Revive an old fear that Zionists will achieve their dream of gathering most Jews into Palestine, creating pressure for expansion into areas of Lebanon and Jordan that Israeli religious extremists consider part of the ancient ``land of Israel.'' ``Israel has declared its expansionist nature and has proved that nature,'' said Abu Jaber, the Jordanian political scientist.

DOC.HEAD: Missteps, Poor Planning Accompany Attempt At Crackdown
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: President Corazon Aquino's get-tough move against her opponents was widely hailed as a welcome sign of strength, but a Supreme Court rebuff and bloodshed in the north raise doubts about skill in implementing the policy. Last week, the government filed rebellion with murder charges against opposition Sen. Juan Ponce Enrile and six others in connection with the failed Dec. 1-9 coup, in which 113 people were killed. The filing of charges was widely praised by commentators and the media, who recalled the generally mild treatment of conspirators after some of the five previous coup attempts since Mrs. Aquino took office. ``It's a welcome sign,'' said one Western diplomat, speaking last week on condition of anonymity. ``It's about time she showed toughness. The top priority for this government now is survival.'' But in recent days, the strategy shows signs of unraveling because of tactical blunders. At issue was a decision to indict Enrile and the others for ``rebellion with murder,'' a charge used by the late President Ferdinand Marcos but which Mrs. Aquino nullified in 1987 as ``repressive.'' Simple rebellion is punishable by six to 12 years imprisonment and defendants are normally allowed bail. Rebellion with murder, however, provides a life sentence with no bail. That would keep Enrile and the others in detention even before the trial began. On Tuesday, however, the Supreme Court released Enrile and two fellow defendants on bail, and a justice said the tribunal would decide later on the validity of the dual charge. Presidential Press Secretary Tomas Gomez today said the ruling ``is neither a setback for the government, nor is it a victory for Enrile because the main topic has not been decided'' _ the validity of the charge. But during his week in custody, Enrile held frequent news conferences, where he sought to portray himself as an aggrieved underdog. He often told reporters he was praying for Mrs. Aquino, whom he helped sweep to power in 1986, and thanked her for the ``free publicity.'' Sen. Ernesto Maceda, a lawyer and frequent administration critic, said the government had tranformed Enrile ``into a martyr and a hero.'' Before leaving the police headquarters where he was held, Enrile signed autographs for his jailers. They cheered when he told them, ``if you need anything, just come to my office.'' ``Whoever was responsible for the misguided advice and ensuing fiasco should ... perhaps consider offering their resignations,'' said The Manila Times, an independent daily. Compounding the problem is the public perception that evidence against Enrile is weak. In the charge sheet, the government based its case is based on statements by three waiters who claimed they saw a coup leader, former Lt. Col. Gregorio ``Gringo'' Honasan, at Enrile's home on the first day of the December coup attempt. Enrile's lawyer, Renato Cayetano, claims he has 53 witnesses ready to testify that Honasan was not there. The waiters did not testify about any alleged conversations between Enrile and Honasan, according to documents made public. ``We can only hope the government has sufficient evidence to back up the charges,'' said the independent Philippine Daily Inquirer. ``Otherwise, it would lend credence to the Enrile camp's accusations that the senator was held on a spurious charge as part of a grand political vendetta.'' The decision to indict the seven on the controversial dual charge may also have contributed to Sunday's bloodshed in Tuguegarao, 250 miles north of Manila. Officials went to Tuguegarao, capital of Cagayan province, to arrest suspended provincial Gov. Rodolfo Aguinaldo, one of the seven defendants. Aguinaldo told reporters he was willing to surrender on rebellion charges but not murder because ``I didn't kill anybody.'' After four days of negotiations, Aguinaldo's followers seized a hotel, taking Brig. Gen. Oscar Florendo prisoner and trapping Local Governments Secretary Luis Santos on the second floor. Florendo was killed when government troops recaptured the hotel. Aguinaldo escaped with an estimated 200 armed followers. Mrs. Aquino says Florendo was murdered by Aguinaldo's forces. ``Most lawyers believe that the situation in Cagayan would never have ended in bloodshed if government prosecutors had not `reinvented' the charge of rebellion complexed with murder,'' wrote commentator Luis Beltran in The Manila Standard. ``Was it worth the price just to show decisiveness and firmness?''
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Robert Reid has been AP chief of bureau in Manila since September 1986.

DOC.HEAD: Postal Rate Hike: The Process is Under Way
LaserPhoto WX7
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Postal Service is beginning steps to raise prices, even while conceding that the new rates may be ``too much, too soon.'' More expensive postage, including a 30-cent first class stamp, is still nearly a year away thanks to a lengthy and complex ratemaking process established by Congress. The mail agency is facing a deficit of between $1.4 billion and $1.6 billion in this fiscal year, forcing it to begin the effort to raise revenue. It is required by law to break even over time and no longer receives any taxpayer subsidy. ``I think it should have been 28 or 29 cents, and we want to pay that back to the American people. We want to improve service and operate below the rate of inflation. We want that to be translated into never again saying `too much, too soon,''' Postmaster General Anthony M. Frank said Tuesday. ``We cannot ignore that increases in postal costs do occur, just as they do in any business,'' said Robert Setrakian, chairman of the postal service's board of governors, which proposed the rate hikes. Setrakian estimated that the higher rates would cost the average individual $10 to $11 annually. Frank said the rate increase is more than the inflation that has occurred since the current prices took effect in 1988 because of unexpectedly high costs. Productivity, although improving recently, didn't increase as fast as expected, he said. In addition, costs were considerably higher than planned, including employee health costs and the requirement that the postal service contribute funds to help defray the federal budget deficit in recent years. Those factors forced the agency to seek a 19 percent rate increase to cover a period when inflation is projected to total about 14 percent, Frank said. Opposition to higher prices came immediately from diverse directions. The New York State Consumer Protection Board announced that it will intervene in the rate case to oppose the plan. ``It is ludicrous to ask consumers to pay more for slower mail service,'' said Richard M. Kessel, the commission's executive director. The proposed increase is excessive and self-defeating, the American Bankers' Association argued. ``Such postal rate increases imposed upon business ultimately, in some fashion, will be paid by busness customers,'' said Vincent A. Liguori, chairman of ABA's Postal Service Committee. ``The people are going to have to save the post office from itself,'' said consumer advocate Ralph Nader, who proposed to set up a grassroots organization of mail users. The planned rate hike is ``unreasonable and unjustified,'' charged Tracey Schreft of the U.S. Chamber of Commerce. And Robert Kamerschen, head of ADVO System Inc., the nation's largest advertising mailer, said he is concerned that raising rates will drive profitable mail out of the postal system just at the time it's needed most. The vote Tuesday by the postal board of governors was just the first step in the process. The question now goes to the independent Postal Rate Commission. The five-member commission has 10 months to consider the case. It will hold hearings and solicit information from the postal service, businesses and individuals. Following that, the commission will send a set of proposed rates back to the postal governors. Often it agrees with the original request, but not always. In 1984, for example, the postal service proposed a 23-cent first class rate. The Postal Rate Commission cut that back to 22 cents. The governors accepted that decision. But they don't have to. If the governors can put together a unanimous vote they can overrule the commission. That happened in 1981, when the governors raised the first-class rate from 15 cents to 20 cents even though the commission said 18 cents would be enough.

DOC.HEAD: Examples of Higher Postal Rates
With PM-Postal Rates
DOC.TEXT: The new rates proposed by the board of governors of the U.S. Postal Service would mean higher mail costs for most individuals and businesses. Here are some examples of the changes when the new rates take effect, probably sometime in early 1991: _Individual cost of mailing a letter or paying a bill: 30 cents, up from 25 cents. _Cost to mail a regular post card: 20 cents, up from 15 cents. _Price of sending a seven-pound package: $5.06, up from $4.00. _Charge to a bank to send a three-ounce statement: 76 cents, up from 65 cents. _Department store cost to mail a pre-sorted bill: 26 cents, up from 21 cents. _Price to send a credit-card bill, sorted according to the full nine-digit ZIP code: 25.3 cents, up from 20.5 cents. _Utility company cost to send a bill with imprinted bar code, allowing it to be handled by machines: 24.3 cents, up from 20 cents. _Lawyer's cost to send one-pound of legal documents by priority mail: $2.75, up from $2.40. _Charge to send eight ounces of high-speed business information via Express Mail: $9.75, up from $8.75. _Cost for two-pounds of urgent business materials via Express Mail: $13.75, up from $12.00. _Postage for a typical weekly newsmagazine: 16 cents, up from 13.5 cents. _Cost of sending a somewhat heavier monthly magazine: 37.4 cents, up from 29.7 cents. _Postage for two ounces of advertising, with special bar code imprinted to permit handling by new automated machinery: 16.1 cents, down from 16.7 cents. _Rate for half-pound catalog, sorted according to ZIP code: 33.1 cents, up from 27.1 cents. _Charge for advertising mail, sorted in advance according to the sequence of houses that the letter carrier visits: 9.6 cents, down from 10.1 cents. _Cost of sending a local three-pound business package: $2.00, up from $1.58. _Book club cost to mail a four-pound package: $2,26, up from $1.95.

DOC.HEAD: Airlines Improve On-Time Performance
DOC.TEXT: Major airlines improved in the number of on-time flights and received fewer baggage handling complaints in January, the government says. The Transportation Department, in its monthly Air Travel Consumer Report, said Tuesday the largest domestic carriers reported that 77.6 percent of their flights were on time in January, compared with 70.2 percent in December. The January performance was also a slight improvement over a year ago, when the on-time rate was 76.7 percent. Delays caused by mechanical failures are not counted. Southwest Airlines had the best record for the month, with 82.5 percent on-time performance, and Eastern had the worst, with 70.7 percent. Reports of mishandled baggage averaged 8.7 per 1,000 passengers, compared with 12.78 in December, which was the worst performance since the department began the consumer report in 1987.

DOC.HEAD: AMA Calls for Expanding Medicaid, Requiring Health Insurance
DOC.TEXT: The American Medical Association today proposed revamping the nation's health care system by expanding Medicaid and requiring employers to provide health insurance to fulltime employees. The AMA's 16-point plan also would create state risk pools to provide group insurance policies for the medically uninsurable, small businesses and others unable to afford coverage under the current system. The plan would cost about $60 billion, the AMA said, but it did not suggest where the money should come from. The physicians' group said its proposals are aimed at offering health care coverage to all Americans, regardless of income, and preserving patients' freedom to choose their health-care provider. ``The individual's freedom of choice remains a cornerstone of the American system,'' said Dr. Alan R. Nelson, AMA president. Revision in the current system is ``badly needed,'' Nelson said, but ``it would be counterproductive to `fix' aspects of our system that are not broken.'' The AMA's proposal is similar to a $66 billion plan recommended last week by the U.S. Bipartisan Commission on Comprehensive Health Care, known as the Pepper Commission for its first chairman, the late Rep. Claude Pepper, D-Fla. Both proposals are aimed at closing the gaps in the current health care system. The nation's health-care bill is expected to reach $600 billion this year, more than 11 percent of the gross national product. Yet more than 33 million Americans lack health insurance. The highlights of the AMA plan include: _Expanding Medicaid to all people below the poverty level, and establishing a uniform set of benefits. Medicaid now covers fewer than half of those living below the poverty line, and eligibility and benefits vary from state to state. _Requiring employers to provide health insurance for all fulltime employees and their families, and eliminating state-mandated benefits. Employers would be allowed tax deductions to help with costs. _Establishing state risk pools to make coverage available for the medically uninsurable and for others for whom individual health insurance policies are too expensive and group coverage is not available. About 15 states currently have such pools. _Expanding private sector coverage of long-term care with tax incentives. _Revising medical malpractice laws to reduce liability insurance costs for physicians and the practice of defensive medicine, such as ordering tests and procedures that otherwise might not be ordered.

DOC.HEAD: GOP Renewing Fight to Permit Full Payments to Working Elderly
DOC.TEXT: Congressional Republicans are renewing a 25-year-old fight to allow more older Americans to draw full Social Security pensions even if they continue to work. Republicans say they will try to force repeated votes in the Democratic-controlled House and Senate to get their way this year. ``We are going to vote on it over and over and over again,'' said Sen. Phil Gramm, R-Texas. For the moment, the Bush administration is on the sidelines because by some estimates the change would cost the Treasury about $4 billion a year in lost taxes. Sponsors of the bill say the government actually would end up with more money as former retirees returned to the work force. The battle is over a provision that is as old as the Social Security system itself. The ``retirement test'' or ``earnings limitation'' restricts the amount of wages a person age 62 to 70 may earn without losing any Social Security pension. A person age 62, 63 or 64 may earn $6,840 a year without penalty; for each $2 earned above that level, the person forfeits $1 in benefits. A person who has reached 65 but has not yet turned 70 gives up $1 for each $3 earned above $9,360. There is no restriction on those 70 and older. The GOP bill would repeal the earnings limitation for those 65 and older, as the party first promised in the 1964 party platform on which Barry Goldwater ran. The limitation is ``a government-sponsored program to push seniors out of the work force and into the rocking chair,'' Senate Republican Leader Bob Dole of Kansas told a news conference Tuesday. ``In my opinion, that's age discrimination of the worst sort.'' ``It is time that this Depression-era fossil was done away with,'' said Rep. Dennis Hastert, R-Ill., chief House sponsor of the bill. Hastert said 181 of the 435 House members have signed on as cosponsors, as have 18 of the 100 senators. A big reduction in the earnings limit was approved by the full House and by the Senate Finance Committee last year but died in the Senate as part of a deficit-reduction agreement. Democratic leaders have fought the repeal bill over the years for two reasons. They note the first limit was placed in the law in 1939, even before the first Social Security check was ever written, to ensure that pensions went only to people who were retired. Secondly, congressional analysts say that repealing the earnings limit would benefit only the wealthiest 10 percent of older Americans. According to the House Ways and Means Committee, more than 8 million people age 65 through 69 received Social Security benefits in 1986. Although one of every five beneficiaries had some earnings that year, only 600,000 earned more than the limit and, thus, forfeited part of their pension. ``It's an outdated idea that penalizes productive older Americans who choose to remain in the work place,'' said Sen. Rudy Boschwitz, R-Minn. ``If we are serious about tax equity, this is the place to start,'' said Rep. John J. Rhodes III, R-Ariz. Backers of the bill say the earnings limitation, in combination with federal and state income taxes and Social Security taxes, has the effect of pushing some older Americans into a 70 percent tax bracket.

DOC.HEAD: Elizabeth Taylor Lobbies for Money to Combat AIDS
LaserPhoto WX8
DOC.TEXT: Her best movies may be behind her and she's no longer a congressional wife, but Elizabeth Taylor can still draw a crowd on Capitol Hill. The movie star and outspoken advocate of more AIDS spending used her celebrity appeal Tuesday to help promote a new bill that would provide $600 million in emergency aid to care for people with the disease. ``We need money _ we need lots of money, and we need it now,'' she said. ``Our cities and states are being choked by the enormous cost of caring for AIDS patients.'' She helped draw a crowd of television cameras and reporters to a news conference at which Sens. Edward Kennedy, D-Mass., and Orrin Hatch, R-Utah, unveiled their bipartisan AIDS bill. Later, she was the main witness at a House hearing on AIDS. ``It took Elizabeth Taylor to get you to one of my hearings,'' the subcommittee chairman, Rep. Barbara Boxer, D-Calif., said to Rep. Richard Durbin, D-Ill. Appearing with Taylor were lawmakers from both parties, leaders on the AIDS issue and mayors including Democrats David Dinkins of New York and Ray Flynn of Boston and Republican Dick Berkley of Kansas City, Mo. The bill would provide $300 million in direct emergency assistance to 13 cities with the worst AIDS problems. Another $300 million would go to states to develop comprehensive programs to care for people with AIDS, or acquired immune deficiency syndrome. Much of the urban aid would be directed at big city hospitals which are swamped with impoverished AIDS victims. Kennedy said the rest of the money would be aimed at small cities and rural areas, now seeing the greatest increase in AIDS cases. Taylor, whose list of former husbands includes Sen. John Warner, R-Va., is the founding chairman of the American Foundation for AIDS Research. She wore a dark green dress, her black hair swept high above her ahead, and appeared to have put back on some of the weight she shed in a well-publicized diet. Later, Taylor attended a White House dinner honoring Italian Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti. She told reporters she had spoken to Barbara Bush on Monday about AIDS. ``She's very informed and very receptive. She knows a lot about the issue,'' the actress said. ``I came to Washington for AIDS. In a way it was kind of therapeutic for me,'' the actress said, referring to the recent death of her friend and companion, publisher Malcolm Forbes. The fuss over Taylor on Capitol Hill was noted by Belinda Mason, a member of the National Commission on AIDS. While saying she appreciated Taylor's appearance, she added: ``I think it's kind of sad we have to have Miss Taylor ... to get the kind of attention this issue needs. I find that demeaning as a person with AIDS.'' Taylor said she was concerned that there was ``a very disturbing resurgence of ignorance and misinformation'' about AIDS, including the suggestion that AIDS affects only homosexuals, drug users, the poor and minorities. ``Sadly, the darkest days of the AIDS crisis still lie ahead of us,'' she said. ``Hundreds of thousands of lives hang in the balance unless we begin to confront AIDS as a true national medical emergency.''

DOC.HEAD: Atwater Being Treated for Benign Brain Tumor
DOC.TEXT: Republican Party chairman Lee Atwater will undergo treatment for a benign growth on the right side of his brain and his doctor says he should be back at work next week. ``No surgery is planned and we expect no difficulty with followup treatments,'' Dr. Edward R. Laws said Tuesday. Mary Matalin, chief of staff at the Republican National Committee, said it was ``business as usual at the RNC, except for the fact that what used to be the chairman's office is now a flower shop.'' Matalin said Atwater ``has stayed on top of political developments across the country and is eager to get back to work.'' Laws, chairman of the department of Neurosurgery at George Washington University Medical Center, said Atwater should be able to resume ``a reasonable work schedule and normal activities next week.'' ``I've never led a normal life,'' an aide quoted Atwater as saying. The hard-driving political operative collapsed Monday while addressing a breakfast meeting of financial supporters of Sen. Phil Gramm, R-Tex. He was rushed to a hospital, and doctors performed a needle biopsy Tuesday morning, a procedure in which a thin needle is used to remove cells from the affected area. Laws did not specify the non-surgical treatment, but radiation is commonly used in such cases. A native of South Carolina, the 39-year-old Atwater managed President Bush's 1988 campaign and was the president's choice to become chairman of the Republican National Committee. Atwater met Bush in 1973. The South Carolinian came to Washington to take over as executive director of College Republicans. Bush was RNC chairman. Bush and two of his predecessors in the White House, Ronald Reagan and Richard Nixon, were among those calling the hospital to wish the chairman well.

DOC.HEAD: Jerusalem Council Rebuffs Bush on Future of Holy City
DOC.TEXT: An angry Mayor Teddy Kollek gathered his City Council in a Jewish neighborhood built on the edge of Arab east Jerusalem and criticized the United States for opposing Jewish settlement there. The special meeting Tuesday was just the latest reflection of an uproar that began three days earlier when President Bush said aid to Israel could be affected by the Israeli government's policy of settling Jews on captured land. That land includes east Jerusalem. For 23 years, Israel and the United States have disagreed about the status of Jerusalem, a city fought over for centuries because it is holy to Jews, Christians and Moslems. Although the United States and most other countries have never recognized Israel's annexation of east Jerusalem, U.S. presidents have previously not challenged Israel's building programs there. The council resolution repeats Israel's stand that Jerusalem's Arab eastern sector, annexed after its capture from Jordan along with the West Bank in the 1967 Middle East war, was part of ``the eternal capital of the Jewish people.'' ``Declarations that differentiate between the status of various Jerusalem neighborhoods and prejudice the rights of (Jewish) immigrants to come and live in Jerusalem ... do not contribute to the overall peace process,'' it says. Kollek said he felt ``offended'' by recent American statements about Israel's settlement policies. Since 1967, seven new Jewish neighborhoods have been built on the fringes of east Jerusalem, which is home to about 150,000 Palestinians. An estimated 120,000 Jewish residents now live in these ``suburbs,'' including about 15,000 in the Neve Yaacov neighborhood where Tuesday's council session was held. More construction is planned, some to house the thousands of Jews expected to immigrate here from the Soviet Union. The issue of Soviet resettlement has angered Palestinians in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip and in Jerusalem. They have been rebelling against Israeli rule for the past 27 months in hopes of establishing an independent state with Jerusalem _ known in Arabic as al-Quds, or ``the holy'' _ as its capital. ``It is a question that is not subject to negotiations,'' Palestinian activist Sari Nusseibeh said in a telephone interview Tuesday. ``East Jerusalem is the capital of the occupied Palestinian state.'' He added: ``The unilateral action of Israel having annexed it does not change the historical facts and the political facts.'' Nusseibeh, a philosophy professor whose family is believed to have come to Jerusalem with the Arab conquerer Saladin in the 12th Century, said he accepted Israel's demand that the city remain undivided. However, he said, ``It could be a city with two capitals or the seats of two capitals.'' Such a compromise is ruled out by the Austrian-born Kollek, who says it would lead to rebuilding the walls that separated Jews and Arabs before 1967. ``Two capitals in one city would mean two laws, two police forces, two customs courts,'' Kollek told reporters. ``Within no time you would have the wall up again that we had before.'' But Israel's capital is now in practice divided _ by the Palestinian uprising. Before the revolt began in December 1987, Israelis went regularly to shop on Saladin Street, the main Arab shopping area, on the Jewish holy day of Saturday when virtually all shops in Jewish west Jerusalem are closed. Now, few Israelis are seen in east Jerusalem on Saturday, or any other day. Jewish cab drivers often refuse fares to the area, and the government is building a new bypass road to allow residents of West Bank Jewish settlements to get to their homes without going through east Jerusalem.

DOC.HEAD: 1980s Crunch Left Its Mark on Agricultural Lenders
DOC.TEXT: The financial crunch on farmers during the 1980s left its mark on the major agricultural lenders by changing their shares of the credit market, says an Agriculture Department analyst. In 1980, the cooperatively owned Farm Credit System was the giant among lenders with 44.1 percent of the market, followed by commercial banks with a 31.3 percent piece of the action. But Doug Duncan of the department's Economic Research Service said the two lenders ``nearly reversed their positions'' by 1989, with commercial banks owning 40.6 percent market share while the FCS dropped to an estimated 32.5 percent. The Farmers Home Administration, long known as the government's lender of last resort to people denied loans by others, began the decade with 14.6 percent of the market, rose to 20.6 percent in 1987 and probably wound up last year with an 18.7 percent share. Duncan, writing in the March issue of Agricultural Outlook magazine, said ``only life insurance companies have retained a fairly constant market share,'' which ranged between 8.2 percent and 10 percent in the 1980s. Life insurance companies, he added, were the only ones of the four lender groups that were relatively unaffected by direct regulatory or legislative action during the decade. For example, the FmHA has seen its lending thrust changed from direct lending to more guarantees for privately made loans. In 1980, 99 percent of the agency's farm loans was earmarked as direct loans. By 1989, only 46 percent went to direct loans and 54 percent to guarantees. Looking at the FCS, Duncan said the network of banks and associations ``nearly collapsed in 1985'' but was saved by a series of legislative actions culminating in the Agricultural Credit Act of 1987. ``The act radically changed the structure of the FCS,'' he wrote. ``It required district-level mergers between federal land banks and federal intermediate credit banks, creating new farm credit banks.'' Further, the new credit banks were then allowed to merge across the system's 12 districts to as few as six banks. The law also permitted mergers among banks for cooperatives, and mergers between federal land bank associations and production credit associations. More structural changes are anticipated as the system ``strives to become more efficient and regain its market share'' of the loan business, Duncan said. Commercial banks were deregulated at the federal level in the early 1980s. As the decade progressed, many states relaxed their regulations against branch banking, and interstate banking was fostered. ``The farm- and oil-related contractions, combined with surging bank failure rates and new failure resolution policies, led to greater differences between large and small banks' performance,'' Duncan wrote. Nearly 1,600 banks, mostly small, went out of business between 1982 and 1989, and Duncan expects the trend to continue. ``Even though agriculture traditionally has been served by small, independent banks, as of midyear (1989) the largest banks held nearly one-quarter of commercial bank farm debt,'' he said. ``And the big banks are increasing their share.''

Dry conditions still hung on in the northern Great Plains, but rain and above-normal temperatures continued to boost winter wheat prospects in the central and southern plains, according to the government's Joint Agricultural Weather Facility. ``In Kansas, crop condition was good except in the central and north-central area, where soil moisture was still short,'' the facility said Tuesday in its report for Feb. 26-March 4. ``Insect and disease problems were very light.'' The facility is operated by the Agriculture and Commerce departments. Weekly reports cover wheat and crop conditions but do not include production forecasts. Relatively warm weather and ample moisture supplies hastened wheat growth in Oklahoma, while the crop's condition was reported good in Arkansas and fair to good in Missouri. Rain also helped the Texas crop. But the report added, ``The northern Great Plains remained dry. In Nebraska, winter wheat was fair to poor. Wind damaged fields in the northern and western areas.'' Wheat was ``breaking dormancy'' in eastern and southeastern areas of Nebraska but were under stress from lack of moisture. ``In Montana, winter wheat was fair to good,'' the report said. ``Growth was good in California,'' although the numbers of Russian wheat aphids continued to increase in the Sacramento Valley. Crop conditions were reported good to fair in Washington, while in Oregon winter wheat was said to be fair in the east and good to excellent in the western part of the state. ``In the Corn Belt and Southeast, winter wheat was fair to good, with adequate moisture supplies,'' the report said. `` The crop was breaking dormancy in portions of the Corn Belt.''

The Agriculture Department says farmers who participated in the 1989 corn and sorghum programs will get subsidies totaling about $1.08 billion later this month. Most corn and sorghum producers requested advance payments at the time they signed up in last year's program. Those included corn payments of $2.6 billion and sorghum payments $250 million, John Stevenson, acting executive vice president of the Commodity Credit Corp., said Tuesday. Payments now due farmers include about $780 million in corn ``deficiency'' payments and $145 million in ``0-92'' payments, he said. Sorghum producers will get about $120 million in deficiency payments and $35 million in 0-92 payments. Deficiency payments are basically the difference between target prices and market prices, or basic price support rate, whichever is higher. Under the so-called 0-92 provision, wheat and feed grains producers have the option of not planting on all or a portion of their permitted acreage and still collect payments for up to 92 percent of their permitted crop acreage.

DOC.HEAD: Bennett Says Multi-Phase Approach to Steer Kids From Drugs
DOC.TEXT: Teaching children to stay away from drugs requires a lot more than lectures from teachers, says national drug policy director William J. Bennett. It takes tough school policy, community involvement and law enforcement, too. ``This is not about lock 'em up,'' he said Tuesday in a speech on drug education at George Mason University in suburban Fairfax, Va. ``It is about establishing an environment in which good things flourish and bad things don't.'' Recounting a visit two weeks ago to a drug-infested Los Angeles neighborhood where police barricaded certain areas and operated street patrols with local residents, Bennett said crime decreased, as expected. ``But something else happened, too _ something you might not expect: school attendance went up _ way up. Perhaps as many as 200 additional students went to school once a police presence was established. ``The police made it safe to go to school,'' he said. ``They moved kids from the streets back into the classroom. If that isn't drug prevention, then I don't know what is.'' Some critics have said Bennett and the drug control strategy he developed is too weighted towards law enforcement, with 71 percent of the proposed $10.6 billion drug budget for 1991 devoted to law enforcement and 29 percent to demand reduction, including education and treatment. But Bennett said, ``Too many insist that our drug policy options force us to choose between enforcement and education. That's wrong, flat-out wrong.'' The former education secretary said, ``Education can provide the answer'' to turn young people away from drugs. But he said education must be well-rounded, and anti-drug courses alone won't ``inoculate our children from the temptations of drug use.'' They must be included in a balanced program that stresses resistance to peer pressure in a school that maintains rigid anti-drug policies, Bennett said. And he said they will work if the total effort _ in the school, at home and in the community _ is on building character and self-esteem ``through hard work and achievement.'' Some mistakes have been made in past drug education efforts, he said, and one is ``to pretend that what adolescents need most is merely more information about drugs.'' ``If anything, well-packaged information on drugs can even serve to pique youthful curiosity about them,'' he said. ``Another mistake we have sometimes made is trying to scare children with drug horror stories,'' he said. But many students ``are too skeptical to believe them or too smart and aware to be persuaded that every drug encounter leads to fatal injury.'' ``The most encouraging signs today come from drug education programs that stress peer resistance: learning how to say no to peers,'' he said. Tough school policies also play a strong role, he said, and the best are those which suspend students and notify their parents if they use drugs and which expel repeat offenders. ``Young people know hypocrisy when they see it,'' Bennett said. ``If principals don't walk it like instructors talk it, students will walk it as they wish. ... Talking a good game is insufficient to the task.''

DOC.HEAD: Retirement of Top US Spy Plane Leaves Some Uneasy
LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: The SR-71 Blackbird spy plane, star of American aerial snooping for 25 years, didn't look like museum material on its record-setting final coast-to-coast flight that took just over an hour. But it soon will be, to the regret of some admirers. ``This is one of the first victims of the effort to scale back defense,'' Sen. John Warner, R-Va., said Tuesday after Blackbird No. 17972 marked its retirement by whizzing from Los Angeles to Washington, D.C, in record time of 68 minutes, 17 seconds _ not counting time for takeoff and landing. It also set four other speed marks along the 2,404-mile route. The Air Force is donating the plane to the Smithsonian Institution, which plans to display it here at the Washington Dulles International Airport wing of the National Air and Space Museum. The full Blackbird fleet was officially retired two months ago. Warner, the ranking Republican on the Senate Armed Services Committee, said the Blackbird is still unmatched as a technological wonder, but is being assigned to the junk heap because of a growing perception in the United States that military spending must be reduced as East-West tensions ease. ``I cannot honestly say this is a happy day for me,'' said Ben Rich, the Lockheed Aeronautical System Co. executive who helped design the black, dagger-shaped plane. Rich said he had only one parting sentiment: ``Bye-bye, Blackbird.'' Congress, in agreeing last fall with the Air Force's decision to retire the twin-engine Blackbirds, said advances in technology enable satellites to do similar work more cheaply than the spy plane, which first entered service in 1964. Doubts about the decision remain. George Carver Jr., an intelligence specialist at the Center for Strategic and International Studies in Washington, said in a telephone interview that he doubted the wisdom of ``giving up an asset that has been extremely useful'' in providing intelligence data. The Blackbird's coast-to-coast dash easily eclipsed the previous time record of 3 hours, 38 minutes, set in 1963 by a Boeing 707. The spy plane took a running start, refueling over the Pacific Ocean at 60,000 feet before heading east from the California coastline and crossing its finish line near Salisbury, Md., said Malvern Gross, president of the National Aeronautic Association, which certifies aviation records. The Blackbird then refueled before cruising in to Dulles Airport. The flight also set three city-to-city speed records: 2,153.24 mph between Los Angeles and Washington; 2,242.48 mph between St. Louis and Cincinnati and 2,200.94 mph between Kansas City, Mo., and Washington. The pilot was Lt. Col. Ed Yeilding, and Lt. Col. J.T. Vida was the reconnaissance systems officer. It was one of the few public displays of a Blackbird. And despite the rush to publicize this final flight, most details of the plane's design and capabilities are still top secret. The Air Force won't even say how many of the planes exist. Maj. Suzanne Randle of the Strategic Air Command's headquarters at Offutt Air Force Base, Neb., said nine Blackbirds are going to museums, three are being mothballed at Palmdale, Calif., and three will be used by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration for research. Ms. Randle said she could not say whether that accounted for all the planes. The highflying Blackbird regularly flew missions over heavily defended North Vietnam and provided intelligence in many other regions, including the Middle East and China. The plane can outrun the fastest fighters and has never been shot down. Built to withstand temperatures of more than 800 degrees Fahrenheit, its skin is a titanium alloy instead of the aluminum used on most airplanes. It can sustain a speed of Mach 3, or three times the speed of sound, but its maximum speed is classified.

DOC.HEAD: House-Passed Bill Would Tighten FmHA Debt Collection
DOC.TEXT: The farmer's lender of last resort, the Farmers Home Administration, will be less lenient with delinquent borrowers if a bill approved by the House becomes law. The House by voice vote Tuesday passed legislation that would close loopholes in the 1987 Agricultural Credit Act that lawmakers said caused abuse of the law. ``We've discovered some farmers have found loopholes big enough to drive their tractors through,'' said Rep. Butler Derrick, D-S.C. ``Many of the abuses are downright scandalous.'' The bill's author, Rep. Glenn English, D-Okla., emphasized, ``This is a very, very small number of people we are talking about.'' But he said some of the abuses have been multimillion-dollar in scale. The Senate is writing a similar bill under the leadership of Sen. Kent Conrad, D-N.D., chairman of the agricultural credit subcommittee. Conrad said he doesn't expect any major obstacles and believes whatever difference might exist between the House and Senate versions will be settled quickly in conference committee. House members said the measure was an effort to make a program that was well intended work better. ``Since the act of 1987 became law it has helped thousands of ranchers and producers,'' said Rep. Thomas Coleman, R-Mo., the bill's cosponsor. ``These amendments will strengthen the act.'' The National Family Farm Coalition, however, says the legislation threatens the small farmer's existence. And the National Farmers Union voted against the proposed changes at its national convention in Oklahoma City on Monday. The credit act was designed to prevent FmHA from forcing family farmers off their land if the government could make more money from a restructured loan than through the foreclosure and liquidation process. The options available to the deeply indebted borrowers have been stretching out repayment, consolidating loans, reducing interest rates, deferring payments and reducing the amount owed, known as a writedown. Borrowers that FmHA finds cannot manage a restructured loan have been able to keeps their property through a buyout, paying only the net recovery value _ the appraised market value minus the amount FmHA would have spent foreclosing on the property. However, both the congressional General Accounting Office and he inspector general's office in the Agriculture Department, have said that FmHA is vulnerable to even more losses than it already has sustained if its loan-making and servicing procedures aren't changed. The GAO says about half of FmHA's $23 billion outstanding loans are owed by delinquent borrowers. The bill approved by the House and supported by the Bush administration would: _Limit to $250,000 the amount FmHA could write down for any one borrower. _Allow a borrower only one writedown and one net recovery buyout. _Let the FmHA consider all of the borrower's assets, except those necessary for family living, when calculating a writedown. Currently, the agency only considers the assets used in calculating the original loan. _Extend from two years to 10 years the time that the government has to collect profits made by farmers who sell their property after buying out their loan at net recovery value. _Require borrowers to act in ``good faith'' as defined by FmHA regulations to be eligible for net recovery buyouts. _Extend the time periods in which borrowers may apply for restructuring, in which FmHA must process these applications and in which borrowers may exercise the option for a net recovery buyout.

DOC.HEAD: Conservative Thomas Set for Swearing in as Federal Appeals Judge
DOC.TEXT: Conservative civil rights official Clarence Thomas is set to become a federal appeals judge after winning Senate confirmation despite criticism from senior citizens and liberal groups. ``I believe he will be an excellent judge,'' Sen. John C. Danforth, R-Mo., said after the Senate confirmed Thomas on Tuesday on a voice vote. Danforth, who led the confirmation drive, said the Senate ``recognized in Clarence Thomas ability, accomplishment and dedication to justice.'' The Senate as late as Monday night had planned to take a roll call vote on Thomas but called it off after it became obvious that it would be lopsided. The 41-year-old Thomas becomes a judge of the U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia, which because of the high-profile cases that come before it is sometimes called the nation's second highest court behind the Supreme Court. His outspoken criticism of hiring quotas and affirmative action programs as chairman of the Equal Opportunity Employment Commission over the last eight years has won praise from conservatives. Liberals, however, were often critical of Thomas, one of the most visible black officials in the Reagan and Bush administrations. Danforth and other supporters stressed that Thomas rose the hard way from a poverty-ridden farm in rural Georgia to Yale Law School graduate and prominent federal official. They also stressed what they described as his proven legal ability. Critics complained that the statute of limitations on thousands of age-discrimination cases lapsed with no action taken while Thomas was in charge of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission. They said he failed to cooperate with congressional investigations of these lapses. When Thomas at his confirmation hearing sought to blame state and local fair-employment commissions for these lapses, critics said he apparently did not know that these bodies were regulated by his own agency. While critical of Thomas on that point, the American Association of Retired Persons did not take a formal position on whether the Senate should confirm Thomas.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT ^Fighting Said To Continue In Kabul Despite Claims Coup Attempt Thwarted
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 14 grafs to UPDATE with fighting reported continuing Wednesday. Picks up 7th pvs, `U.N. Ambassador ...' EDITS thereafter to TRIM and conform. ^LaserPhoto NY16
DOC.TEXT: Soldiers led by the defense minister joined with Moslem guerrillas Tuesday to try to overthrow Afghanistan's government and diplomats said fighting continued in the country's capital on Wednesday. Kabul radio had reported Tuesday night that the rebels were defeated by troops loyal to President Najib. But Western diplomats said mutinous Afghan air force pilots were still bombing loyalist positions in Kabul Wednesday morning. ``There was also a lot of heavy anti-aircraft fire to drive them away,'' said one diplomat. A second Western diplomat said efforts to contact people in Kabul on Wednesday had been difficult: ``It seems they are all hunkered down in their bunkers and that means there must be shooting in the streets of Kabul.'' Both diplomats spoke on condition of anonymity. Afghanistan's U.N. envoy, Noor Ahmad Noor, said in New York on Tuesday that security forces were searching for the defense minister, Maj. Gen. Shah Nawaz Tanai. Noor told reporters at U.N. headquarters that Tanai was believed to be in hiding in the Kabul vicinity. Shortly after Tanai launched the coup attempt, fundamentalist Moslem rebel leader Gulbaddin Hekmatyar offered his support. Abdul Haidi, a spokesman of Hekmatyar's Hezb-i-Islami rebel group, told The Associated Press on Wednesday ``We are getting news from the Kabul wireless that the fighting is still going on.'' He claimed Tanai's forces controlled the airport but were under heavy rocket fire from troops loyal to Najib. Haidi said Moslem insurgents intercepted a radio broadcast between Tanai forces at the airport and others from a base within the capital. A Radio Kabul broadcast Wednesday morning, monitored in Islamabad, claimed government troops were in control of the Defense Ministry, where Tanai had earlier been reportedly orchestrating the coup attempt. The broadcast also urged government loyalists to arm themselves and report to the nearest ruling party headquarters in the capital, ``in order to guarantee the security of the people.'' In the Soviet Union, which sponsors the Najib government, the official news agency Tass had reported that the coup attempt was crushed Tuesday. It claimed fighting had abated by nightfall and Najib's forces were firmly in control. Western diplomats, guerrilla leaders in Pakistan and the Soviet media reported heavy fighting Tuesday and said Afghan air force planes had bombed Arg Palace, Najib's headquarters in the heart of Kabul. Heavy artillery and tanks fired for hours on the buildings of the Defense Ministry and the army's main political directorate, Tass said. It also reported shelling of residential districts, but said they abated after dusk. U.N. Ambassador Noor reported ``very, very limited'' civilian casualties and said the number of people involved in the coup was said to be ``very small.'' Most rebels gave up and only ``a very limited number were killed,'' he said. Tanai, a hard-line Marxist, was linked to at least of two of the five previous coup attempts reported against Najib, who took office in 1986. Najib said on state television Tuesday night: ``Some soiled elements today tried to carry out a conspiracy and provoke bloodshed, but the government forces have neutralized them. They have been suppressed.'' Repeating a message broadcast earlier in the day by Interior Minister Aslam Watanjar, who was named to replace Tanai, Najib urged Afghans to help capture the general ``dead or alive.'' He said mutinous soldiers who surrendered by 4 a.m. Wednesday would be given amnesty. Ahmad Sarwar, Afghan ambassador in New Delhi, said he spoke with Najib by telephone Tuesday night and the president sounded ``very strong and very confident.'' ``He said everything is under control,'' said Sarwar, whose wife is a sister to Najib's wife. He said Najib told him one group of Tanai's followers had been killed and another captured. Najib did not say when the fighting started or mention where he was when the telephone contact was made, Sarwar said. According to a source, Sarwar said, some of Tanai's supporters bombed Kabul from the air, but no bombs fell within half a mile of Najib or Arg Palace. Tuesday's attempted coup was the third said to involve Tanai and Hekmaytar. Hekmatyar, a 42-year-old engineer, has broken with the guerrillas' exile gpvernment formed a year ago in neighboring Pakistan and has been accused by other resistance groups of killing rival guerrillas and innocent civilians. He is among the most anti-West leaders of the seven insurgent groups, but has received the bulk of U.S. weapons during the 12-year-old civil war in Afghanistan. Tanai, a leader of the coup that installed a Marxist government in April 1968, is said to have had many contacts with the Moslem guerrillas. Reports circulated in July that Tanai and Hekmatyar were conspiring to overthrow Najib. The alleged coup plot was uncovered and Tanai was either detained or put under house arrest briefly, according to later reports. The general, believed to be in his 40s, has opposed Najib's peace overtures. Najib has made various offers to the guerrillas in an attempt to end the civil war, but to no avail. In December, the government arrested 127 people who allegedly were planning a coup. Tanai was implicated but never charged, and was said to have spent weeks under house arrest. On Monday, 124 of those arrested went on trial in Kabul, including senior army officers. The other three were released. Hekmatyar told reporters Tuesday in Islamabad he supports any attempt to oust Najib. If a coup succeeded, he said, the guerrillas would decide whether to negotiate for an Islamic government or fight Najib's successor. Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady I. Gerasimov was asked in Moscow Tuesday what action the Kremlin would take if Najib was overthrown. He replied: ``We will just have to wait and see.'' The Red Army entered Afghanistan in December 1979 to help fight the war. The last Soviet forces withdrew on Feb. 15, 1989, but the Kremlin continues to provide massive aid.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Down In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 33,362.34, down 428.74 points, or 1.27 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Greyhound Training Replacement Workers Since Last Month
DOC.TEXT: Protected by security guards, Greyhound replacement drivers set out before dawn for a day on the open road in their rolling classrooms. The course on how to drive a bus is one of four training operations set up by Greyhound a month ago in anticipation of the strike begun Friday by 6,300 drivers and 3,000 maintenance workers at America's only nationwide bus company. A guard blocked access to visitors Tuesday at the out-of-the-way motel parking lot from which the buses left. A mechanic directed visitors to Room 155. There, a man with a Greyhound ID tag denied any training was going on. Finally, in the room next door, a man wearing a Greyhound tie pin _ who like the others refused to identify himself _ acknowledged that this lot 30 miles south of Richmond was the site of one of the training operations. The trainees undergo a 21-day program of classroom work and behind-the-wheel experience, the unidentified Greyhound employees said. On Tuesday, the training buses were rolling to Charleston, S.C., a 10-hour trip with stops along the way in 22 small towns. Liz Hale, a spokeswoman at company headquarters in Dallas, said the trainees have at least one year of experience in driving large trucks or buses. But some strikers said the regimen was inadequate compared to the 12-week course Greyhound normally provides. ``As much as I hate my ex-wife, I wouldn't let her get on a bus driven by one of these replacements,'' said a picket wearing a ``Scab Watcher'' hat outside the Richmond terminal this week. He refused to give his name. Greyhound estimated 700 replacement drivers are at work and claimed on Tuesday to be running at 34 percent of its normal routes. An additional 300 drivers graduate this week, and some union drivers have crossed picket lines, Hale said. The company has received 6,500 applications to replace strikers, Greyhound said. But 50 to 60 of the new drivers had quit in the first day or two of the strike because of intimidation by strikers, company officials said. ``We are not surprised by that,'' said another Greyhound spokesman, George Gravley. ``These people were recruited and they were told honestly and forthrightly ... the nature of the work.'' Greyhound officials in Dallas would not disclose the training locations, but The Associated Press learned training was going on here and at Indianapolis and Sacramento, Calif. The fourth training location was not immediately known. Chairman Fred G. Currey said over the weekend that Greyhound Lines Inc. has millions of dollars in reserve, and the advance training plans appeared to be a sign the company was girding for a long struggle with the strikers. The replacements are being hired under the contract terms the strikers rejected, including some pay increases contingent on increased ridership, safety records and other productivity factors, Gravley said. In Indianapolis, striking drivers shivered in the cold Tuesday as they watched replacements learning to drive. Half a dozen security guards walked the perimeter of the training lot. Striker Noah N. Young, who has been driving a bus for 35 years and is 2{ years away from retirement, said Indianapolis was selected as a training center because ``it's a small union center.''

DOC.HEAD: D'Amato Asks Agencies to Copy Him in on Reporters' Searches
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Alfonse D'Amato, under scrutiny by the Senate Ethics Committee, is asking federal agencies to send him copies of any documents concerning him that have been released under the Freedom of Information Act. The request, which an official at one department said could result in a ``paperwork nightmare'' if granted, was made last month in a series of letters the New York Republican's office sent to the 14 Cabinet departments and several other agencies. D'Amato's press secretary, Franklin L. Coleman, who signed the letters, said the intense local media scrutiny D'Amato has received in recent months has often included questions about correspondence no longer quickly available to the senator because it has been sent to archives. ``We made this request in order to be in a position to respond promptly and accurately to inquiries regarding correspondence our office generated to agencies in the past,'' Coleman said Tuesday. The letters, on Senate stationery, said D'Amato's office has received inquiries about correspondence and indications that similar requests for the documents had been filed with government agencies under the Freedom of Information Act. ``Senator D'Amato will, as always, want to be as responsive as possible to the media,'' the letters said. They asked that whenever documents mentioning or concerning the senator were released, ``copies of that material also be provided to the senator simultaneously.'' The Associated Press obtained a copy of the letter sent to the Federal Election Commission, and Department of Housing and Urban Development officials said HUD had received an identical request. Coleman later confirmed sending the letters to all the major government departments and independent agencies. The ethics committee is conducting a preliminary inquiry to determine whether it should begin a trial-like investigation of a series of allegations made against D'Amato by Mark Green, his Democratic election opponent in 1986. Green filed the complaint after numerous news accounts detailed the senator's successful lobbying of HUD officials for housing and other developments in New York and Puerto Rico, including a $425,000 grant to pay for a swimming pool in D'Amato's hometown of Island Park, N.Y. The pool project was canceled after a spate of bad publicity. In several cases, the developers who received D'Amato's support were friends or major donors to his campaigns. Another allegation stemmed from a letter that D'Amato's brother, attorney Armand D'Amato, drafted in the senator's name to obtain information for a client, Unisys Corp., concerning a $100 million defense contract. Sen. D'Amato said he did not know about the letter and also has said that several letters to HUD officials bearing his name were signed by staff without his knowledge. In November, D'Amato said he was the victim of a ``pile on'' by the media, adding: ``I have nothing to be ashamed of.'' Coleman said Tuesday he ``took it upon myself'' to write the letters to the agencies and did not tell the senator in advance. He said he was not aware of any responses to the letters. Fred Eiland, spokesman for the Federal Election Commission, said the FEC probably would deny the request on he ground it doesn't meet the requirements of the Freedom of Information Act because it does not ask for a specific document or documents. Although Coleman's letter was not filed as an FOIA request, Eiland said the commission had decided to treat it as such. Eiland also said it was office policy to treat confidentially any media requests for research assistance. ``We never, ever tell another person what someone else is looking at,'' he said. ``It's between us and the reporter.'' HUD has asked its legal staff to review what one agency official said were ``potentially troubling'' questions raised by D'Amato's request. Under review was whether the department should grant such an open-ended request for copies of FOIA responses and, if it decided to comply, whether HUD should identify the reporter or organization requesting the information. The HUD official, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said that if the department complied with the request it could receive similar letters from other members of Congress, reporters and others, ``opening the door for a paperwork nightmare.''

DOC.HEAD: Lawmakers, Group Push to Make Low-Income Housing Credit Permanent
DOC.TEXT: A tax credit that encourages corporations to invest in low-income rental units is the ``only game in town'' to help ease the housing crunch for the poor, a lawmaker says. Rep. Charles Rangel, D-N.Y., made that assessment Tuesday at a news conference called to dramatize the need to make the Low Income Housing Tax Credit permanent. The Chicago-based National Equity Fund, a conduit for corporate investments using the credit, said it used the endangered tax credit last year to invest $77 million in rental housing for 2,000 families. Thirty-five corporations, including banking and insurance giants, invested the money. It will be used as a lever to provide a total of $200 million worth of housing in 15 cities, the fund said. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, and Sen. John Danforth, R-Mo., have introduced legislation to make the tax credit permanent. ``Tax policy has had a negative effect by and large in the 1980s,'' said Danforth, referring to the impact of tax policy on low-income housing programs. ``It's time to turn it around.'' The credit was made part of the 1986 tax overhaul and was extended last year to the end of 1990. The Bush administration has proposed an additional one-year extension. ``It's really sad you have to use the income tax system'' to drive a social program, Rangel said, ``but it's the only game in town.'' The equity fund is an affiliate of the Local Initiatives Support Corp., a private, non-profit group dedicated to community development that was created by the Ford Foundation in 1979. The first partnership created under the fund's auspices invested $14.25 million from 13 corporations to create 857 housing units. The fund said it raised $51 million from 40 corporations last year to develop more than 2,000 units worth over $150 million. The credits, awarded over 10 years, create 100,000 units of low-income housing each year, it said. The fund is involved in projects in Boston; Cincinnati; Hartford, Conn.; Healdsburg, Calif.; Indianapolis; Kalamazoo, Mich.; Kansas City, Mo.; Los Angeles; Miami; Minneapolis; Newark, N.J.; New York; Philadelphia; Raleigh, N.C.; and St. Paul, Minn. Corporate investors are: American Telephone & Telegraph; Aetna Life & Casualty; American Express; Ameritech; Bank of America; Banc One Mortgage Corp.; Bankers Trust New York Corp.; CBS; Capitol Cities-ABC; Chase Manhattan Bank; Chemical Bank; City National Bank; Consolidated Edison Co. of New York; Also, The Continental Corp.; The Dime Savings Bank of New York; Fannie Mae; Freddie Mac; Great Western Bank; Hallmark Cards; HomeFed Bank; INB National Bank; J.C. Penney; J.P. Morgan and Co.; Kaufman and Broad Home Corp.; Also, Knight-Ridder; National Westminster Bank; New York Life Insurance; Payless Cashways; Pfizer; Prudential Insurance; Republic National Bank of New York; The St. Paul Cos.; The Stanley Works; Williamsburgh Savings Bank of New York; and Xerox Corp.

DOC.HEAD: UPI Seeks Arbitration of Photo Dispute with Reuters
DOC.TEXT: United Press International is seeking arbitration of its claim that the Reuters news service has deprived it of photo revenue for the past five years. UPI is seeking damages of more than $600,000 for money it says was lost when some of its customers began buying photos from Reuters instead. UPI filed its request for arbitration on Tuesday with the International Chamber of Commerce Court of Arbitration in Paris, which will handle the case through an affiliate in New York. The news service said Reuters is obligated under agreements between the two companies to reimburse UPI for any revenue lost as a result of UPI subscribers shifting to Reuters' photo service. A Reuters spokesman, Robert Crooke, said there is no evidence UPI lost money due to his company's marketing activities. ``We welcome the opportunity that the arbitration provides to establish not only that Reuter activities are not the cause of UPI's losses but that those causes lie much closer to UPI's own actions,'' Crooke said. Under an arrangement that began Jan. 1, 1985, and was supposed to run for 10 years, UPI provided Reuters with pictures from the United States while Reuters supplied pictures from other countries. Reuters said Feb. 16 it was canceling the agreement and halted its flow of pictures to UPI for more than four hours. A U.S. district judge in New York issued a temporary restraining order barring further such action by Reuters. The court has scheduled a hearing Monday on UPI's request for a preliminary injunction against Reuters' attempts to end the photo arrangement. Reuters has alleged that UPI's photo service has declined since the exchange began.
