DOC.HEAD: East German Workers Win Right To Strike
DOC.TEXT: East German workers have won the right to strike for the first time in their country's 40-year history under a new labor law that also prohibits employers from locking out workers. The law, overwhelming approved Tuesday by Parliament, comes as the country lurches ever closer to reunification with West Germany. Legislators praised the new labor code for its mixing of market-style reforms with traditional socialist protections. But they conceded that it probably would be objectionable to West German investors and employers. The law easily won approval from the 385 lawmakers present for what is expected to be the last session of the 500-member People's Chamber before the country's first competitive elections on March 18. Only six voted against the measure, with 53 abstentions. Debate was minimal. The future of the new law may rest with the new, 400-member Parliament. Many labor principles embodied in the law require implementing legislation that will have to be tackled after the new legislative body is seated. The strike clause, however, is among changes to take effect next week. Lawmakers hailed the no-lockout clause as a workers' right not enjoyed in West Germany. Because the law is likely to be seen as imbalanced by West German industries seeking to build plants or engage in joint production operations in East Germany, it may serve to slow the investment considered essential to turning around the flagging economy. The law comes in the form of a constitutional change. It permits unions to call strikes if arbitration fails to resolve labor-management differences in negotiations. Strikes have been forbidden in East Germany and most other formerly socialist states, with labor unions traditionally powerless to challenge the Communists who ruled until democratic upheavals toppled them last year. The government now will have the right to intercede and stop a strike only if the walkout is deemed a threat to public order. The law provides that ``no one can reduce or hinder unions in their rightful occupation.'' Communist lawmaker Kaethe Niederkirchner said such a broad protection was likely to disturb the capitalists next door. He quoted West German employers association president Klaus Murmann as describing the law as a ``hindrance'' to inter-German economic cooperation. Parliament also adopted additional measures on election procedures, including extending voting rights to foreigners who have lived in East Germany for two years or more. The changes are the latest since a popular uprising forced Communist hard-liner Erich Honecker to step down in October, the opening of the Berlin Wall a month later and the introduction of non-Communists and opposition democratic reformers into the interim government.

DOC.HEAD: Ritter Drew $140,000 From Trust Fund
DOC.TEXT: The Rev. Bruce Ritter, founder of Covenant House, has admitted drawing $140,000 from a tax-exempt fund set up to benefit runaways. The priest, who resigned under pressure last week as president of the nation's biggest network of runaway shelters, told The New York Times in a story today that he contibuted the money to the fund and took it out to cover his expenses and conduct his ministry. The fund's trustee, Edmund J. Burns, told the Times the $140,000 was given to the Roman Catholic priest's Franciscan Order. But Ritter told the Times the money actually went to him. Ritter said he had authorization from the Franciscans to use the money for personal expenses. The Franciscan Order said it did not know of the trust, according to the Times. Ritter said he eventually redeposited in the trust some of the money the trust had paid to him, and told the Times all the transactions were legal. He said he began depositing $60,000 of his $98,000-a-year salary in the trust in 1986 to avoid criticism of his high pay. But Robert Kobel, a spokesman for the Internal Revenue Service, said that under the law, a person cannot give money to a trust with the idea of taking it back. Ritter has been accused of other financial improprieties and four young men have alleged in published reports that he had sexual affairs with them. The state attorney general's office is investigating transactions involving the trust, and Covenant House's board of directors told Attorney General Robert Abrams the trust would be dismantled. On Tuesday, the Times reported that the trust was not registered with the state and that funds from it had been used to make loans to two Covenant House board members and Ritter's sister.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Plunge, Dollar Rises Sharply in Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The key index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange plunged Wednesday, while the dollar was sharply higher against the yen. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average lost 428.74 points, or 1.27 percent, ending the day at 33,362.34. It had dropped 54.12 points Tuesday. The dollar closed at 150.75 yen, up 1.25 yen from Tuesday's close at 149.50 yen. It opened at 150.25 yen and ranged between 150.25 yen and 150.98 yen. Discouraged by the yen's weakness, the benchmark 10-year No. 119 Japanese government bond price fell to 86.67 points as of 3 p.m., down 0.41 points from Tuesday's close at 87.08. Its yield rose to 7.200 percent, up from the previous day'a 7.115 percent. ``This is a triple-low situation ... with declines in all the markets _ stock, foreign exchange and bonds,'' said Masayoshi Yano, a dealer with Nikko Securities Co. Yano said the yen's decline, as well as renewed speculation over a rise in the nation's discount rate, discouraged many investors. Japan's leading economic newspaper, Nihon Keizai Shimbun, said the Bank of Japan will raise its official discount rate from the current 4.25 percent by as much as one percentage point as early as next week. Market players have expected the central bank to raise its key lending rate since shortly after the nation's general election last month. Analysts have blamed uncertainties and speculations involving the rate for recent plunges in the stock market. Yano said computer program-aided arbitrage selling, mainly by foreign securities firms accelerated the Nikkei's drop Wednesday. Arbitrage is a technique of trading in the stock and futures markets simultaneously to profit from price differentials between them. Program trading has been blamed aiding recent declines, though foreign brokers have denied it has had a significant effect on the market. Shortly after the Nikkei fell 1,569.10 points Feb. 26, the Tokyo Stock Exchange requested that securities firms limit program trading to the opening minutes of the morning and the afternoon sessions until Thursday. ``As the deadline approaches, nobody seems to be following the request,'' Yano said. In currency dealings, the dollar remained strong following its surge on overseas markets, dealers said. The dollar surpassed the 150-yen line in Sydney before Tokyo market opened, and it rose further as speculative Japanese investors bought dollars and sold the yen, said Koichiro Amaya, a trader with Chemical Bank in Tokyo. The dollar's surge halted when it neared 151 yen as the Bank of Japan was seen intervening in the market. Traders said the bank sold about $1 billion in the morning session in an effort to halt the dollar's further rise. The bank does not officially comment on its market interventions. ``But the dollar is strong, and there is nothing to encourage dollar-selling, except for the Bank of Japan's intervention,'' Amaya said.

DOC.HEAD: Scientists Extend Doomsday Countdown to Reflect Changes
DOC.TEXT: Eastern Europe's revolutionary changes and Mikhail Gorbachev's commitment to lifting the Iron Curtain have prompted scientists to set back the so-called Doomsday Clock. But those who set the clock at the Bulletin of Atomic Scientists back four minutes Tuesday _ from six minutes to 10 minutes before midnight, or nuclear destruction _ pointed out that nuclear weapons exist in alarming numbers. ``The likelihood of a full-scale nuclear holocaust has been reduced,'' said Leonard Rieser, chairman of the Bulletin's board of directors, before moving the minute hand on the bronze 18-inch instrument that hangs in the magazine's headquarters at the University of Chicago. The 21 directors, 41 sponsoring scientists and editor of the Bulletin voted on the question of changing the clock in mid-January. Only four said the clock shouldn't be changed, while two wanted it set even farther from doomsday. Tuesday's move marked the eighth setting of the clock in its 43-year history. ``Most Americans have thought of the Cold War as a permanent facet of international relations,'' said Gloria Duffy, a board member and president of Global Outlook, a Palo Alto, Calif., security research institute. ``They never expected it to change in their lifetime.'' Dr. Michael McCally, a University of Chicago doctor, was among those opposing change. ``My concern is with the weapons'' proliferation, he said. The clock came closest to midnight _ just two minutes away _ in 1953, after the United States successfully tested the hydrogen bomb.

DOC.HEAD: SEC, Soviet Bloc Officials Discuss Emerging East European Stock Markets
DOC.TEXT: The Securities and Exchange Commission says it has agreed to advise governments of Eastern Europe on how to keep their infant stock markets orderly and honest. SEC Chairman Richard C. Breeden, who has met recently with high-level financial officials from the Soviet Union, Hungary and Poland, announced Tuesday that Wall Street watchdog agency is forming an Advisory Committee on Emerging Securities Markets in Eastern Europe. ``The SEC's expertise in this area hopefully can assist in a successful transition to efficient private capital markets with necessary oversight and supervision,'' said Breeden. The committee will recommend what action the SEC and the financial industry can take to help create organize securities markets in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union. Breeden and other SEC officials met Feb. 21 with a high-level delegation from the Soviet government that was reviewing the operation of U.S. banking and securities markets. Breeden has held similar meetings with delegations from Poland and Hungary. The SEC anticipates receiving additional requests for assistance from several other governments in creating securities markets.
DOC.HEAD: Government Warns of Cushions for Infants
DOC.TEXT: The government says parents should not let infants sleep on small pillows or cushions filled with plastic foam beads because 10 babies using the items have suffocated in two years. However, the Consumer Product Safety Commission declined to identify the products or companies Tuesday, saying negotiations for a recall were continuing. At least 10 infants have died since December 1987, with seven of the deaths occurring since June, the commission said. All of the victims were 3-months-old or younger. The agency said it was unusual for so many deaths associated with a relatively new product to occur over such a short period. The cushions, which became popular items for infants over the past few years, are supposed to be a comfort for babies because they adjust to the contours of an infant's body, government officials said. The cushions, about 24 inches long and 12 inches wide, resemble pillows or small ``bean bags,'' the agency said. Usually made from quilted fabric, the cushions are loosely filled with plastic foam beads or pellets. The commission, which urged parents not to leave children on the pillows unattended, said it believes the products are made and sold by at least 10 companies.
DOC.HEAD: Nation's Population Reaches 250 Million
DOC.TEXT: There are now a quarter-billion people in the United States. This nation started life with just under 4 million people, about as many as now live in metropolitan Boston. On Tuesday it reached 250,000,000, according to estimates by the Census Bureau. A more detailed total will be calculated following the national head count to be taken April 1. The 250 million estimate is a 10.4 percent increase from the 226.5 million Americans counted in 1980. The U.S. population reached 50 million in 1880, doubled to 100 million by 1915, was 150 million in 1949 and climbed to 200 million in 1967. Projections by the Census Bureau indicate the nation could reach 300 million within 30 years. Current population growth is estimated at one new person every 14 seconds in the United States. That is based on a birth every 8 seconds and a new immigrant arriving every 35 seconds, balanced by a death every 14 seconds and a departure every 3 minutes. The United States ranks fourth in the world in population, following China, at 1.1 billion; India, at 833 million, and the Soviet Union, at 289 million. Following the United States are Indonesia, 188 million; Brazil, 151 million; Japan, 123 million; Nigeria, 115 million; Bangladesh, 115 million and Pakistan, 110 million.
DOC.HEAD: December and January, The Winter of Our Dissimilarity
DOC.TEXT: January was the warmest on record in the United States, following one of the coldest Decembers. The average temperature in January was 37.2 degrees Fahrenheit in the 48 contiguous states, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration reported this week. That's the warmest January since uniform record collection was started in 1895, according to NOAA's National Climatic Data Center in Asheville, N.C. The relative warmth was felt most strongly in the region that includes parts of Montana, the Dakotas, Wyoming and Nebraska, the agency said. But readings were above normal across nearly all of the nation except the Southwest. That warmth came hard on the heels of the fourth coldest December on record, a month when bitter cold was felt even in Florida, the agency noted.

DOC.HEAD: Ethics Panel Not Counting on Plea Bargain With Senator
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Subs 2nd graf to CORRECT spelling of anonymity
DOC.TEXT: The Senate Ethics Committee is not counting on plea-bargain negotiations with Sen. David Durenberger and plans to move ahead with trial-like proceedings, according to sources familiar with the case. One source, speaking only on condition of anonymity, said Tuesday the committee would not be placing its ``main focus'' on the hearings if serious negotiations to settle the case were under way. No date has been set for the hearings, sources said, because the committee is still conducting a preliminary investigation into Senate reimbursements Durenberger received for a condominium he partly owned. The committee set the stage last week for the hearings, when it formally notified the Minnesota Republican there was ``substantial credible evidence'' of five specific rules violations and a sixth governing general conduct expected of a senator. Durenberger, who has admitted mistakes in judgment but no willful wrongdoing, ``may have'' violated outside income limits and other rules in his promotion of two books he wrote, the committee said. He also potentially violated annual limits on receipt of gifts when he accepted nearly $5,000 worth of limousine trips for personal travel in 1985 and 1986, the panel said. The committee is in the final stage of the Durenberger investigation, which normally would end with a determination of whether rules were broken. A guilty finding could lead the panel to recommend disciplinary action to the Senate, including censure, loss of seniority or expulsion. Durenberger, however, could decide at any time that he wants to negotiate a settlement rather than defend himself at a trial-type hearing. A plea bargain would likely involve an admission by Durenberger that violations took place and would short-circuit the final phase of the probe. It could end the case without a recommendation from the committee to the Senate. Durenberger's spokeswoman, Carrie Collins, had no comment on the senator's defense strategy. Under ethics committee rules, the panel must give Durenberger ``an opportunity'' for a hearing ``before it recommends disciplinary action'' to the Senate. However, one source said the committee is planning to go ahead with the hearing, whether Durenberger requests one or not, because it is ``in the public interest.'' The panel announced Feb. 22 that ``the committee is continuing its preliminary inquiry'' on reimbursements Durenberger received for rent on a Minneapolis condominium he partly owned. To include the condominium arrangement in the trial-like hearing, the committee would have to find ``substantial credible evidence'' of a violation.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th item to fix `Wednesday' to `today.'
DOC.TEXT: Bryant Gumbel, co-host of NBC's ``Today'' show, will become the latest network news star to be interviewed by another when Barbara Walters puts the microphone to him for ABC's ``20-20.'' The interview will run March 16, ABC announced Tuesday. Bob Costas, whose late-night NBC show last month featured his interview with ABC ``Nightline'' anchorman Ted Koppel, himself recently was interviewed by Dick Cavett for the ``The Dick Cavett Show'' on cable television's CNBC. That program was to be shown today.

DOC.HEAD: Ortega Scores U.S. Efforts at Demobilizing Contras
DOC.TEXT: President Daniel Ortega says that as one of its last acts his outgoing Sandinista government will abolish a news censorship law and allow the establishment of private television stations. Speaking Tuesday before U.S. and Latin American publishers at a meeting of the Inter American Press Association, Ortega said he would introduce a bill in the National Assembly to repeal the much criticized censorship law. Ortega and his leftist Sandinistas were beaten Feb. 25 by the 14-party United National Opposition coalition led by Violeta Barrios de Chamorro. Abolishing the censorship law _ one of Ortega's last acts in the National Assembly as president _ would allow either the Sandinistas, UNO, or others to start up a televison station. TV broadcasting is now in government hands. Mrs. Chamorro, publisher of the only opposition newspaper, La Prensa, championed turning over government control of television during the Sandinistas 10{-year rule. A law passed in April 1989 ended prior restraint of news and the right to indefinitely close newspapers and radio stations, but it maintained the government's TV monopoly. The law also kept up punishment for ``altering'' state press releases or publishing information contrary to the interests of Nicaragua.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Rises Despite Intervention, Stocks Plunge in Japan
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rose sharply against the yen today in Tokyo despite active intervention by the Bank of Japan, while the chief index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange dropped. The dollar closed at 150.75 yen, up 1.25 yen from Tuesday's close of 149.50 yen. It opened at 150.25 yen, its low for the day, and ranged as high as 150.98 yen. The dollar rose from its opening level as market players predicted the Bank of Japan would not raise its official discount rate in the near future, traders said. ``Many market players now think that the central bank will put off the hike because it could hurt the stock market badly,'' said Kenzo Shinomiya, a trader with Fuji Bank. Higher interest rates tend to depress stock prices. Analysts have said a discount rate hike could be unwise because of a series of recent declines in the stock market. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average, the main index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange, has lost 5,124.79 points, or 13.2 percent, so far this year, mainly due to uncertainties over the discount rate increase and to computer-linked trading. Shinomiya said few people except for the Bank of Japan and a small number of profit-takers were selling the dollar. ``Demand for the dollar is very strong, and it will rise as high as 155 yen,'' he said. Discouraged by the yen's weakness, the price of benchmark 10-year No. 119 Japanese government bonds fell to 86.67 points as of 3 p.m., down 0.41 points from Tuesday's close of 87.08. Their yield rose to 7.2 percent, up from the previous day'a 7.115 percent. On the stock exchange, the Nikkei index fell 428.74 points, or 1.27 percent, ending the day at 33,362.34. It had dropped 54.12 points Tuesday. Nomura Securities analyst Yoshio Inoue blamed the drop in stock and bond prices on the yen's weakness. ``It's all because of the discount rate, which has not risen despite investors' expectations,'' he said. Market players have expected the central bank would raise its official discount rate after general elections last month, and analysts have blamed the market's recent decline in part on uncertainties over the key interest rate. ``The discount rate hike has gradually been factored into the market, but the problem is its timing,'' Inoue said. ``This is a triple-low situation ... with declines in all the markets _ stock, foreign exchange and bonds,'' said Masayoshi Yano, a dealer with Nikko Securities Co. He said a front-page story today in the financial newspaper Nihon Keizai Shimbun saying the Bank of Japan would raise its official discount rate from the current 4.25 percent by as much as 1 percentage point as early as next week discouraged stock investors. Inoue said the index, which fell even farther in the morning, remained low as individual investors continued to sell issues while very few participants were buying. Dealers attributed the index's early decline to program-aided arbitrage selling initiated by foreign securities firms such as Morgan Stanley, Salomon Brothers and Shearson Lehman. ``The last day for futures issues due in March is scheduled for tomorrow. So I expect continuing arbitrage selling until the end of tomorrow,'' Yano said. Arbitrage is a technique of trading in two markets, for example spot and futures, simultaneously to profit from price differentials between them. Computer-aided arbitrage selling has been blamed for recent market plunges, although foreign brokers have denied that the technique has had a significant effect on the market. The Tokyo Stock Exchange requested, shortly after the Nikkei's 1,569.10-point fall Feb. 26, that securities firms limit their arbitrage deals to the opening minutes of the morning and the afternoon sessions until Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Police: Officers Shot Themselves in Drug Shootout
DOC.TEXT: Two undercover officers wounded in a shootout with drug dealers were hit by police fire _ one man from his own gun _ and investigators may never know whose bullet killed a third officer, authorities say. The gun battle took place Monday at a housing project during a cocaine buy involving two dealers. ``Right from the get-go, it was a ripoff,'' a police spokesman, Inspector Richard Mayronne, said Tuesday. He said it was clear it was a ripoff because the room into which one of the detectives was taken had no way out. State Police Investigator Joseph T. Aversa, 31, was slain. Two city detectives, Craig Moruzzi, 41, and Joseph Mendez, 29, suffered leg wounds. The three were members of the New York Drug Enforcement Task Force, which includes city, state and federal officers. Authorities and police sources said Aversa's fire struck Moruzzi, and that Mendez shot himself in a struggle with one dealer for control of the detective's gun. ``We can't determine who hit Aversa,'' Mayronne said. ``It's very possible'' investigators never will find out, he added. Authorities did not rule out the possibility that a stray police bullet killed Aversa. They said their investigation was hampered because the bullet, which entered Aversa's left eye and exited behind his ear, was not recovered. David Hernandez, 20, and Oswaldo Santana, 27, were arrested Monday in the afternoon gunfight and charged with murder, attempted murder and robbery. Juan Jose Peralta, 23, was arrested Tuesday on cocaine charges in the case. Santana was shot in the toe, Hernandez in the elbow and abdomen. His injuries were not considered life threatening. Mayronne refused to say how many bullets were fired during the gunfight. The New York Times today quoted unidentified high-ranking officials as saying the three officers fired a total of 12 shots, while between them, the two suspects fired one. The Daily News said the officers fired 14 shots. Hernandez was the only one of the dealers who was armed, police said. Authorities said the shootings occurred when the dealers tried to rob the officers during a cocaine buy-and-bust. Detectives had negotiated earlier to buy more than four pounds of cocaine for $46,000, authorities said. ``It's extremely risky at both ends of the spectrum because when you buy drugs, you're going into the mouth of the tiger,'' said Assistant Police Chief John Hill, head of the department's narcotics division. ``It's dangerous, but it's the main tool in our arsenal. Very successful.''

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Protest FDA's Ban on Haitian Blood Donations
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Haitian-Americans protested the new federal ban on blood donations by Haitians, saying the AIDS prevention policy would increase discrimination against them. After the rally by about 8,000 people Tuesday, the Food and Drug Administration responded by promising to consult with Haitian-Americans and convene a public meeting of its Blood Products Advisory Committee to discuss the issue. The Haitian immigrants gathered in a dusty field across from FDA offices here, chanting ``F-D-A _ Racists,'' waving red-and-blue Haitian flags and carrying signs saying ``FDA bigots must go.'' Police arrested three people when the crowd surged onto FDA property. ``Anyone can die from AIDS _ from the president to the poorest man. I don't see why they blame the Haitians,'' said Jean Francois, a college student. The policy announced last month is designed to help keep AIDS-tainted blood out of the nation's supply by requiring blood banks to refuse donations from people who were born in or who emigrated from Haiti and sub-Saharan Africa. Protesters claim the policy unfairly lumps them with the other groups discouraged from giving blood: intravenous drug users, homosexuals and prostitutes. ``This is an acquired disease. It's behavioral,'' said Philomena Jadotte, 24, a nursing student who emigrated from Haiti 10 years ago. ``There are more Hispanics dying of AIDS in Miami than Haitians. Why are we being singled out? Because we're black.'' Many Haitians already feel unwanted in South Florida because of U.S. immigration policy that welcomes Cuban and Nicaraguan emigres but returns most Haitians to their impoverished, violent homeland. A previous ban permitted blood donations from Haitians and sub-Saharan Africans only if they emigrated before 1977. But the FDA changed its policy after research cast doubt on the reliability of that date as an indicator of when the disease began to spread outside the United States, said FDA spokesman Brad Stone. Unlike other groups, most Haitians who have AIDS got the fatal disease through heterosexual transmission, and Stone said there's no good way to screen potential carriers from the rest of the Haitian population. Local officials in 1988 said that about one-third of the black sufferers of AIDS in Florida were born in Haiti. ``We hope that people won't unfairly stigmatize Haitian-Americans as a result of this policy,'' Stone said by telephone from Washington. ``We'd like to find ways to refine the process, so we could ask questions and screen out those who would be at higher risk.''

DOC.HEAD: Lawmaker Survives Recall Election Over Indian Fishing Rights
DOC.TEXT: A state lawmaker easily fended off a recall attempt by opponents of spearfishing rights for Wisconsin's Chippewa Indians. Rep. James Holperin, the first state lawmaker to face a recall since 1932, won 9,535 votes or 69 percent to 4,380 or 31 percent for businessman Gene Ahlborn in the special Democratic race Tuesday. Holperin still faces Brian Sherren, a resort owner, in a recall election April 3. Sherren, 40, ran unopposed in the GOP primary and garnered 601 votes. Ahlborn, 50, conceded defeat and said he was ``extremely happy. I certainly wasn't looking for a job.'' ``It was a referendum on treaty rights and if that's what the people want, I guess I can live with it,'' he said. ``It looks to me like they want to roll over and play dead.'' The recall campaign was the work of groups opposed to Indian spearfishing, a right that was granted to the state's Chippewas in 19th century treaties with the U.S. government. A 1983 federal court ruling also gave the Indians rights to cut timber, hunt and gather food off the reservation. Spearfishermen harvest the fish each spring as the spawn. It is an extremely efficient fishing method, and outdoorsmen and those in the tourism industry fear it will reduce the population of walleyed pike for sports fishing. The issue has caused years of unrest in northern Wisconsin. Last April and May, hundreds of sportsmen showed up at lakes during the three-week spearfishing season. Some threw rocks or shouted ethnic slurs at the Indians. Holperin, 39, a former radio and TV newscaster, was elected to the Assembly in 1982. Organizers of the recall were especially critical of his support last year for Republican Gov. Tommy G. Thompson's plan to pay a Chippewa band $50 million in cash and other aid over 10 years to curtail exercise of their treaty rights. Tribal members voted down the plan. Dean Crist, a spokesman for Stop Treaty Abuse-Wisconsin, the anti-spearfishing group that circulated the petitions for recall, said his group had not supported either candidate in the race. ``The purpose of STA was to send a message that we were unhappy,'' Crist said. In Wisconsin's last recall election, 58 years ago, Republican Sen. Otto Mueller retained his seat.

DOC.HEAD: Key Events in Najib's Tenure
With PM-Afghanistan
DOC.TEXT: Main events since Najib replaced Babrak Karmal as president of Afghanistan:

1986: May _ Radio Kabul announces that Najib, former head of the secret police, is replacing President Babrak Karmal, who was demoted to revolutionary council head. December _ Najib meets Mikhail S. Gorbachev in Moscow and announces a national unity government will be formed to include Afghans living in exile.

1987: January _ Najib offers rebel fighters a cease-fire and expands his national reconciliation program to include rebel groups. Rebels reject the cease-fire as a trap. They also reject Najib's national reconciliation plan, promising to fight until he is toppled and an Islamic government is established in Kabul. April _ Najib claims to have established national reconciliation commissions in 1,681 villages, representing about 6 percent of the villages in Afghanistan. September _ Talks in Geneva aimed at finding a political end to Soviet intervention in Afghanistan adjourn without agreement. November _ Najib proposes a 12-month timetable for the withdrawal of Soviet troops from Afghanistan, saying Moscow has given it approval.

1988: January _ Afghan and Soviet troops break a five-week rebel siege of the eastern Afghan garrison town of Khost. Najib said the victory was proof of his troops' strength. February _ Gorbachev offers to withdraw his troops beginning May 15. Najib says he's confident of surviving without direct Soviet military help. March _ President Reagan promises the U.S. commitment to anti-communist rebels won't end with the withdrawal of Soviet troops. April 14 _ The foreign ministers of Pakistan and Afghanistan sign a United Nations-brokered accord providing for the withdrawal of about 103,000 Soviet combat troops from Afghanistan within 10 months. May 14 _ Several thousand Soviet soldiers leave Afghanistan's second largest city, Kandahar, and return to the Soviet Union, marking the start of the negotiated troop withdrawal. December _ Najib convenes a grand council and proclaims himself president.

1989: January _ Several Western nations, including the United States, close their embassies in Kabul. Najib says the closures are an attempt to undermine his government's ability to withstand a rebel onslaught following the final withdrawal of Soviet soldiers. Feb. 15 _ The last Soviet soldier crosses the Friendship Bridge linking Afghanistan and the Soviet Union, ending nine years of direct military intervention by Moscow. February-March _ Najib's troops defend Afghanistan's eastern city of Jalalabad against a rebel offensive. His success defies earlier predictions that his government would crumble after the Soviet troop withdrawal. April 27 _ Najib stages a Revolution Day parade a day early after learning that a faction of the army planned to kill him. May 20-21 _ Najib convenes another council to extend a state of emergency imposed following the final Soviet troop withdrawal. July _ House-to-house searches and arrests are made after Najib reportedly uncovers a coup plot. Defense Minister Shah Nawaz Tanai is rumored to be linked to the plot but nothing is proved and he holds on to his portfolio. June _ An Afghan army general in charge of Najib's security defects to the guerrillas. December _ Searches end in 127 arrests for allegedly plotting a coup against Najib, the second such plot to be uncovered in less than one year. Maj. Gen. Tanai again is implicated and reportedly placed under house arrest for several weeks. He is later seen in public with Najib.

1990: Tuesday _ Radio Kabul reports Tanai and mutinous soldiers tried to overthrow the government with the help of fighters linked to fundamentalist guerrilla leader Gulbuddin Hekmatyar. The official radio says the coup is crushed but heavy fighting is reported. Today _ Diplomats and Moslem guerrillas report continued fighting in Kabul, with Tanai's forces reportedly bombing loyalist positions and in control of the main airport.

DOC.HEAD: Contras Insist Sandinista Army Must Go
DOC.TEXT: A Contra leader insisted after talks with a representative of Nicaragua's new government that the Sandinistas cede control of the country's military before the rebels quit their fight and return home. The statement Tuesday by Oscar Sovalbarro, chief of the Contra team discussing the rebels' eventual demobilization, came hours after outgoing Nicaraguan President Daniel Ortega said any attempt to include Contra officers in the army ``would unleash a national war.'' The leftist Sandinistas say the army's revolutionary nature and role is enshrined in the constitution, and that the constitution must be reformed before the army can be changed. The U.S.-backed Contras accuse the Sandinistas, who which lost the Feb. 25 presidential and legislative elections, of scheming to retain power by refusing to hand over military command. ``What we're saying is that for there to be true reconciliation in Nicaragua, it is important that the military forces be disarmed. The army that exists in Nicaragua is not a national army. It is the army of a political party, and it must disappear,'' said Sovalbarro, who commented after a meeting between Contra commanders and an aide to President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro. The rebels also issued a statement accusing the Sandinista air force of ``indiscriminate'' bombing of eight villages in the northwestern province of Nueva Segovia. They accused the Sandinistas of ``trying to convince the people of Nicaragua and world opinion that these are defensive operations'' against the Contras. The Sandinistas earlier Tuesday had accused Contra forces of attacking Sandinista positions in northern Nicaragua. Jaime Cuadra, Mrs. Chamorro's representative, described the talks as preliminary and said no accord on demobilization was reached. The date for demobilization of 4,000 Contras inside Nicaragua and thousands more in Honduran camps has emerged as a major stumbling block to a peaceful transfer of power in Nicaragua. ``We support Dona Violeta and she will decide after April 25 what to do with the Sandinistas and what to do with the armed forces,'' Sovalbarro said. Sovalbarro and Pepe Matus, legal adviser to the Contras, outlined what they said was a Contra proposal that could lead to demobilization. They suggested Contra forces should march, with their weapons, from their Honduran camps to Nicaraguan ``enclaves,'' which they would occupy under international supervision. ``We see that as very favorable, as it provides a solution to the problem of occupation of Honduran territory,'' said Sovalbarro. Honduras has been a reluctant host to the Contras in recent years. President Rafael Callejas said last week the rebels should leave as soon as possible. The United States, which helped form the Contras in the early 1980s and sustained them through the decade, said last week that immediate measures should be taken to achieve the Contras' demobilization. But the State Department also said the rebels must enjoy ``full guarantees'' regarding personal and economic security before disbanding. Mrs. Chamorro, who has pledged to end the draft and cut back the size of the military, on Tuesday called for a demilitarized Central America. In a meeting in northern Costa Rica with its president, Oscar Arias, she called for his support for regional demilitarization.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``As much as I hate my ex-wife, I wouldn't let her get on a bus driven by one of these replacements.'' _ A picket who refused to give his name, commenting on Greyhound drivers-in-training participating in a 21-day learning program that strikers said ordinarily takes 12 weeks.

``Hooray for Hollywood and Leningrad and Moscow, too.'' _ Time Warner President N.J. Nicholas Jr., announcing the debut in those two Soviet cities of multiple-screen movie theaters that are fixtures in U.S. shopping malls.

``Some Republicans are going to support the president on this, but I think they're going to do it holding their nose and walking the plank for a person they don't particularly feel good about.'' _ Rep. James Oberstar, D-Minn., referring to Eastern Airlines President Frank Lorenzo as he discussed the chance of Republican House members helping to override a veto of a bill that would have the government intervene in the Eastern strike.

DOC.HEAD: Autopsy Shows Racing Commission Official Shot Self
DOC.TEXT: The slaying of a Texas Racing Commission official shot to death with his wife and two children at their home has been ruled a suicide. But police said they have not yet determined whether 41-year-old David Joost also killed his wife, Susan, 35, and their children, ages 10 and 5. Medical Examiner Robert Bayardo on Tuesday said that Joost, who handled administrative duties for the Racing Commission, died of a self-inflicted gunshot wound to the chest. All four victims died early Sunday, he said. Sheriff Paul Hastings said no suicide note had been found but that the pressure of Joost's job may have led him to kill himself. ``He basically had an extremely difficult job,'' the sheriff said. Sheriff's spokeswoman Rachel Vasquez said officials could not confirm whether the same .38-caliber handgun killed all four family members. ``The case is still under investigation, so all we can assume at this point is that we have three homicides and one suicide,'' Ms. Vasquez said. Joost's body was discovered Monday at his home in Buda, outside Austin, after he failed to show at a commission meeting. Mrs. Joost worked for the surface mining and reclamation division of the Texas Railroad Commission.

DOC.HEAD: Thunderstorms Lash Plains; Continued Cold in Northeast
DOC.TEXT: Wyoming was under a blanket of heavy snow today as were Colorado and much of the Northeast, which braced for continued cold. A storm moving out of the Rockies and onto the Plains blasted Wyoming and Colorado with heavy, wet snow Tuesday, closing schools and hundreds of miles of highway and shutting down the Wyoming Legislature. Winter storm warnings went up in Colorado, Wyoming, Nebraska and South Dakota. Advisories for freezing rain were posted today for Minnesota, and snow advisories were up across the Cascades in Washington state and Oregon. By late Tuesday afternoon, Wyoming had 16 inches of snow at Wheatland, 13 at Cheyenne and 12 at Douglas. Nebraska snowfall included 8 inches at Harrison and Bushnell. Colorado had 14 inches at Monument and 10 at Fort Collins. The Wyoming Highway Patrol closed some 200 miles of Interstate 80 from the Nebraska line west to Walcott Junction, and about 150 miles of Interstate 25 from the Colorado line north to Orin Junction. Denver's Stapleton International Airport reported delays in arrivals and departures because of visibility as low as 1,000 feet. Colorado Gov. Roy Romer, stranded by a blizzard en route to a meeting of business leaders in Boulder, delivered his speech by car phone. ``The only thing we need to have a healthy economy in this state is to have a freeway system that works right,'' Romer joked on Tuesday from his car, which was stuck on a snowbound highway near Broomfield. Snowfall diminished over New York state and New Jersey, after producing 2 to 5 inches of snow Tuesday. Snow lingered in Massachusetts Tuesday night, as well as in Wyoming, Colorado, South Dakota, Nebraska and Kansas. Freezing rain extended from Illinois, Nebraska and South Dakota. Rain and a few thunderstorms reached across parts of Texas, Oklahoma, Kansas and Nebraska. Rain also extended over the Pacific Northwest with rain changing to snow in the mountains. Today's forecast called for rain across the Northwest with snow expected in the higher elevations. Precipitation also was predicted across most of the Midwest with snow and ice predicted from Colorado to Minnesota, changing to rain and showers from Nebraska and Iowa into Louisiana. Sunny skies weren't expected to warm up the East today, though a gradual warming was seen for the weekend. Varying degrees of cloudiness were forecast for the Southeast, with a cold front lingering over the Carolinas. The nation's high temperature Tuesday was 88 degrees at Laredo, Texas. Other reports at 3 a.m. EST: _East: Albany, N.Y. 9 fair; Atlanta 54 fair; Boston 16 fair; Charleston, S.C. 54 fair; Chattanooga 44 fair; Cincinnati 29 fair; Cleveland 17 fair; Detroit 19 fair; Hatteras 46 windy; Jacksonville 53 foggy; Key West 71 fair; Knoxville 49 fair; Macon 49 fair; Miami 66 fair; New York 18 fair; Philadelphia 23 fair; Pittsburgh 22 fair; Portland, Maine 12 fair; Richmond 36 cloudy; Tampa 64 fair; Washington, D.C. 30 fair. _Central: Birmingham 53 cloudy; Denver 25 snow; Des Moines 32 cloudy; Indianapolis 27 cloudy; Kansas City 39 showery; Little Rock 55 rain; Louisville 40 cloudy; Memphis 64 cloudy; Nashville 53 partly cloudy; New Orleans 59 foggy; North Platte 32 snow; Oklahoma City 59 drizzle; Omaha 35 rain; Rapid City 24 snow; St. Louis 42 hazy; Minneapolis-St. Paul 25 partly cloudy; Sault Ste. Marie 4 fair; San Antonio 69 drizzle. _West: Albuquerque 39 partly cloudy; Anchorage 18 cloudy; Boise 31 fair; Casper 20 cloudy; Fairbanks 3 cloudy; Great Falls 37 fair; Honolulu 72 thunderstorm; Las Vegas 55 fair; Los Angeles 53 fair; Medford 43 cloudy; Pendleton 42 fair; Phoenix 57 fair; Portland, Ore. 47 cloudy; Reno 36 fair; Salt Lake City 42 cloudy; San Diego 53 fair; San Francisco 49 fair; Seattle 47 rain; Spokane 38 cloudy. _International: Calgary 41 partly cloudy; Montreal 5 fair; Ottawa 7 fair; Regina 32 partly cloudy; Toronto 14 fair; Winnipeg 25 partly cloudy.

DOC.HEAD: Vermont Town Votes to Keep Alcohol _ But Get Rid of Board Member
LaserPhoto MR1
DOC.TEXT: Residents of this New England town voted to keep alcohol _ but get rid of the board member who wanted to turn the place dry. Settling the score Tuesday on an issue that had led to a fistfight between two selectmen and intensified a 12-year feud between two families, the town voted 269-111 to allow Rupert's only general store to sell beer and wine. The Green Mountain town was one of hundreds of northern New England communities holding town meetings, the late-winter democratic ritual in which residents speak their mind on matters from snowplow routes to school policy. In Vernon, neighbors of Vermont's only nuclear plant voted Monday to support a low-level radioactive waste site near the plant. Vermont is the only state with a nuclear power plant that has no place to put such waste. In the coastal Maine town of Penobscot, residents overwhelmingly rejected a plan Tuesday to abolish local property taxes and finance town services instead through voluntary payments and user fees. The town budget is $1.2 million a year. Residents felt ``if you didn't have to pay, if you just ask your conscience, the town would crumble,'' said Royce Perkins, architect of the no-tax plan. He said the vote was approximately 235-15 against the proposal. In Rupert, with a population just over 600, a rejection of alcohol sales would have forced residents to travel six miles or more to buy their beer and wine and made the town one of only six dry communities in Vermont. The town was dry until voters in 1981 narrowly approved the sale of beer and wine. But many felt the real issue on the ballot had more to do with the family feud than the issue of wet vs. dry. ``It's really just a grudge match,'' said Rupert Selectman Jay Wilson Jr., who had pushed for an end to beer and wine and ended up losing his 32-year seat 221-156. He said the feud began when John Pelton charged that Wilson's son, now town road commissioner, and several of his friends were taking gasoline from the town garage for their personal use. Pelton is the owner of Rupert's only general store. Pelton is not the only one feuding with the Wilsons. Edward Lewis said his road is the last to get plowed by Wilson's son because he has challenged the elder Wilson for the selectman's seat. The Rev. Paul Mychack of the Church of Christ said some residents have ``been against me mindlessly'' because he took another of Wilson's sons to court 11 years ago.

DOC.HEAD: New York Chancellor Proposes Schools in Office Buildings
DOC.TEXT: The city's schools chancellor wants to set up elementary schools inside office buildings so youngsters can learn with their parents nearby. Joseph A. Fernandez touted the plan Tuesday as a way to improve employee performance and attendance while easing school overcrowding and integrating classes in the nation's biggest school district, with about 1 million students. Fernandez set up similar ``satellite learning centers'' in 1988 while he ran the Miami school system. The school system would supply teachers while the company would provide the space for classes of at least 25 children, from pre-kindergarten through second grade, at each workplace. ``It's conceivable that in a satellite learning center you could have the vice president's kid sitting next to the janitor's kid,'' he said. ``It's also conceivable you could get some of our middle class to start bringing back their kids to our schools.'' Fernandez, who hopes to have a pilot program going by September, said that at the first such center, a kindergarten at a Miami insurance company, employee turnover dropped from 11 percent to 4 percent within a year.

DOC.HEAD: Lawyer: Charges Against Agent Leaked to Sabotage Promotion Hearings
DOC.TEXT: The FBI is harassing a decorated agent with allegations of espionage to sabotage an investigation into anti-Hispanic bias at the bureau, the agent's attorney says. Fernando Mata is on paid leave with his security clearance revoked but has not been advised of any charges, his lawyer, Hugo Rodriguez, said Tuesday. Mata, a 15-year FBI veteran in counterintelligence who received the Justice Department's top award in 1983, has undergone repeated polygraph exams about his career since being suspended six weeks ago, said Rodriguez. The test results have been favorable for Mata, the lawyer said said. The New York Times reported Monday that Mata was being investigated for unauthorized contacts with Cuban agents. Rodriguez said he could not discuss specifics of the allegations against Mata because he is under a national-security gag order. But he said, ``Fernando Mata is not a spy. They know that, everyone knows that.'' The FBI would not comment other than to say: ``This action is totally unrelated to agent Mata's participation in a discrimination class-action lawsuit.'' Mata, 48, was a key witness in a successful 1988 suit by 311 Hispanic agents who accused the bureau of bias in hirings, promotions and discipline. A Texas federal judge set up a panel headed by former U.S. Rep. Barbara Jordan to review promotions to rule out discrimination. ``It is very ironic that those hearings are going to go forth next month, and that allegations against Mr. Mata and other agents ... are all of a sudden surfacing,'' Rodriguez said. He said more minor administrative actions had been taken against about 10 others involved in the lawsuit, including agents in El Paso and San Antonio, Texas; Los Angeles; San Juan, Puerto Rico, and Atlanta. Rodriguez said he will file additional charges of harassment with U.S. District Judge Lucius Bunton in Texas, who has jurisdiction over the lawsuit. About 425 Hispanic agents serve among the FBI's 10,000 employees, said Rodriguez, himself a former agent.

DOC.HEAD: 10 in New York Arrested for Possession of Hypodermics
DOC.TEXT: Police arrested 10 AIDS activists on a street corner before any intravenous drug users could take advantage of their offer to exchange dirty syringe needles for clean ones. The activists had set up a table Tuesday to distribute the needles and AIDS education materials. Among those arrested was Jon C. Parker, a medical student and former drug addict who has led a three-year effort to distribute 50,000 free needles to addicts on the East Coast. The activists were protesting Mayor David Dinkins' decision last month to phase out a needle exchange program begun by the administration of former Mayor Ed Koch. The pilot program was meant to curb the spread of the AIDS virus, HIV, which can be transmitted by sharing used needles. ``People will use drugs, people will shoot up whether they have a clean needle or not,'' said Alan Beck, a spokesman for the AIDS Coalition to Unleash Power, which organized the event with Parker's National AIDS Brigade. By providing clean needles, the activists are saving lives, Beck said. New York is one of 11 states where possession of a hypodermic needle without a prescription is illegal. Those arrested in the Lower East Side section of Manhattan on Tuesday were given tickets for misdemeanor possession of a hypodermic needle, said Sgt. Nick Vreeland, a police spokesman. Intravenous drug users accounted for about 43 percent of the 4,000 AIDS cases reported last year in the city, which has an estimated 200,000 intravenous drug users.

DOC.HEAD: The Spirit of the Boston Tea Party Comes to Britain
DOC.TEXT: Police today accused ``international socialists'' of being behind widespread tax protests that disrupted local council meetings and led to clashes with authorities. But a protest organizer said 99 percent of the demonstrators were local people angered at having to pay higher taxes. The controversial new ``community charge'' is a flat tax on all adults over age 18 that opponents say unfairly favors the wealthy. People rebelling against it included an 89-year-old former war correspondent who handed back his medal at Buckingham Palace and a teacher who lectured magistrates on the Magna Carta. Four constables were injured and 21 demonstrators arrested Tuesday in the worst violence, in Bristol. Anti-tax disturbances also were reported in Bradford, Birmingham, Exeter, Maidenhead, Norwich, Weston-super-Mare, Worcester, Gillingham, Lowestoft and Reading. Police Federation chairman Alan Eastwood claimed that many protesters were from outside London. ``It is rent-a-mob Trotskyites who attend most of these demonstrations,'' he contended in an interview on British Broadcasting Corp. Radio 4. ``Why should a police officer have to be assaulted because somebody feels aggrieved about a tax? It is these international socialists who take on any issue to have a go at the police,'' he said. Steve Nally, secretary of the All Britain Anti-Poll Tax Federation, said he sympathized with the far-left Militant group, which along with ``many other people from a broad political spectrum'' had been involved in peaceful protests against what has been dubbed the poll tax. He insisted 99 percent of the protesters were local people. ``We don't condone the violence that has gone on, but we understand people are very angry about this issue,'' he said on the same program. The citizens were backed by their representatives in the House of Commons, where Michael Martin of the opposition Labor Party told Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, ``Your friends are deserting you. Why don't you give up this irrational obsession to implement the poll tax?'' Mrs. Thatcher, whose waning popularity has been blamed in part on the tax, again blamed local councils for spending too much money and thus forcing taxes to be increased. Scuffles began in Bristol as about 500 demonstators learned that the council set a tax of $810 per adult per year, one of the highest in England. One policeman was taken to the hospital unconscious after he was knocked to the ground, kicked and punched. In the northern city of Birmingham, protesters scuffled with council officials and police. A councilor of the governing Conservative party and two teenage aides held doors to the council chamber shut and kept all but half a dozen demonstrators out. David Green, 18, who is working for the Conservatives before starting university studies, was punched in the face and bruised. ``They just started to push their way in and I was determined to stop them,'' he said. The council meeting was suspended for 30 minutes. There were no arrests. Two officers were injured as police fought running battles with tax protesters in Weston-Super-Mare in Avon. The council meeting there was suspended for more than two hours as doors and windows were smashed and scores of people invaded the building. One group of protesters staged a sit-in annd nine people were arrested before order was restored, police said. Council meetings in Norwich and Maidenhead were halted by invasions of demonstrators. Several people were injured when trouble erupted outside the civic offices in Reading, Berkshire. Hand-clapping protesters disrupted a hearing in Bradford, where teachers also walked out Tuesday to protest spending cuts made to keep the tax down to 267 pounds ($440). A day earlier, protesters dressed as Robin Hood's merry band invaded the council chamber in Nottingham, blew whistles, tossed papers and attacked council members with shaving-cream pies. Former war correspondent Richard McMillan, 89, who returned his Order of the British Empire at Buckingham Palace, said his protest was not for himself ``but for the hundreds of thousands of poor people who are worse off than I am.'' Robert Orme lectured magistrates in Stroud, Gloucestershire that the Magna Carta, signed by King John at Runnymede in 1215, requires ``general consent'' to any tax. ``This government appears to have general dissent,'' he said. The average English household will pay 170 pounds ($280) more under the community charge than under the property tax it replaces _ an increase from $837 to $1,112, the BBC said Tuesday. The figures were calculated by the Chartered Institute of Public Finance Accountants based on charges already set by 250 councils.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Higher on Weakness of Yen and Mark, Gold Lower
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was higher in European trading late this morning, buoyed by the weakness of the West German mark and Japanese yen, dealers said. Gold prices were lower. Foreign exchange dealers said the market was again testing the central banks' resolve to keep the dollar from rising. ``The dollar is well bid, but the market is extremely nervous because it expects to see the central banks any moment now,'' a trader said. Central banks refrained from intervening Tuesday, following heavy dollar sales on Monday. Traders said the weakness of the mark and the yen were the main factors pushing the dollar up at the moment. ``We're bullish,'' said a trader at a large U.S. bank in Frankfurt. Dealers said there were no new factors in the market, but added investor demand for dollars was sustained and would keep the dollar well supported. In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar rose 1.25 yen to a closing 150.75 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a higher rate of 150.80 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Tuesday: _1.7040 West German marks, up from 1.7005 _1.5020 Swiss francs, up from 1.4985 _5.7570 French francs, up from 5.7450 _1.9185 Dutch guilders, up from 1.9105 _1,256 Italian lire, up from 1,254.75 _1.1863 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1866 In London, the dollar rose against the British pound. It cost $1.6415 to buy one pound, cheaper than $1.6495 late Tuesday. Bullion dealers said gold prices were weaker, reflecting the market's preoccupation with the dollar's movements and the lack of any clear indication of a retreat from its recent advances. Gold opened in London at a bid price of $402.25 a troy ounce, down from $405 bid late Tuesday. At midmorning, the city's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended price of $402.60. In Zurich, the bid price was $402.75, down from $405.50 late Tuesday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell $1.83 to close at a bid $402.90. Silver fell in London to a bid price of $5.14 a troy ounce, from Tuesday's $5.15.

DOC.HEAD: Rowdy Students Making Annual Migration to Texas Beach Town
DOC.TEXT: Hotels this month are charging steep security deposits to make guests think twice about tossing furniture out the windows. Paintings that normally hang in lobbies and hallways now sit safely in storage. Otherwise, the tolerance level for disorder has risen with the noise level as spring break and its hordes of beer-drinking, hormone-driven students arrive at this resort island. Myndy Michaels, 20, a sunbathing Ball State student, said Tuesday that she and her sorority sisters had stayed ``buzzed'' for about 24 hours on a drink called ``whammies.'' ``Padre is the best place to party because it's not like a meat market and there's no rules,'' she said, ``and this is my new bathing suit.'' Noon had yet to arrive, but fresh kegs of beer were planted in the sand near volleyball nets. Sun reflected off rows of suntan-oiled young women and the ubiquitous day-glow beach wear. ``We switched into what we call a spring break mode as of last Saturday,'' said Craig Vogel, sales director of the Sheraton South Padre Island Beach Resort. ``We abandoned being a three-star hotel and turned into a spring break hotel.'' That means the hotel's convention and brunch areas will shut down for the month and that getting a room requires a $50-per-person deposit. Paintings, plants and other portable objects have been moved out of high-traffic areas. Island promoters say they expect up to 200,000 spring breakers over a nine-week period that began the last week of February. The student population reaches its peak from March 10-24, when many Texas schools are out, said Geri Jean Wilson, director of the South Padre Island Visitor & Convention Bureau. Some resort areas, particularly in Florida, in recent years have grown weary of the rowdy students and established strict ordinances to discourage spring breakers. Not so in South Padre Island, a town of about 1,000 permanent residents near the Mexican border. ``South Padre Island welcomes spring breakers, and we extend an invitation to them,'' Ms. Wilson said. ``We look at it as if we're creating brand loyalty right now.'' Police chief Ed Sanders says his 17 officers tend to leave the students alone. Police did, however, arrest nearly 1,000 of the students last year, most for severe public intoxication and disorderly conduct. Mexican officials have started a voluntary sign-in program for spring breakers, as a means of keeping track of who's there, said Antolin Licona Lopez, immigration director for the Mexican government in Matamoros, 25 miles south of here. He said the program was not created because of the disappearance and cult murder last March of University of Texas student Mark Kilroy, who was found buried near Matamoros along with 14 other victims. Judging by the high occupancy rate at the island, the cult murders don't appear to have affected the spring break business, officials say.

DOC.HEAD: NEC, AT&T to Cooperate in Semiconductor Technology
DOC.TEXT: Japan's NEC Corp. and American Telephone & Telegraph Co. today announced an agreement to cooperate in developing and manufacturing a wide range of semiconductors and other technologies. The agreement will greatly enhance the U.S. corporation's access to Japan's world-dominating electronics market. NEC, the world's largest maker of semiconductors, agreed to cooperate with AT&T's Microelectronics division on various projects for at leat five years. Under the agreement, AT&T Microelectronics will receive a license to market, design and produce NEC gate-array computer chips, which can be used for a wide variety of applications because they are programmable. ``An important feature of this agreement is that customers of both companies will enjoy the advantage of having two stable sources of identical gate-array products,'' said William Warwick, president of AT&T Microelectronics. ``From AT&T, NEC will receive our most sophisticated computer-aided design tools,'' Warwick told a news conference. He said the two companies are working on accelerating the placement of AT&T Microelectronics semiconductor products into a variety of NEC products, such as communications systems and computers. AT&T Microelectronics, which is based in Berkeley Heights, N.J., also will provide manufacturing support for certain NEC microchips that are widely used in consumer electronics products. ``This will allow Japanese customers to obtain products made by an American firm, and will give AT&T a greater presence in the Japanese market, especially with consumer electronics companies,'' Warwick said. ``The agreement will benefit customers of both companies through the strength of product lines and capabilities, and enhancing of business opportunities,'' he said. Tomohir Matsumura, NEC executive vice president and director of its semiconductor division, said computer chips are often referred to in Japan as the ``staple food'' or ``crude oil'' of the electronics industry. ``This agreement shows that one single company cannot stand alone and needs more resources to survive,'' Matsumura said. ``It makes sense for AT&T as a big semiconductor user to go to NEC, a big semiconductor producer,'' said Charles Elliott, an electronics analyst with the investment firm Goldman Sachs. ``But AT&T is also a big semiconductor developer, and it makes sense for AT&T to design and NEC to produce.'' Neither of the executives would attach monetary figures to the accord, but Warwick said he was confident it would be continued after five years. ``It's long enough to indicate to our customers that our access to gate-array technology is not a one-generation access,'' Warwick said. ``I have no doubts it will grow, and continue indefinitely.'' The agreement will facilitate NEC's policy of increasing purchases of foreign semiconductors to ease trade friction. U.S. officials, angered by what they claim is a closed Japanese market to foreign semiconductors, say Japan agreed to boost the foreign share of the semiconductor market here to 20 percent by July 1991. But foreign chips' share stood at only 12.9 percent in the final quarter of 1989, according to the Ministry of International Trade and Industry. NEC expects to purchase $5.3 million worth of AT&T semiconductors in 1990, and more in 1991, though there is no target figure for next year, NEC spokeswoman Akiko Sato said. The manufacturer plans to raise its internal use of foreign computer chips from the current 20 percent to 23 percent by July 1991, when the U.S.-Japan semiconductor accord expires, and to some 24 percent by the end of next year, Miss Sato said. The NEC-AT&T accord reflects an increasing trend toward corporate tieups in the semiconductor industry. AT&T Microelectronics announced two weeks ago that it will produce semiconductor memory chips for the international market in a joint venture with Mitsubishi Electric Corp., another major Japanese chip manufacturer. International Business Machines Corp. said in January that it would set up a joint venture with Siemens AG of West Germany to develop advanced memory chips.

DOC.HEAD: Masked Gunmen Kill Prominent Turkish Journalist
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with more on journalist's views, background on terrorism in Turkey. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Masked gunmen today shot and killed a prominent journalist who often criticized Moslems fundamentalists in Turkey and blamed Syria for a resurgence of terrorism in his homeland. Cetin Emec, a board member and columnist of Turkey's largest circulation newspaper, Hurriyet, died after being rushed to the hospital shortly after the 9 a.m. shooting, police said. His driver also was killed in the attack. Authorities said two masked gunmen fired on Emec and his driver as they were leaving his house in the fashionable Suadiye district to go to work. The driver, Sinan Ercan, was shot in the back as he fled, police said. The gunmen escaped in a stolen car, the semi-official Anatolia news agency said. No group immediately claimed responsibility for the shooting. President Turgut Ozal denounced the attack, saying: ``The assailants and the treacherous people behind them should know that they will not succeed to ruin the calm and stability of our country with terrorism.'' In his last column, published in Hurriyet today, Emec expressed alarm at the resurgence of terrorism in Turkey. He accused Syria of supporting terrorist groups in the region and claimed Syrian leaders were behind the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 over Scotland in December 1988. Emec, the son of a newspaper publisher, was known for his liberal views and often criticized the Moslem fundamentalist minority in Turkey. A month ago, a gunman shot and killed a prominent Turkish jurist, Muammer Aksoy, at the entrance to his house in the capital city, Ankara. A previously unknown Moslem fundamentalist group, calling itself the Islamic Revenge Organization, claimed responsibility for that shooting. Callers to newspaper offices said Aksoy was punished for his opposition to the Islamic style of dress for women, which requires covering from head to toe. Police could not verify the claim. A wave of terrorism in late 1970s claimed 5,000 lives in Turkey and triggered a military takeover in 1980 that lasted three years.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Grand Jury Hears Testimony in Mail Bomb Probe
DOC.TEXT: A junk dealer who was once the focus of a mail bomb investigation said there were no surprises when he testified before a federal grand jury. ``It was the same things we've been through before,'' Robert Wayne O'Ferrell of Enterprise said Tuesday after he left the federal courthouse. O'Ferrell's attorney, Paul Harden said his client was not subpoenaed to appear before the grand jury. He said O'Ferrell and his wife agreed to testify voluntarily at the request of federal prosecutors. O'Ferrell again denied any wrongdoing and said he continued to believe he was not a suspect in the case. As for the grand jury, ``I don't think they believe we had anything to do with it,'' he said. Federal authorities declined to comment on the proceeding. No one has been charged in the December mail bombings that killed Judge Robert Vance of Birmingham, a member of the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, and a Savannah, Ga., lawyer. In January, federal investigators swarmed over the Enterprise area, searching O'Ferrell's home, salvage business, septic tanks and other property in the southeast Alabama vicinity. O'Ferrell came under scrutiny because he had an employment case that was heard by a three-judge panel that included Vance. Federal agents said typewritten court correspondence from O'Ferrell matched typewritten material sent by the alleged mail bomber. O'Ferrell has said he could have had the typewriter and used it to type his court case letters but then sold it to an unknown buyer. Investigators found several typewriters in the salvage store but none that had type matching the letters, according to federal agents.

DOC.HEAD: 106-Year-Old Twin Dies, Two Months After Sister
DOC.TEXT: Maggie Grubb Lambeth, who with her sister gained recognition as the world's oldest identical twins, has died at a nursing home. She was 106. Her sister, Allie Grubb Hill, died Jan. 10, three days before their birthday. Mrs. Lambeth, who had been in declining health for several months, died Tuesday at Mount Vista Health Park, nursing director Yvonne Leach said. Mrs. Lambeth was never told of her sister Allie's death, Leach said. The women were listed in the Guinness Book of World Records as the oldest living set of identical twins. Mrs. Lambeth is survived by nine children.

DOC.HEAD: Parliamentary Hearings Expose Army Corruption, Stupidity
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Fixes typo in 16th, `Bokor's allegations...' and subject-verb agreement in 20th, `The initial...' Pickup 21st, `The affair...'
DOC.HEAD: An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: In a country where not everybody can get a telephone, a sumptuous, illegally built luxury hideaway for top army brass had phones in the sauna and on docks within arm's reach of fishing generals. A lieutenant colonel promoted himself after receiving a Defense Ministry invitation that mistakenly identified him as a full colonel. He was allowed to keep the extra star after complaining that removing it from his epaulets would make him a laughing stock. A new book by Col. Imre Bokor is full of such anecdotes about the Hungarian army _ some funny, others frightening, but all calculated to expose three decades of stupidity and corruption in high places. Bokor, 59, was retired less than a week after publication of his book ``Petty Monarchs in Uniform,'' which depicts former Defense Minister Lajos Czinege as an inept and corrupt warlord who beat his adjutant and took large tracts of state property for his own use. The book says Czinege created a private game reserve on state land, put up 80 miles of fence and stocked the area with deer and other trophy animals. High-ranking visitors tested their marksmanship from army helicopters or Czinege's special four-wheel-drive vehicle with a rotating seat and rifle-rest. Some of his generals are described as alcoholics who danced on banquet tables laden with food and drink or slept for hours in moving Defense Ministry elevators. Others are accused of emulating Czinege by building luxurious private homes with army manpower and materials. The book depicts one general, who had no medical training, as donning a doctor's robe on a voyeuristic excursion to a women's ward in a military hospital. Senior government officials have said most of the allegations are true, as did a parliamentary committee set up specifically to deal with Bokor's accusations. In a report made public March 1, the committee condemned the past Communist practice of choosing leaders on the basis of political reliability instead of competence and qualifications, saying it ``led to the selection of the unfittest.'' It recommended that the supreme public prosecutor consider criminal charges against those accused of the greatest transgressions. Even Defense Minister Ferenc Karpati has described the allegations as ``largely true.'' He has offered to reactivate Bokor, but the soft-spoken colonel now wants nothing to do with an army he feels was betrayed by much of its senior staff. He told of harassment following publication of the book in November, both by superiors trying to pressure him to retract his allegations and by others. ``I received several dozen anonymous death threats in the first weeks that the book was available,'' he told a reporter, adding that he now carried a handgun as a result. ``It got to the point where my poor wife didn't want to answer the phone.'' The book appeared at a time of increasing debate about the future of the army, with Hungary beginning to replace decades of following Moscow's lead with indepedendent strategic goals as it evolves into a democracy. The army had a strength of 106,000 in the early 1980s, and its mission was largely to act with other Warsaw Pact forces. Bokor's allegations of poor leadership followed assertions by others that the army would have been unable to muster an indepedendent defense of the country in recent years. With few exceptions, ``the transport vehicles are in terrible shape, and commanders are relieved if the vehicles manage to get outside camp gates,'' Lt. Gen. Mihaly Toeroek, secretary of Parliament's defense committee, declared on Feb. 12. ``The army ... has no suitable organization capable of independent military activity.'' Some of the book's key figures have remained on active duty. Czinege, who has denied wrongdoing, retired as defense minister in 1985 and as deputy premier in 1987. The initial 50,000-run printing of the book was sold out less than two weeks after publication, and extensive testimony before the parliamentary commission investigating Bokor's allegations was on front pages of many newspapers. The affair has taken on an international dimension with criticism of the Soviet Union. Jenoe Fock, premier during some of Czinege's tenure as defense minister, told the nine-member commission on Feb. 6 that the Soviets felt they could work with Czinege _ so he stayed, even though the leadership was familiar with some of his shortcomings. Commission members have criticized not only Czinege and his contemporaries but also the entire 42-year Communist era in Hungary. ``This investigation has made one thing very clear, and that is that insignificant, primitive politicians had run this country,'' panel head Ernoe Raffay said on state radio. Bokor said the faults he exposed originated in the monolithic rule of Communists in Hungary and other Soviet bloc countries. ``In the final analysis, these were created by the system, and not only within the army,'' he said. ``I've heard it said that there is the need of many Bokor books to expose corruption elsewhere in our society.''

DOC.HEAD: Marxist Hard-liner Behind Attempted Coup
With PM-Afghanistan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs last graf, `He was...' with 1 graf to restore dropped word.
DOC.TEXT: The Afghan defense minister trying to overthrow his government is a longtime Marxist hard-liner who opposes President Najib's efforts to make peace with the U.S.-backed Moslem guerrillas. Both Tanai and Najib were key players in the 1978 coup that first brought the People's Democratic Party of Afghanistan to power. But while Najib in recent years has sought to distance himself and the party _ at least publicly _ from their communist roots, Tanai has a reputation as an unreconstructed, militaristic Marxist. Afghans who are both pro- and anti-Najib and the party say Tanai has been involved in three of five known coup attempts against Najib since the former secret police chief became president in December 1986. The fact that Najib retained Tanai in the Cabinet and even promoted him to the party's 14-member Politburo illustrates the paradoxes inherent in the Soviet-backed Kabul government. On the one hand, Najib has sought to placate some foes within the party by giving them positions of power. On the other hand, he has had to guard against attempted coups by them. The Afghan sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Tanai was linked to previous coup plots in July and December 1989. Government-run Kabul Radio identified Tanai as the ringleader of Tuesday's attempted coup and President Najib demanded his capture ``dead or alive,'' according to Afghan exile monitors in New Delhi. Radio Kabul said Tanai, who was named defense minister by Najib about 18 months ago, plotted with fundamentalist guerrilla leader Gulbaddin Hekmatyar to try to topple Najib. Such as alliance, if true, would be more one of convenience and opportunism than ideology, for Tanai has long been known to advocate a harsher stance against the mujahedeen guerrillas than Najib himself. By linking Tanai to Hekmatyar, Najib's government may be attempting to set the stage for Tanai's final _ and perhaps fatal _ disgrace. In recent months, Najib has increasingly used Hekmatyar as the personification of evil while maintaining there are other mujahedeen leaders who are more rational and welcome to join the government. At the same time, Hekmatyar has become increasingly estranged from his fellow guerrilla leaders, rejecting their political leadership and executing some of their followers. Tanai is one of the top leaders of Khalq, or ``masses,'' faction of the ruling party. Najib is the leader of its Parcham, or ``flag,'' faction. Although both factions include hardliners with commitments to communism, Parcham has become less doctrinaire and is less hawkish than Khalq, especially when it comes to making political overtures to the mujahedeen guerrillas, or Islamic holy warriors. Najib loyalists say the president has recently embarked on attempts to change the party _ and even its name _ in an effort to make it more palatable to the mujahedeen, the Afghan people and foreign opponents, such as the U.S. government To the mujahedeen, such overtures are futile, since these Islamic fundamentalists refuse to deal with a party they consider nothing more than a bunch of ``godless communists.'' Tanai, who is thought to be in his mid 40s, has a reputation as an ultra-hardliner, especially when it comes to making any concessions to the mujahedeen or modifying the party, which Najib has sought to portray as a defender of Islam and champion of a free-market economy. Tanai, like many Afghans, takes his surname from his ancestral homeland _ the Tanai region near Khost in southern Afghanistan. He became defense minister sometime in 1988. As often happens in Afghanistan, his appointment apparently was not formally announced. But by late 1988 he was being referred to in Kabul as the defense minister and when Najib reshuffled his Cabinet in February 1989 after the Soviet withdrawal, Tanai remained defense minister. He was elevated to full membership from alternate membership in the party Politburo in either late 1988 or in 1989, a promotion that can only take place with Najib's concurrence.

DOC.HEAD: Kaifu Criticizes Gephardt's Sanction Threat
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu criticized a U.S. congressional leader who threatened to press for sanctions on Japanese imports this summer unless progress is made in trade talks, Japanese newspapers reported today. Richard Gephardt, Democratic majority leader in the House of Representatives, made the comment Sunday, one day after President Bush and Kaifu held two days of talks in Palm Springs, Calif. The two leaders announced no specific measures to further trade talks, and Gephardt said the meeting produced nothing to resolve the countries' worsening trade relationship. Speaking to Japanese reporters Tuesday, Kaifu said Gephardt's statements were ``cruel'' and representated a threat that unless Japan cut its trade surplus ``to zero,'' it would be subject to retaliatory tariffs on exports, Japan's major economic newspaper, the Nihon Keizai Shimbun, reported. Similar remarks were also reported in the Daily Yomiuri newspaper. An aide to the prime minister said he could not confirm the newspaper reports. Kaifu, speaking before Parliament's upper house Tuesday, urged lawmakers to cooperate in changing Japan's economic structure for the sake of the Japanese people as well U.S.-Japanese relations. The United States trade deficit with Japan last year totaled $49 billion.
