DOC.HEAD: Mitsubishi, Daimler-Benz Announce Cooperation Agreement
DOC.TEXT: Two giant business groups in Japan and West Germany have announced plans for wide-ranging cooperation in fields such as semiconductors and aeronautics, officials said. Specifics of the accord between West Germany's Daimler-Benz and Japan's Mitsubishi still must be ironed out, but if it goes through, the agreement could pose a competitive challenge for the United States, analysts said today. The agreement to expand ties was reached in secret meetings between the top exeuctives of the massive industrial groups in Singapore last weekend, Mitsubishi officials announced Tuesday. Mitsubishi said the industrial giants were discussing cooperation in ``high-growth industries such as aerospace, electronics and the service sector that would benefit from development on a global scale and make effective use of the skills of both groups.'' The statement gave few other details. ``The European market has become increasingly important for Japanese companies, and many are desperately seeking a firm foothold before the integration of the European Community in 1992,'' said Atsushi Takashima, a corporate analyst with Nomura Research Institute. ``For Benz, Mitsubishi is a giant company in Japan, and the cooperation with Mitsubishi will help it achieve its plan to expand outside Europe in regions such as Asia,'' Takashima said. But analysts said cooperation between the corporations in aerospace and semiconductors might worry U.S. companies with which Mitsubishi Heavy Industries has had close ties in jet and rocket production. ``For the United States, aerospace is the only field left in which it can be proud of its technology,'' Asahi Shimbun newspaper said today. Some Japanese newspapers speculated the agreement might worsen trade tension between Japan and the United States, but an analyst with Sanwa Research Institute disagreed. ``The arrangement between Mitsubishi and Daimler may be threatening to the United States, but I don't think it will hurt ongoing trade talks,'' he said. He said on condition of anonymity that the accord was part of a ``global trend to establish joint projects among companies from Japan, Europe and the United States.'' Such projects will only increase in coming years, he said. International Business Machines Corp. agreed in January with Siemens AG of West Germany to develop advanced computer memory chips, he said. Mitsubishi Heavy Industries spokesman, Ryo Suzuki, tried to ease any U.S. concern about the agreement today. ``For us, the most important partner has been the United States, and it will remain the same if we start a joint project with Daimler,'' he said. He said the partnership did not indicate company interest was shifting from America to Europe. Mitsubishi said the companies excluded defense from areas of possible cooperation because Japanese companies are prohibited by law from exporting weapons. ``Defense is one area where the private sector is unable to make its own decisions. It is understood that it is the government's job,'' Suzuki said. Newspapers speculated the companies avoided cooperation in defense to avoid a repeat of their negative wartime images. During World War II, both Mitsubishi and Daimler were active in arming the Axis powers. Daimler-Benz engines were used extensively in German tanks, fighters and bombers, and Mitsubishi helped produce Japanese aircraft such as the Zero fighter. Mitsubishi spokesman Kyosuke Mori said executives from both companies agreed to meet once a year, and he said the next meeting was likely in 1991. In 1988, Mitsubishi Motor and Mercedes-Benz established Stuttgart Auto Service Inc., a joint-venture company to sell and service Mercedes-Benz cars in Japan, said Yoshimi Mizuno, a spokeswoman for Mercedes-Benz Japan Co. Last year, 31,511 Mercedes-Benz were sold through the joint venture, she said.

DOC.HEAD: State Prison, Hospital Hit Again by Power, Heat Outage
DOC.TEXT: A state prison and hospital complex lost heat again today when a fuse blew as workers tried to restore power to buildings housing about 3,200 prisoners and patients. The Howard Complex was hit by a power outage Tuesday morning and about five hours later the complex's boilers stopped working. Steam from the complex's boilers is used for heat and to generate electricity. Thomas Romeo, director of Mental Health, Retardation and Hospitals, said this morning that portable boilers would be needed to restore heat to the complex. ``We're sure back to square one,'' Romeo said after learning of this morning's mishap. Heat had been restored overnight as the temperature dropped to 10 degrees. Gov. Edward D. DiPrete called in the National Guard Tuesday night to provide blankets and portable generators. Most of the 30 buildings in the complex had backup generators.

DOC.HEAD: Rise in Bad Loans Held Consumer Bank Profits to $2.7 Billion
DOC.TEXT: A sharp rise in bad real estate and other domestic loans held consumer bank profits to a weak $2.7 billion in the final three months of last year, the government said today. For the year, banks earned $16.3 billion, a sharp 34 percent decline from last year's record $24.8 billion profit, said the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. Earnings reached record highs in the first two quarters of 1989 of $7.3 billion and $7.0 billion. But the industry went into the red in the July-September period, losing $740 million because of Third World debt problems. ``1989, like March, came in like a lion and went out like a lamb. We had record earnings in the first half of the year...(and) we had a dramatic change in the second half,'' said FDIC Chairman L. William Seidman. Loan losses industry-wide soared to $9.2 billion in the fourth quarter, a record since 1948, when that figure was first tracked. In the Northeast, bad real estate loans more than doubled. Four Northeastern states joined oil-producing states on the list of 10 states with the worst real estate loan problems. In order, starting with the worst, were Arizona, Texas, Massachusetts, Connecticut, Alaska, Oklahoma, Louisiana, New Hampshire, New York, New Mexico. Seidman predicted the industry's performance would improve this year, at least in the first six months. ``All is not on the black side....particularly (small) community banks showed improved earnings,'' he said. ``Much of the ... (third world loan problems) would appear to be behind most of the large banks.'' In another positive sign, the list of ``problem'' banks, which the FDIC uses to predict bank failures, stood at 1,093 at the end of 1989, down from 1,394 a year earlier. Seidman forecast fewer bank failures in 1990 than the 206 failures in 1989. He said the FDIC insurance fund, after a small loss in 1989, should break even or grow slightly in 1990.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev May Give Commencement Speech at Brown University
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has ``agreed in principle'' to be a commencement speaker at Brown University, a State Department official confirmed today. But the official, who asked not to be identified, said it was unclear whether the Soviet leader would speak at the Rhode Island university this spring or at some later date. ``The timing of Brown's commencement does not coincide with plans for the summit,'' said the official. Gorbachev and President Bush plan to meet in the United States in June, but probably not until late in the month. Brown's commencement is scheduled for late May.

DOC.HEAD: Chemical Weapons to Be Removed from Germany This Summer
DOC.TEXT: The removal of U.S. chemical weapons from German soil will begin this summer and transporting the more than 100,000 shells will pose no danger to the public, U.S. and West German officials said today. Defense Minister Gerhard Stoltenberg detailed plans for a massive, high-security transport of the nerve gas weapons, which have been stored in this country for more than 20 years. In May 1986, then-President Reagan and Chancellor Helmut Kohl agreed that all the artillery shells would be removed. The presence of chemical weapons on German soil has long been criticized by West German environmentalists and peace activists. They have alleged that in case of an accident involving chemical weapons, U.S. security concerns would take precedence over the protection of West Germans. U.S. officials have strongly denied the claim. Speaking to reporters, Stoltenberg insisted the transport, which is expected to take about three months, would present no dangers to the environment or the public. But he asked West Germans to help make sure there are no ``attempts at disruption'' of the shipments. Stoltenberg did not specify what kinds of ``disruptions'' concerned him. U.S. Army Gen. John Heldstab, deputy chief of staff for operations for the U.S. Army-Europe, told reporters the army was ``confident'' that proper security would be provided for the transports. Stoltenberg said withdrawal of the artillery shells is scheduled to begin in July and last until September. He said the shells _ now kept at a depot near Clausen in the state of Rhineland-Palatinate _ would be loaded into thick, airtight steel magazines which would in turn be placed inside specially designed sheet-metal containers. It was apparently the first official statement indicating where the chemical weapons are kept. Their location had previously been kept top secret for security reasons. Stoltenberg said the containers would be transported by truck to a U.S. munitions depot in Miesau, 25 miles from Clausen, and loaded aboard railway cars. The trains would transport the containers to the North Sea port of Nordenham, where they will be loaded aboard specially equipped U.S. transport ships. Stoltenberg said the munitions will then be shipped to the Johnston Atoll in the Pacific for destruction. He also said the ``strictest security conditions'' would be used for the transport of the artillery shells, including ``special training'' for truck drivers moving the containers out of Clausen. Col. Eckart Fischer, of the West German army, said the artillery shells contain about 400 tons of the nerve gases ``VX'' and ``Sarin.'' Fischer told reporters that more than 5,000 containers will be needed to move the 155mm and 203mm artillery shells. Heldstab said the munitions represented about 1 percent of the United States' total stockpile of chemical weapons.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Hold Hunger Strike to Protest Martial Law in Tibet
DOC.TEXT: About 4,000 Tibetans staged a one-day fast today to demand that Chinese authorities lift martial law, imposed exactly one year ago. Men, women and children joined Tibetan Buddhist monks in the fast at the mountain headquarters of the Tibetan government-in-exile. ``Though China has swallowed Tibet, it has not been able to digest it,'' said the Dalai Lama, Tibet's spiritual and temporal leader and winner of the 1989 Nobel Peace Prize. He accused the Chinese of trying to ``wipe out'' his people. Chinese authorities in Lhasa, the Tibetan capital, have urged increased vigilance in the upcoming weeks because of several anniversaries in the Tibetan fight against Chinese rule. For the past two years on March 5, pro-independence Tibetans have clashed with security forces. At least 16 people died and hundreds were injured last year after three days of fighting, and martial law was imposed March 7. March 10 is the anniversary of a crushed uprising in 1959 that prompted that Dalai Lama and thousands of his supporters to flee to India. A Western tourist speaking in Beijing said Tibetan authorities have banned tourists from the Himalayan region until mid-March. About 100,000 Tibetans now live in India and have been granted refugee status. Tibetan activists have clashed with Chinese security forces at least four times since September 1987, leaving scores of protesters dead and wounded. Hundreds of activists have been arrested and executions have been carried out, Tibetans say. China claims Tibet has been part of China since the 13th century. Tibetan activists say their homeland was an independent country until Chinese troops invaded in 1950. For years, the Dalai Lama demanded that China leave Tibet and grant the huge, mountainous territory complete independence. But in June 1988, he offered to allow China the responsibility for Tibet's defense and foreign affairs in exchange for Tibetan autonomy over internal affairs. China rejected the proposal but has said it is willing to hold talks. No negotiations have been scheduled.

DOC.HEAD: Cabinet Vote Delayed on Middle East Peace Plan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with death of Arab collaborator, march, house demolished. Edits to trim. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Ministers of the right-wing Likud bloc and the left-of-center Labor Party clashed today over U.S. Middle East peace proposals, but a Cabinet vote on the plan was postponed until the weekend. Also today, a suspected Palestinian collaborator was found hanged near his village in the occupied Gaza Strip, Arab reports said. The army said it demolished the West Bank home of a suspected uprising activist. Labor leaders said that if Likud rejected the American proposals at Sunday's Cabinet session, they would ask Labor's Central Committee to vote the next day on leaving the government and forming a new coalition with small religious and left-wing parties. Economics Minister Moshe Shahal, a Labor member, told reporters after the session he doubted the ministers from Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's Likud could accept the compromise proposals. ``I don't think there is a possibility to get Likud to change their minds,'' Shahal said. ``I think that if the answer is negative from Likud, this government has no continuation.'' Today's Cabinet debate focused on the composition of a Palestinian delegation to preliminary peace talks with Israel in Cairo that would prepare the ground for elections in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. Likud refuses to allow Palestinians from Israeli-annexed Arab east Jerusalem to participate in the talks, saying such representation would threaten Israel's claim of sovereignty over the disputed city. Some Likud hard-liners have also rejected the participation of Palestinians who have been registered as residents of the occupied lands but have since been deported by Israel. The compromise proposed by U.S. Secretary of State James Baker technically met Israel's requirement that the Palestinian negotiators be residents of the occupied territories. But in a nod toward the Palestinians, Baker says the delegation should include at least one Palestinian who has an office or a second home in Jerusalem and one Palestinian who was deported by Israel. In today's session, Labor ministers urged that the Cabinet, based on Baker's proposal, agree to ``consider on a name-by-name basis any Palestinian who is a resident of the territories,'' Shahal said, explaining Labor's stand. The two sides agreed before the session to postpone a vote until Sunday, apparently because two Likud ministers were missing from the crucial meeting, Shahal said. The 12-member Inner Cabinet, the government's key decision-making body, consists of six ministers from Labor and six from Likud. Arab reports said the body of Fahmi Zaanin, 23, was found hanging from a tree near the Gaza village of Beit Hanoun, where he was accused by fellow Palestinians of collaboring with Israeli authorities. He was kidnapped from his home Saturday by masked Palestinians, they said. At least 659 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians in the 27-month-old Palestinian uprising. An additional 193 Palestinians have been slain by fellow Arabs, most on suspicion of collaborating with Israel. Forty-three Israelis have died. Also today, soldiers blew up the home of Mohammed Karoush, 45, of the West Bank village of Deir Balout. Arab reports said 14 people lived in the house.

DOC.HEAD: `60 Minutes' With Andy Rooney Back in Top 10
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to CLARIFY that ABC's Feb. 25 special was a major factor in temporary ratings drop. Picks up 8th graf, `For the week...'
DOC.TEXT: A few minutes with Andy Rooney and the return of regular competition helped lift ``60 Minutes'' from 18th to fourth in the ratings. The rebound of ``60 Minutes,'' which was beaten the week before by an entertainment program _ ``America's Funniest Home Videos'' _ for the first time since 1978, put CBS second in the overall A.C. Nielsen Co. ratings for the week. Sunday's broadcast, in which Rooney discussed his three-week suspension and denied he is a bigot, had a 22 rating, easily beating ABC's ``Life Goes On.'' That series had an 8.9 rating, trailed by NBC's Disney movie, which averaged an 8.3. Each ratings point represents 921,000 homes. On Feb. 8, Rooney was given a three-month suspension without pay after a gay magazine quoted him as saying blacks had ``watered down their genes.'' Rooney denied making the remark. CBS later cut short the suspension, allowing the curmudgeonly humorist to return to his end-of-the-show slot. The ratings of ``60 Minutes'' slipped during Rooney's three-week absence, and the program on Feb. 25 dropped to 18th. However, network research analysts said the major factor in the Feb. 25 drop was competition from the one-time rerun of the premiere of ABC's hit ``America's Funniest Home Videos.'' CBS research vice president Michael Eisenberg said viewer curiosity over Rooney's return to Sunday's ``60 Minutes'' played a part in its ratings rebound, as did ABC's return to its regular program. For the week, NBC was first with an average rating of 14.4. CBS had a 13.1 and ABC 12.4. Here are the top 10 shows, their networks and ratings: ``Roseanne,'' ABC, 22.7; ``The Cosby Show,'' NBC, 22.4; ``Cheers,'' NBC, 22.3; ``60 Minutes,'' CBS, 22.0; ``America's Funniest Home Videos,'' ABC, 21.8; ``A Different World,'' NBC, 21.0; ``CBS Sunday Movie _ The Incident,'' CBS, 20.8; ``The Golden Girls,'' NBC, 20.1; ``Empty Nest,'' NBC, 19.5; ``The Wonder Years,'' ABC, 19.2. ``The Incident'' starred Walter Matthau as a small-town lawyer who defends a Nazi prisoner of war charged with murder. It was Matthau's first TV movie. ``The 1990 Miss USA Pageant'' was No. 20 for the week with a 15.9 rating. On the other end of the numbers, ABC's ``H.E.L.P,'' about an elite rescue squad, premiered at No. 79 for its Saturday 8 p.m. time slot. ``Nasty Boys,'' in its second week for NBC, was tied for 52nd place with ABC's ``Elvis.'' ABC captured first among the evening news shows for the eighth week in a row. Peter Jennings' ``World News Tonight'' had an average rating of 11.1, Tom Brokaw's ``NBC Nightly News'' a 9.8, and Dan Rather's ``CBS Evening News'' 9.7.

DOC.HEAD: Fatherly `Waltons' Actor Running for Congress
DOC.TEXT: Actor Ralph Waite, who played the hard-working father on the TV series ``The Waltons,'' is running for Congress, Democratic Party officials said. Waite revealed his plans at the monthly Riverside County Democratic Central Committee meeting Sunday and was to formally announce his candidacy today for the Democratic nomination for the 37th District. If he wins the nomination, his opponent likely would be incumbent Rep. Alfred A. McCandless, a Republican from La Quinta first elected in 1982. Tom Jameson, chairman of the central committee, said a Waite candidacy ``will certainly add a great deal of excitement to the race.'' Other Democratic candidates include Jeffrey E. Jacobs, a paper company account executive, and Johnny Pearson, a retired Air Force master sergeant. The 37th District includes most of Riverside County. Republicans account for 48.6 percent of registered voters, and Democrats 42.2 percent. A resident of Rancho Mirage, a desert resort city near Palm Springs, Waite briefly considered a congressional bid two years ago. On ``The Waltons,'' which ran from 1972 to 1981, Waite played the father of a large family struggling to make a living during the Depression in Virginia's Blue Ridge Mountains.

DOC.HEAD: Pope to Visit 11 Cities in Mexico and Curacao
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II will visit 11 cities and towns in Mexico during a seven-day tour in May and stop briefly in Curacao, West Indies, before returning to Rome, the Vatican said today. The May 6-14 trip will be John Paul's 47th foreign pilgrimage and second to Mexico. He is visiting Czechoslovakia April 21-22. The Vatican issued a schedule for Mexico listing stops in Mexico City; the gulf port of Veracruz; Aquascalientes in the northwest; San Juan de los Lagos in western Jalisco state; the northern cities of Durango, Zacatecas, Chihuahua and Monterrey; the southeastern cities of Tuxtla and Villahermosa, near the Yucatan Peninsula. The pope will also stop in Chalco, a poor suburb of Mexico City and the site of a well-known shrine. On his way back to Rome, John Paul is scheduled to visit Curacao, part of the Netherlands Antilles on May 13. He returns to Rome the afternoon of May 14. John Paul visited Mexico in January 1979, his first foreign trip as pontiff.

DOC.HEAD: Brazilian Communist Leader Dies, Led Opposition for 60 Years
DOC.TEXT: Luis Carlos Prestes, who led Brazil's Communist opposition for half a century, died today of cancer, doctors said. He was 92. Prestes had suffered from leukemia, said Dr. Peylor Meira, administrator of the Beneficiencia Portuguesa Hospital, where Prestes died. In the 1980s, Prestes accused the Brazilian Communist Party of abandoning Marxist-Leninist dogma. He was removed from the leadership in 1980 and expelled from the Communist Party in 1984. He campaigned for center-left candidate Leonel Brizola in Brazil's 1989 presidential election, won by conservative Fernando Collor de Mello. In his final days, nearly penniless, Prestes was largely supported by world-famous Brazilian architect Oscar Niemeyer, a long-time Communist sympathizer. Born Jan. 3, 1898 in the southern city of Porto Alegre, Prestes moved with his family to Rio de Janeiro, where he attended the prestigious Realengo military academy. In the 1920s, Prestes took part in unsuccessful military uprisings against President Artur Bernardes, who was accused by critics of selling out national interests to England to pay the foreign debt. In 1924, Prestes, an army captain, led rebelling soldiers on a trek through Brazil's remote interior to preach revolution. The legendary ``Prestes Column'' crossed 15,000 miles and 13 states, outmaneuvering and outfighting superior government forces. He became a popular hero. Three years later, the Prestes Column with just 65 men crossed the border into Paraguay. In exile in Bolivia and Argentina, Prestes became a Marxist and moved to the Soviet Union. In 1935, as head of the Brazilian Communist Party, Prestes returned to Brazil and led an unsucessful uprising against the government of President Getulio Vargas. The movement gave Vargas the excuse he needed to declare the ``Estado Novo'' dictatorship in 1937, and Prestes was sentenced to 46 years in prison. After the dictatorship fell in 1945, Prestes was given an amnesty and elected to the senate. Two years later the Communist Party was outlawed again and Prestes was forced into hiding. He led opposition to a 1964 right-wing military coup, but in 1971 he fled the country for the Soviet Union. He returned with a new amnesty in 1979. Prestes' body was to lie in state at the Rio de Janeiro state assembly and later to be buried at Rio's Sao Joao Batista cemetery, Dr. Meira said. Prestes is survived by wife Maria do Carmo Ribeiro and 10 children.

DOC.HEAD: Bikers Help Pay Tribute to Jimmy Carter's Sister
DOC.TEXT: Sixty bikers guided their Harley-Davidson motorcycles into a rural cemetery for the funeral of former President Carter's sister, Gloria Carter Spann, an avid rider. Mrs. Spann, the last surviving sibling of Jimmy Carter, died early Monday of the same cancer that killed three other members of the family. She was 63. About 300 people, including Mrs. Spann's husband, Walter, and the former president and his wife, Rosalynn, gathered at the Lebanon Cemetery on Tuesday for a 30-minute graveside service. The mourners included men in business suits, women in Sunday dresses and bikers in grimy faded jackets with club colors emblazoned on the back. Walter Spann, his long hair tied in a pony tail, wore a black leather jacket. Mrs. Spann belonged to the Georgia Motorcycle Rights organization and was named Most Outstanding Female Motorcyclist in the nation in 1978. The Harley-Davidson Motorcycle Co. sent a floral spray. Riding side-by-side on 30 motorcycles, the bikers led the funeral procession from Americus to the cemetery, a few miles southwest of Plains in rolling farm country. Eight bikers served as pallbearers. John ``the Reverend'' Herlihy, a photographer and custom bike builder from Melbourne, Fla., was introduced to the mourners by the Rev. Jenny Jackson Adams, pastor of Morningside United Methodist Church in Americus. The bearded middle-aged biker, with tattooed arms and long hair, and wearing a black T-shirt emblazoned with ``Biker Lifestyle,'' stood at a microphone a few feet from the coffin. His voice cracked with emotion as he remembered his discussions with Mrs. Spann. ``Please take some time and say a prayer for her because I know she's in biker heaven,'' Herlihy said. The pastor described Mrs. Spann as a courageous person who lived life to the fullest and was an inspiration for others. ``Gloria was tough and Gloria was wonderful,'' she said. ``Gloria was a private person and saw no real need to explain her life to people. She did not seek the spotlight, but she was a light _ bravest of the brave _ and of course she knew exactly what she was up against with this disease.'' Mrs. Spann had been diagnosed in December as having pancreatic cancer, the same disease that killed her father, James Earl Carter; her sister, Ruth Carter Stapleton; and her brother, Billy Carter. Adams said Mrs. Spann felt that Christianity can be meaningful for all types of people. ``Perhaps it was part of her nature to transcend culture and to transcend lifestyles in the way that she did and to bring out the best in all kinds of people who thought of themselves as pretty rough characters,'' Adams said.

DOC.HEAD: More Than 130 Feared Drowned in Ship Collision
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs grafs 8-10, `The riverboat...its side,' with 3 grafs to ADD size of boats, CORRECTS name of freighter. Pickup 11th graf, `It had...
DOC.TEXT: A riverboat carrying 209 people, most of them children, smashed into a freighter and sank during the night in the Amazon River. Police said one person died and 134 were missing and feared drowned. The Andresito sank 7:30 p.m. Tuesday, an hour and and a half after leaving Iquitos, a Peruvian river port 715 miles northeast of Lima, police there said. The boat's helmsman told police in Iquitos that the Andresito's motor failed and vessel began drifting in the Amazon's fast currents. In the darkness it smashed into several small boats anchored along the shore. It then careened into a freighter tied to a dock, rolled over and sank in the dark, swirling waters of the Amazon, police said. Police said 74 people had been rescued by dawn today and that the body of a small girl was found. Heavy rain was hampering rescue boats and divers in their search for survivors and bodies. Most of the passengers were children, their parents and school teachers who were returning home from Iquitos after school holidays, police said. They were headed to Puritoyacu, a jungle village on an Amazon tributary three days travel by boat from Iquitos, police said. The 182-foot riverboat rolled over quickly and sank because it was overloaded with passengers and lumber for building a new school in Puritoyacu, authorities said. They said the 430-foot, 7,500-ton freighter received minor damage. It was identified as the Yacu Caspi, a Peruvian-owned vessel that travels the Amazon to the Atlantic and to Caribbean ports. The freighter was tied to a dock when the Andresito smashed into its side. It had arrived Feb. 28 from Panama with sugar and wheat flour for Iquitos and steel pipes for Occidental Petroleum Corp., which produces oil in jungle fields in the Iquitos area.

DOC.HEAD: Gathers' Death Points Up Dilemma for Doctors
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf, `But the specialists...' with 4 grafs to UPDATE with report Gathers did not heed doctors' advice. Picks up 9th graf, ``One of...'. A version moving on sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: Heart specialist Richard Kehoe recalls being jolted when he heard a radio play-by-play announcer say his patient, a pro basketball player, had collapsed during a game. Only after a long commercial break did Kehoe learn, to his relief, that Terry Cummings of the San Antonio Spurs had simply sprained an ankle. It has been about five years since Kehoe helped Cummings decide whether to continue his career despite an irregular heartbeat, and the decision to go ahead appeared to be ``quite safe,'' Kehoe said. But, he added: ``There probably isn't a day that goes by that I don't think about it.'' His experience illustrates the difficult medical dilemma of whether an athlete's career should continue despite risk from a life-threatening disease _ a problem highlighted by the death on Sunday of basketball star Hank Gathers. A player with Loyola-Marymount University in Los Angeles, Gathers collapsed during a game and died. He had been diagnosed as having an irregular heartbeat after fainting during a game in December ot conduct its affairs by coercion,'' Caperton said. ``The deal is off.'' Federation leaders said they would meet with their county representatives today and decide whether to strike. Under the proposal, raises for public school teachers and higher education employees would have been financed by a $1 per ton tax on coal. The proposal also guaranteed full funding of the state's health insurance program. Attorney General Roger Tompkins said state law does not permit a teacher walkout, but federation executive director Bob Brown said this week a 1980 Supreme Court opinion gives public employees the right to strike. The walkout could jeopardize today's start of the state high school basketball tournament, an official said. Warren Carter, assistant director of the Secondary Schools Activities Commission, which governs prep athletics, said each county has individual rules concerning extracurricular activities when schools aren't in session.

DOC.HEAD: House Of Commons Renews Prevention Of Terrorism Act
DOC.TEXT: The House of Commons voted to renew for another year the Prevention of Terrorism Act, which allows police to detain terrorist suspects without charge for up to seven days without having to inform anyone. The extension, granted in a 227-136 vote late Tuesday, also allows police to ban suspects from Northern Ireland from entering mainland Britain. The act was first passed in 1974 after the Irish Republican Army bombed two pubs in the central England city of Birmingham, killing 21 people. It now is used to combat international terrorism in general but remains a prime weapon against the outlawed IRA. The mainly Roman Catholic IRA fighting British rule in Northern Ireland wants to unite the predominantly Protestant province with the 95 percent Catholic Republic of Ireland under socialist rule. Home secretary David Waddington, the member of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Conservative Cabinet responsible for police, told the Commons: ``During 1989 the nation witnessed not only 62 further killings in Northern Ireland ... but also the terrible incident at Deal in which 11 soldiers were brutally murdered and the callous shooting of a Royal Air Force corporal and his baby daughter in West Germany ... As time goes on, we are more, not less, resolved to defeat terrorism.'' Waddington said without the act, the work of security forces in countering terrorism would have been more difficult and less effective. He said the casualty toll also would have been higher. An IRA bomb at an army school of music at Deal in southeast England in September killed 11 people who play in military bands. Two IRA gunmen killed an RAF corporal and his 6-month-old daughter in October near a British air base at Wildenrath in West Germany.

DOC.HEAD: County Defies Judge's Order on Malibu Cityhood Vote
DOC.TEXT: County supervisors defied a judge's order and refused to schedule a June election on making Malibu a city. They instructed county attorneys to challenge the judge's jurisdiction over the issue. Backers of cityhood for the star-studded seaside enclave said their lawyers would ask Superior Court Judge Dzintra Janavs to cite the supervisors for contempt. ``What we are seeing is an unmitigated outrage,'' Walt Keller, co-chairman of the Malibu Committee for Incorporation, said of the county's move Tuesday. Ms. Janavs last week ordered supervisors to comply with an order she issued in January to set an election date no later than March 9, the deadline to include the cityhood vote on the June 5 ballot. The Board of Supervisors has opposed incorporation, insisting that a sewer system be installed before cityhood is established. They contend that once elected, a new Malibu government would try to block the planned system. Many cityhood supporters regard the county's insistence on a new sewer system as a prelude to widespread development. They filed a lawsuit against the supervisors accusing the county of violating a state law that sets a 60-day limit on the duration of a hearing before an election date is set.

DOC.HEAD: Official Says World's Poor Can Be Educated for $5 Billion More a Year
DOC.TEXT: Children in the 72 poorest nations could gain access to a basic education by 2000 if $5 billion a year is spent on the task, a senior United Nations official said today. ``The annual cost by the mid-1990s is roughly equivalent to the amount the world now devotes to military expenditure every two days, or to the total of the USA's annual expenditure on cigarette advertising and the amount the Soviet Union spends a year on vodka,'' said James P. Grant. Grant, director of the U.N. Children's Fund, did not say what current education spending is. He as addressing the third day of the 155-nation World Conference on Education for All. U.N. officials sponsoring the conference have said almost 1 billion adults are illiterate, and more than 100 million children have never seen the inside of a classroom. A U.N. official, who requested anonymity, said the World Bank and other agencies and countries have pledged half of the extra $5 billion needed annually. He said the conference sponsors hoped to persuade donor countries to make up the rest. At Tuesday's conference session, the World Bank announced it will substantially increase its loans for international education, to an annual level of $1.5 billion by 1993. The U.N. Children's Fund said it would increase education funding to $200 million annually by the end of the century. Grant said Latin America and sub-Saharan Africa had the worst problems educating children and the newly industrialized countries of East Asia were the success stories. Some conference delegates said that even with new loans, poor nations can't improve their education programs unless the bank and other lending institutions abandon current repayment conditions for large-scale debt. World Bank President Barber Conable told reporters today that poor nations can devote more resources to education by changing spending priorities and eliminating waste, including excessive military budgets. ``Should we forgive debt built up for military purposes?'' he asked.

DOC.HEAD: Barge Explodes in Shipping Channel
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with spill estimate, cleanup and tighten, picking up 7th graf pvs, `Govs. Jim....'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY6,7
DOC.TEXT: Coast Guard officials fought today to contain a slick of more than 100,000 gallons of heating oil spreading from the smoldering wreck of an oil barge that exploded and caught fire in a busy waterway. A sheen of oil spread along a four-mile area on the Arthur Kill waterway between New Jersey and New York's Staten Island, said Coast Guard Capt. Robert North. The oil was released by two explosions and fire Tuesday afternoon aboard the barge Cibro Savannah, which was leaving the Citgo Petroleum Corp. docks in Linden with a cargo of 4.2 million gallons of diesel fuel. One person was injured. It was the third time in a week crews had to place containment booms around a vessel to prevent further pollution in the shipping channel, which connects through the Kill Van Kull to New York Habor. Govs. Jim Florio of New Jersey and Mario Cuomo of New York directed their environmental officials to meet with oil executives and questioned industry standards for refining, transporting and storing oil in the New York harbor. ``Enough is enough. We need to be shown that everything is being done to end this string of environmental tragedies,'' Florio said. Donald Wright, the vessel's captain, said at his hospital bed that he had just loaded the barge with No. 2 fuel and was being towed by a tugboat from the Citgo docks when the first blast occurred. ``All I seen was steel flying and flames,'' said Wright, 41, of Saratoga Springs, N.Y. He said gasoline vapors from a previous cargo may have caused the first explosion, but he did not know how the vapors would have been ignited. Coast Guard Petty Officer Howard Holmes said the explosion nearly broke the barge in two. ``It was like a branch that's still green. You can break it, but it won't totally break in two,'' he said. Booms were put in place to keep the slick from spreading to part of Staten Island, two rivers and a sensitive refuge and spawning ground for birds. The Arthur Kill, which separates New York City's Staten Island from New Jersey, was the site of a 567,000-gallon oil spill on Jan. 1-2 from a ruptured Exxon underwater pipeline. On Feb. 28, 30,000 gallons of heating oil spilled into the Kill Van Kull from a barge anchored in Bayonne. On Thursday, 3,500 gallons of heavy crude spilled from a barge into the Arthur Kill at Exxon's refinery in Linden.

DOC.HEAD: Libya Denies U.S. Allegations of Chemical Weapon Production
With AM-Chemical Weapons, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Libya today denied U.S. reports that a plant outside Tripoli is producing chemical weapons and said the allegations were aimed at creating suspicion surrounding moves by Arab-African nations toward unity. In Washington, the White House said today the Libyan plant at Rabta, 60 miles south of the Libyan capital, was dangerous and urged ``vigorous efforts'' to stop its operation. White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said evidence suggests the plant ``is dangerous and becoming more so.'' Late Tuesday, U.S. officials said the plant was turning out mustard gas and nerve agents. The officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, did not disclose the quantity of chemicals allegedly produced. ABC television news, in a report broadcast late Tuesday, said the plant had been producing mustard gas and assembling hand-packed, small bombs that could carry the chemical weapons to targets. JANA, the Libyan news agency, in a dispatch monitored in Rome, said an unidentified ``official source'' at the Libyan Foreign Ministry today ``disclaimed'' the ABC report that Libya has produced ``quantities of chemical weapons in (the) Rabta medicine factory.'' The source, according to JANA, said ``such allegations aired at present by some media circles aim at creating a state of suspicion'' surrounding Arab-African nations' efforts toward economic and political unity. The Arab Magreb Union, formed in February 1989, groups Libya, Algeria, Tunisia, Morocco and Mauritania and aims to set up an economic common market on the European model. Since Western reports surfaced in 1988 that the factory was gearing up to produce chemical weapons, Col. Moammar Gadhafi's regime has insisted the plant's purpose is to produce pharmaceuticals. Western journalists were invited to tour the plant in January last year but were not allowed to inspect the facility after they arrived in Rabta. The West German government has investigated allegations a West German firm helped build the plant. The investigation has not yet been concluded. U.S. officials have urged foreign companies not to help develop or supply the plant. The JANA dispatch today said the Foreign Ministry source expressed ``sorrow over the sham'' reports, especially in light of Libya's call for ``balanced and open dialogue with the new U.S. administration.'' Former President Ronald Reagan ordered the bombing of Tripoli and another Libyan city, Benghazi, in April 1986 in retaliation for what he called Libya's support of international terrorism.

DOC.HEAD: `Hack Rat' Faces Judgment Day
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 4th graf, beginning `On Thursday ...,' to delete reference to value of licenses. Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Mile for mile, Vehbi Gunduz is probably the worst cab driver in town. He insults, bullies and threatens passengers, dispatchers and inspectors. He overcharges riders, denies them receipts and refuses to take them where they want to go. His cab is filthy, his trunk a mess, his hack license as hard to find as a taxi on a rainy night. But his ride on the wild side may be over. On Thursday, the Taxi and Limousine Commission plans to ask a judge to revoke license No. 411689. Although the ranks of the city's 34,000 taxi drivers contain many candidates for the unofficial title of New York's worst cabbie, Gunduz's resume is five pages long. In recent years, he has been convicted of, or admitted to, 119 rules violations. ``He's in a pickle,'' said attorney Michael Stone, who has represented Gunduz. The best Stone can say about Gunduz's record? ``He never has attacked a member of the public.'' Gunduz has dodged expulsion from the industry by never going too far. He's the kind of driver who, according to commission staffer Bruce Schaller, ``consistently does a lot of fairly bad or pretty bad things, but nothing really outrageous'' that would lead to license revocation. Gunduz, who is in his late 30s, recently moved from his Long Island home and had his telephone disconnected. He could not be reached for comment on the case against him. Last year, he was one of eight ``hack rats'' whose faces appeared in the Daily News. Gunduz, who was serving a two-month suspension, blamed most of his troubles on airport dispatchers trying to shake him down for money. ``I am getting tired of this job,'' he said. ``I'm going to give up. I'm working and working, and I'm paying all the money for the summonses.'' But a few months later, a taxi inspector at Kennedy International said he saw Gunduz charging an Asian passenger $15 for a ride between the TWA and United terminals. The meter was off, and the inspector found that a seal that prevents tampering had been broken. When the inspector tried to remove the cab's medallion, Gunduz ``physically poked and pushed me,'' the inspector reported. Three months later, according to commission records, Gunduz picked up a couple outside Iberia's terminal. They had only one piece of luggage, which was fortunate, because his trunk was so cluttered it had room for no more _ rule violation No. 1. The couple said they wanted to go to another terminal. Gunduz, who does not like short fares, said no _ violation No. 2. The dispatcher told him to get going, because cabbies must take passengers to any destination in the city. Gunduz drove off from the stand, but about 1,000 feet away, he stopped, announced that his meter did not work and told his passengers to get out. When they refused, he stepped out, yanked their suitcase from the trunk and dumped it in the road. When the couple got out to retrieve it, he jumped back in and sped off _ violation No. 3. Inside the cab, there had been no sign of the driver's photo, name, or license number _ violation No. 4. But the man scribbled down the plate number, and Gunduz eventually was given a ticket in absentia for $400. Meanwhile, the commission was hatching a plan to rid the roads of chronically bad cabbies who by some estimates are responsible for 10 percent of rider complaints. The commission searched its files and fashioned a most-wanted list of nine cabbies. The plan was to wait for any of them to commit an infraction, and use it to seek license revocations based on the entire driving record, rather than one or several egregious incidents. All the commission needed was one new violation, no matter how small, to get a driver before a judge. The commission did not have to wait long. The rules took effect Oct. 15; three days later Gunduz allegedly threatened a dispatcher at Kennedy. When the summons popped up in the commission computer, agency lawyers went to work. A judge will hear Gunduz's case this week and tell the commissioners within a few weeks whether Gunduz should be thrown off the road. Whatever the fate of his license, Gunduz is a dinosaur; under the new rules, no New York cabbie will ever again be allowed to be so bad for so long. Thanks to an automatic point system for violators, ``We'll get them off the road before they can accumulate a record like his,'' promised Schaller.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Says He is Encouraged as Efforts to Free Captives Proceed
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with Rafsanjani and White House reaction; picks up 2nd graf pvs, Secretary of ...; edits throughout to tighten
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration said today it was encouraged by the latest comments from Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani saying a solution is near to the plight of the Western hostages in Lebanon. ``We're encouraged by the comments. ... They certainly are more hopeful than what we've heard in the more distant past,'' said White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. Iran's official Islamic Republic News Agency today quoted Rafsanjani as saying, ``My feeling is that the issue of the hostages is moving toward a solution.'' Rafsanjani repeated Iran's demands that Western nations help trace Iranian hostages missing in Lebanon and ``also reduce their mischievous acts,'' the news agency reported. Fitzwater said the remarks ``are in line with statements that we have seen in recent days and weeks that there was some interest in Iran in better relations with the West. We hope that that's the case and that it will result in release of the hostages.'' The White House spokesman added, ``But we have no direct knowledge that that is going to happen, and we have no direct knowledge of Mr. Rafsanjani's motives or purposes in making those remarks.'' Secretary of State James A. Baker III registered his hope Tuesday that the hostages would be released. ``We see what is coming across here and we are encouraged by the fact there is speculation,'' he told reporters. ``Let's see if that speculation proves out. ... We would like to see anybody that could influence it in that regard weigh in.'' While the Bush administration is not suggesting release is imminent, officials are confirming reports of a flurry of behind-the-scenes talks by officials outside the government. ``We've been talking for a long time to anyone who could have influence, Algerians, Syrians,'' a U.S. official told The Associated Press. ``We talk to the Iranians through a lot of people. We have talked to enough people that the message has gotten through to the Iranians.'' The message, said the official, who demanded anonymity, is: ``We know you want access to the West. You've said you are against terrorism. We want to see action.'' Even with all the activity, the official acknowledged, ``we don't have anything to correlate all this together and say this is moving.'' Meanwhile, a Tehran newspaper close to Rafsanjani said 1990 would be the last year for captivity for the hostages and that a resumption of ties to the United States was not a condition for their release. In an editorial, the English-language Tehran Times said Syrian President Hafez Assad would visit Tehran soon, after an expected trip by his foreign minister, Farouk Al-Sharaa. Syria is both the dominant military force in Lebanon and the closest Arab country to Iran that also maintains U.S. ties. Officially, the State Department had no explanation for the flurry of rumors. ``There are no U.S. government talks,'' spokeswoman Margaret D. Tutwiler said. ``Our policy has not changed since yesterday. There is nothing new today and I don't know why all those rumors sprung up.'' But Baker, intercepted by reporters in the diplomatic entrance as he ushered Italian Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti to his limousine, did not choose to spike the rumors. Another senior U.S. official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, suggested that a political struggle in Iran might explain some of the positive westward-leaning statements from Tehran. Iran is believed to exert considerable influence over Hezbollah, the umbrella group for radical Shiite Moslems holding some if not all of the eight American hostages. The eight Americans are among 18 Westerners believed to be held captive in Lebanon. Terry A. Anderson, who was Middle East bureau chief of The Associated Press, has been held the longest _ since March 16, 1985. In Beirut, the respected An-Nahar daily ruled out any hostage release soon, but quoted unidentified Lebanese fundamentalist sources as saying Iran was prepared to tackle the hostage issue. The sources were quoted as saying there had been no direct contacts between Iran and the United States, but both were looking for a mechanism for releasing the hostages. The report did not elaborate.

Here are excerpts from recent editorials in newspapers throughout the country. March 5 Austin (Texas) American-Statesman on crime: A dramatic report out of Washington has evidence that nearly one in four black men nationwide is in the hands of the criminal justice system at some level, a much higher rate than that of white or Hispanic males. Although the report advocates alternatives to prison, which could include needed social services, what should be emphasized is alternatives to crime. ... In far too many inner-city neighborhoods, crime is becoming the legacy that parents leave their children. In far too many communities, the only skills passed down to the new generation are survival skills, often survival at any cost. For young men trapped in poverty and living in a society where chances for success are constantly shrinking, selling drugs and robbing people is considered by some the best means of support. The inner-city unemployment rate approaches 40-50 percent in many communities. A few months back, the National Urban League advocated that the so-called peace dividend be used to overcome such social problems. While use of that illusory fund in itself was somewhat unrealistic, the problem does demand attention. For those who are willing and able to work, job training that is compatible with the job market must be offered. And the resulting jobs must be more than minimum-wage dead-end jobs. But the best and most long-term solution would be to create an environment in which fewer people are introduced to the criminal justice system.

Feb. 28 The Athens (Ohio) Messenger on asbestos: In a new and persuasive report in the magazine Science, a group of American and French researchers make it clearer than ever that when it comes to asbestos in schools and other public buildings, the cure can often be worse than the disease. They point out, among other things, that in schools where asbestos-containing material is not damaged, the danger of asbestos-related disease is several thousand times lower than the danger from aircraft accidents, high school football, drowning, home accidents or long-term smoking. They also say that while one type of asbestos is frequently associated with lung disease in miners and asbestos workers, the type most commonly used in the United States sheds a fiber of a different shape that's more easily repelled by the lungs. ... ``Prevention of tobacco smoking, the prinicipal cause of lung cancer,'' they conclude, ``is both a more promising and rational approach to eliminating lung tumors than asbestos abatement.''

March 6 The Arizona Daily Star, Tucson, Ariz., on foreign searches: The Supreme Court ... gave an unsatisfactory answer to an indirect question about what kind of country this is. The court said the Fourth Amendment doesn't protect foreigners from warrantless searches by U.S. officials on foreign soil. And you thought this was a place where justice is an all-inclusive philosophy. Apparently not. This country will split semantic hairs to justify actions that go against the grain of the Fourth Amendment's assertion that people should be secure in their persons, houses, papers and effects. ... The decision may make is easier in the future _ or in the case of evidence seized during the American invasion of Panama _ to prosecute drug smugglers and other unsavory characters. It will make a handy tool in the war on drugs; drug trafficking knows no borders and honors no high-sounding ideals about human rights. But the Constitition was not written to make law enforcement easier. It was not designed to facilitate the war on drugs. It was not meant to be read with an eye to convenience. It was designed to reflect the kind of country this is and what it believes to be the proper relationship between government and people. To narrow those sentiments ... makes America's much-touted devotion to human rights look a little less than sincere. ... (The decision) invites the kind of behavior the United States should discourage.

March 2 Duluth (Minn.) News-Tribune on foreign searches: What kind of message does the United States send to the rest of the world when we allow agents of our government to do things in other countries that wouldn't be allowed here? A bad one. What kind of example of freedom is it when we don't practice elsewhere what we preach in our own Constitution? A hypocritical one. The U.S. Supreme Court ... ruled the Fourth Amendment's provisions barring unreasonable search and seizure do not apply to property located abroad and owned by foreign suspects. That's not surprising. No one expects the U.S. Constitution to apply in other parts of the world. What Americans should expect is that its principles would be observed by representatives of our government operation abroad. The Constitution is the document, after all, that is held up as the shining example of freedom that should be emulated. The issue was brought before the high court in a dispute over the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration operations in Mexico in which houses owned by a Mexican drug smuggler were searched by U.S. agents without a warrant. The ruling is expected to strengthen the hand of U.S. law enforcement officials in the war on drugs. No one (except drug dealers) would want to impede those efforts, but we question a government policy that would order American agents to function in foreign countries by a different set of standards than those we observe at home.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: at home.
DOC.TEXT: March 4 The Reporter, Fond du Lac, Wis., on credit card frauds: The story out of Milwaukee the other day about credit fraud via card numbers retrieved from merchants' trash holds a message for users of credit at both ends of the system. ... The Milwaukee gang, and others around the country, pulled carbons from merchants' trash containers, not only for credit cards, but long-distance access codes and accounts with shipping companies as well. They used the numbers for purchases and the card owners got the bills. Consumers tend to treat credit cards casually. In truth, they represent a great deal of money. Even though laws protect consumers from heavy losses when card numbers are used by thieves, there still is a potential for some loss unless safeguards are taken. The simplest is to not leave behind the carbon copy of a credit transaction. Some carbons are automatically split but even that is not totally safe. Credit customers should be sure to retrieve their own carbons after credit purchases and store clerks should be instructed to offer to return the carbon.

March 1 The Register-Guard, Eugene, Ore., on smoking: There is good news and bad news on the smoking front. The good news is that ... smoking has been banned on all domestic airline flights of less than six hours. That means smoke-free airplanes on all flights within the contiguous 48 states and on 99.8 percent of all domestic flights. The only exceptions are flights of six hours or longer to Alaska or Hawaii. In time, given the steady march toward more smoke-free environments, it can be hoped that all domestic flights will be smokeless. There is also good news in the fact that the percentage of American adults who smoke fell to 29 percent in 1987 from 40 percent in 1965. The bad news is that smoking costs the nation $52 billion a year in health costs and lost productivity. That's $12 billion more than the cigarette companies generate in sales each year. ... That's 390,000 Americans dying from smoking-related causes each year _ more than the yearly deaths from all American homicides, suicides, auto accidents, cocaine-heroin-alcohol abuse and fires combined.

March 1 The Philadelphia Inquirer on Jimmy Carter's role in Nicaragua: For too long, and unfairly to boot, he was the Rodney Dangerfield of former presidents. But Jimmy Carter has been redeeming himself with good works, capping a stellar comeback ... with a truly magnificent performance in Nicaragua's low-flashpoint elections. The so-far peaceful Sandinista concession could still fly apart, of course, but without ... Carter's energetic, personal efforts it might not ever have gotten this far. He was always a detail man, and as he bounced down dusty Nicaraguan roads in his role as an observer, he paid close attention to the election's finer points. On each visit he nailed down another agreement _ safeguarding the return of exiled Nicaraguan Indians, condemning campaign violence, unfreezing stalled U.S. funds intended for opposition parties. But ... Carter has not been without a vision, too, of the potential for peace in what appear to be otherwise intractable conflicts. He has proved that recently as a globe-trotting mediator _ a ``diplo-evangelist,'' one reporter called him _ brokering disputes from Ethiopia to Panama. In fact, his verdict of fraud in Panama's vote last May was widely regarded as the last straw for Gen. Manuel Noriega, stripping him of any pretense of legitimacy. In Nicaragua, ... Carter apparently went one better. Beyond legitimizing the outcome, he provided some evidently much-needed counseling to a stunned Daniel Ortega (as perhaps only one defeated national leader can give to another), while urging victorious Violeta Chamorro to adopt a sober, conciliatory public demeanor. Coming only a week after former President Ronald Reagan was demonstrating his shaky grasp of Nicaraguan affairs in taped testimony on the Iran-contra imbroglio, the Carter mission was a reminder that a steady, hands-on approach isn't the worst way to deal with tough conflicts.

March 2 Las Vegas Review-Journal on the Nicaraguan election: The American left _ including those residents of West Hollywood, Berkeley, Santa Monica and Cambridge, Mass., who traipsed off to communist Nicaragua to plant coffee, teach English and propagandize for the Sandinistas _ is crestfallen. The people of Nicaragua have spoken, and American leftists hated what they said. With the demise of the Sandinistas and their Marxist-Leninist ``experiment'' in which the Nicaraguan people were used as guinea pigs, what's a poor pro-Sandinista American leftist supposed to do now? Perhaps they shall shift their resources toward helping the Cuban-backed guerrillas in El Salvador impose a communist dictatorship on that unfortunate nation. Or perhaps they can work toward preventing Fidel Castro's bankrupt dictatorship from biting the dust in Cuba. One of these days, American Marxists who idolize the likes of Ortega and Castro are going to have to face up to the fact that they are no longer ``progressive.'' Instead, they truly must be called reactionaries now, in a world in which people from East Germany to Nicaragua are sweeping out the deadwood of communism.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: of communism.
DOC.TEXT: Feb. 28 The Westerly (R.I.) Sun on the Nicaraguan election: As the world continues to spin, so do events, and both the pace and magnitude are dizzying. In Nicaragua, the results are in and President Daniel Ortega ... is out. More significantly, he agrees he's out. The winner, Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, captured in the vicinity of 55 percent of the popular vote. ... Despite Ortega's loss, the Sandinista Front remains alive and well and may not be as gracious in defeat as its leader says he is. ... It is accustomed to power which it may be reluctant to release. The voters of Nicaragua elected Mrs. Chamorro to serve them. For the moment, it is Ortega who, by standing firm in his acceptance of the election outcome, can serve those voters best.

March 5 Albuquerque (N.M.) Journal on the Exxon indictment: Exxon Corp., which failed to contain last spring's Alaska oil spill before it blackened 1,100 miles of shoreline, has been frustrated again in its efforts to contain the spill's damages. This time it was not oil, but criminal damages, that Exxon was attempting to confine. Just a week ago, it looked as if the company would succeed. In a tentative plea agreement that outraged Alaskans, the Justice Department declared itself ready to limit Exxon's criminal liabilities for the spill to $500 million. Civil suits by the federal government would be banned for four years. A storm of protest was kicked up, however, by environmentalists and others involved in the 150 lawsuits pending against Exxon _ and the proposed settlement was abandoned. Exxon was indicted on five charges. Criminal damages could reach more than $600 million, and there are no limits on civil suits. ``By pursuing criminal charges in this case,'' Attorney General Richard Thornburgh said in announcing the indictment, ``the federal government is sending a strong signal that environmental crimes will not be tolerated.'' Those are welcome words.

March 5 The North Jersey Herald and News, Passaic, N.J., on Andy Rooney: CBS _ also known as the Cynical Broadcast Company _ has put Andy Rooney back on the air after the commentator served three weeks of a three-month suspension. Rooney was booted off the airwaves for racial remarks attributed to him by a gay magazine. Rooney denied making the remarks. The suspension created a wave of protest from free-speech advocates and from viewers. During Rooney's suspension, the ratings for ``60 Minutes'' _ the program on which he rambles about whatever comes to mind _ dropped. So now, CBS is putting him back on. Not because the network became a believer in free speech. But because his return will certainly boost ratings. Did you ever wonder if Rooney would have been reinstated early if the ratings for ``60 Minutes'' had soared while he was gone? Just a rhetorical question.

March 4 Victorville (Calif.) Daily Press on Sen. Alan Cranston: Sen. Alan Cranston, the Sierra Club's creature, keeps making noises about how he's not only not going to resign, but plans on seeking yet another six-year term. Were he re-elected, which he won't be, he would have been a member of the Senate for nearly a quarter of a century. ... Cranston, of course, is but the latest example of why we'd all be better off if United States senators were limited to a maximum of two terms, and congressmen to a maximum of six _ thus limiting the membership in both chambers to a maximum of 12 years of ``public service.'' Even 12 years in some cases _ Cranston again comes to mind _ is too long. ... He sees nothing sinister, for instance, about his role in the savings and loan debacle and his acceptance of $850,000 in contributions from the Lincoln Savings & Loan pipeline. ... Worst of all _ well, perhaps not worst, but right in there _ Cranston finds the idea of returning the $850,000 not only abhorrent, but downright silly. How sad. ... (T)he Sierra Club, despite its avowed purpose of conserving all creatures great and small, won't be able to keep this one around much longer. His continued presence would only harm, and perhaps ultimately destroy, some of the club's pet projects, chief among them the passage of the desert preservation bill. Cranston has become damaged goods, and will soon be dumped. It's too bad, in a way. We'd started to develop a certain affection for the old fraud.
DOC.HEAD: End Editorial Rdp
US Aid to Soviets May be Money `Down a Rathole,' Lawmakers Say
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 7 grafs, Baker comments; picks up 2nd graf pvs, ``We shouldn't ...; edits throughout to tighten
DOC.TEXT: The United States should support reform efforts in the Soviet Union through moves such as liberalized trade, credit guarantees and continued grain sales, Secretary of State James A. Baker III said today. But Baker, testifying before a House appropriations subcommittee, said there is no need for direct financial aid to Moscow and ``they haven't asked for it.'' Rather, Baker said, the United States should share its business and economic expertise, lift restrictions on credit and credit guarantees and ``enhance'' discussions aimed at concluding a new long-term grain sales agreement. ``We ought to support the reform efforts in the Soviet Union,'' Baker said. Asked whether communism has ceased to be a threat to the United States, he added, ``We ought not to gloat too much over our success ... It is not overly-productive to stick a stick in their eye, just for the hell of it.'' The secretary's comments came a day after the No. 2 House Democratic leader, Rep. Richard Gephardt, proposed offering not only trade and investment incentives for the Soviets but also direct food aid as ways of keeping President Mikhail Gorbachev's reform campaign alive. Gephardt's proposal brought reactions from colleagues ranging from wary approval to outright condemnation. ``We shouldn't be writing out checks to Gorbachev while he's propping up Castro'' in Cuba and other communist regimes and insurgencies around the world, said Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan. Dole said it is time for the United States to aid Eastern European countries emerging from decades of Soviet domination, but that direct aid to Moscow of the sort proposed Tuesday by Gephardt, the House majority leader, would at best be premature. ``We ought to exact a fair price for those benefits,'' including a cessation of support for Cuba, Syria, Afghanistan and Angola, Dole said. It was Dole who led the way five years ago in making the Soviets eligible for U.S. subsidies to buy grain, a move that helped Kansas wheat farmers. Since then, Moscow has bought more than 730 million bushels of U.S. wheat at a subsidy value in the hundreds of millions of dollars. Sen. Bill Bradley, D-N.J., noted that the Soviets haven't requested U.S. help and that if they did, it would be wasted without economic reform. ``Unless they reform the economy, it's going down a rathole,'' Bradley said. Others on Capitol Hill said that while they thought Gephardt's proposal would spark a useful debate, the idea would fall on disapproving public ears. ``If you're going to start giving foreign aid to the hated commies ... you've got a real sales job to do in the United States,'' said Sen. Alan Simpson, R-Wyo. Gephardt said when he offered the idea in a speech that he knew there would be political risks involved and that Americans might react negatively. But he told reporters: ``When I was in Europe two months ago I was embarrassed that we are not being as strong and as courageous as they are,'' weathering dramatic price increases and other dislocations in the name of economic reform. ``Can't we do something to help?'' he asked. Specifically, the Missouri Democrat called for food aid to the Soviet Union along with most-favored-nation trading status and U.S. risk insurance to businesses that want to invest in Soviet ventures. House Speaker Thomas Foley, D-Wash., backed the Gephardt proposal and said attitudes in Congress are changing along with the rapidly moving events in the crumbling East Bloc. ``It is a dramatically different circumstance than it was only a few months ago,'' Foley said, citing multiparty elections in the Soviet Union. ``We should recognize these changes that are coming on very fast, and that we have a stake in this country in supporting those changes that are moving toward private economic activity and democracy.''

DOC.HEAD: France's Second City Defends Its Image
DOC.TEXT: Civic leaders in Marseille took out full-page ads in major newspapers Wednesday complaining that prejudice toward France's second-largest city was jeopardizing its future. The ad, addressed ``to France, to Europe and the world,'' came a week after Marseille officials protested a nationally televised documentary about the city that they believed revived stereotypes that it was crime-infested and filled with poverty-stricken Arabs and violent right-wing reactionaries. ``Sustained rumors, willful distortions, repeated lies, perverse calumnies, sometimes bordering on hatred, tarnish our image and risk obstructing our growth,'' said the ad, signed by Mayor Robert Vigouroux and 69 other leaders from the ancient Mediterranean port city. Marseille, population 900,000, has been attracting disenchanted Parisians who have been moving their businesses to the sunny southern city. There has been a recent proliferation of new theaters, major exhibitions and other cultural events that irate Marseillais believe have been overlooked. ``Marseille is not a wounded city. It's a city very much alive, proud of its past and confident of its future,'' the ad said.

DOC.HEAD: Secessionist Rebels Reject Ethiopian Reforms
DOC.TEXT: Secessionist rebels in Ethiopia's northernmost province of Eritrea are rejecting economic and political reforms proposed by President Mengistu Haile Mariam. The Eritrean People's Liberation Front said Ethiopia's economy has been shattered by the government's war against it and other rebel groups, and the only solution is to end the conflict. In a clandestine radio broadcast monitored in Nairobi on Tuesday night, the rebel group called again for a plebiscite in Eritrea to determine the province's independence or unity. It said Mengistu was ``opposing this choice, which can genuinely solve the Ethiopian problem promptly.'' Mengistu on Monday proposed scrapping the rigid, Marxist economic system Ethiopia has followed for 15 years and replacing it with a mixed economy with free markets. He also proposed that the name of the ruling Marxist-Leninist Workers' Party be changed to the Ethiopian Democratic Unity Party and that it seek a broader, more representative base. In a speech to the party's Central Committee, Mengistu invited opposition groups to participate, but he stopped short of proposing a multiparty system or diminishing the ruling party's monopoly on power. ``In short,'' the rebel radio broadcast said, ``there is nothing which can be changed except the name (of the party). What is very surprising is that Col. Mengistu even now believes that he will be able to deceive the people through such a kind of open mischief.'' The Eritrean rebels have been fighting for independence for 28 years. Last month, they opened a new offensive and claimed to capture Ethiopia's only deep-water port of Massawa on the Red Sea. The government has not acknowledged that claim, but admits the port has been closed by fighting that it says continues in and around the city. The government also faces a threat from a smaller rebel force, the Tigre People's Liberation Front. It has been fighting for 14 years to overthrow Mengistu and replace his regime with one patterned after that of Albania, the last hard-line Marxist state in Eastern Europe.

DOC.HEAD: China to Cut Enrollments of Ideologically Weak Schools
DOC.TEXT: Universities found to be weak in ideological or political studies will have their enrollments cut and may be shut down, China's leading daily said Wednesday. The official People's Daily said the State Education Commission also decided to reduce enrollments of universities with graduates in majors in less demand when job assignments are made. Most likely to be affected are programs in the liberal arts. The commission, meeting in the southern city of Changsha, worked out an enrollment plan for 620,000 new undergraduates and vocational students for the school year starting in the fall. In 1989, colleges and universities enrolled 597,000 freshmen, a sharp drop of 10.8 percent from 1988 as the government moved to purify campuses of ``bourgeois liberal'' tendencies. Many universities where students actively participated in the April-June pro-democracy movement had their freshman classes cut. Beijing University, China's most prestigious campus and a center of the democracy campaign crushed by military force on June 3-4, had its freshman enrollment slashed from 2,100 to 800, with all first-year students sent out of Beijing for a year at a military school. Ideological studies emphasizing loyalty to the Communist Party were expanded and made compulsory, and work-study programs designed to make students more in touch with the masses were increased. The Education Commission said enrollments will be cut, or suspended, in 1990 for schools weak in political and ideological work and where courses are not clearly linked to future jobs. It said experiments in allowing a few students to pay their own way would continue, but that self-financed students would be restricted to less than 3 percent of the total. The government previously promoted the idea of accepting more students who pay their own tuition as a means of raising funds for the woefully underfinanced education system. Self-paid students were accepted with lower test scores and given greater freedom to choose their own jobs after graduation. The drive to ensure the ideological loyalty of students, however, appears to have made financially independent students suspect. Normally, almost all tuition and boarding costs are subsidized by the government. The People's Daily, in a separate article, reported a Public Security Ministry crackdown on students who pay large sums to obtain admission documents from foreign schools. It said the ministry, which must approve all passports, won't recognize illegally bought admission notices or economic guarantee documents, and that anyone caught practicing fraud or illegally dealing in foreign exchange will have their passports seized. A small number of foreign organizations and individuals have cheated Chinese and made large profits by selling admissions to foreign schools, it said. The government has already moved to discourage the many students wanting to study in the West by making it more difficult to obtain transcripts and take English-language proficiency tests and requiring applicants to have up to five years' work experience before going abroad.

DOC.HEAD: Seven Killed, 500 Injured in Clash With Troops in Second Black Homeland
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 3rd pvs, `Police using...' with 2 grafs to UPDATE with state of emergency declared in homeland. Pickup 4th, `The Star...' Recasts 8th pvs, `The Bophuthatswana...' to conform.
DOC.TEXT: Police today fired on thousands of protesters who attacked and burned government buildings in the black homeland of Bophuthatswana. Seven people were reported killed and up to 500 injured. The clash began after up to 50,000 protesters in the nominally independent homeland _ the second to erupt in violence in four days _ attempted to stage a march to demand its reintegration into South Africa and the resignation of the territory's president. Police using rifles and tear gas guns opened fire after protesters set fire to public buildings and vehicles in Garankuwa in the homeland north of Johannesburg, local officials said. Homeland President Lucas Mangope tonight declared a state of emergency in several parts of Bophuthatswana, which has about 2 million residents scattered over seven separate pieces of land. The Star newspaper of Johannesburg, quoting witnesses and doctors, said at least seven people were killed by gunfire and that up to 500 people suffered various injuries. The independent South African Press Association said the sound of gunfire and fighting was heard in several areas. The new violence erupted as South African troops restored order in the Ciskei homeland on the southeastern coast after rioting in the wake of a military coup. South African officials said Ciskei was calm and no unrest was reported today in that territory. The Ciskei military government seized power Sunday in a bloodless coup and, allying itself with the anti-apartheid African National Congress, declared itself in favor of reintegration into South Africa. Anti-apartheid activists contend the homelands were established in an attempt by the white minority government to restrict blacks to the most isolated and underdeveloped parts of the country and deny them citizenship. About half of South Africa's 28 million blacks live in the 10 homelands, whose ``sovereignty'' is not recognized abroad. The Bophuthatswana army staged a coup in 1988, but South African sent in troops and blocked the overthrow of the government. In the past month, unrest has cost six lives and injured dozens of people in the homeland. Protesters today called for the resignation of Mangope, who has rejected calls to return the territory to South Africa. All government offices and many businesses, shops and schools in the area were closed and protesters hijacked buses to take them to the march, officials said. Many people stayed away from work or school to support the protests. In Ciskei, after widespread rioting and looting broke out, the new junta declared a state of emergency on and asked for assistance from South African troops. At least 27 people were killed and 550 injured in the unrest. Brig. Gen. Oupa Gqozo, who heads the junta, said ousted President Lennox Sebe would be arrested if he attempted to return. Sebe was on a trade mission in Hong Kong when the military struck. Ciskei industrialists said looting and arson that followed the coup had shattered the economy and destroyed up to 10,000 jobs. Ray Brentnall, head of the Ciskei Chamber of Industries, said rioting caused damage worth millions of dollars, but did not give any overall figure. ``People are very upset. After sweating blood to build up their businesses it's heartbreaking to see them go up in flames,'' he said. The coup in Ciskei was hailed by most people, who detested the authoritarian Seke regime. But the celebrations that followed turned to riots and looting, with mobs attacking and burning shops, factories and businesses. Dozens of foreign-owned factories were burned because they were identified with the old government, which attracted foreign investment by providing labor at wages of $50 a month or less. Gqozo told the state South African Broadcasting Corp. that his government had begun to release political prisoners held by Sebe. Gqozo also said the new government would investigate charges of corruption against the ousted president. Human rights groups said Sebe's government had detained hundreds of dissidents. South Africa's pro-apartheid Conservative Party criticized the South African government for not intervening sooner in Ciskei to prevent the chaos. ``These little stone-throwing, looting arsonist (criminals) are probably a precursor to the new South Africa,'' said Tom Langley, a member of Parliament for the Conservatives.
