Since taking office in August, President F.W. de Klerk has made a series of concessions to blacks in a bid to bring black leaders into talks on dismantling apartheid and sharing power. South Africa established the homelands in an attempt to create separate, tribal-based states for blacks while whites would retain control of national politics and the economy.

DOC.HEAD: Workers' Poductivity Improves Only Slightly in 1989
DOC.TEXT: American workers' productivity in the non-farm portion of the nation's economy last year posted its worst performance since 1982, improving only 0.9 percent, the government said Wednesday. Meanwhile, hourly labor costs _ a major inflation measure for businesses _ escalated significantly, jumping by 5.4 percent, the Labor Department said. That increase, up from 4.7 percent in 1988, was the biggest rise in hourly labor costs since the 1981-82 recession. ``That's what happens when you have a slowdown in the economy, you get squeezed from both ends. The two blades of the scissors _ subdued productivity and higher labor costs _ began to push together,'' said Robert Dederick, chief economist for the Northern Trust Co. of Chicago. ``There is no real evidence that productivity is going to escalate any time soon. We're not likely to break out of this vice in 1990,'' Dederick said. The 0.9 percent productivity gain for the year was the same improvement reported in preliminary figures provided last month, as was the 0.2 percent productivity gain reported for the October-December period. The Labor Department said the 0.9 percent increase in productivity _ defined as output per hour of work _ was less than half the 2 percent gain recorded in 1988. The fourth quarter's productivity gain of 0.2 percent was well below the 2.4 percent gain of the previous quarter. Since the end of the 1981-82 recession, productivity growth has averaged 1.8 percent a year. While a slight improvement over the 1.2 percent average growth in the 1970s, it was still far below the 3.3 percent rate of increase posted in the two decades after World War II, when American workers enjoyed healthy wage gains and a rising standard of living. Increasing productivity is considered basic to boosting living standards because it allows businesses to pay workers more as their output rises without risking higher inflation. In addition to the large increase in hourly compensation, the report showed that unit labor costs, another key determinant of future price inflation, shot up 4.5 percent for the year, compared with a 2.7 percent increase in 1988. Unit labor costs reflect changes in compensation as well as changes in productivity. Hourly labor costs for the fourth quarter increased by 6 percent, the department said. Output in the non-farm portion was up 3.3 percent in 1989 while the number of hours worked rose by 2.4 percent, giving the 0.9 percent increase in productivity. For the fourth quarter, output was unchanged and the number of hours worked fell by 0.2 percent, the first drop since 1986. In the manufacturing sector, productivity grew by 2.8 percent for both the year and the quarter. During the October-December period, productivity in the manufacturing of non-durable goods increased by 8.3 percent to outweigh the 0.4 percent productivity decline in durable goods, the report said.

DOC.HEAD: At Least 19 Killed in Attack by Sikh Extremists
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to ADD location of attack relative to New Delhi, more background on Sikh extremists. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Sikh extremists exploded a grenade and opened fire in a crowded market today in Punjab state, and at least 19 people were killed and 38 wounded, police said. Press Trust of India, citing unofficial reports, gave a higher death toll, saying about 25 people were killed. Police Chief K.P.S. Gill, who provided the police casualty report, said at least 10 gunmen were involved in the attack at 8:15 p.m. in Abohar. Another police spokesman said the attackers wore masks and arrived on foot. ``Nobody knows how they escaped,'' he said. Abohar is 125 miles southwest of Chandigarh and 200 miles northwest of New Delhi. Sikh extremists have been fighting since 1982 for an independent Sikh nation in Punjab state. It is the only state in which Sikhs form a majority. The great majority of India's 880 million people are Hindus. The Sikh campaign has killed more than 370 people in Punjab this year. Sikh militants, complaining of political discrimination by Hindus, want to establish a nation called Khalistan, or ``Land of the Pure,'' in Punjab, a rich northern farming state. The Sikh faith has roots in both Hinduism and Islam.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Afghan Coup Leader Reportedly Flees to Pakistan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to add details of Tanai's reported flight and explanation for Tanai-Hekmatyar alliance. SUBS graf 19 pvs, `The government...' to conform.
DOC.TEXT: A renegade Afghan general who tried to overthrow the government of Afghanistan fled with his family to Pakistan today, Pakistani and guerrilla sources said, giving weight to government claims the coup attempt had been crushed. Gen. Shah Nawaz Tanai, the battle-hardened defense minister linked to three coup attempts against the Soviet-backed government in Kabul, flew aboard an Afghan military helicopter with his wife, two daughters and a son to the frontier town of Peshawar, said the sources, who demanded anonymity. According to guerrilla sources, Tanai left Bagram air base at 2 p.m. Earlier reports said mutineers had seized control of Bagram, Afghanistan's largest air base. The Afghan government had denied those reports, and the situation remained unclear late today. The sources said Tanai contacted Gulbuddin Hekmatyar, a fundamentalist Afghan guerrilla leader, before fleeing and that one of Hekmatyar's commanders had been with Tanai since the coup attempt was launched Tuesday. Such an alliance would be more one of convenience and opportunism than ideology. Tanai, a Marxist hard-liner, has long advocated a harsh stance against the U.S.-backed guerrillas and opposed President Najib's attempts to make peace with them. At the same time, the radical fundamentalist Hekmatyar has become increasingly estranged from his fellow Moslem guerrilla leaders, rejecting their political leadership and executing some of their followers. Pakistan should be a safe haven for Tanai, as its government strongly opposes the Najib government. Earlier today, a foreign diplomat said mutinous soldiers, who had the support of guerrillas, had seized control of Bagram, 30 miles north of Kabul. A government spokesman denied it but acknowledged fighting at the base. Western diplomats and guerrilla leaders in Pakistan said they also had reports of fighting between rival factions in the southern city of Kandahar and the northwestern city of Herat. The diplomats and guerrilla sources, all speaking on condition of anonymity, also told of sporadic street fighting in Kabul, the capital, and said mutinous air force pilots bombed the capital for a second day but were repulsed by loyalist troops. Afghanistan's highest-ranking diplomat in Pakistan, Charge d'Affaires Qudratullah Ahmadi, denied there was widespread fighting. ``There is only fighting in Bagram. All of Afghanistan is quiet,'' he told reporters in Islamabad. Of the Bagram battle, Ahmadi said, ``This was a strong challenge. This was their (the mutineers') last chance.'' He denied the base had fallen. But a foreign diplomat said, ``All indications are that the mutineers are in control of Bagram.'' The diplomat added: ``Beyond that, the situation in Afghanistan is exceedingly unclear.'' Claims made by the Kabul government and the Moslem insurgents are often exaggerated and impossible to verify independently. In a brief speech today on official Radio Kabul, Najib again claimed victory over the mutineers and said renegade soldiers were surrendering. ``Tanai has escaped. His allies are defecting, and those who do not surrender will be punished,'' he said. Radio Kabul said troops loyal to Najib controlled Kabul, a city of 2 million, but urged residents to stay indoors. It also accused another high-ranking party member, Asadullah Sarwari, of involvement in the attempted overthrow. Sarwari was a former interior minister known as ``the butcher'' for hundreds of killings following the 1978 revolution that installed the Communist government. The whereabouts of Sarwari was not immediately known. Najib, who was installed as president by the Soviets in December 1986, said ``a number of people,'' mostly civilians, had been killed and injured since Tuesday. He gave no figures. The government appealed to supporters to take up arms in defense. Hekmatyar, leader of one of the most fundamentalist of the guerrilla groups that took up arms against the government 11 years ago, claimed six Soviet warplanes joined the government's fight. A Soviet official denied it. Hekmatyar offered his support to the mutineers within hours after planes began bombing the presidential palace Tuesday afternoon. A spokesman for Hekmatyar said Tanai's forces controlled the Kabul airport today but were under heavy rocket attack. Western diplomats and U.N. officials in Pakistan backed the report and said the Chinese, Italian and Indian embassies had been slightly damaged. Those sources also claimed troops loyal to Najib were pounding the air base in Bagram, trying to rout Tanai's supporters. Radio Kabul, monitored in Islamabad, said Najib had ordered the air force to bomb Bagram. Guerrilla sources and Pakistani officials claimed three high-ranking Afghan generals flew a transport plane to the Pakistan border and surrendered to the guerrillas. One guerrilla source said the soldiers supported neither side and did not want to stay in Afghanistan. Western diplomats and guerrilla sources said they also had reports of Afghan helicopters and warplanes landing at towns along the border. They said they did not know who was on the aircraft. Moscow withdrew its soldiers from Afghanistan in February 1989 after a nine-year military intervention in the war, but it continues to ship arms to the Afghan armed forces. Hekmatyar, speaking in Pakistan, claimed Moscow sent six warplanes from the bordering Soviet republic of Tadzhikistan to bomb Bagram. He said one Soviet warplane was shot down. A political officer at the Soviet Embassy in Islamabad denied the allegations. Tanai and Hekmatyar were linked to at least of two of the five previous reported attempts to oust Najib, who took office in 1986. Tanai belongs to a faction of the ruling party that is a bitter rival of Najib. He is said to have had many contacts with Moslem guerrillas who took up arms after the 1978 coup that brought the Communists to power. Hekmatyar told reporters Tuesday in Islamabad that he supports any attempt to oust Najib. If a coup succeeded, he said, the guerrillas would decide whether to negotiate for an Islamic government or fight Najib's successor. Hekmatyar, a 42-year-old engineer, has has been accused by other resistance groups of killing rival guerrillas and innocent civilians and broke away from the government-in-exile formed by the guerrillas after the Soviet withdrawal.

DOC.HEAD: Former Policeman Says He Made Only One Arrest, but Killed Often
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Insert 2 grafs after 6th, `Asked if...' to ADD further testimony on killings. Pickup 7th pvs, `Nofomela provoked...
DOC.TEXT: A former policeman who has admitted killing anti-apartheid activists said today that during his eight years on the force he made only one arrest, but kidnapped and killed often. Butana Nofomela testified that he was trained at a special police base in 1980 to ``kidnap, ambush and shoot'' members of the African National Congress and the Pan Africanist Congress, two black guerrilla groups fighting the white-led government. Nofomela, on death row for a killing with no political overtones, testified in Pretoria at a judicial inquiry into allegations that the national police and military operated hit squads against anti-apartheid activists. The head of the investigating commission, Supreme Court Justice Louis Harms, asked Nofomela why he kidnapped people instead of arresting them. ``In most cases, we were not instructed to arrest .... We were instructed to kidnap,'' Nofomela replied. Asked if he arrested anyone during his eight years as a policeman, Nofomela said, ``Only once. All other times I kidnapped. I kidnap and kill.'' Nofomela detailed several killings, including the 1981 stabbing death of black anti-apartheid attorney Griffiths Mxenge. Earlier this year, Nofomela pleaded guilty to the killing. ``Money benefits were promised to me'' for the killings, Nofomela said. ``Bonuses were rated on how important the person was who was to be eliminated or kidnapped.'' Nofomela provoked a storm of controversy in October when he confessed, the night before he was scheduled to hang, that he had participated in police death squads. Nofomela's execution has been postponed indefinitely while the death squad allegations are being investigated. Two other former policemen, a black man and a white captain, subsequently acknowledged participating in the alleged hit squads along with Nofomela, who is black. All three have said they acted on orders from their superiors. Police have denied authorizing murders. However, police have said they suspect a covert military unit, the Civil Cooperation Bureau, was involved in the killing of at least two anti-apartheid figures. Activists say they believe the security forces were involved in the unsolved killings of at least 60 government opponents in the past decade. Maj. Gen. Joep Joubert testified Tuesday that the military approved plans in 1985 for undercover agents to go abroad and disrupt ANC operations. Several prominent ANC officials outside South Africa have been assassinated or had attempts on their lives in recent years, and the cases have never been solved. The ANC and the smaller PAC were legalized last month by President F.W. de Klerk. Thousands of exiles belonging to the groups are expected to begin returning to South Africa shortly. The military has said the secret bureau had 139 members, an annual budget of $11 million and was in engaged in highly sensitive intelligence gathering operations in South Africa and abroad. Yet top military and government officials have claimed they had no knowledge of the bureau until recently. No military officers have been charged in connection with the activities of the bureau, but two men have been detained for questioning, and police are searching for several former police officers in connection with two assassinations.

DOC.HEAD: Kentucky Becomes 41st State to Adopt King Holiday
DOC.TEXT: Kentucky became the 41st state to adopt a Martin Luther King Jr. holiday when Gov. Wallace Wilkinson signed legislation before a jubilant crowd in the Capitol rotunda. The bill's chief sponsor, freshman Rep. Leonard Gray of Louisville, called Monday's signing ``the end of a long march.'' Wilkinson signed the bill at the base of a statue of Abraham Lincoln during a ceremony punctuated by prayers, applause and, for many of the assembled veterans of the civil rights movement, tears of joy. Borrowing some rhetoric from the slain civil rights leader, co-sponsor Rep. Porter Hatcher held a page of the legislation aloft and said, ``Signed at last; signed at last. Thank God almighty, it's signed at last.'' The bill designates the third Monday in January an official state holiday and grants state employees a day off with pay to commemorate King's birthday.

DOC.HEAD: Italian Prime Minister Wants U.S. to Keep Troops in Europe
DOC.TEXT: Italian Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti on Wednesday encouraged the United States to remain bound to Europe by keeping troops there as a guarantee of stability. Andreotti, addressing a joint session of Congress, also said a reunited Germany must be anchored in the 16-nation NATO alliance of Western nations and bound by internationally recognized border agreements. The Italian leader discussed the future of a united Germany and European concerns about the merger at White House talks Tuesday with President Bush. Andreotti, one of Italy's most enduring politicians who is serving as prime minister for the sixth time, was greeted with a prolonged standing ovation by members of the House, Senate and diplomatic corps. The theme of his speech was the changing face of Europe _ one with reduced superpower arsenals, democratic governments throughout and an improved quality of life for its inhabitants. ``The real issue today is how can we encourage change in the East without provoking repercussions that would stop its impetus,'' Andreotti said. ``A New Deal with the East should first of all include a drastic reduction of arms, especially conventional weapons which threaten us Europeans in terms of proximity and continuity,'' he said. The United States, Soviet Union and their allies are negotiating sharp reductions in conventional weapons arsenals. A treaty may be ready for signing by year's end. ``We want to continue building a Europe that is open to the world, not a fortress Europe as some mistakenly fear,'' he said. Italy assumes the chairmanship of the European Economic Community in July and Andreotti has been assuring the United States that the process of unifying the markets of the 12 member nations is not meant to exclude the United States. The new Europe will be ``ever ready to collaborate in a spirit of true partnership with the United States, whose military presence in Europe must remain ... as a guarantee of stability and balance,'' Andreotti said. ``Moreover, we want this new Europe that is being built to develop new and increasingly close and effective forms of linkage with this essential partner nation.'' Italy and other West European countries are concerned the United States might reduce its commitment to Europe in response to the declining danger from the Soviet Union and the rising influence a united Germany is expected to wield. A reunited Germany, which is expected to emerge by the end of the year, ``has an essential anchorage in NATO and a secure guarantee in the larger assembly'' of the 35 signatories of the Helsinki agreements, he said. The 1975 agreements ratified the European borders set after World War II. Italy and other European countries are worried that a united Germany might lay claim to lands taken away from the vanquished Germany of Adolf Hitler. Poland has been especially worried because one-third of its territory used to be German. Andreotti has also voiced concerns that Italy and other NATO allies might be overlooked in the ``two-plus-four'' approach to German unification. The ``two-plus-four'' are the two Germanys and the four World War II victors _ the United States, Great Britain, France and the Soviet Union. Andreotti received assurances from his U.S. hosts that Italy would not be ignored in the discussions expected to begin later this month.

DOC.HEAD: Congresswoman Says Pentagon Still Pays Too Much for Many Items
DOC.TEXT: The Air Force spent $81,397 on a C-5A cargo plane pilot seat when a similar model was available for about $16,000, a lawmaker said Wednesday in accusing the Pentagon of continuing to buy overpriced spare parts. Rep. Barbara Boxer, D-Calif., also criticized the Defense Department's procurement chief, John Betti, for his order to civilian auditors discouraging the withholding of program funds if they suspected waste, fraud, abuse or mismanagement by a contractor. Under the Jan. 28 directive, Betti said he or his deputy would have the authority to withhold payments to contractors to ensure that the step is taken only when absolutely necessary. ``It in no way indicates any reduction in my desire for disciplined and responsive management of our acquisition programs,'' Betti said in the order. ``Rather, it signals my belief that self-disciplined and responsible program managers are a more responsive and cost-effective control system than are a series of hierarchical reviews.'' But Boxer told reporters at a Capitol Hill news conference that Betti took away the ``one main tool'' that had been given to civilian auditors. ``I think he is bowing to the demands of the services as opposed to the civilian side,'' she said. The congresswoman, in a letter released Wednesday, urged Betti to rescind his order, saying his decision ``sends the wrong signal to defense contractors and those in the services responsible for programs'' Boxer, who in the mid-1980s disclosed the Pentagon paid $7,400 for a coffee brewer and $539 for arm rests, used the news conference to show that the public and congressional outcry has forced the department to buy similiar items at a cheaper price. The Air Force recently spent $283 on a commercial coffee maker for its C-5 aircraft and is repairing damaged arm rests for a mere $25. However, the Pentagon is ``still blowing taxpayers' money on spare parts,'' Boxer said. ``We have found other parts outside the glare of publicity where the Air Force had returned to its old ways of accepting overcharges on spare parts,'' she said. But Defense Department spokesman Glenn Flood said that ``across the board, the Pentagon was making progress in keeping prices down.'' In 1988, the Air Force bought one Weber-manufactured pilot seat for $81,397 for the C-5A aircraft and eight more seats at $29,476 each. But for the C-5B aircraft, the Air Force bought $16,047 seats made by IPECO. ``The Air Force says the Weber and IPECO seats are interchangeable,'' Boxer said. In addition, the Air Force purchased 4,000 eight-day clocks at a cost of $596 each. But a supplier contacted by the Project for Government Procurement said it could supply clocks meeting the same specifications for $270 each, Boxer said.

DOC.HEAD: Sudan Faces Crisis as Refugee Influx Climbs, Foreign Aid Falls
DOC.TEXT: Sudan's top relief official said his nation may be forced to reconsider its liberal relief policies if foreign aid does not increase to match a growing influx of Ethiopian refugees. Refugee Commissioner Abdul-Rahman Sir el-Khatem also appealed for worldwide pressure to help persuade Ethiopia to allow delivery of relief supplies inside its borders to help slow the flood of refugees crossing the frontier. Sir el-Khatem said 11,800 Ethiopian refugees fled to eastern Sudan in the last week of February, bringing to 35,800 the number of new arrivals in that month. Foreign officials said they expect tens of thousands of new refugees in the coming weeks and Sir el-Khatem's office already counts 1.2 million refugees in Sudan, mostly Ethiopians. The U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees disputed the figures and said no more than 800,000 refugees were in Sudan. It was unclear what action Sudan could take to halt the refugees who cross the huge, mostly unmarked and unguarded border to escape war and famine. ``Assistance from the international community to refugees in Sudan is decreasing, while the influx across Sudan's eastern border is increasing,'' Sir el-Khatem was quoted as saying by the government newspaper Al-Sudan Al-Hadith. He said budget cuts at the U.N. relief organization led to a 50 percent reduction in spending at its Khartoum office which ``might force us to change our permanent policy towards refugees.'' In eastern Sudan Sir el-Khatem's office operates six U.N.-financed reception camps and 16 settlements for refugees. Many still house people who fled the 1984-85 famine in Ethiopia that is believed to have killed a million people. Sir el-Khatem did not spell out what steps Sudan is likely to take if more refugee aid does not arrive. He also said Sudan will allow relief agencies to transport food through Sudanese territory and across the frontier into Ethiopia.

DOC.HEAD: Rafsanjani Says Hostage Issue Nearing End, But Radical Group Denies It
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to ADD further details from communique. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Iran's president today said the problem of the Western hostages held in Lebanon is nearing a solution, but a group holding two Americans said it has no intention of freeing the captives. The Revolutionary Justice Organization also accused the United States of planning a military operation to free the hostages and said, ``We warn America away from what it calls the hard option because we are on alert. We are today stronger and better prepared and more determined to hit out at strategic interests and deal painful blows.'' President Hashemi Rafsanjani of Iran said his country was not directly linked to the hostage issue but had pledged to use Iran's influence to seek their freedom. ``My feeling is that the issue of the hostages is moving toward a solution,'' Iran's official Islamic Republic News Agency quoted him as saying. He repeated Iran's demands that Western nations help trace Iranian hostages missing in Lebanon and ``also reduce their mischievous acts,'' IRNA said. Eighteen Westerners, including eight Americans, are missing in Lebanon, most believed held by Shiite Moslem groups loyal to Tehran. The longest held is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, who was abducted March 16, 1985. Rafsanjani's statements at a news conference followed a series of editorials in English-language newspapers in Tehran saying the hostages should be freed because they were being used as anti-Islamic propoganda. Syrian and other officials also have expressed optimism that the hostages may be freed. In a hand-written statement issued today, Revolutionary Justice said, ``We tenaciously cling to keeping America's nose in the mud under our feet. There is no intention to release hostages.'' The statement was accompanied by a black-and-white instant photograph of American hostage Joseph Cicippio, of Valley Forge, Penn. It was delivered to the Beirut newspaper An-Nahar and a Western news agency. Cicippio, acting comptroller of the American University of Beirut, was kidnapped Sept. 12, 1986. Revolutionary Justice also claims to hold Edward Austin Tracy, an American author from Vermont. The date of his seizure is not known, but the group made the claim of responsibility Oct. 21, 1986. ``By monitoring American moves here and there and through planting elements in regional American stations, and after trailing some spies, we have acquired accurate information that an American military operation is imminent against areas where the Americans believe hostages are held,'' the Arabic statement said. ``We call upon all to watch out against this threat and beware and be on the alert against what America is hatching,'' the communique added. In apparent reference to recent comments by Lebanon's most influential Shiite Moslem cleric, the statement said, ``the Revolutionary Justice Organization holds spies, and humanitarianism requires just punishment, not a reward.'' It did not elaborate. The cleric, Sheik Mohammed Hussein Fadlallah, said in a sermon Feb. 23 that ``We have to think of finding a realistic and humanitarian means to free the foreign hostages.'' Fadlallah is spiritual guide of the pro-Iranian Hezbollah, or Party of God, believed to be the umbrella for factions holding the captives. Revolutionary Justice said it issued its communique after ``a comprehensive study of audio and printed statements and reactions about the hostages question and some issues and developments in the region.'' On Tuesday, the Tehran Times said 1990 would be the last year for captivity for the hostages and that a resumption of ties to the United States was not a condition for their release. Several newspapers also have said the United States and Iran were negotiating over the fate of the hostages, which Washington has denied. Rafsanjani denied that any such talks had occurred, according to IRNA, monitored in Nicosia. The president said the only official talks between the two nations are those carried out under the U.S.-Iran claims tribunal in the Netherlands, under the auspices of the International Court of Justice. The tribunal is sorting out billions of dollars in claims from contracts broken following the 1979 Islamic revolution. But he said the U.S. officials ``themselves have established contacts with regional governments.'' That was an apparent reference to U.S. contacts with Syria, which as the main power broker in Lebanon has facilitated past hostage releases. Diplomatic sources in the Syrian capital, Damascus, have said the United States used Syria as an intermediary with Tehran. Rafsanjani's brother Mahmoud Hashemi, a high-ranking foreign ministry official, was in Damascus this week for meetings with the Syrian foreign minister, Farouk Al-Sharaa. A Syrian source said the talks were to coordinate policy on getting the hostages released and that Hashemi had arrived from Beirut, where he also discussed the hostage issue with senior Shiite Moslem clergy. Rafsanjani echoed the recent Tehran Times editorials in saying the hostages should be released because their captivity was being used to smear the reputation of the Islamic faith and the Lebanese. He also referred to recent statements by Fadlallah and the Tehran editorials as indicating there was new hope for the captives. Rafsanjani has indicated the desire to separate Iran from the hostage issue as he seeks Western technology and financing to rebuild Iran's troubled economy. But the factions holding the hostages are said more loyal to radicals in the Tehran government who oppose Rafsanjani, viewing confrontation with the West as the wellspring of the Islamic revolution.

DOC.HEAD: Four Ceausescu Bodyguards Acquitted
DOC.TEXT: Four bodyguards of Nicolae Ceausescu were acquitted Wednesday of charges they helped the deposed dictator try to flee during the December revolution, state television said. Maj. Aurel David, Maj. Florian Rat, Capt. Marian Rusu and Paulica Tanase were accused of securing a helicopter Dec. 22 which took Ceausescu and his wife, Elena, from Communist Party headquarters to Snagov, 20 miles north of Bucharest, and then arranging a move to Ploiesti, 35 miles north of the capital. No rank was given for Tanase. All four were members of Ceausescu's Securitate secret police, which was officially disbanded after the revolution. The verdict was reported on television without any details. Acquittals have been rare in the trials of former Securitate agents accused of crimes under Ceausescu's 24-year tenure or during the revolution that pitted secret police remnants against the army and civilian freedom fighters. In Timisoara, where the revolution began, 21 Securitate officers are on trial on charges arising from the mass shootings of unarmed demonstrators.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Pool Completed in Poindexter Case
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 8 grafs North to be government's leadoff witness; picks up 7th graf, One of...
DOC.TEXT: Oliver North will be the government's leadoff witness at John Poindexter's Iran-Contra trial and Poindexter's lawyers are trying to limit the former White House aide's testimony, the judge in the case disclosed today. Ten additional people were sent into a pool of prospective jurors, making a total of 45, and the jury for the trial was to be chosen this afternoon. It will consist of 12 people, plus six alternates. U.S. District Court Judge Harold Greene said he understood that North ``will be the first government witness'' in Poindexter's trial. Lawyers in the case later confirmed that North would be the first witness. Greene made the comment as he announced that Poindexter's lawyers are trying to limit North's potentially damaging testimony. North met frequently with Poindexter on the Iran arms sale initiative, resupply of the Contras and the diversion of funds to the rebel force. Greene said he would consider a motion filed under seal by Poindexter that seeks to limit some aspects of North's testimony, based on Fifth Amendment rights against self-incrimination. Greene denied another motion by Poindexter that would have struck all or part of North's upcoming testimony. The government alleged at North's trial last year that he had given unreliable testimony when he took the witness stand in his own defense, Richard Beckler, a lawyer for Poindexter, said in explaining the basis for the motion. Opening statements are to be Thursday morning and North could be on the stand for several days. One of those picked for the pool Tuesday was a retired Defense Department employee who may have confused the Watergate scandal with the Iran-Contra affair. Asked what last year's trial of North focused on, the Defense Department retiree, a woman who worked at the Army Materiel Command in Alexandria, Va., said it was ``about the tapes. He had so many tapes he did erase, Oliver North and secretary.'' In the Watergate scandal, then-President Nixon's secretary Rose Mary Woods said she might have accidentally erased a portion of one taped conversation. The tape in question was of a conversation between Nixon and his chief of staff, H.R. Haldeman, about how to handle the spreading FBI investigation of the Watergate scandal. Also sent into the jury pool was a distribution clerk at Dulles International Airport outside Washington, who said he had heard that North ``was going to court,'' but didn't know the outcome of last year's trial in which Poindexter's one-time subordinate was convicted of three felonies. Asked whether he had heard of Poindexter, the man said that if he had, ``I ... didn't pay any attention.'' One juror was excused for failing to note on a questionnaire that she had sat on a jury previously, a fact that came out during questioning. Greene noted there had been ``a big flap'' at North's trial last year over a juror who had answered the questionnaire incorrectly. The juror in the North case, Tara King, failed to note the fact that a number of relatives had been involved in criminal cases, including one who served time in prison. The issue is part of North's appeal, now before the U.S. Court of Appeals. A truck driver who said ``I read the paper a lot'' was disqualified for jury duty after telling Greene that Poindexter ``might be guilty'' and saying of Reagan: ``I know he was in on it, but I don't know if he did anything wrong.'' Poindexter is under indictment on charges of conspiracy, two counts of obstructing Congress and two counts of making false statements. The charges relate to allegations that Poindexter covered up North's secret resupply network to the Contra rebels in Nicaragua and to allegations that Poindexter lied concerning a November 1985 shipment of Hawk antiaircraft missiles to Iran.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Cabinet Wields Power, Influence
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's Cabinet has evolved into the most powerful in a quarter century even though it meets infrequently, insiders and analysts suggest. When it does convene, two things distinquish it from Cabinet sessions under former President Reagan: The vice president speaks out and there's no mistaking who's the secretary of Housing and Urban Development. The full Bush Cabinet gets together only about once a month, but in some months it hasn't met at all. The meetings seldom last more than an hour and usually are held in response to some event or trip. For instance, Bush called his Cabinet together Monday to report on his California summit with Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu and to discuss the recent Nicaraguan election. But Bush's 14-member Cabinet may wield more power and have more influence with the president than any since President Eisenhower's in the 1950s. At the same time, Bush's White House staff is one of the least powerful of recent presidencies, analysts suggest and some top Bush aides agree. While Eisenhower met with his Cabinet almost once a week, Bush met with his full Cabinet only 11 times last year and three times so far this year. One reason he gathers his Cabinet so infrequently is that he knows the members so well. Some of them _ Treasury Secretary James A. Baker III, Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher and Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady _ are among his oldest friends. ``He doesn't use the full Cabinet as a decision-making body,'' said David Q. Bates, who as Cabinet secretary schedules sessions, prepares the agenda and keeps the president informed of agency developments. Bush constantly telephones Cabinet secretaries. And, Bates said, he often meets individually with them _ such as a lunch he had Wednesday with Mosbacher _ reducing the need for more frequent full-Cabinet meetings. The secretaries can call matters to the president's attention by slipping a note into Bates' weekly report to Bush on what each Cabinet agency is doing. Roger Porter, Bush's domestic policy adviser who also worked in the Reagan White House, said that Reagan _ who once failed to recognize his own reticient housing secretary, Samuel Pierce, at a gathering of mayors _ also held infrequent Cabinet meetings, particularly near the end of his term. ``The frequency of Cabinet meetings tends to deteriorate over time,'' Porter said. There's little chance Bush would fail to recognize his housing secretary, Jack Kemp. According to White House aides, Kemp is one of the most forceful and frequent speakers at Cabinet sessions, often dominating the conversations. In fact, several White House aides suggested privately that the irrepressible Kemp's outspokenness may be one reason Bush doesn't convene the full Cabinet more often. Kemp does not fit into the old-friend category. Does Kemp talk too much at Cabinet meetings? ``Not at all,'' said Kemp spokesman Robert Nipp. ``But he does talk.'' Another major difference between the Bush and Reagan Cabinets, White House aides say: Vice President Dan Quayle frequently speaks up. During Reagan Cabinet meetings, Vice President Bush seldom did. Bush has retained a Cabinet structure set up in the Reagan presidency in which two sub-Cabinet groups _ the Domestic Policy Council and the Economic Policy Council _ meet frequently on major policy issues. The economic group includes the secretaries of treasury, commerce, agriculture, labor, transportation, state and the trade representative. The domestic group includes the attorney general and secretaries of interior, energy, health and human services, education, veterans affairs and housing and urban development. Budget Director Richard Darman sits on both councils. Kemp doesn't, but usually shows up at both anyway. Those councils, augmented by the National Security Council, are where the bulk of the administration's top policy decisions are forged _ not within the White House staff. Bush frequently drops in on the council sessions. With the exception of chief of staff John Sununu and Darman, few on the White House staff wield much real power, senior White House officials say privately. Stuart Eizenstat, a Washington lawyer who was President Carter's domestic policy adviser, said Bush's Cabinet ``is stronger relative to the White House staff than any recent Cabinet.'' Bush ``broke the mold'' by putting his closest friends in the Cabinet instead of on the White House staff, Eizenstat said. Reagan brought a whole retinue of California cronies to the White House and Carter gave many of his Georgia friends top White House positions. By contrast, few on Bush's White House staff have known or worked with him for more than several years. Eizenstat said Carter's Cabinet met about once a week at the start and then about once every two weeks. But he said Carter didn't rely much on the sessions for making decisions. ``Cabinet meetings are not terribly illuminating sessions. You don't want to have your secretary of agriculture voting on whether to have an MX or Midgetman missile system,'' Eizenstat said.

DOC.HEAD: Snack Survey: One of Three Americans Feels Guilty About the Munchies
DOC.TEXT: One in three people suffer pangs of guilt along with pangs of hunger for a snack, and 11 percent said they feel guiltier quenching their craving for the munchies than cheating on their taxes, a survey has found. The survey, released Wednesday, was conducted for Continental Baking Co., the maker of Twinkies, Hostess Cupcakes and Ho Hos. A random sample of 1,000 people over age 18 were contacted by telephone during the weekend of Feb. 2 and asked about their snacking habits and what bothered people more than snacking. Other findings included: 10 percent said they feel more guilt snacking than lying to their spouse about how much money they spend, and 18 percent said they would feel less guilt lying about their weight than grabbing a snack. Dr. Felix Larocca, whose medical practice specializes in dieting and eating disorders, said the results add more evidence to how strong the temptation to eat sweets and desserts is in modern society. ``It's 10 a.m. in the morning and you may be at work and you may be hungry. Why not have an apple? Instead you'll probably eat a luscious pastry and while you do it talk about how you need to lose a few pounds,'' said Larocca. ``Snacks are the forbidden fruit,'' said Larocca, who has operated a St. Louis-based program for mood and eating disorders since 1983. But a spokesman for the Snack Food Association said it doesn't seem fair to single out snack foods for their association with guilt. ``There's no reason that people should feel guilty about snacking,'' said Al Rickard, spokesman for the Alexandria, Va.-based group. ``We've always maintained that snacks should be eaten as part of an appropriate diet.'' Despite the guilt, what will the average person give up to savor a snack? According to the survey, 40 percent would rather snack than shop; 18 percent would rather snack than travel; 29 percent would rather snack than go to the movies; and 10 percent would rather snack than make love. The survey was conducted by Bruskin Associates and had a margin of error of 3 percentage points.

DOC.HEAD: Chiang Kai-Shek's Sole Surviving Son Thrust Into Limelight
DOC.TEXT: Chiang Wego, the sole surviving son of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, has emerged as a wild card in the upcoming presidential election as his father's aging cronies dream of re-establishing the family dynasty. ``Gen. Chiang is still highly respected by our mainland compatriots,'' said Teng Chieh, a prominent member of the electoral college that will chose a new president March 21. The attention focusing on Chiang Wego, a 73-year-old retired general, has come quickly after a career spent in the shadow of his father and elder brother, Chiang Ching-kuo, who together led the Nationalist Chinese government for six decades, first in China and then in Taiwan. His political star did not rise measurably when his brother died in 1988 and was succeeded by his handpicked vice president, Lee Teng-hui. But President Lee is shakily approaching his first major political test in which he must win the approval of the 752-seat National Assembly, or electoral college, to secure a six-year term. Although Lee already has received the ruling Nationalist Party endorsement, the assembly is dominated by aging politicians who escaped to Taiwan with Chiang Kai-shek in 1949 after losing a civil war to the Communists. They still dream of returning victoriously to the Chinese mainland. The old guard assemblyman have not faced election since arriving in Taiwan and have been frozen in office to support the Nationalist claim to still be the legitimate government of all China. While Chiang Wego shares their dream of returning to the mainland, Lee is a pragmatic Taiwan-born politician more concerned with ruling this island of 20 million people. About 200 assemblymen have defied Lee's choice of a top aide as running mate by openly supporting Chiang for vice president. Many of them actually want Chiang to be president but realize that a Taiwanese must fill the top slot for political reasons. Chiang has responded by saying he would not actively seek the presidency or vice presidency, but he added that ``there is nothing I can do to control the assemblymen.'' He has refused to rule out accepting either position. He also has accused media of misinterpreting remarks made in 1985 by his brother, who said: ``If someone asks me whether anyone in my family would run for the next presidential term, my reply is, `It can't be and it won't be.''' The statement was widely viewed as referring to all relatives, but Chiang Wego has claimed his brother was only referring to his sons. Lee is taking the challenge seriously and has scrambled to meet with assemblymen to shore up support. The power struggle has stirred up ``the most serious political crisis in 40 years,'' said Lu Ya-li, history professor at National Taiwan University. Among Chiang's critics is the liberal weekly magazine Journalist, which said in an editorial that his activities exposed ``his backward thoughts, muddled head, unrestrained mind, and weak will.'' Other critics say Chiang still lives in the conservative past and has ignored calls for greater democracy. Most Taiwanese view the aging mainland Chinese assemblyman as an obstacle to democratic change and want them to be replaced by Taiwan-elected politicians. But Chiang has praised their refusal to step down. As local industrialists press for direct trade with China, Chiang claims Chinese Communists are trying to destabilize Taiwan through growing trade. Chiang Wego was born in Shanghai on Oct. 6, 1916. Some reports claim that he was the adopted son of Chiang Kai-shek and that his real father was Tai Chi-tao, the generalissimo's close friend. ``I dont't really know which is my father, but I am happy to be the son of either of them,'' he once said. Chiang likes to socialize, swap jokes, and sing popular songs at public gatherings. He has practiced Chinese boxing since he was a child and learned to fly helicopter at age 70. Educated in prestigious military academies in Germany and the United States, Chiang joined the Nationalist Chinese Army as lieutenant at 25. He was assigned to several administrative positions and served as lieutenant general for 14 years until being promoted to full general in 1985, one year before retiring. He is secretary general of the National Security Council, widely viewed as a symbolic seat with little power. Many believe Chiang Kai-shek prevented his son's career from advancing quicker to avoid criticism of nepotism. Others believe that Chiang Wego just was not qualified to tackle key postings. ``He is a nice man to make friends with, but not the type of person who fits the post of vice presidency,'' said Chang Chung-tung, a history professor at National Taiwan University. Noting the trend toward democratic reform since martial law was lifted in 1987 after 38 years, Chang believes the days of the Chiang dynasty are over and that the Taiwanese people would never accept another family member to rule.

DOC.HEAD: Investigators Look for Cause of Bank Blast
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 14 grafs to UDPATE with arrival of some investigators, bank executive saying no threats received, bank opening makeshift facility and to CORRECT to Zavala sted Zavela. Picks up 12th graf pvs, ``I felt....'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos CRBX1,2
DOC.TEXT: Authorities today were investigating whether a bomb or a methane gas buildup caused an explosion that flattened a two-story bank building ``like an accordion,'' killing three people and injuring 14. A 12-member team from the federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms began assembling this morning in this Rocky Mountain ski resort to search for clues in the rubble of Crested Butte State Bank. The building _ except the vault _ was leveled by the blast. Firefighters and volunteers dug by hand through the rubble to pull out survivors. Heavy snow hampered rescue efforts and delayed the arrival of ambulances. Police Chief Hank Smith said two restaurants had received bomb threats in the past week, and one of them was evacuated. ``I'm not ruling out a bomb, and I'm not ruling out an explosion from methane buildup,'' he said. ``We're just now beginning the investigation.'' Bank executive vice president Cliff Goss said the bank hadn't received any bomb threats. ``This came completely out of the blue,'' he said. ``We care about our co-workers and we're not going to work in that situation. People lost their children and their mothers, and I personally lost three good friends.'' Dick Schussler, an FBI spokesman in Denver, said sabotage was a possibility, but he didn't know of a motive. ``It's not like this is a bank that's financing South Africa,'' he said. The explosion occurred at 9:15 a.m., shortly after the bank opened. Goss opened a temporary bank in a nearby building today and said it would be able to handle most transactions. A retired bank employee and several people from a Colorado Springs data processing center helped out. Three bank employees were in listed serious condition today at a Grand Junction hospital, including bank President Thom Cox. ``I saw the second-floor windows blown out and the roof going up in the air,'' said a businessman across the street who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``Then the side walls started to blow out, and the front seemed to come out, breaking in half, with the top coming out and the bottom folding like an accordion.'' Bank employee Lucy Zavala was working in her second-floor office when she ``thought someone had fallen out of their chair. Then I was just falling. I ended up in a fetal position, and could see some light, and then almost immediately heard voices. Somebody dragged me out, and I thought it was a dream.'' ``I felt the floor drop beneath me,'' said teller Joe Sabino, who was treated for scratches and burns on his hands. ``Fortunately, nothing came into contact with me. It (the rubble) built a little cave around me.'' Killed were bank employees Donna Smith, 33, Jade Woelk and Monica Henning, all of Crested Butte. Authorities hopep to learn more about the blast from autopsies on the victims, said Gunnison County Coroner C.J. Miller. Dusty Demerson ran over from his photography shop about a block from the bank to help in the rescue. ``The president of the bank ... was hanging out the back of the bank by his legs and we got him down,'' he said. Bob Gillen, spokesman the Crested Butte ski area, said the resort handled rescue operations as if it were an avalanche. ``We have some heavy equipment there, but most of the rescuers are using their hands,'' he said. Crested Butte, population about 1,000, is 9,000 feet high in the western Colorado mountains.

DOC.HEAD: Arrington Says Civil Rights Bill Would Shorten Job Bias Litigation
DOC.TEXT: Birmingham, Ala., Mayor Richard Arrington urged senators Wednesday to approve a new civil rights bill and help his city end 16 years of costly litigation over its hiring and promotion practices. Arrington told the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee the ``terrible financial burden on the city'' from the court battle will continue indefinitely unless Congress overturns a Supreme Court decision last year on affirmative action. The Supreme Court ruled white Birmingham firefighters may challenge a court-approved 1981 agreement between the city, the Justice Department and black workers giving preferential treatment to minorities and women in city jobs. The proposed Civil Rights Act of 1990 would overturn that ruling by permitting workers to challenge employment practices from court orders or consent decress only if they did not know about or were denied a chance to challenge the orders beforehand. ``We are not here seeking a license to engage in unlawful reverse discrimination,'' Arrington testified. ``We are not here seeking to gag the objections, legitimate or otherwise, of white employees to affirmative action.'' But Raymond P. Fitzpatrick Jr., attorney for the white firefighters, told the committee Congress should let the ruling stand, saying the court had reaffirmed ``the fundamental principle... that all Americans are entitled to a day in court when they believed they have been wronged.'' Fitzpatrick hinted any legislation to reverse the court ruling would lead to another prolonged legal battle over its constitutionality. He said the 1981 agreement, approved by a federal judge, has never been reviewed by an appeals court. ``The city has spent nine years trying to block a court from reviewing its decree,'' he said. Arrington said the new bill would guarantee everyone in hiring bias disputes ``the right to a day in court'' but would still allow cities and other employers the right to ``finality in litigation.''

DOC.HEAD: City Torn by Rumors Raised in Wake of Credit Union Failure
Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: Money, sex and prominent names have become the talk of the town in this staid Midwestern city since a credit union failure spawned federal and state investigations and rumors of child prostitution. James Martin Davis, an attorney who has been involved in the case, recently warned that Omaha could be ``the first city in the history of the world to gossip itself to death.'' No charges have been filed in connection with the sexual abuse and child prostitution allegations that began to circulate just weeks after the Franklin Community Federal Credit Union closed on Nov. 4, 1988. But the credit union is missing $39 million and a former manager is to stand trial. Since then, a newspaper columnist facing unrelated child sex assault charges has resigned. A former publisher and civic leader has spoken out. Grand juries are at work. The saga began when federal regulators, citing unsound fiscal practices, closed the credit union, which was organized to help north Omaha's poor. Soon, stories began surfacing of alleged sexual abuse at parties thrown by credit union officials. The rumors received new life earlier this year when a former legislator wrote a memo naming five prominent people who he said were the focus of allegations that could be heard in bars or barber shops. The memo was eventually leaked to thousands of people. Last weekend, retired Omaha World-Herald Publisher Harold Andersen, who served on an advisory board for the credit union, had enough. He issued a statement acknowledging his name had been raised in rumors and saying there was ``not a shred of truth'' to the allegations. His statement came one day after an Omaha television station reported that Andersen and four other people were named in a federal grand jury subpoena seeking information from an investigator for a legislative committee probing Franklin. In December 1988, the Legislature's Executive Board received information in a closed hearing from the state Foster Care Review Board on allegations of abuse of foster children at parties thrown by Franklin officials. A New York Times story based on information submitted to the Executive Board described the alleged sexual incidents as ``reminiscent of slave auctions.'' State Sen. Ernie Chambers, the Executive Board vice chairman, said that was ``a genteel way of characterizing it.'' But last year, Omaha police and the FBI said their investigations indicated there was no substance to the allegations. The state attorney general and the State Patrol agreed. The Legislature's Franklin committee questioned whether the allegations were adequately investigated. In December, committee chairman Loran Schmit said the panel had 21 hours of videotaped statements from three ``victim-witnesses'' who said they were sexually abused. Now, a state grand jury is investigating allegations of child sexual abuse and child prostitution. A federal grand jury already has investigated alleged financial wrongdoing that led to Franklin's failure and another is ready to investigate the child sexual abuse allegations. Former state Sen. John DeCamp, now a lobbyist, said his memo listing the five names forced state Attorney General Robert Spire to seek a state grand jury investigation. The news media did not report the names in DeCamp's memo, but a potential legislative candidate obtained a copy and mailed the contents to 10,000 Omaha households. After World-Herald columnist Peter Citron was arrested Feb. 23 on two counts of child sexual abuse unrelated to Franklin, his attorney told reporters that the 50-year-old writer was named in the DeCamp memo. ``We're suffering here in Omaha under a firestorm of suspicion, and we have hurricane-force rumors,'' said his attorney, Davis, who warned about the gossip. Citron has denied any involvement in Franklin-related matters but has resigned. As for the money missing from the credit union, the National Credit Union Administration filed a lawsuit against Lawrence E. King Jr., Franklin's manager, alleging that he diverted money from Franklin for his personal use and for his businesses. King, a wealthy black businessman who sang the national anthem at the 1984 Republican National Convention, is scheduled for trial in June on 40 counts charging conspiracy, fraud and filing false tax returns.

DOC.HEAD: Inter American Press Association Hails Advances in Press Freedom
DOC.TEXT: The Inter American Press Association on Wednesday praised Nicaragua and Panama for restoring press freedom, but said journalists' lives remain threatened in Colombia and elsewhere in the American hemisphere. The association, which groups 1,400 newspapers, magazines and broadcasters in the Americas, declared at its congress here that ``a free press' triumph has been most rewarding'' in Panama and Nicaragua. In Panama, independent newspapers have reopened following last December's U.S. invasion that overthrew dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega. Nicaraguan publisher Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, whose newspaper La Prensa struggled to operate under the leftist Sandinista government, is now Nicaragua's president-elect after the victory of her 14-party coalition over the Sandinistas in elections Feb. 25. Mrs. Chamorro pledged total press freedom. In addition, Sandinista President Daniel Ortega told the IAPA Tuesday that in his last days in office, he will liberalize news media laws and permit private TV broadcasting. The Sandinistas, who will become Nicaragua's largest single opposition party, are likely to be among the chief beneficiaries of the move. The IAPA congress also declared its solidarity with Colombian journalists threatened by violence from that nation's drug lords. Nineteen Colombian newspaper employees were killed by suspected drug traffickers last year, and two have died so far in 1990. IAPA also declared that ``repression of the press in Cuba is grave and extreme,'' and expressed concern over the jailing of Cuban human rights activists, accused of giving false information to foreign journalists. IAPA said seven journalists died in recent months while covering fighting in El Salvador between President Alfredo Cristiani's conservative government and leftist guerrillas. It noted reports that guerrillas killed five press employees during their offensive in November, and said the armed forces and extreme-right groups have also intimidated the media. In a report on the United States, the association said the Pentagon failed to cooperate adequately with the pool of U.S. reporters it took to Panama to cover the U.S. invasion. ``The current Pentagon,'' IAPA said, ``seems institutionally profoundly suspicious of the press.''

DOC.HEAD: Three Killed, 119 Injured in Subway Derailment in Philadelphia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with woman pulled from wreckage dying; picking up 5th graf, `There was...' SUBS final graf to conform.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto PX3
DOC.TEXT: A crowded subway train derailed and crashed into tunnel support beams this morning, shearing a car in half, killing three people and injuring at least 119 others, authorities said. Five people carried from the tunnel were listed in critical condition at hospitals. The city medical examiner's office said a man and a woman were killed. Hahnemann Hospital spokeswoman Linda Clossey said a third woman who died this afternoon arrived in critical condition after her right leg was amputated to free her from the wreckage. She also had severe chest injuries and a broken left leg, Clossey said. A mobile surgical team worked with rescuers and evaluated the conditions of trapped passengers as they were freed, police Commissioner Willie Williams said. The victims' names were not immediately released. There was no information on the cause of the derailment, Williams said. James Sweeney, a transit inspector, said the train hit three tunnel support beams. He said a preliminary inspection did not indicate any danger of a cave-in. ``The second and third cars were bent and the whole side of the second car was torn off like it was peeled like a sardine can and the floor was ripped out,'' said passenger Mark Robinson, who was going home after getting off work as a cashier. ``I saw people pinned in the car, and they couldn't move and yet no one was hollering, and that was odd,'' said Robinson. Conductor Steven Young said there was standing room only on the six-car train when it ``suddenly pitched to the left.'' He said he watched as a tunnel support beam punctured the side of the car. ``There were some people sitting there and they got crushed,'' Young said. ``One (man) was alive and I watched him die. I tried to comfort him.'' Passenger Gene Paul Henry said the train started shaking just before the accident. The train was headed to the city's western residential areas and connections to suburban bus and trolley lines when it derailed just after 8:30 a.m. It had just left the 30th Street stop, a major downtown station connecting the city subway with Amtrak and regional commuter trains, said Jim Whitaker, Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority spokesman. Presbyterian Medical Center said it received 53 injured, the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania reported 40, Hahnemann Hospital reported 14 in addition to the woman who died, the Children's Hospital of Philadelphia had six, Thomas Jefferson University Hospital had five and Pennsylvania Hospital reported one.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Agency to Lend to Czechoslovakia
DOC.TEXT: The federal government's Export-Import Bank announced Wednesday it will begin lending to Czechoslovakia for the first time since 1946. It said the bank's board of directors approved Czechoslovakia for all the agency's programs, including subsidized loans and guarantees of private bank loans to help other countries import U.S. goods. ``I am delighted to announce that, as of today, Ex-Im Bank can be a major participant in the process of increasing U.S. exports to this major Central European democracy,'' Chairman John D. Macomber said in a statement. Among countries formerly under hard-line Communist rule, the bank was already doing business with Hungary and Yugoslavia. It recently announced that it was ready to issue insurance on short-term trade loans to Poland, although not yet to make loans or guarantees. The bank cannot lend to the Soviet Union, East Germany, Romania or Bulgaria until President Bush waives the Jackson-Vanik amendment, which limits U.S. business relations with countries that restrict emigration. Bush announced a waiver for Czechoslovakia last month during the visit of President Vaclav Havel. The bank said it would support loans to and loans guaranteed by the Czechoslovak Ministry of Finance, the State Bank of Czechoslovakia and the Czechoslovak Commercial Bank.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Author Stephen King may be a master of the macabre, but he's not so bad at one-liners. ``People want to know why I do this, why I write such gross stuff,'' King told 2,300 fans at City Hall on Tuesday night. ``I like to tell them I have the heart of a small boy, and I keep it in a jar on my desk.'' King, who was taking part in the city library's centennial celebrations, said some people pay psychiatrists to tell them ``their most twisted fantasies.'' ``I, on the other hand, write them down, and they pay me. It's a great way to live,'' said the author of such chillers as ``Carrie,'' ``The Shining,'' ``The Dead Zone,'' and ``Cujo.'' ``People want to know if I have nightmares,'' he said. ``Of course not. I give them to you.'' Then there are those who are curious about King's reading habits. ``Somebody will walk up to you, usually in a restaurant _ I usually read a book when I eat _ and say, `How come you're not reading one of your own?' ``Think about it. Because I know how they come out. Every last one!''

Environmentalists want Bob Hope to donate his 7,400 acres of land in the Santa Monica Mountains to a national preserve, but the 86-year-old entertainer wants to turn a profit. Hope, the largest private landholder in the coastal range north of Los Angeles, has optioned most of the land he acquired in the 1950s to developers who plan golf courses and high-priced homes, said Payson Wolff, an attorney for Hope. ``Mr. Hope regards his properties as investments, and he is fully entitled to a fair return on them,'' Wolff said Tuesday. ``It's presumptuous for people to say that he should give his land away. ... If he wants to sell it, more power to him.'' Supporters of a vast Santa Monica Mountains National Recreation Area, which includes an ocean-front stretch near Malibu, say acquiring Hope's land is crucial, because the National Park Service cannot compete with developers. ``Of all the lands you can get in the mountains, Hope has the critical ones,'' said Joseph T. Edmiston, director of the state-run Santa Monica Mountains Conservancy, which works with the park service to acquire land. One 339-acre oceanfront tract in Malibu's Corral Canyon is under option to a company that plans a golf course and resort. Another, the 1,300-acre Jordan Ranch in the Agoura Hills, has been valued at $20 million to $30 million. The park service has set aside $12 million this year for acquiring land in the Santa Monica Mountains, and $15 million has been contributed by the conservancy.

The state Supreme Court on Wednesday upheld Johnny Paycheck's seven- to 9{-year sentence in the 1985 shooting of another barroom patron in southern Ohio. Authorities said Paycheck, best known for his 1978 hit ``Take This Job and Shove It,'' pulled out a pistol in the Hillsboro lounge on Dec. 19, 1985, and fired a shot after interpreting a remark as an insult, wounding Larry Wise in the scalp. Paycheck was sent to the Chillicothe Correctional Institute on Feb. 7, 1989, with no chance of parole for at least five years and eight months. The country crooner originally was charged with felonious assault involving the use of a gun, but a jury convicted him of a lesser offense of aggravated assault. He also was convicted of tampering with evidence. In an appeal, lawyers for Paycheck argued that he should not have been given a mandatory three-year sentence for use of a firearm. They contended the lesser charge did not provide for the firearm specification. The court ruled that a firearm specification in the assault charge applied to other lesser charges against him. The opinion said that when a person is charged with a felony, the indictment ``necessarily and simultaneously charges the defendant with the lesser offenses as well.''

Mikhail S. Gorbachev has accepted Brown University's invitation to speak on campus, a State Department official said Wednesday, but the school is refusing to comment. The State Department official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, told The Associated Press that Gorbachev had agreed in principle to speak at the Ivy League school, but it was unclear whether the Soviet president would be available to speak at Brown's commencement in late May. ``The timing of Brown's commencement does not coincide with plans for the summit,'' said the official. Gorbachev and President Bush plan to meet in the United States in June, but probably not until late in the month. School officials have refused any comment since reports of Gorbachev's possible visit surfaced Tuesday. ``We still don't feel we can say anything,'' said Robert Reichley, when told about the State Department official's comment. ``I can't tell you what the reason is.'' On Tuesday, a congressional source also said Gorbachev had agreed to accept an honorary degree from Brown, but no date had been set.

The family of the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. criticized the British musical ``King,'' saying it trivializes the legacy of the slain civil rights leader. A spokesman for the King family said Tuesday the family ``feels strongly that there has been no meeting of the minds'' despite years of discussions with a team of writers, producers and directors. ``The family believes that the musical falls short of the historical authenticity and that it trivializes Dr. King's legacy,'' spokesman Kent Matlock of Matlock & Associates Inc. said in a statement. Matlock said the King family would provide no authorization for the musical or the stage play soundtrack. The statement indicated that musical is produced by the London, England-based production group, Multi Media AG and Hargitay Group Holdings AG.

DOC.HEAD: Postal Board Chairman Urges Labor Changes
DOC.TEXT: The requirement that the Postal Service and its unions go to binding arbitration when they cannot reach agreement on a contract should be changed, the chairman of the post office's governing board said Wednesday. Leaders of the two biggest unions representing postal workers immediately rejected the suggestion from Robert Setrakian. Contracts with the major unions representing postal workerts expire this year. ``I think it's a very, very bad idea,'' said Vincent Sombrotto, president of the National Association of Letter Carriers. ``Final and binding arbitration was made part of the postal reorganization act to balance the inability of postal employees having the right strike.'' Moe Biller, head of the American Postal Workers Union, responded: ``If they want to give us the right to strike, that's fine. But other than that it's obvious that he either knows nothing about the collective bargaining process or he doesn't want collective bargaining.'' Both Biller and Sombrotto stressed they would rather work out a contract agreement with postal mamnagement than go to arbitration. Several postal board members told the House Post Office Committee they think changes are needed in the arbitration process, although not necessarily those proposed by Setrakian. Testifying a day after the postal service announced plans for a rate increase next year, Setrakian said labor accounts for 83 percent of postal spending. Setrakian told the committee that when a dispute goes to arbitration the final result is usually ``to take the baby and cut it in half.'' Since both sides know arbitration will likely result in the difference between them being split, they consider that in their negotiations, said Setrakian. Management and labor should be forced to come together, he said, and the element of uncertainty should be increased. For example, he suggested the president or a special committee of Congress could be allowed to settle an impasse. Postal Governor Ira Hall suggested another solution might be a limited arbitration _ in which the arbitrator may only choose the position of one side or the other, and not to divide their differences. That, said Hall, would force both sides to get as close as possible before going to arbitration. But Sombrotto said, ``It's kind of a cynical approach to say that all the arbitrators do is to split the difference.'' Both he and Biller said postal contracts have only gone to arbitration once in recent decades. Setrakian also suggested responsibility for raising rates should be left to the board of governors, instead of the current system of sending a plan to the independent Postal Rate Commission which then can take nearly a year to make a decision. Other board members attending the meeting did not join him in that idea, however. His proposal came a week after several members of the rate commission told the committee they should have final authority for setting rates. Currently, the governors send a rate plan to the commission. It considers the matter and sends back its own rate plan. If both groups agree, new rates take effect. If not, the governors can ask the commission to reconsider, accept the commission plan or overrule it _ but to overule they must vote unanimously. Mustering a unanimous vote is a difficult task most times, and would be even less likely this year, considering that the governors voted only 6-4 to submit this year's proposed increase in the first place.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Prosecution Rests in Hazelwood Trial
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with state resting its case; picking up 4th graf pvs, ``Prouty, chief...
DOC.TEXT: The prosecution rested its case today against Joseph Hazelwood after a defense lawyer tried to poke holes in an expert's testimony that the skipper was drunk while in command of the Exxon Valdez. Richard Prouty acknowledged his method of calculating backwards to determine someone's prior level of intoxication is a subject of dispute among experts. He also said his results would have been different if he had different facts about Hazelwood's liquor consumption before he boarded the tanker. Prouty said he was told by prosecutors that Hazelwood drank five shots of 100-proof vodka in a period seven hours before he boarded the ship on the night it ran aground. Defense attorney Dick Madson asked if Prouty's conclusions would be different if Hazelwood had only two or three drinks of vodka with a lower potency beginning just four hours before boarding the ship. Witnesses gave different accounts of Hazelwood's drinking on that day. Prouty said the figures would definitely be different, and would not reach the 0.14 percent blood alcohol level he concluded Hazelwood had at the time of the grounding. Prouty was the state's 45th and final witness in 4{ weeks of testimony. Superior Court Judge Karl Johnstone told jurors they shouldn't form any opinions before hearing the defense witnesses. ``You haven't heard it all,'' he said. Hazelwood's lawyers contend the defendant wasn't drunk when the tanker rammed a reef March 24, setting off the nation's worst oil spill. Prouty, chief forensic toxicologist with the Oklahoma medical examiner's office, said he used a combination of figures to ``calculate backwards'' from blood and urine tests done on Hazelwood 10{ hours after the grounding. He said Hazelwood's blood alcohol level would have been .14 percent at 12:05 a.m. when the tanker ran aground in Prince William Sound. The legal limit in Alaska for driving a car is .10 percent. The Coast Guard has a limit of .04 for operating a commercial vessel, but jurors weren't told of the regulation because Hazelwood is charged under state law, not federal. Evidence on whether Hazelwood was drunk has been inconclusive, but the issue remains a key factor in the prosecution's effort to prove he was reckless. Crew members have testified that except for alcohol on his breath, their captain showed no signs of being drunk when he boarded the ship in Valdez four hours before the grounding. And they said he was calm and in control of the ship after the disaster. But Prouty said he has seen cases of men with a blood alcohol level of .20 who showed no signs of being drunk. Assistant District Attorney Brent Cole asked whether Prouty would consider a person with a level of .14 to be impaired in reasoning and decision-making. ``It is my opinion they definitely would be impaired,'' Prouty said. Hazelwood, 43, of Huntington, N.Y., is charged with criminal mischief, reckless endangerment, operating a vessel while intoxicated and negligent discharge of oil. He could get up to 7\ years in prison and $61,000 in fines. The Exxon Valdez spilled nearly 11 million gallons of Alaska crude into Prince William Sound, killing countless birds, fish and other wildlife and polluting hundreds of miles of rocky shoreline with black goo. In 4{ weeks of testimony, prosecutors have sought to show that Hazelwood was reckless in leaving a third mate in charge of the bridge during the ship's passage into the sound. They maintained also that he recklessly tried to run the ship off jagged Bligh Reef after the grounding. Underlying the recklessness charge is the claim of intoxication. When Hazelwood was tested at about 10:30 a.m on March 24, his blood alcohol reading was .061. Prouty said he ``calculated backwards in time,'' considering Hazelwood's height, weight and an estimate that he stopped drinking at 8 p.m. The toxicologist said accurate and specific information is critical in attempting such a calculation. ``It's desirable to know the individual's body size and weight, what the person was drinking, when he started, what type of beverage he consumed, and when he stopped,'' Prouty said. He indicated he also usually figures in what a person had to eat. There are conflicts among witnesses over how much Hazelwood drank, when he drank it and when he stopped. In addition, there has been testimony suggesting the skipper drank a low-alcohol beer after the grounding. Hazelwood's history of drunken driving convictions and his participation in an alcohol rehabilitation program are inadmissible and jurors will not be told about them.

DOC.HEAD: Small Town Copes with Greyhound Strike
LaserPhoto DN1
DOC.TEXT: Life in Cooper is just the way its residents like it. They know each other by name, and people smile when they speak to strangers. At Miller's corner drugstore, high school football dominates the conversation and the milkshakes are homemade. But one constant, dependable part of that life has abruptly come unglued. Greyhound is on strike and Cooper is one of 9,000 communities where the company's buses provide the only intercity transportation. ``I've only sold one ticket since the strike started, and that person knew about the strike and wound up hitching a ride to Dallas,'' said Marion Miller, who runs the family drugstore with his father, Manton. ``Actually it's a good thing he didn't wait around because the bus was an hour and a half late,'' said the younger Miller, whose store doubles as the bus station in this town of 2,315 people 80 miles northeast of Dallas. Greyhound Lines Inc., America's only nationwide bus system, has been limping along since its 6,300 drivers and about 3,000 office and maintenance workers went on strike. The union, which walked out Friday over wage and job security issues, has asked for new talks but none are scheduled. The company has been operating a reduced schedule during the 6-day-old strike, using about 700 replacement drivers plus union members who cross picket lines. Greyhound said Wednesday its ridership Tuesday was 37.1 percent of the same day last year, an increase from Monday' 33.8 percent and Friday's 30 percent. But bus travel in small towns such as Cooper has slowed to a virtual crawl. ``In a small town, it's more of a sporadic stream of business,'' the younger Miller said. ``I might have five or six people in a day trying to catch a bus, but then on other days I might not have any.'' Manton Miller said he normally sells about 10 tickets a week _ Greyhound pays him $75 a week to serve as agent _ but some of his regular customers are business people who regularly use the bus to ship and receive supplies ranging from auto parts to bull semen. ``It would be kind of hard for farmers and breeders to schedule the semen shipments for their artificial breeding. That stuff has to be refrigerated and I don't think it can stand to be left around for more than two or three days,'' he said. Before the strike, four buses passed through Cooper daily on the route between Texarkana and Dallas. But this week, Manton Miller said, no buses stopped by his store.
