He said the limited bus service resulting from the strike reminds him of a time about two years ago when a woman told him that it took a rookie bus driver more than 90 minutes to make the 20-mile trip from the town of Paris. ``That's the kind of problems they have when they're training these new drivers,'' he said. ``When you've got to fill in your schedule with all new people, you're just asking for problems.'' Since Delta County has evolved from an economy driven by agriculture to one struggling to fuel itself by light industry, a prolonged strike could cripple local businesses that depend on Greyhound's freight service. ``Well, it's going to hurt us,'' said Bonnie Oats, who runs a clothing manufacturing plant with her husband, Zane. Mrs. Oats said they often receive up to three supply shipments a week. And the convenience provided by the bus schedules is invaluable, she said. ``We can depend on the bus. You don't ever know when UPS is going to get here,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Text of Revolutionary Justice Statement
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Repetition of some words or phrases is correct.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Hostages, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Text of the statement released Wednesday by the Revolutionary Justice Organization as translated by The Associated Press bureau in Beirut: In the name of the powerful Almighty, After a comprehensive study of audio and printed statements and reactions about the hostages' question and some issues and developments in the region, the Revolutionary Justice Organization announces the following: First _ During the prolonged American darkness that has engulfed the region, all have fallen into U.S. traps. Intentions are obscured, guns have been deviated and rules of classifying friends and foes by members of the same ranks have changed. Painful stabs have been dealt to our essential causes. Strugglers and martyrs have fallen in the arenas of shame everywhere with America behind them, above them and in between them, not to say inside of them all. In this deluge, and in spite of all, the Revolutionary Justice Organization remains, and remains, and remains holding to its positions and directing all its efforts and strugglers against America and its allies, only America and its allies. The organization counsels all that this is the right and sole course to which suicide strugglers and special operations should be directed. They should wake up and ponder what they do. In this atmosphere, the United States has raised the question of the hostages from a humanitarian angle. But by monitoring American moves here and there and through planting elements in regional American stations, and after trailing some spies, we have acquired accurate information that an American military operation is imminent against areas where the Americans believe hostages are held. We call upon all to watch out against this threat and beware and be on the alert against what America is hatching. We are sorry over some irresponsible declarations by local friends in this regard that may have resulted from failing to understand the nature of the American movements. And we call upon them to concentrate their humanitarian attempts on areas that can be more positive and more productive. Second _ The Revolutionary Justice Organization holds spies and humanitarianism requires just punishment, not a reward. We warn America away from what it calls the hard option because we are are on alert. We are today stronger and better prepared and more determined to hit out at strategic interests and deal painful blows. Washington realizes more than anyone else that our strength today is not that of yesterday. Third _ We tenaciously hold to keeping America's nose in the mud under our feet. There is no intention to release hostages. No one should ask for resolving the hostage issue except within the balanced and positive framework for which we have often proposed several adequate outlets, on many occasions, that will guarantee the rights of all. Victory for the oppressed in the march toward liberation and justice, Glory and immortality for the revered martyrs, The Revoltuionary Justice Organization.

DOC.HEAD: Bank Proficts Off 34 Percent Last Year
LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Bank profits tumbled 34 percent in 1989, held back in the last half of the year by mounting real estate woes in the Northeast and debt troubles in the Third World. The nation's commercial banks earned $16.3 billion, down from a record $24.8 billion in 1988, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. said Wednesday. The contrast between the first six months of the year and the last half was dramatic. In the January-June period, banks posted $14.3 billion in earnings, the best ever for six months, compared with a weak $2 billion in the final half. Fourth quarter earnings were held to $2.7 billion after the industry set aside $8.4 billion to cover losses on domestic loans. Most of the problems centered on real estate development lending, but the percentage of sour consumer loans edged up for the fifth consecutive year to 1.6 percent. In the third quarter, big banks set aside $7.6 billion to cover Third World debt losses, producing a rare loss for the industry of $740 million. It was the worst showing since the second quarter of 1987, when a previous round of reserving for developing country loans caused a $10.6 billion loss. Banks in the oil-producing Southwest continued to recover slowly from the oil and real estate busts earlier in the mid-1980s, but northeastern banks deteriorated sharply. Western and Midwest banks showed strong gains and southeastern institutions held steady. Bad real estate loans more than doubled in the Northeast, where four states were among the 10 with the highest percentage of sour real estate loans. The Boston-based Bank of New England alone lost $1.1 billion last year, most of it in real estate. Despite the problems, banks continued to pour money into real estate lending, particularly in the Southeast and West. Real estate lending increased 12.8 percent nationally, compared with a 5.4 percent growth rate for bank assets generally. Five of the country's 10 largest banks were in the red last year, primarily because of provisions for losses on developing country loans. They were Chase Manhattan, Morgan Guaranty, Manufacturers Hanover, Bankers Trust and Chemical Bank. The chairman of the FDIC, L. William Seidman, predicted that the industry's performance would improve this year, at least in the first six months. Private analysts were less optimistic. ``We are in a particularly vicious real estate cycle,'' said economist Paul Getman of Regional Financial Associates of Philadelphia. ``I think you're going to get more bad news ... particularly in the Southeast in Florida, Georgia, the Carolinas because there was a lot of speculative buying there.'' Seidman, however, said, ``All is not on the black side. There was some good news. Particularly (small) community banks showed improving earnings. ... Much of the (Third World loan problems) would appear to be behind most of the large banks.'' In another positive sign, the list of ``problem'' banks, which the FDIC uses to predict bank failures, stood at 1,093 at the end of 1989, down from 1,394 a year earlier and 1,559 at the end of 1987. Seidman forecast fewer bank failures in 1990 compared with last year, when 206 banks failed or required government assistance to stay open. The failures and a spate of mergers reduced the number of banks to 12,706 at the end of 1989, compared with a peak of 14,496 five years earlier.

DOC.HEAD: White House Welcomes Iranian Comments on Hostages
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with measure sent to full committee, subbing 14th graf, Amid the
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Hostages Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration on Wednesday welcomed ``more hopeful'' statements from Iran about the American hostages in Lebanon while members of Congress pressed for a special envoy to deal with the situation. In Beirut, meanwhile, the Revolutionary Justice Organization, a group claiming to hold two American hostages, said it had no intention of releasing them. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said administration officials were ``encouraged by the comments'' of Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani who said there might be a solution soon. ``They certainly are more hopeful than what we've heard in the more distant past,'' he said of Rafsanjani's remarks. Rafsanjani was quoted by the Islamic Republic News Agency as saying: `My feeling is that the issue of the hostages is moving towards a solution.'' But he also said Western nations must help trace Iranian hostages missing in Lebanon and ``also reduce their mischievous acts.'' Revolutionary Justice, the group that claims to hold Joseph Cicippio of Valley Forge, Pa., and Edward Austin Tracy, an American author, said ``there is no intention to release hostages.'' The statement, delivered to Beirut newspaper An-Nahar and a Western news agency, was accompanied by a black-and-white instant photograph of Cicippio. U.S. officials made clear they did not see Rafsanjani's statements as portending any immediate release of eight missing Americans, most if not all of whom are thought to be held by pro-Iranian Shiite Moslems in Lebanon. All told, there are 18 Western hostages. But officials described the comments as positive. Fitzwater called them ``in line with statements that we have seen in recent days and weeks that there was some interest in Iran in better relations with the West.'' ``We hope that that's the case and that it will result in release of the hostages,'' he said at a briefing before reports of the Revolutionary Justice communique. Fitzwater said the United States did not have ``direct knowledge of Mr. Rafsanjani's motives or purposes in making those remarks.'' But a State Department official familiar with the hostage issue said he believed the Iranians ``won't be able to get the economic aid and credit'' they seek from the West so long as hostages remain in Lebanon. ``I think they realize there is no longer any benefit to holding the hostages,'' he said, speaking on condition he remain anonymous. Amid the flurry of reports about the hostages, a House Foreign Affairs subcommittee referred to the full panel a proposed ``sense of Congress'' resolution that the president ``should designate a special envoy to negotiate the release of American hostages in Lebanon.'' The measure was introduced by Rep. Louise Slaughter, D-N.Y., who said she also hoped to draw attention to the March 16 date marking the fifth year of captivity for Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press. ``We cannot replace those lost years, but we owe it to Terry, to his little girl, and to the seven other American hostages to secure their release,'' she said. Anderson, the longest-held American hostage, has a daughter born 3 months after he was seized. Sen. Daniel Moynihan, D-N.Y., has proposed a companion Senate resolution. A concurrent resolution does not go to the president for his signature so it does not have the force of law, but it puts Congress on record. U.S. officials usually oppose the idea of special envoys, a State Department official said. ``Remember Terry Waite _ he was a special envoy,'' the official said, referring to the Anglican churchman who was seized in Beirut while trying to free the hostages. ``We have mechanisms for talking with the Iranians and we aren't sure there is anything to gain from talking directly to the hostage-holders,'' the official said. Another official, also speaking on condition of anonymity, said, ``We've been talking for a long time to anyone who could have influence, Algerians, Syrians. We talk to the Iranians through a lot of people. We have talked to enough people that the message has gotten through to the Iranians.'' The message, said the official, who demanded anonymity, is: ``We know you want access to the West. You've said you are against terrorism. We want to see action.'' The official U.S. policy is not to deal directly with the Iranians. ``There are no U.S. government talks,'' spokeswoman Margaret D. Tutwiler said. Iran is believed to exert considerable influence over Hezbollah, the umbrella group for the radical Shiite Moslems.

DOC.HEAD: Spreadsheet Designer Cautions Against Copyright Protections for Ideas
DOC.TEXT: One of the nation's most successful computer software designers cautioned Congress Wednesday against passing laws that would overprotect ``intellectual property'' by extending copyright protection to ideas. ``It's the nature of software for ideas to slosh and flow back and forth between competitors, companies and industries,'' Mitchell D. Kapor told a House subcommittee. ``If, as a software designer, I can use a program and learn from it without copying its internals, then I should be free to use the knowledge that I've gained as long as I expressed the ideas in my own way.'' The subcomittee is considering a revision of laws governing intellectual property _ a phrase covering copyrights, patents and trade secrets _ and heard from Kapor, software designer Daniel S. Bricklin and government officials concerned with copyrights and patents. Software refers to sets of instructions for computers, whether the instructions are stored on punched cards, magnetic tape, disks or chips. Kapor designed a spreadsheet known as Lotus 1-2-3, which became a standard of the computer industry and made Lotus Development Corp, which he founded, one of the most successful software firms in the country. The firm is involved in a copyright suit against two competitors. ``There is no question, as I look at my industry, that there has been an unsteady but stubborn march to extend the scope of copyright,'' Kapor said. ``Twisting and straining each step of the way to secure additional copyright protections, too many companies seem to have decided that it's easier to sue their rivals than compete with them. ``Litigation is becoming a business tactic, not a practice of last resort. Software should not be an industry driven by litigation,'' said Kapor, adding that he was not complaining about the lawsuit. Kapor said he sees no way to prevent potential competitors from profitiing from his company's efforts. ``If they can replicate our efforts or go them one better because our approach inspired them to do so, more power to them,'' he said. ``I would only call my lawyer if we found that these competitors had not just copied the idea, but the actual lines of code underlying it.'' James W. Curlin of the congressional Office of Technology Assessment presented the committee with an OTA study that said the United States' 70 percent share of the world's computer software market could shrink without better legal protection. With continued innovation, the United States can keep outshining its foreign competitors, the study said, claiming that intellectual property protection encourages innovation by providing incentives for creation and security for investors. Last year, software and related services were a $60 billion industry in the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Fitzwater Says Democratic Leader ``the Maxwell Smart of Politics''
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 3 grafs after 4th graf pvs, The president's, with Gephardt no comment and Baker comments on aid; also SUBS 7th graf pvs, Gephardt also, to restore dropped word; picks up 8th graf pvs, The 1988
DOC.TEXT: Presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater compared House Majority Leader Richard A. Gephardt to television's bumbling secret agent Maxwell Smart on Wednesday and said, ``It's hard to figure out what he's up to.'' Fitzwater took issue with the Missouri Democrat's stinging rebuke of Bush and his proposal for direct economic aid to the Soviet Union. ``He's hard to believe,'' Fitzwater said at his daily White House news briefing. ``He's the Maxwell Smart of politics. Do you believe he wants to raise taxes on the American people to give money to the Soviet Union?'' The president's spokesman did not elaborate on his reference to the well-intentioned but self-important and clumsy hero of the 1960s ``Get Smart'' comedy series. Gephardt spokeswoman Deborah Johns said the majority leader did not wish to respond to Fitzwater's characterization. Secretary of State James A. Baker III, testifying Wednesday on Capitol Hill, said there is no need or direct financial aid to Moscow and ``they haven't asked for it.'' ``We ought to support the reform efforts in the Soviet Union,'' Baker said. Asked whether communism has ceased to be a threat, he added, ``We ought not to gloat too much over our success ... It is not overly-productive to stick a stick in their eye, just for the hell of it.'' Gephardt on Tuesday accused Bush of presiding over a government ``of the polls, by the polls and for the polls.'' ``The Bush foreign policy is a policy adrift, without vision, without imagination, without a guiding light save precious public opinion polls,'' Gephardt said in speech to the Center for National Policy, a liberal research organization. Gephardt also proposed direct aid to the Soviet Union and accused Bush of a ``lack of vision'' for not doing more to encourage and embrace changes in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. The 1988 Democratic presidential contender proposed food aid to the Soviets along with other forms of assistance and a lifting of trade restrictions. ``Well, I don't know, that Gephardt. It's hard to figure out what he's up to,'' Fitzwater said. ``I mean, the Soviet Union has indicated that they don't want direct support. They have not made economic reforms that would be able to use that kind of support,'' he added. Fitzwater noted Sen. Bill Bradley, D-N.J., and other Democrats had opposed the Gephardt proposal as ``pouring money down a rathole.''

DOC.HEAD: Company Sells What People Can Get For Free
DOC.TEXT: It cost the government $185,000 to tell people they bought Social Security information they could've gotten for free and didn't get the right material at that. The General Accounting Office on Wednesday issued a report on the Social Security Protection Bureau, a private company that has come under criticism for offering benefits considered by many to be of dubious value. The $7 fee for membership in the bureau brings help in getting earnings information from the government's Social Security Administration, information that is available for free directly from SSA, the GAO said. The report said the bureau appears to operate ``without violating federal legal requirements'' _ but not without cost to the government. The Social Security Administration has processed more than 350,000 requests for earnings and benefit information generated by the private company, the GAO said. It cost the government $900,000 to process those requests, including $185,000 in ``extraordinary expenses'' because the company had given people outdated government forms for requesting the earnings information. The $185,000 was spent to send people letters ``explaining that they had spent $7 for what they could have received free and asking them to submit the new revised request form,'' the GAO said. ``At the same time, the Social Security Protection Bureau could have received $2 million in membership fees from those 350,000 new members.'' The Social Security Protection Bureau is the trade name for Foxhall Corp., which is controlled by Watson & Hughey Co., a partnership that has grown into a multimillion-dollar business promoting non-profit groups. Watson & Hughey has been criticized because the partnership _ not the charitable organizations _ gets most of the money obtained from the public, the GAO said. Thirteen states have taken action against Watson & Hughey because of possible violations related to non-profit organizations and consumer protection. Attorney Michael Kushnick, who represents Watson & Hughey, said he had not seen the GAO report but stressed the bureau's operations ``did not violate the law. Kushnick said if the information requests cost the government money, ``I think the benefits to the consumer in getting this information probably outweighed those costs.''

DOC.HEAD: Group Holding Captives Denies Release Imminent
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Stands for NICOSIA, Cyprus-dated story on AM-News Digest.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY20
DOC.TEXT: A pro-Iranian underground group holding two American hostages in Lebanon said Wednesday it does not intend to release the captives, and it urged attacks on U.S. targets. The group also accused the United States of planning a military operation to free the 18 Western captives. The statement was released by the Revolutionary Justice Organization just hours after Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani said he wants the issue of Westerners held in Lebanon resolved. It followed a flurry of news reports that had raised hopes some hostages might be released. ``We tenaciously cling to keeping America's nose in the mud under our feet. There is no intention to release hostages,'' Revolutionary Justice said in an Arabic-language statement delivered to the independent Beirut newspaper An-Nahar and a Western news agency. The handwritten statement was accompanied by a black-and-white photograph of hostage Joseph Cicippio of Valley Forge, Pa. Cicippio, acting comptroller of the American University of Beirut, was kidnapped Sept. 12, 1986 in Lebanon. The group said ``suicide strugglers and special operations should be directed'' against the United States and its allies, adding this was ``the right and sole course.'' In the picture, Cicippio, dressed in a striped sweater over a T-shirt, looked straight into the camera. He was without his eyeglasses and had a bushy, grayish beard. His hair was disheveled. The statement was the first from Revolutionary Justice since Aug. 3, when the group announced it had reversed a decision to kill Cicippio, 59. The execution had been threatened to retaliate for Israel's abduction of a Shiite Moslem cleric from southern Lebanon. ``By monitoring American moves here and there and through planting elements in regional American stations, and after trailing some spies, we have acquired accurate information that an American military operation is imminent against areas where the Americans believe hostages are held,'' the statement said. ``We call upon all to watch out against this threat and beware and be on the alert against what America is hatching,'' the communique added. In an apparent reference to recent comments made by Lebanon's leading Shiite cleric, the communique said: ``The Revolutionary Justice Organization holds spies, and humanitarianism requires just punishment, not a reward.'' On Feb. 23, the clergyman, Sheik Mohammed Hussein Fadlallah, said a ``realistic and humanitarian means'' must be found to free the hostages. The statement was one of several recent developments that had raised hopes a solution may be in the works. Editorials in English-language Iranian newspapers have said the hostages should be freed because they are being used as anti-Islamic propaganda. Syrian and other officials also have expressed optimisim the captives may be freed. Rafsanjani, in his most direct statement so far that he wants the hostages freed, said Wednesday: ``I and my friends would like the issue to be settled since the United States and others are exploiting the matter as a means for branding the Lebanese as terrorists and so they are not seriously seeking a solution.'' Rafsanjani said Iran was not directly linked to the hostage issue, but that he had pledged to use Iran's influence to seek their freedom. ``My feeling is that the issue of the hostages is moving toward a solution,'' he said. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Bush administration officials were encouraged by Rafsanjani's comments. ``They certainly are more hopeful that what we've heard in the more distant past,'' Fitzwater said. Rafsanjani is believed to be eager to obtain the captives' release because he wants to improve ties with the West. But radicals opposed to him see confrontation with the West as the wellspring of the Islamic revolution and are believed to hold greater sway over the hostage-holders. Revolutionary Justice also holds American writer Edward Austin Tracy, 58, of Burlington, Vt., who was kidnapped Oct. 21, 1986. There are six other Americans held hostage, including Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press. Anderson, kidnapped March 16, 1985, has been held longer than any hostage. The other hostages are four Britons, two West Germans, two Swiss, an Irishman, and an Italian. ``We warn America away from what it calls the hard option because we are on alert,'' Revolutionary Justice said. ``We are today stronger and better prepared and more determined to hit out at strategic interests and deal painful blows.'' There was no immediate comment from the White House on the latest development. Earlier, the Bush administration said it was encouraged by Rafsanjani's comments. ``They certainly are more hopeful than what we've heard in the more distant past,'' said White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. Members of a House panel were taking up a proposed ``sense of Congress'' resolution that the president ``should designate a special envoy to negotiate the release of American hostages in Lebanon.'' The measure was introduced by Rep. Louise Slaughter, D-N.Y., who said she also hoped to draw attention to the March 16 date marking the fifth year of captivity for Anderson.

DOC.HEAD: Boat with Children, Freighter Collide; 134 Missing
DOC.TEXT: At least 134 people were missing Wednesday after a boat carrying children returning from holiday collided with a freighter and sank into the Amazon River, police said. The riverboat Andresito sank Tuesday evening near the Amazon port of Iquitos, 715 miles northeast of Lima, police said. The boat had just left Iquitos for Puritoyacu, a jungle village three days' journey away. Police said the Andresito was carrying 209 crew members and passengers who were mostly children. Some parents and teachers also were aboard. The boat also was loaded with lumber to be used for a new school in Puritoyacu. Police said the heavy cargo may have contributed to the accident. The boat's helmsman told police that the Andresito's motor failed and the boat began drifting out of control in the Amazon's fast currents. In the darkness it smacked into several small boats anchored along the shore and then careened into a large freighter, rolled over and sank into the river's dark waters, police said. Police said Wednesday that 74 people had been rescued and the body of a girl had been recovered. They said the freighter's crew rescued five of the passengers by throwing life preservers into the water, but others were quickly swept away by the current. They said heavy rain was hampering rescue boats and divers. The 182-foot Andresito had a 40-ton capacity, according to dock authorities in Iquitos. The freighter, an ocean-going ship 420 feet long and with a capacity of 7,500 tons, received only a minor dent in its side, police said. The freighter was identified by its owner, Naviera Amazonica Peruana, as the Yacu Caspi, which travels the Amazon to the Atlantic and to Caribbean ports. It was tied up at a dock at Punchana, 6 miles from Iquitos, when the Andresito smashed into its side. Alfredo Bringas, the company's manager, said the Yacu Caspi arrived last week from Miami with sugar and wheat flour for Iquitos and steel pipes for Occidental Petroleum Corp., which produces oil in jungle fields in the Iquitos area.

DOC.HEAD: INS Chief Discusses Universial ID Card for Job Seekers
DOC.TEXT: Requiring all job seekers to show an identity card would greatly help enforcement of laws barring the employment of illegal aliens, the nation's chief immigration official said Wednesday. Gene McNary, who heads the Immigration and Naturalization Service, told reporters he was not proposing a nationwide identitiy card, but would consider the concept if it were advanced by others. ``I believe it would greatly enhance our ability to enforce employer sanctions'' that prohibit businesses from hiring illegal aliens, McNary said. ``I'm not taking the initiative; it's something that should be reviewed and discussed,'' McNary said. ``I think its up to some others; it's going to take a law'' passed by Congress. Before endorsing the concept, ``I'd like to have the benefit of discussion; I'd like to get the viewpoint of some of the interest groups,'' he said. An identity card would also eliminate the use of fake documents by illegal aliens to forge false identities, the INS chief said. Under the concept, an identity care would be issued to all adults seeking work, both citizens and aliens with permission from INS to hold jobs in this country. Those issued the card would have to show it only to prospective employers. Under the 1986 Immigration Reform and Control Act, employers can be fined or prosecuted for employing illegal aliens. The provision has resulted in complaints that employers have discriminated against people they feared were illegal aliens. Studies in California and New York recently blamed the 1986 law's employer sanctions for discrimination against Hispanics and members of other ethnic groups who were wrongly suspected of being illegal aliens. The law also bars such discrimination and a Justice Department unit set up in 1987 to handle such cases has received more than 800 complaints from citizens. McNary said he believed the congressional General Accounting Office would discuss the feasibility of issuing a uniform identity card in a report it is preparing on the immigration service. McNary said he did not know whether the GAO would endorse the concept, which has been discussed by a growing number of lawmakers as a way to tighten immigration laws. Many of the discrimination complaints against employers arise from confusion about what types of documentation should be required for job seekers, said Andrew Strojny, the Justice Department's acting special counsel for immigation-related unfair employment practices. ``Many of the complaints deal with employers not understanding what documents are acceptable'' as proof that a person is a citizen or has INS permission to get a job, he said Strojny said that a nationwide identity card would result in less discrimination but that, personally, he feared it would lead to a system under which the government would be granting citizens permission to work.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Prods Electronics Industry
DOC.TEXT: President Bush prodded electronics-industry officials Wednesday to ``do better'' against foreign trade rivals in marketing U.S.-developed products such as videocassette recorders. ``So many of the world's advanced technologies, from robotics to the VCR, were first developed here. And yet, so many of these concepts were ultimately brought to the marketplace by our competitors,'' Bush said in a speech to the American Electronics Association. Bush said he was asking the White House Council on Competitiveness, chaired by Vice President Dan Quayle, to ``find ways that American industry can better translate new ideas and technologies into marketable products.'' He said he would try ``to level the playing field'' by strictly enforcing trade laws and pressing other nations to open their markets more fully. But, he told his audience, ``It will be leaders like you right here in this room that have to take the ball and run with it. ``We can do better. And I am determined we will do better.'' Bush proposed no new trade strategies, but said congressional enactment of many of his lanquishing initiatives would help make U.S. high-tech goods more competitive. Without passage of his proposed reduction in the capital-gains tax rate, ``every business in America _ of every size _ is at a competitive disadvantage abroad,'' Bush said. Among the nation's major trade competitors, Bush said, Japan has a 5 percent capital gains tax and South Korea, Taiwan and West Germany have none. Capital gains are the income from the sale of stocks, real estate and other assets. It is taxed at the same rate as other income _ up to 33 percent. Bush's proposal would lower the rate, in effect, to about 19.5 percent. Bush promised Wednesday to work toward helping the U.S. electronics industry ``regain and retain'' its lost leadership in world markets, saying he was optimistic that his meeting last weekend with Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu would help pry open more markets in Japan. He said he and Kaifu ``specifically discussed satellites and telecommunications, supercomputers, forest products and ... semiconductors. I hope, on the basis of our talks, that Japan will be moving toward early resolution of these problem areas.'' There has been a longstanding trade dispute between the United States and Japan over semiconductors, or computer chips, that resulted in temporary sanctions against Japan in 1987 for deliberately selling chips in U.S. markets at below-market prices.

DOC.HEAD: European Countries Reach Agreement on Cleaning Up North Sea
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with agreement reached; CORRECTS date of Bremen conference to 1984, sted 1986, and CORRECTS London conference to 1987, sted 1988.
DOC.TEXT: Nine Western European nations agreed Wednesday on a plan to clean up the North Sea, one of the world's most polluted salt water bodies. The nations agreed to reduce by 70 percent their emissions of mercury, lead, cadmium and dioxin, which they described as among the most dangerous materials polluting the sea. The reductions are to be achieved by the end of 1995, said Dutch Transport Minister Hanja Maij-Weggen, chairman of a conference on cleaning up the North Sea. Levels of 37 other toxic materials would be cut in half by the same date and polychlorinated biphenyls, or PCBs, would be phased out by 1999, he said. The 228,000-square-mile North Sea is surrounded by Western Europe's most heavily industrialized nations. Pollution from smokestack emissions, sea dumping and rivers used as industrial sewers have threatened fish and seal populations with toxic chemicals. Each year, industrial emissions cause some 45 tons of mercury, 3,500 tons of lead and 95 tons of cadmium to accumulate into the North Sea. A figure for dioxins was not immediately available. Agreement to limit the materials was a breakthrough for the conference. As the meeting got underway, several nations criticized Britain, which environmental activists here called ``the dirty man of Europe.'' But Maij-Weggen said that during discussions Wednesday, Britain had been ``very constructive. ... I think that the criticism against it has helped a little bit.'' In a letter to British Environment Secretary Chris Patten, Norway, Sweden and Denmark had expressed dissatisfaction with London's announcement this week that it planned to phase out industrial waste dumping by late 1992 or early 1993. ``We are of the opinion that this should take place without further delay,'' the said the letter, a copy of which was obtained by The Associated Press. Participating nations at a conference in 1987 in London pledged to halt all industrial waste dumping by Jan. 1, 1990, and all North Sea countries except for Britain have met the deadline. The conference is the third in a series that began in the West German port city of Bremen in 1984. The Netherlands, Sweden, Denmark, Norway, West Germany, Belgium, France, Britain and Switzerland, as well as the European Commission, the EEC's executive body, are participating. Ten other European nations, including East Germany and Czechoslovakia, have observer status. Britain announced this week it would end dumping industrial waste in two or three years' time. Meantime, it would allow annual dumpings of 205,000-270,000 tons. Before the conference, Dutch Transport Minister Hanja Maij-Weggen said the British announcement on waste dumping was ``too little and too late.'' Patten said ``land-based means of disposal have not yet been established'' for the types of waste that will be dumped in the North Sea in the coming years. But critics said the British business world, burdened by aging industries, is balking at the cost of converting to land-based waste treatment. Another contentious subject at the conference was marine pollution by PCBs, believed to be among the most hazardous substances manufactured. Annually, 39 tons of PCBs find their way into the North Sea, where they are a serious threat to the reproductive cycle of seals. Seal populations in the area are rapidly dwindling. Patten said that contrary to the opinion of the other states, ``it is essential to link phase-out with destruction.'' He said long-term storage of PCBs is ``environmentally unacceptable.'' West Germany is strongly pushing for a total ban on the use of PCBs by 1995. Under that proposal, PCBs now in use _ for instance as coolants in heavy-duty electrical equipment _ should be stored until environmentally safe technology has been develop to destroy them.

DOC.HEAD: Bright & Brief
DOC.TEXT: Frank Wynn said he hopes his telephone stops ringing with calls from people looking for an iguana. Wynn took nearly 40 phone calls in two days about an iguana he found on his patio Feb. 24, and was quite relieved to surrender it Monday night to a woman who convinced him she was the real owner. The Morning Advocate newspaper ran an article Monday about Wynn's discovery, loosing a flood of calls from lost-iguana seekers. ``The amazing thing to me is there's so many iguanas loose all over the city,'' Wynn said.

An 11-year-old girl said it felt good to return $200,000 in lost jewelry to a vacationing Michigan couple who hadn't even noticed their loss. Jennifer Hawkins of West Palm Beach, Fla., was jogging Friday with her father, Darrell Hawkins, when she spotted a tapestry bag in a gutter outside a Palm Beach hotel. She took it to the police. They said it contained $2,600 in cash, gold and pearl earrings, gold necklaces and pendants, pearl, emerald, ruby and diamond studs, a gold leaf pin, a 28-inch strand of pearls and a diamond pendant. ``It was very exciting, actually, to be involved in finding something,'' Jennifer said Tuesday. ``It especially felt good to return it to the lady. Police found a matchbook from the Heart of Palm Beach Hotel in the bag, enabling them to trace the owners, Betty and Montgomery Shepard. The couple gave Miss Hawkins a $100 reward. ``She didn't even realize the purse was missing,'' West Palm Beach Police Officer Craig E. Gunkel said.

DOC.HEAD: Report Says Strategic Arms Treaty Could Save Up to $12 Billion
DOC.TEXT: A U.S.-Soviet treaty to reduce strategic weapons would produce annual federal savings ranging from $3 billion to $12 billion depending on President Bush's plans to modernize strategic forces, said a congressional study released Wednesday. The Congressional Budget Office projected long-term savings based on the likelihood that an agreement to limit nuclear warheads to 6,000 on each side will emerge later this year from superpower negotiations in Geneva. The treaty would not limit the production of new weapons systems, and the CBO estimated the savings based on three options _ the Bush administration continuing full-scale modernization of its strategic forces, a less expensive plan to upgrade the systems and minimum steps to improve the arsenal. If the United States signs a treaty and continues current plans to buy 132 B-2 stealth bombers, 500 single-warhead Midgetman missiles, 23 Trident submarines and move 50 multiple-warhead MX missiles to railroad cars, savings would be about $3 billion. Retirement of B-52 bombers, Minutemen land-based missiles and Poseidon submarines would have to accompany these actions, the CBO said. ``Virtually all of the savings under this option would come from reduced operating costs associated with smaller strategic forces,'' the CBO said. ``Because of the aggressive program of modernization assumed under this approach, average savings for procurement would be modest.'' However, if the United States adopts a plan calling for rail-garrison MX missiles, 250 Midgetman missiles, 20 Trident submarines and 66 B-2 stealth bombers, savings would total about $8 billion a year. A drastic plan to buy no more than the 17 Trident submarines and 15 B-2 bombers under contract, and no rail-garrison MX and Midgetman missiles, would mean savings of about $12 billion a year. Sen. Pete V. Domenici, R-N.M., who requested the study, said the report indicates the ``big savings in defense are not going to come out of this part (strategic forces) of the budget,'' The Republican senator also stressed the importance of continuing modernization. ``I don't think it is prudent to abandon our modernization efforts at this time and I don't think it would be prudent to do so after the conclusion of the START treaty,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Arabs Protest Easing of Strike Restrictions, Collaborator Killed
With AM-Israel
DOC.TEXT: Masked Palestinians marched through the West Bank's largest market Wednesday to protest the easing of an Arab commercial strike that was announced in a new leaflet from the uprising leadership. Arab reports said a suspected collaborator was found hanged near his village in the occupied Gaza Strip, and the army said it demolished the West Bank home of a suspected uprising activist. Soldiers also shot and wounded four Palestinians in scattered stone-throwing clashes throughout the West Bank, Arab hospital officials said. The army said it was checking the reports. The march in the Nablus casbah by men from PLO Chairman Yasser Arafat's Fatah faction represented a rare show of defiance against the uprising leadership, which has directed the nearly 27-month-old revolt through clandestinely produced leaflets. A leaflet released Tuesday said shopkeepers could open their stores from 9 a.m. to 2 p.m. starting Saturday. Shopkeepers have been closing their stores since January 1988 at noon in observance of a previously ordered strike. The limited hours, which were widely observed, were part of a display of strength by the uprising's underground leadership. Israeli authorities had first ordered striking shopkeepers to open their stores, but later gave up when the efforts proved futile. The marchers shouted through loudspeakers that Nablus will be excluded from the decision on store hours and that violators would be punished. It was unclear how merchants in Nablus, the West Bank's largest town with 120,000 people, would respond. Although some merchants in Arab east Jerusalem welcomed the longer hours as a way to revive depressed businesses, others were upset with the new directive. ``It sends the wrong message to Israel,'' said one east Jerusalem shopkeeper who insisted on anonymity. ``It suggests there is no uprising anymore.'' There have been other indications the revolt has been losing steam. Last month, nine Palestinians were killed by Israeli gunfire, the lowest monthly casualty toll since the uprising began in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip in December 1987. At least 659 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians in the revolt. Another 193 Palestinians have been slain by fellow Arabs, most on suspicion of collaborating with Israel. Forty-three Israelis have died. On Wednesday, Arab reports said the body of Fahmi Zaanin, 23, was found hanging from a tree a night earlier near the Gaza village of Beit Hanoun. He had been kidnapped from his home Saturday by masked Palestinians, they said. ``The fate of Zaanin is the fate of all collaborators,'' said wall slogans signed by the Red Eagles, a group believed affiliated with the Marxist Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine. Also Wednesday, soldiers blew up the home of Mohammed Karoush, 45, of the West Bank village of Deir Balout. Arab reports said that 14 people lived in the house. The army said it took the action against Karoush's 25-year-old son, Maher, who has been wanted since July on charges of throwing firebombs at Israeli cars, damaging property on Jewish settlements and attacking soldiers and suspected collaborators.

DOC.HEAD: Romanians Tear Down Statue of First Premier
DOC.TEXT: Angry demonstrators have torn down a statue of the nation's first Communist premier, exactly 45 years after he took power. The statue was felled Tuesday night after hundreds of demonstrators gathered in front of the monument to Petru Groza and, without waiting for an official decision, took a crane from a nearby construction site and ripped the statue down. ``Thus a more than symbolic act of justice which closed a nefarious chapter in our national history was closed, a chapter based on lies and political pressure,'' the daily Romania Libera said. The demolition took place a day after work crews lifted the statue of Vladimir I. Lenin from its foundation after two days of intensive work. The demonstration began earlier Tuesday when 300 people gathered in front of the institute of Medicine to demand the removal of the statue of Groza. Demonstrators placed an inverted tin washbasin over Groza's head and a broom stick in his hand and a swatch of red cloth, representing communism. They then placed a placard at the base of the statue saying, ``You are staying here far too long. Aren't you tired? Get down.'' The protesters also carried posters reading ``Petru Groza, the faker of the elections in 1946'' and ``Groza the founder of the Romanian gulag.'' The demonstrators them went to a nearby building site, took a crane and quickly tore the statue down. The demolition of Lenin was not as easy, and work crews had to labor for two full days with jackhammers and blowtorches before they were able to dislodge the imposing figure from its marble base in front of the recently renamed House of Free Press. ``After 30 years during which the star of Communist demagoguery looked impassively toward red horizons defying generations of Romanians who sacrificed their lives in the name of a utopian ideal, the moment of truth has finally come,'' Romania Libera commented on the removal of the Lenin statue. In the first days of the December revolution that overthrew dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, Romanians tore the communist emblem out of the center of their flag.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Honors `Hometown Heroes' in Drug War
DOC.TEXT: President Bush paid tribute Wednesday to 28 ``hometown heroes'' who he said are helping America win its war against drugs. The anti-drug crusaders from 21 major cities were feted at a White House luncheon where drug policy chief William Bennett introduced them as ``the soldiers and the sergeants and the lieutenants and the colonels'' in the fight. ``If we had 10,000 more like them, this (war) would be over in about six months,'' Bennett told Bush. Bush said their efforts to drive drug dealers from their neighborhoods and cities had ``proved to America that this war can be won.'' ``You are America's hometown heroes _ unconventional warriors, but this is an unconventional war,'' Bush said. The president in recent months has seen firsthand the anti-drug projects of two of those cited _ Alvin Brooks of the Ad Hoc Group Against Crime in Kansas City, Mo., and Erma Scales' Acres Homes War on Drugs Committee in Houston. ``We're going to keep on fighting against drugs and fighting for you, for your neighborhoods and most of all for the kids,'' Bush said. Bush also lauded Bennett's leadership. ``He's out there in the trenches. He's in the boardrooms. He's everywhere. He's like Batman,'' Bush said, evoking laughter. The luncheon was held in the ornate Old Indian Treaty Room of the Old Executive Office Building. Bush left loaded with anti-drug T-shirts and other memorabilia. The honorees got M&Ms in boxes with the presidential seal. In addition to Brooks and Scales, the honorees were: _Jack Candelaria of the South San Jose Neighborhood Association in Albuquerque, N.M. _Jaci Feldman of the National Training and Information Center, Bennie Meeks of the South Austin Coalition Community Council, and Alberto Trujillo of the Logan Square Neighborhood Association's Crime Prevention Committee, all in Chicago. _Inez Killingsworth of the Union Miles Development Corp., and the Rev. Jay Matthews of Mt. Sinai Baptist Church, both in Cleveland. _Dorothy Davis of STOP Crime Watch in Dallas. _Brenda LaBlanc, a citizen activist, and Margaret Toomey of Homes of Oakridge, both in Des Moines, Iowa. _Ines Pegeas, a history teacher and president of Hartford Areas Rally Together in Hartford, Conn. _Deloyd Parker Jr. of SHAPE (Self-Help for African People Through Education) Community Center in Houston. _Philip Saldivar, principal of Jefferson High School in Los Angeles. _Rev. T. O'Neal Crivens of Greater Mt. Zion Baptist Church in Memphis, Tenn. _Jeffrey Miller, principal of Thomas Junior High School in Miami. _Ruth Varnado of the Stop the Violence Movement in Milwaukee. _Dalma DeLarosa of the Northwest Bronx Community Clergy Coalition in New York. _Jo Anna Lougin of Oakland Community Organizations in Oakland, Calif. _Dorothy Harell of the Abbottsford Crime Prevention program in Philadelphia. _E. Ray Leary of Self-Enhancement Inc. in Portland, Ore. _Cecilia Estrada, principal of Sherman Elementary School in San Diego. _Joe Marshall of Omega Boys Club in San Francisco. _Jean Veldwyk of the South Seattle Crime Prevention Council in Seattle. _The Rev. Michael Lewis of Faith House Inc. in Tampa, Fla. _Robert Alexander of the Living Stage Theatre Co., Barbara Humphris of Mothers on the Move Spiritually, and Edward Johnson of the Fairlawn Coalition, all of Washington, D.C.

DOC.HEAD: Seven Killed When Police Fire on Demonstrators
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 3rd graf pvs to UPDATE South Africa assisting security forces in Bophuthatswana; INSERTS 1 graf after graf 10, ``Mangope on,'' to UPDATE telephone lines down in homeland ; and SUBS penultimate graf, ``Scattered violence ...'' to UPDATE with Buthelezi meeting with de Klerk.
DOC.TEXT: Seven people were killed Wednesday when police fired on demonstrators in the black homeland of Bophuthatswana, one of several black-ruled territories facing growing unrest, reports said. South African President F.W. de Klerk said his government was concerned the violence in the homelands could hinder efforts to open negotiations on a new constitution that would include the country's black majority. Speaking to journalists in Cape Town, de Klerk said negotiations could not begin if there was ``anarchy'' in black areas. South African Foreign Minster Pik Botha said Wednesday night his government's security forces were providing ``cooperative assistance'' to Bophuthatswana. He did not say specifically whether troops had been sent to the nominally independent homeland, but de Klerk said that step would be taken if necessary. Dozens of blacks have died in recent days during violence in several of South Africa's 10 black homelands. Most of the deaths occurred in the southeastern homeland of Ciskei, where the military staged a coup Sunday. South Africa sent troops into Ciskei on Monday to help quell looting and rioting, and de Klerk said he would take similar action in Bophuthatswana if necessary. In nominally independent Bophuthatswana, police using rifles and tear gas battled some 50,000 protesters demanding the reintegration of the homeland into South Africa. Clouds of smoke hung in the air after protesters set fire to public buildings and vehicles and looted shops in Garankuwa, part of the homeland 12 miles north of Pretoria, South Africa's capital. The Star newspaper of Johannesburg, quoting witnesses and doctors, said at least seven people were killed and up to 500 others suffered various injuries. Protesters called for the resignation of homeland President Lucas Mangope and waved placards denouncing his government. Mangope on Wednesday night declared a state of emergency in several parts of the homeland, which has about 2 million residents scattered over seven separate pieces of land. The independent South Africa Press Association quoted an unidentified homeland official as saying that telephone lines in and out of Bophuthatswana had been cut off ``for political reasons.'' South Africa established the homelands in the 1960s to try to create separate, tribal-based states for blacks, while whites would retain control of national politics and the economy. About 14 million of the country's 28 million blacks live in the territories. Activists in several of the homelands are demanding reintegration into South Africa and calling for the end of white-minority rule in South Africa. Four of the homelands are nominally independent, although no nation but South Africa recognizes them. In Ciskei, South African troops helped restore order Wednesday after three days of rioting and looting that left at least 27 people dead and 550 injured. Dissident officers in the Ciskei military seized power Sunday in a bloodless coup, but chaos erupted shortly afterward. Ciskei industrialists said the rampage that followed the coup had shattered the economy and put 10,000 people out of jobs. Ray Brentnall, head of the Ciskei Chamber of Industries, said rioting caused damage worth millions of dollars, but did not give any overall figure. ``People are very upset. After sweating blood to build up their businesses it's heartbreaking to see them go up in flames,'' he said. Many people in the Ciskei were opposed to the goverment of ousted President Lennox Sebe, whose rule they considered oppressive and corrupt. Sebe was in Hong Kong at the time of the coup. He was expected to arrive in South Africa on Thursday. In other homelands: _ Scattered violence was reported Wednesday in KwaZulu, where supporters of homeland leader Mangosutho Buthelezi have waged a 4-year-old power struggle against groups aligned with the African National Congress guerrilla movement. Buthelezi met with de Klerk on Wednesday for talks on the violence in the southeastern region. _ Government offices, schools, businesses and shops remained closed in the northeastern homeland of Gazankulu as part of a three-week-old protest led by activists demanding the ouster of Chief Minister Hudson Ntsanwisi.

DOC.HEAD: Attack by Sikh Extremists on Crowded Market Kills 22 Hindus
DOC.TEXT: Masked Sikh extremists opened fire with rifles on a crowded market in Punjab state Wednesday night, killing 22 Hindus and wounded 42 others, officials said. At least 10 Sikh gunmen converged on the main market street of Abohar and began shooting, deputy district commissioner Rakesh Singh said in Ferozepur, district headquarters. He said 18 men and one woman were killed instantly. Three more people died on the way to the hospital, he said. Press Trust of India, citing unofficial reports, said about 25 people were killed in the attack. Two bombs planted in the market exploded during the shooting, Singh said. Police suspected more bombs may have been planted along the street and army bomb experts were investigating, he said. He said all the victims were Hindus and most were shopkeepers. Abohar, a predominantly Hindu town with a population of about 96,000, is 125 miles southwest of Chandigarh and 200 miles northwest of New Delhi. A police spokesman in Chandigarh, the state capital, said the men were masked and arrived on foot. ``Nobody knows how they escaped,'' he said, speaking on condition of anonymity. State police chief K.P.S. Gill said the ``assailants resorted to indiscriminate firing followed by bomb blasts.'' Sikh extremists, who have been fighting since 1982 for an independent Sikh nation in Punjab called Khalistan, have killed more than 370 people in the rich northern farming state so far this year. Sikhs, who comprise only 2 percent of India's 880 million people, have a slight majority in Punjab. Sikh militants complain of political discrimination by the Hindus, who make up 82 percent of the nation's population. The Sikh faith has roots in both Hinduism and Islam.

DOC.HEAD: Mourners March for Slain Picketer
With AM-Greyhound-Small Town, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: About 500 mourners, half of them striking Greyhound drivers in uniform, marched Wednesday in memory of a driver crushed to death by a bus at a picket line. The mourners were led by the widow of 59-year-old Robert Waterhouse, who was pinned against a building Saturday, the second day of the nationwide strike, near the Greyhound depot by a bus operated by a replacement driver. An investigation is under way, but no charges have been filed. Walking with the aid of a cane and flanked by two longtime co-workers of her husband, Dorie Waterhouse fought back tears as she led the procession past a dozen parked buses and down the alley where her husband died. ``He was a very gentle and unassuming man,'' Mrs. Waterhouse said. ``This would overwhelm him. This is a tribute to my husband. It has nothing to do with the strike.'' About 50 drivers dropped flowers at the corner where Waterhouse died. The Amalgamated Council of Greyhound Local Unions suspended picketing for the day at the Redding Greyhound terminal. A few non-striking Greyhound workers and passengers in the terminal watched silently from inside. Local union leaders had requested that the funeral march not involve any picket signs except for black armbands that said ``ATU 1225, Bob Waterhouse.'' ``This is a memorial only. That was a unanimous decision,'' said pallbearer Norm Barrington, a driver who worked with Waterhouse for 19 years.

DOC.HEAD: Consumer Credit Rose $3.54 Million in January
DOC.TEXT: Americans took out $3.54 billion more in consumer credit than they retired in January as they flocked to auto dealerships to lock in on newly reinstated sales incentives, the Federal Reserve said Wednesday. The Fed said overall consumer credit advanced at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 5.9 percent following a 7.3 percent gain in December, when holiday shopping was at its peak. Consumer credit includes all consumer loans except mortgages. Credit card debt slowed to a 1.4 percent gain at an annual rate after rising 23.7 percent during the December holiday shopping period. Revolving, or credit card, credit rose just $243 million in January, compared to a $3.94 billion advance in December. It was the lowest increase since a $904 million advance in September. Except for auto sales, sluggish consumer buying as the new year began also was reflected in last week's Commerce Department report, which showed that personal consumption spending slowed from a 1 percent gain in December to a 0.6 percent increase in January. Automobile credit, on the other hand, jumped a seasonally adjusted $1.86 billion, 7.7 percent at an annual rate, after falling 0.4 percent in December before rebates and lower interest rates kicked in. Bank and credit union loans not secured by real estate were up $1.45 billion, a sharp 8.6 percent advance, after a 3 percent gain in December. But outstanding mobile home debt fell $18 million, a 0.9 percent drop and the fourth consecutive monthly decline. Mobile home debt in December was revised Wedensday to a 0.9 percent decrease from the previously reported 1.9 percent increase. That meant that mobile home debt fell in 11 of the last 12 months. September's 2.8 percent gain was the exception. The various changes left total consumer debt at the end of January at $720.1 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Agreement Would Boost Flights Between U.S., Soviet Union
DOC.TEXT: The United States and the Soviet Union plan sharp increases in air service between the two nations, ending cutbacks that began with the 1979 Soviet invasion of Afghanistan, a State Department official said Wednesday. The official said that under a tentative agreement reached in London last week, U.S. airlines would increase scheduled service to Moscow and Leningrad and gain new rights to serve six additional Soviet cities, including two in the Soviet Far East. These cities include Kiev, the capital of the Ukraine; Riga the capital of Latvia; Minsk, the capital of Byelorussia; Tbilsi, the capital of Soviet Georgia; and Magadan and Khabarovsk in the Soviet Far East. Confirming the tentative agreement, State Department spokeswoman Anita Stockman said Soviet airliners would be permitted to increase trans-Atlantic service to New York City and Washington and would gain new rights to serve Chicago and Miami with onward service to two undisclosed points in South America. Soviet air service over the Pacific also would begin to Anchorage, Alaska and to San Francisco with a mandatory stop in Anchorage, the department said. Additionally, both nations would be allowed up to 100 charter flights a year over the Atlantic. Positive consideration also would be given to additional charter flights between the United States and the Soviet Union over the Pacific, she said. Airlines of both nations would also have the right to increase the number of weekly flights and to increase the number of airlines designated to serve the expanded routes. Stockman said the agreement in principle was reached at a second round of negotiations held in London last week to consider expanding the Civil Air Transport Agreement between the two nations. The State Department said a third round of the talks will be convened in London in late April to discuss financial provisions and other remaining issues. Then-President Jimmy Carter ordered the Soviet airline Aeroflot to stop its service to New York after Soviet troops moved into Afghanistan in 1979. In 1981, President Ronald Reagan ordered Aeroflot to terminate its service to Washington, citing Soviet repression in Poland. That halted all Soviet air service to the United States except for Aeroflot flights carrying diplomatic personnel and goods intended for Soviet embassies and consulates. Aeroflot's offices in New York and Washington were ordered closed after the Soviets shot down a Korean passenger liner over the Soviet Union in 1983. Commercial flights between the two nations were resumed in April 1986 with regularly scheduled Aeroflot flights landing here and Pan American Airways flights landing in Moscow. The next year the two nations signed an agreement permitting the expansion of air service beginning in May 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Cult Member Pleads Guilty in Avery Deaths
DOC.TEXT: One of 13 defendants in the cult slayings of a family of five was allowed to plead guilty Wednesday to five reduced counts of murder in return for his promise to testify for the prosecution. Richard E. Brand, 26, of Independence, Mo., was the first to plead guilty in the shooting deaths of a couple and their three daughters, who also were members of the cult. He had been charged with five counts of aggravated murder and five counts of kidnapping, and could have faced the death penalty if convicted. The prosecution says Brand led the victims into a barn at the cult's farm in nearby Kirtland in northeast Ohio, bound them with tape and watched as four of the five were shot. The bodies of Dennis Avery, 49, his wife, Cheryl, 42, and their children _ Trina, 15, Rebecca, 13, and Karen, 7 _ were unearthed from a common grave in the barn Jan. 3-4. Brand told Lake County Common Pleas Judge James W. Jackson that he helped cover up the bodies. Brand told Jackson that cult leader Jeffrey Lundgren recruited him to help with the slayings, and said he considered Lundgren ``a prophet of God.'' ``He informed me I would be helping him in the killings,'' said Brand, standing before the judge in blue jail coveralls and leg irons. The plea could result in a sentence of 75 years to life for Brand, who would serve at least 20 years, said prosecutor Steven LaTourette. ``Justice is served because obviously we now have a valuable witness,'' LaTourette said. The prosecutor said plea bargains with other defendants were possible. Brand pleaded guilty to five counts of murder in return for prosecutors agreeing to drop the aggravated murder and kidnapping counts. LaTourette said his office would agree to seek dismissal of those counts if Brand cooperates as promised. LaTourette has said the family was killed as part of a ``cleansing'' sacrifice before the cult left the Kirtland farm for wilderness treks in West Virginia and Missouri. Lundgren is a defrocked lay minister of the Reorganized Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints. The church is separate from the Salt Lake City-based Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, known as the Mormons, although they share beliefs. Lundgren had been a tour guide at the Kirtland temple. Four members, including Lundgren and his 19-year-old son, Damon Lundgren, were arrested in San Diego. They are fighting extradition. The rest have been brought to Painesville to face charges that include aggravated murder, kidnapping, conspiracy and complicity. Brand, who was facing extradition proceedings, agreed Feb. 5 to return to Ohio from Kansas City, Mo., to face charges. Prosecutors said Brand was known to fellow cult members by the code name ``Talon-1.'' He worked for two years for the nearby city of Mentor as a sewer and drainage inspector.

DOC.HEAD: By-Election, Marred by Violence, Vote Fraud, Countermanded
DOC.TEXT: The Election Commission on Wednesday canceled a Feb. 27 state by-election allegedly rigged by supporters of a top leader of Prime Minister V.P. Singh's party. Chief Election Commissioner R.V.S. Peri Sastry said new voting had been ordered in the Meham constituency in Haryana state. The state's chief minister, Om Prakash Chauthala, was the Janata Dal party candidiate in Meham. Press Trust of India quoted Sastry as saying that the decision was taken because ``the entire electoral process was vitiated.'' Chauthala, who is also the eldest son of Deputy Prime Minister Devi Lal, was linked by newspapers to widespread violence and vote fraud in Meham. At least 13 people were killed in the constituency on Feb. 27-28 when new balloting was conducted in a few voting centers. Several newspapers reported from Meham that Chauthala's supporters allegedly instigated violence and stuffed hundreds of ballot boxes, aided by the state police. Chauthala has denied the charges, saying they are politically motivated. He has also not responded to demands by newspapers and opposition parties that he resign. Most political parties, including the Janata Dal, had asked the Election Commission to order new balloting in Meham. The decision followed investigations by an Election Commission team which returned to New Delhi on Tuesday from Meham, 60 miles northwest of the capital. Chauthala, who was appointed to the chief minister's elected post, was required under Indian electoral laws to seek the voters' mandate to ratify his position. He was named the chief minister after his father resigned from the post to join the federal government as deputy prime minister. The by-election was held along with elections for eight state legislatures and that of a federally controlled territory. Press Trust said the entire election process would have to begin anew, which will take at least 31 days.

DOC.HEAD: Two Want Sovereignty Commission Records Edited
DOC.TEXT: Two participants in the legal fight to open the files of a defunct state segregation agency want a federal appeals court to order the records edited to protect the privacy of people listed in the files. John Salter Jr. of Grand Forks, N.D., and the Rev. Edwin King of Jackson made thet request in a brief filed in the 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in New Orleans. They contend people's reputations would be unnecessarily damaged if the records of the defunct Mississippi Sovereignty Commission are opened without editing. ``The unrestricted release of the documents will destroy privacy rights of hundreds of citizens, and will severely aggravate the harm already suffered as a result of the commission's illegal spying and disruptive activities,'' they said in the brief filed recently by New York City attorney David Goldstein. Salter is a former Tougaloo College professor and King was chaplain there during the 1960s. The commission spied on both men, who were heavily involved in the civil rights struggle. The commission was established in 1956 to fight integration. Gov. Bill Waller vetoed funding for the agency in 1973, and the 1977 Legislature sealed the files until 2027, citing the need to protect the privacy of people named in the documents. U.S. District Judge William H. Barbour Jr. on July 27 ordered the agency's files unsealed, but delayed opening them pending the appeal by King and Salter, who were among the plaintiffs who sued to open the files. King and Salter's appeal seeks to keep private the names of victims and of those who unknowingly aided the commission. Plaintiffs who are seeking to open the files maintain, however, that the effort is a subterfuge to protect certain, unidentified people. King and Salter oppose the release of information they describe as private, saying the commission made claims of homosexuality, drug use or communist affiliations against civil rights activists. In his ruling, Barbour said victims of commission skulduggery could read the records before they were opened and supply any desired response or rebuttal, which would be made part of the permanent files. ``The judge has made it clear he believes state law as it exists protects those (privacy) rights and we find that reasonable,'' said Ken Lawrence, one of the plaintiffs. ``We would have accepted more restrictions, but none of the sort King and Salter are suggesting.''

Here is the 261-160 roll call Wednesday by which the House sustained the veto of the president of a bill which would have set up a commission on the Eastern Airlines labor dispute. A two-thirds vote was required for an override. A ``yes'' vote is a vote to override the veto. Voting yes were 236 Democrats and 25 Republicans. Voting no were 13 Democrats and 147 Republicans. DOC.HEAD: END HOUSE-EASTERN VETO ROLL CALL _ 3 TAKES
Nadia Cancels Speech on Long Island
DOC.TEXT: Nadia Comaneci, apparently upset over the breakup of a personal relationship, canceled a lecture scheduled for Wednesday night, her agent said. The speech, titled ``Vault into Freedom,'' at Nassau Community College on Long Island was to have been the former Olympic gymnast's first U.S. appearance on the lecture circuit, said Mike Lewis, a spokesman for the college. Lewis said Comaneci's agent, Bob Davis of American Program Bureau in Boston, called the college Wednesday to say she would not be attending. Davis told The Associated Press he has not spoken to Comaneci since she left for Tokyo more than a week ago with Constantin Panait, a self-employed roofer who engineered her escape from Romania last December. He said that people in her party have told him that Comaneci and Panait, who has a wife and four children in Florida, had broken up on the way back from Tokyo. He said Comaneci is staying with friends in Montreal, the site of the 1976 Olympics where she won the first perfect scores in Olympics gymnastics history. Panait is on the road, Davis said. A call to Comaneci reached an answering machine. Comaneci said in a recent magazine interview that she and Panait had no plans to marry. She said last month that she intends to marry a 30-year-old fellow Romanian who is expected to enter the United States later this year. ``She was aware of her (speaking) engagement (but) her personal life, I think, has changed,'' Davis said. She was to be paid $7,200 for the speech, which Lewis said would not be rescheduled. The school had spent about $2,400 for preparations and publicity, but did not plan any legal action against Comaneci.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Panel OKs Alaska Forest Bill
DOC.TEXT: The government moved closer to changing its management of Alaska's huge Tongass National Forest on Wednesday when a Senate committee voted unanimously to modify contracts with two timber companies. The bill approved by Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee also calls for increased environmental protections, but does not go as far as the measure already passed by the House. That bill has tougher environmental provisions and would cancel rather than modify the 50-year contracts the government has with Alaska Pulp Co. and Louisiana Pacific-Ketchikan. ``Who would have predicted we would end up with a unanimous 19-0 vote on such a contentious vote as Tongass?'' said Sen. Frank Murkowski, R-Alaska, who has worked to preserve the timber industry's position in the forest. Approval of the bill by the full Senate would send it to a conference committee to work out differences with the House version. Both chambers would then have to vote on the final product. Environmentalists interested in preserving wilderness areas have focused on the forest, which is bigger than some states. But people in the five or so cities or communities that base their economy on the forest's timber don't want the changes, said some Wrangell, Alaska residents who were on hand for the committee action. They said changes will cost the region jobs. The representatives of Alaska Women in Timber said Congress was reneging on its promise to the two companies and at least one of the companies would leave the area if the bill passed. ``When you invest so much of your life in an area, Congress shouldn't dictate `we're going to make some changes, so you are going to have to move,''' said Wilma Leslie, who operates an independent tree-cutting company with her husband. But critics charge the companies have monopolized timber and violated antitrust and labor laws. Supporters of the House version say canceling the 50-year sweetheart deals would open the area to competition from other firms. Provisions in the Senate bill would _delete from the law the $40 million appropriation that goes to Tongass for road-building and other timber sale preparation activities. _end the requirement that the Forest Service provide for sale 4.5 billion board feet of Tongass timber each decade. Instead, the service would be obligated to ``seek to meet market demand for timber.'' _protect hundreds of thousands more acres of land in the 16.7 million-acre forest from logging. _create buffer zones around certain streams to protect fisheries. The contract modifications would make the deals with the two companies conform with independent national forest timber sales and strengthen Forest Service management of the Tongass.

DOC.HEAD: Printing Error Blamed for Listing of 39 Deaths Instead of Two
DOC.TEXT: The State Department said Wednesday a printing error in a recent report caused it to say wrongly that security forces in Northern Ireland killed 39 people in 1989. Actually just two people were kiled by those forces, which include the regular British Army, the Royal Ulster Constabulary and the Ulster Defense Regiment, the department said. The department stood by its statement in the report that 62 people were killed in terrorist incidents in Northern Ireland last year, 23 of whom were members of the security forces. The report is a survey of human rights in all countries that the State Department must submit to Congress each year.

DOC.HEAD: White House Welcomes Kohl's Decision on Poland
With AM-Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl's decision to recognize the current Poland-Germany border is a positive and important step, the White House said Wednesday. ``As the president has made clear, the U.S. recognizes the current German-Polish border'' reaffirmed in the 1975 Helsinki accord signed by 35 nations, said White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater. Those borders were set when Germany was divided by the World War II victors _ the United States, Soviet Union, France and Great Britain. Poland is worried that if Germany is reunified, it would try to retake territory that is now Poland but was part of Germany before the war. Fitzwater said Kohl sent President Bush a message Wednesday telling him of his reversal on the Poland matter.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Refuses to Dismiss Charges as Prosecution Rests Case
DOC.TEXT: A judge Wednesday refused to dismiss charges against Joseph Hazelwood after the prosecution rested its case and the defense offered a new theory on why the former Exxon Valdez skipper should be cleared. Attorney Dick Madson argued that Hazelwood should be acquitted of the charge of operating the vessel while intoxicated because he technically was not in control of the tanker when it went aground March 24, causing the nation's worst oil spill. Basing his argument on case law involving drunken driving, Madson said Hazelwood's decision to go below and turn over control of the bridge to the third mate absolves him from responsibility whether he was drunk or sober. ``The state is charging Captain Hazelwood with being intoxicated and operating a vessel,'' said Madson. ``Under the law for driving while intoxicated, he has to have direct control. ... Nowhere at all can I find a case that an intoxicated person can be convicted of DWI when they do not control the vehicle.'' He drew the analogy to a person who is intoxicated, gets in a cab and tells the driver where to go. If the driver runs a red light and hits a school bus, then the person in the back seat giving directions can not be liable. Assistant District Attorney Brent Cole said Coast Guard regulations clearly require the captain to be sober, no matter where he is on the ship. But the judge noted that Coast Guard regulations do not apply in the trial because Hazelwood is charged under state, law, not federal. Still, Superior Court Judge Karl Johnstone refused to drop the charge, saying ``reasonable minds can differ'' on the allegations. He also declined to dismiss the felony charge of criminal mischief and two other misdemeanors, reckless endangerment and negligent discharge of oil. Johnstone also said he believes the Exxon Valdez was immovably grounded once it hit Bligh Reef and could not have been driven off the reef even if Hazelwood tried. But he said the question remained open whether he will instruct the jury to disregard the skipper's efforts when they consider the charges. Hazelwood's defense opened with testimony from a Valdez flower shop owner who said the master bought flowers to be sent to his hometown of Huntington, N.Y., on March 23, before he sailed. Emily Kaiser said she remembered Hazelwood clearly because she also is from Huntington and they talked at length about their hometown. She said he entered the shop between 2 p.m. and 3 p.m. and put the purchase on a credit card which was recorded at 2:02 p.m. She said he showed no signs of intoxication: ``He was sober.'' The prosecution rested its case after Madson tried to poke holes in an expert's testimony that Hazelwood was drunk while in command of the oil-laden ship. Richard Prouty acknowledged his method of calculating backwards to determine someone's prior level of intoxication is a subject of dispute among experts. He also said his results would have been different had he different facts about Hazelwood's liquor consumption before the captain boarded the tanker. Prouty said he was told by prosecutors that Hazelwood drank five shots of 100-proof vodka in a period of seven hours before boarding the ship the night it ran aground. Prouty, the chief forensic toxicologist with the Oklahoma medical examiner's office, was the state's 45th and final witness in 4{ weeks of testimony. Prouty said he used a combination of figures to ``calculate backwards'' from blood and urine tests done on Hazelwood 10{ hours after the grounding. He said Hazelwood's blood alcohol level would have been 0.14 percent at 12:05 a.m. when the tanker ran aground in Prince William Sound. The legal limit in Alaska for driving a car is 0.10 percent. The Coast Guard has a limit of 0.04 for operating a commercial vessel. Evidence on whether Hazelwood was drunk has been inconclusive, but the issue remains a key factor in the prosecution's effort to prove he was reckless.
