Hazelwood, 43, could get up to 7\ years in prison and $61,000 in fines if convicted on all counts.

DOC.HEAD: Patriarch of Istanbul Dies After Fall
DOC.TEXT: Archbishop Shnork Kaloustian, patriarch of the Armenian Church of Istanbul, died in the Armenian capital of Yerevan early Wednesday after injuring his head in a fall, Armenian sources said. He was 77. Kaloustian fell Tuesday on the steps of the residence belonging to His Holiness Vazken I, head of the Armenian Church, according to the Armenian National Movement's information service. Kaloustian was taken from the home in Etchmiadzin to a hospital in Yerevan, where he died early Wednesday after a three-hour operation, Fatenik Paramajian of the Armenian National Movement said in a telephone interview from Yerevan. The movement is an umbrella group for several grass-roots groups in Armenia.

DOC.HEAD: S&L Withdrawals Last Year a Record $73.6 Billion
DOC.TEXT: Withdrawals from savings institutions accelerated in December, bringing outflows for all of 1989 to a record $73.6 billion, the government said Wednesday. The industry lost $8.6 billion in deposits, excluding interest credited, in December, the Office of Thrift Supervision said. That was the biggest one-month drain since a $8.8 billion outflow in September and the 18th in 19 months. Withdrawals totaled $4.8 billion in November and $6.3 billion in October. Outflows for the full year were the largest on record. The last big outflow, $25.4 billion, occurred in 1981, when interest rates for competing money-market mutual funds skyrocketed above 20 percent at a time when thrift rates were capped by law. Total deposits, with interest credited, declined $16 billion in 1989 to $946 billion. ``What you're seeing now is unprecedented ... but it's not surprising,'' said economist Martin Regalia of the National Council of Savings Institutions. Early in the year, the industry lost deposits in part because S&L problems had shaken customers' confidence. But economists say the shrinkage in the last half of the year is almost entirely a response to tough financial standards in the S&L bailout legislation enacted in August. The rules require thrifts to back their loans with more of their owners' money. Most can't raise the capital and, as a result, must trim their balance sheets. Thrifts shed $25.6 billion in assets in December, with $4.6 billion of that coming at S&Ls under government control and almost three-fourths of the remainder at weakly capitalized thrifts still operating independently. S&L assets at the end of the year totaled $1.25 trillion, down $100 billion or 7.3 percent, from a year earlier. In contrast, commercial bank assets grew 5.4 percent to $3.3 trillion. ``I think the (S&L) downsizing is going to continue throughout 1990 and maybe into 1991 as well, although we might see some ebbing of the pace,'' Regalia said.

DOC.HEAD: Medical Rescue Teams Perform Surgery in Subway Tunnel
With AM-Subway Crash, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Three doctors stood on a train rail and reached up into twisted metal, trying to save a woman's life by amputating her leg. A female doctor, one of the first to arrive at the deadly subway accident Wednesday morning, had to borrow a paramedic's buck knife to amputate the leg of a dead man to free a survior caught underneath. The accident on the Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority subway line sent 20 paramedics and 10 doctors rushing underground. The doctors discovered that all the rescue equipment in the world was useless in some cases. A team of surgeons, Robert Dalsey and Rick Smith of the Medical College of Pennsylvania and Thomas Jefferson University's Murray Cohen, amputated an unidentified woman's right leg when rescue workers could not free her. ``I've never seen anything quite like this,'' said Dalsey. All equipment ``that you could possibly want was there, but it was less than ideal conditions. There was no obvious way to free her.'' Dalsey said the woman was going into shock, unable to communicate with the physicians. She died later at Hahnemann Hospital, one of three dead and more than 160 injured in the derailment. Smith said that working in the tunnel was a unique experience he did not want to repeat. ``As an orthopedic surgeon, I'm used to seeing injuries in a hospital, not in the field,'' he said. The tranist agency shut down all power to the tunnel to prevent electrocutions, leaving medical crews with only portable light. Use of emergency oxygen was out of the question _ the threat of fire was too great. Dr. Jina Joder, an emergency physician at the Medical College, was one of the first physicians to arrive. ``It was dark when I first got there. The medics already there had begun IVs using flashlights (to see), and then the fire crew set up generators and floodlights. Light was probably the biggest problem,'' she said. She said she had to use a paramedics's buck knife to amputate the leg of a dead man to free a man caught underneath him. Her hospital contracts with the city to train to the Fire Department's paramedics, and provides physicians to direct paramedics in the field, according to hospital trauma program coordinator, Cindy Blank. Jefferson dispatched a four-person surgical team, the ``Jeff State'' team, to the crash site to work with five surgeons and three emergency medicine fellows from the Medical College, according to hospital spokeswoman Betsy Samuels. At the emergency room of the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania, a team of more than 100 physicians and more than 50 nurses treated more than 40 patients, according to Dr. Sheldon Jacobson, director of emergency medicine. More than four hours after the accident, Jacobson said, the emergency room was finally ``almost back to normal.''

DOC.HEAD: Moslems Ambush Truck Carrying Security Forces
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS two grafs after 7th `At least...' to UPDATE with parties to send delegation to Kashmir; pickup graf 8 `Jagmohan said....' One name for Gov. Jagmohan is cq.
DOC.TEXT: Moslems blew up a truck carrying security forces Wednesday, killing three soldiers in the few hours the government relaxed a curfew designed to stop the Kashmiri separatist uprising, officials said. In separate incidents, militants shot and killed a Moslem they said was a police informer and a Moslem died after he was caught in an exchange of fire between militants and security forces, officials said. Also Wednesday, Moslem snipers fired on security forces in three parts of Srinagar during a five-hour relaxation of curfew, said Gov. Jagmohan of Jammu-Kashmir state. There were no casualties, he said. The curfew was relaxed from 5 a.m. to 10 a.m. to allow people in the city of 1 million to shop for food and other essentials. An around-the-clock curfew was imposed Friday after security forces the day before shot and killed 49 Moslem demonstrators marching into Srinagar to take part in a pro-independence rally. At least 1 million Moslems demonstrated to demand independence for the predominantly Moslem state; India is predominantly Hindu. Srinagar, the summer capital of Jammu-Kashmir, is the center of the separatist movement. At least 171 people have been killed in Kashmir since a government crackdown on the separatist movement began on Jan. 20. Leading national parties decided Wednesday to send a ``high-powered delegation'' to Srinagar, according to the Press Trust of India news agency. It did not name the members, but it said they would go Thursday. The decision was taken at the end of a daylong multiparty meeting on Kashmir called by Prime Minister V.P. Singh. A joint statement after the meeting said ``despite their ideological and political differences, (the parties) were one in defending the unity and integrity of the country,'' the news agency reported. Jagmohan said the truck was driving around Srinagar distributing food to troops on street corners when it was blown up by Moslem militants. He gave no further details of the attack. The attacks came amid government claims that security forces arrested at least 12 leaders of the Moslem group Hezbul Mujahedeen. Jagmohan said the militants, from Srinagar and the border towns of Baramulla and Kupwara, have been arrested since Sunday. Hezbul Mujahedeen is one of 30 militant groups fighting for secession. It is believed the second most powerful independence group after the Jammu-Kashmir Liberation Front. ``We are going to hit hard at anti-national elements, there is no way they can get away with what they are doing,'' Jagmohan said. ``It may take a month, six months, maybe a year, but ultimately these anti-national elments are going to be neutralized.'' Jagmohan, a Hindu, was appointed the state governor of Jammu-Kashmir on Jan. 18 in an attempt by the government to control the unrest. Kashmir has been a problem for more than four decades following the 1947 partition of British colonial India into predominantly Moslem Pakistan and the mostly Hindu India. Jammu-Kashmir, then a princely state, chose to merge with India. Pakistan protested, claiming the territory because of its predominantly Moslem population. The two countries have twice gone to war over the territory. The Kashmir portion of Jammu-Kashmir is mostly Moslem, while the southern Jammu segment is predominantly Hindu. Overall, about 65 percent of the state's 6 million people are Moslem. Nationwide, Moslems make up 12 percent of India's 880 million people and Hindus account for 82 percent.

DOC.HEAD: China May Extend Military Training of Students
With AM-China-Students
DOC.TEXT: A senior education official said Wednesday that China may extend to other institutions a program in which Beijing University students were sent to a military academy to build discipline. The university's freshman class of about 800 students was sent to an academy in Hebei, south of the capital, for training that the official press said included firing guns and throwing grenades. Beijing University played a major role last spring in the student-led pro-democracy movement, which was crushed by the military, and the school was singled out by the government as it acted to prevent a repeat of the movement. On Wednesday, Teng Teng, vice chairman of the state education commission, said of the military training program, ``If the experiment works out, we can apply it to other institutions.'' Teng spoke with reporters at Jomtien, near Bangkok, where he was attending an international conference on education. He said that besides receiving military training, the Beijing University students who participated also worked in factories and on farms. The aim was to bring students into contact with soldiers, workers and farmers ``to let them know what the realities are,'' Teng said. He said the program has had mixed results. ``Some of the effect is sound and some not so favorable,'' Teng said without elaborating. But he added, ``It has greatly enhanced discipline among students.'' Teng said sending Chinese students to study in Europe and Japan had worked out fairly well. But he complained that North America kept the students, instead of their returning to work in China to repay its investment in them. Teng said students should be free to express whatever political views they hold but should not resort to ``radicalism.'' ``Democracy can only be pursued on a gradual basis,'' he said. ``If education works well it can promote democracy. But if we overstress the role of democracy it can give rise to riots and chaos.'' He said China wanted to improve its grade school system and provide nine years of education for people in the coastal provinces and at least six years for those in remoter inland areas. China also wants to place more emphasis on scientific and technical teaching in colleges, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Winter Weather In The Upper Midwest
DOC.TEXT: Snow and freezing rain spread across the upper Midwest on Wednesday, and rain fell south and east of the snow belt from Texas into Illinois. At midday, snow fell from central South Dakota to western Nebraska, southeastern Wyoming and northern Colorado. Freezing rain extended from north-central and eastern South Dakota to southeastern Minnesota and much of Iowa, with rain over central and eastern Nebraska. Winter storm watches were in effect through Thursday across southern Minnesota and central and northern Wisconsin. Showers and thunderstorms extended from Missouri to northern and eastern Kansas, eastern Oklahoma, central through northeastern Texas, Arkansas, western Tennessee, western Kentucky and southern Illinois. Rain also fell over the Pacific Northwest, changing to snow at higher elevations. Heavier rainfall during the six hours up to noon CST included 1.94 inches at Waco, Texas; 1.14 inches at Killeen, Texas; and 1.10 inches at El Dorado and Hot Springs, Ark. Record lows Wednesday were 10 degrees at Bridgeport, Conn.; 7 at Hartford, Conn.; and 13 at Newark, N.J. Binghamton, N.Y., tied its record of 1 degree and Providence, R.I., tied its record of 10. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EST ranged from 15 degrees at Limestone, Maine, to 83 at Brownsville, Texas. Wednesday's low for the Lower 48 states was 18 below zero at Houlton, Maine, and Saranac Lake, N.Y.

DOC.HEAD: Inflation Up Third Year in Row in US, Other Major Countries
DOC.TEXT: Inflation speeded up in the United States and other major industrial countries in 1989 for the third year in a row, the International Monetary Fund reported Wednesday. Prices paid by consumers in the seven industrial countries rose an average of 4.4 percent compared with 3.4 percent in 1988, 3 percent in 1987 and 2.4 percent in 1986. The fund calculated prices in the United States increased their rise from 1.9 percent in 1986 to 4.8 percent last year. The fund said last year's overall increase last year was ``relatively moderate compared with the average annual increase of about 7.9 percent registered during the period 1970-85.'' Britain showed the biggest rise, to 7.8 percent, from 3.4 percent three years earlier, according to the report in the fund's monthly ``IMF Memorandum.'' The increase was also high in Italy, although complete figures were not in. By last August, Italy was showing a 6.3 percent annual inflation rate, compared with 5.1 percent for 1988. Japan, which had only a 0.6 percent inflation rate in 1986, showed the smallest increase in 1989 at 2.3 percent. West Germany had a 2.8 percent inflation rate last year, the fund said. Prices in France increased 3.5 percent in 1989 and Canada had a 5.2 annual inflation rate through November, the last month for which the fund had figures. The fund reported a continued rapid rise in prices for consumers in Third World countries, though only partial figures for 1989 were available. It reported an average annual rate of 89.8 percent for 130 countries in August 1989, compared with 58.7 percent in 1988 and 26.7 percent in 1986. The western hemisphere, where figures were available for the entire year, led the Third World with an average increase of 334.6 percent, far more than the annual rate of 82.4 percent in 1986. Prices in developing nations in the western hemisphere have risen 11,677 percent since 1985, the fund said. That rise was heavily influenced by rates by Brazil, which accounts for a third of Latin America's economy. Prices paid by Brazilians rose 1,287 percent in 1989 after inflation of 682 percent in 1988. Argentina's inflation was even faster, reaching an annual rate of 3,967 percent last August. Developing countries in Asia were much more successful in holding down prices. South Korean prices rose 5.7 percent last year, less than the year before. Most Asian countries appeared able to keep inflation in single digits, though the fund had no figure to show what happened after China reported 20.7 percent in 1988.

DOC.HEAD: President Proclaims All Americans Should Answer Census
EDs. Adds 2 grafs end with cost of Census, Mosbacher comment
DOC.TEXT: President Bush issued a proclamation Wednesday asking everybody who lives in the United States to truthfully answer all questions on the 1990 Census. The Census Bureau is mailing out questionnaires March 23 to all American households in its decennial head-counting exercise. Bush quoted Abraham Lincoln as saying, ``If we could just know where we are and whither we are tending, we could better judge what to do and how to do it.'' ``The census helps to provide us with such insight,'' said Bush. The Census Bureau has enlisted 425,000 workers to ring doorbells, canvass householders and even tally the homeless on big-city streets. The forms by law must be filled out and returned by April 1, the official ``Census Day.'' The U.S. population has just passed the 250 million mark, according to the latest Census estimate. There were only 3.9 million Americans in 1790 when U.S. marshals carried out the first Census under the direction of then-Secretary of State Thomas Jefferson, Bush noted. This will be the 21st census. ``Each decennial census has helped to chart the growth and change experienced by our vast country during the past 200 years,'' said Bush. The primary purpose today, as in 1790, is to fix the state population totals that determine the number of seats each state gets in the House of Representatives. Bush said it also now serves to help reshape voting districts for state and local governments, and plays an essential role in allocating billions of dollars for education, health care, crime prevention, transportation and other purposes. The information will help the government and private sector make ``critical decisions as we prepare to enter the 21st century,'' Bush said. ``It is the responsibility and obligation of every person who usually resides in the United States to take part in the 1990 Census of Population and Housing by truthfully answering all questions on the census forms applying to him or her and to each member of the household to which he or she belongs,'' the president proclaimed. Bush also assured the skittish the census results won't be released in any way ``that will identify or harm any person or household.'' That means they cannot be used for tax-collection purposes, by immigration authorities, for jury service or similar intrusive purposes. The census is expected to cost $2.5 billion, a figure driven up in part by an expected drop in the number of Americans who respond by mail. Fewer mail responses means the Census Bureau has to do more work to contact people. Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher said, ``The U.S. taxpayers can save $10 million for every 1 percent of the population that responds by mail.'' Nearly 81 percent responded by mail to the 1970 Census and 75 percent in 1980. Census officials fear only 70 percent will respond by mail this time.

DOC.HEAD: Aid Official Welcomes Thai Decision to Open Neutral Camp
DOC.TEXT: A senior Western aid official Wednesday welcomed the government's decision to establish a neutral camp for more than 275,000 Cambodian refugees now under control of three guerrilla groups. The guerrilla-run camps will be closed and the refugees sent to the neutral grounds in preparation for their return home when the 11-year-old war in Cambodia ends. The deputy government spokesman, Likhit Hongladarom, said the Cabinet made the decision at its weekly session Tuesday. The United Nations Border Relief Operation and the U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees, which aid the camps along Thailand's eastern border with Cambodia, have long favored establishing a neutral camp. An unaffiliated camp would protect the refugees from being forcibly repatriated by the guerrillas, or pressured to go to certain areas of their homeland. ``We welcome the idea of starting the preparations for repatriation,'' said the senior aid official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. But he warned that guerrilla leaders may respond by quickening their own repatriation of the refugees, without U.N. supervision. Aid officials say thousands of civilians under Khmer Rouge guerrilla control have been moved out of the refugee camps in recent months and resettled in strategic areas. The refugee camps were established shortly after Vietnam invaded Cambodia in late 1978 and ousted the brutal Khmer Rouge regime, sending hundreds of thousands of people fleeing to the Thai border. The three guerrilla groups _ the Khmer Rouge, the Khmer People's National Liberation Front and the forces of Prince Norodom Sihanouk _ have used the camps for military recruitment and to back their claims to have a popular following. In briefing reporters on the Cabinet meeting, Likhit said Tuesday that a neutral camp was needed because the refugees have caused numerous problems for Thailand, particularly with security. ``The Thai government is not happy with the situation and has therefore decided to close all refugee centers and to replace them with a neutral camp, which is to be set up with United Nations cooperation in the form of an assistance budget to feed the refugees,'' he said. He said the Foreign Ministry has been instructed to contact the Vietnamese-installed government in Phnom Penh, Cambodia's capital, and urge it to take back the refugees. Likhit also said Tuesday that Prime Minister Chatichai Choonhavan will also ask other nations to stop supplying the Cambodian factions with weapons.

DOC.HEAD: Panel Hears Disagreements on U.S. Role in Afghanistan
DOC.TEXT: The Reagan administration's top specialist on Afghanistan said Wednesday that the United States has become entangled in internal Afghan politics and that it must stop arming the Mujahedeen rebels. Robert Peck, the State Department's chief analyst on Afghanistan until last June, testified before two House subcommittees debating the advisability of continued military support for the rebels. ``What disturbs me most about the American role in all this is the degree to which the United States has become involved in what are essentially internal Afghan affairs,'' Peck said. However, Assistant Secretary of State John Kelly said the United States was determined to keep supporting the Mujahedeen until Soviet-installed President Najib is removed. Despite Bush administration predictions that the rebels would defeat Najib once the Soviets pulled out of Afghanistan in February 1989, the sides have been locked in a military stalemate. State Department officials are examining the direction of U.S. policy in light of the stalemate, but the administration is under strong pressure from many in Congress to maintain the aid program for the rebels. Kelly rejected suggestions from Rep. Stephen Solarz, D-N.Y., that the United States and Soviet Union negotiate a mutual halt to arming the warring sides. Najib enjoys an advantage over the Mujahedeen in terms of arsenals provided by the Soviet Union _ more than $300 million a month _ and a cutoff of weapons would give him an unfair advantage, Kelly said. The United States provides the Mujahedeen weapons, including anti-aircraft Stinger missiles, through Pakistan. The program is covert and reportedly costs $300 million to $400 million a year. Saudi Arabia and several other countries also give money. The United States, Kelly said, also is pushing for a political settlement that would include convening a summer leadership council of all opposition elements from Afghanistan. Representatives of the council would negotiate with residents of Afghan cities controlled by Najib's forces about forming a new government through elections, Kelly said. The United States is determined to exclude Najib from the process and believes the Soviets can persuade him to step down, Kelly said. Peck said that the main U.S. task is to negotiate with the Soviets an end to foreign arms supplies, but in such a way that would deny Najib an unfair advantage. Kelly said the United States does not have much information about this week's coup attempt against Najib launched by renegade military officers, in part because U.S. Embassy personnel were withdrawn from Kabul last year. He said the United States did not have advance word about the attempted coup.

DOC.HEAD: Navy Plans No Cutback in Trident Nuclear Sub Program
DOC.TEXT: The Navy plans no reductions in the Trident nuclear submarine program despite the warming of East-West relations, the Navy's top submarine officer told a congressional panel Wednesday. Vice Adm. Daniel L. Cooper told the House Seapower Subcommittee that the Navy plans to build a total of 24 submarines at a rate of one per year. ``Has the (Soviet) threat really changed?'' Cooper asked. ``As we look at the Navy, we see no change,'' he answered. Cooper, the assistant chief of naval operations for undersea warfare, said the Trident program the only leg of the nation's nuclear triad of bombers, missiles and submarines that has been modernized. Cooper also said that with improvements in submarine communications, nuclear submarines will be able to shoulder a larger share of the nation's strategic defense burden. Cooper's remarks were the first public affirmation since President Bush submitted his budget in January that the Navy is sticking to its plan of building one Trident per year at a cost of about $1.2 billion each. Navy sources had said prior to the budget announcement that the Trident program might be cut back to one every other year. But slowing down Trident production, Cooper said, ``would have a very great impact. One, I think, the cost of of a Trident submarine would go up 10 to 15 percent. ... I strongly recommend that we continue buying one a year.''

DOC.HEAD: Jackie Onassis Ends 10-Year Land Dispute with Wampanoag Indians
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf, `The new ...,' to CORRECT name to `Zack's Cliff,' sted `Vack's Cliff'.
DOC.TEXT: Jacqueline Onassis agreed Wednesday to give a group of Wampanoag Indians a plot of land and $100,000 in exchange for a tiny beachfront site, ending an acrimonious 10-year dispute over the property. The case pitted Mrs. Onassis' desire for privacy against the Indians' belief that they should retain tribal lands on Martha's Vineyard. ``After all this time I'm just happy the land was settled,'' said Selma Weissberg, one of the 25 descendants of William Vanderhoop, a Wampanoag who lived in the area in the 1870s and owned the 1.5-acre plot. ``I've lived on the island all my life and I'm happy that we have some of our land back.'' The agreement was ratified by Judge John S. Macdougall Jr. in Dukes County Probate Court. At issue was a 1.5-acre section of land surrounded by Onassis' estate but owned primarily by the Wampanoags, a tribe that has lived at the picturesque cliffs of Gay Head for centuries. The tribe considers the land sacred. The Wampanoags believe the tract is the last resting place of the great chief Moshup and his wife, Squant. Tribal lore holds it was there that Moshup threw his children into the sea when he foresaw the coming of the white man. The new plot of land is about two acres, with a 250-foot ocean frontage, at Zack's Cliff in Gay Head. In 1980, Mrs. Onassis obtained one-sixth interest in the 1.5-acre plot, and sought to buy the remaining five-sixths from the 25 descendants of Vanderhoop. She wanted to close access to the parcel and keep beachgoers and tourists away from her 400-acre property. But the Wampanoags resisted and a series of lawsuits and countersuits followed. According to the terms of the agreement signed Wednesday, the Wampanoags will surrender title and access to the 1.5-acre site in exchange for $100,000 and the larger section of beachfront 1,500 feet closer to the nearest road. Mrs. Onassis also will pay all costs related to the land transfer and the Indians agreed to drop all suits pending in the matter. ``This way, everybody wins,'' said attorney Paul Sulla, who represented the Wampanoags. ``Until now, they've always been asked to move from their land and given money. Now they've gotten some land in exchange.'' Brian Hurley, one of Mrs. Onassis attorneys, said: ``She's just pleased to have resolved this long matter and hopes to continue being good neighbors. She wants to put it behind her.'' Since 1974, various Wampanoags have regained about 400 acres of what they consider tribal land on Martha's Vineyard through a series of federal lawsuits. They claimed that the 1790 Indian Non-Intercourse Act, which forbids transfer of Indian lands without federal approval, was violated in the 1870s when the state redistributed tribal lands to other island residents. The Wampanoags have maintained a tribal structure for more than 370 years, according to tribal council president Donald Widdiss, but they did not receive federal recognition until 1987. There are only 250 Wampanoags left at Gay Head, and only 630 total in the nation.

DOC.HEAD: Israel's Labor Party Extends Ultimatum on Peace Plan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with demonstration, quotes, details. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Ministers of the left-leaning Labor Party on Wednesday extended an ultimatum for quitting the coalition government, giving Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's Likud bloc four more days to approve U.S. peace proposals. About 2,500 right-wing demonstrators and Jewish settlers, by police estimate, gathered in downtown Jerusalem Wednesday, demanding that Shamir reject the proposals for Israeli-Palestinian talks put forward by U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III. They held signs saying: ``Israel is not for sale,'' and ``People of the Bible are returning to the land of the Bible.'' Youths wearing knitted skullcaps danced in circles. A donkey carrying an effigy of Baker stood nearby. The crowd included settlers from the occupied West Bank and members of such right-wing and nationalist parties as Tehiya, Moledet and Tzomet. Thwarted in their plans to march to Shamir's residence, some gathered instead at the U.S. Consulate. Others walked the streets with burning torches. Labor ministers announced the extension after the Inner Cabinet failed to decide on the U.S. proposals in a two-hour meeting and postponed a vote until Sunday. If Baker's proposals are not approved then, Labor's Central Committee will meet Monday with a recommendation that the party quit, toppling the 15-month-old government, Labor officials said. ``If Shamir uses some delay trick Sunday, we will view it as a negative answer and respond as we have decided,'' Labor legislator Chaim Ramon warned. Energy Minister Moshe Shahal of Labor predicted Shamir's Cabinet would fall, saying: ``I don't think there is any possibility of getting Likud to change their minds.'' However, the extra time gives Shamir breathing room to negotiate a compromise with Labor's leader, Vice Premier Shimon Peres. In an Israel Television interview, Peres said Wednesday's extension was the last he was willing to grant Shamir. ``I think we have reached the end. He asked for two more days, fine, I would not break the government apart over that. But if the prime minister thinks he can prolong it on Sunday too ... that is a mistake,'' Peres said. ``I think the countdown has started, and Likud ministers have decided to put an end to the coalition government.'' Peres said Labor ``may form a narrow government, go to opposition or to new elections. I'm not promising anything.'' Some Labor leaders are hesitant about withdrawing from the government, notably Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin, Labor's No. 2 man. ``Maybe till Sunday reason would prevail in each camp,'' Rabin said during a tour of northern Israel. Labor's Cabinet Minister Mordechai Gur expressed the same hope: ``I dare to say that reason will indeed prevail and we will be able to find a common formula,'' he said on Israel army radio. At Wednesday's Cabinet session, Labor and Likud leaders argued heatedly over Baker's proposals that call on Israel to agree to including east Jerusalem Arabs and Palestinians deported by Israel in preliminary peace talks planned for Cairo. The suggestions are a compromise with Palestinian demands for direct PLO involvement in the talks, which Israel strongly opposes. Shamir opened the Cabinet meeting by reporting on a telephone call from Baker on March 1. ``What about the decision of the Israeli government?'' Shamir quoted Baker as asking, according to Israel radio. ``The issue is serious, we still have to think,'' Shamir said he replied. Foreign Minister Moshe Arens of Likud said Baker also refused to back fully the Israeli withdrawal from Cairo talks if Palestinian negotiators announce they represent the Palestine Liberation Organization, Israel army radio reported. ``You will have to trust us,'' Arens said Baker told him at last month's talks in Washington, to which Arens replied: ``We cannot trust you in the issue of PLO.'' According to Shahal, Peres read out Baker's proposals and demanded a vote. Likud leaders balked, and Shamir said they would continue discussions Sunday and then vote, Shahal added. The radio said the focus of debate was on involving 140,000 East Jerusalem Arabs in the Israeli elections plan for the occupied lands, seen as part of an interim settlement of self-rule for Palestinians. The elections are expected to be the focus of the planned Cairo talks. ``If East Jerusalem Arabs participate in the vote, is it not tantamount to our agreeing to the division of Jerusalem?'' Arens said in the meeting, according to Israel radio. Peres reportedly responded by chiding Arens: ``So you agree to let Arabs in Nablus (the West Bank's largest town) into the delegation. Does that mean you are ready to give up Nablus? This already is progress.'' Hard-liners in Likud fear allowing East Jerusalem Arabs to vote will raise questions about Israel's annexation of the sector after it was captured in the 1967 Middle East War. At least 659 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians in the 27-month-old Palestinian uprising in the occupied lands, and 43 Israelis have died.

DOC.HEAD: Congressmen Say Northrop Plea Bargain ``Inexcusable''
DOC.TEXT: The government's plea bargain agreement with the Northrop Corp., on alleged violations of defense contracting procedures is ``utterly inexcusable,'' two congressmen said Wednesday. Reps. Christopher Shays, R-Conn., and Peter Smith, R-Vt., called on the House Government Operations subcommittee on legislation and national security to hold hearings on Northrop's agreement. ``We think this kind of activity on the part of our prosecutors and court system, let alone the government, is utterly inexcusable and indicates the potential for collusion,'' Shays and Smith said in a letter. Northrop pleaded guilty last month to 34 federal counts related to falsified testing of parts for the AV-8B Harrier jet and cruise missile components, and agreed to a $17 million fine. In the plea bargain, the defense contractor entered guilty pleas through attorney Richard Sauber to making false statements to the government. The two congressmen said whistleblowers have alleged as much as $20 billion was lost or stolen during the classified phase of the B-2 stealth bomber program. Northrop manufactures the radar-evading plane. ``Northrop, as you also know, has a long and some say one of the worst, records with regard to compliance with federal regulations when it comes to procurement and acquisition,'' Shays and Smith said. On Feb. 27, the day of the agreement, the Los Angeles-based Northrop issued a statement, saying: ``The U.S. government and Northrop Corporation reached a complex compromise today under which the government agreed to withdraw various charges the company had been contesting for over a year, and Northrop in turn agreed to pay a $17 million fine for charges arising out of actions by some employees it subsequently fired in 1987 from its now closed Western Services Department.''

DOC.HEAD: Washington Gives $25 Million in Emergency Aid to Panama
DOC.TEXT: The United States on Wednesday agreed to provide $25.1 million in emergency aid to Panama to help it rebuild from the American invasion, but President Guillermo Endara asked for more. Wednesday's agreement was the first in a series of aid packages the Bush administration plans for Panama. It is trying to revive the economy, which suffered from a decade of rule by Manuel Antonio Noriega and from economic sanctions the United States imposed trying to force the general from power. Endara and U.S. Ambassador Deane R. Hinton signed the aid agreement at the Metropolitan Cathedral. The president, installed by the U.S. forces on Dec. 20, is in the seventh day of a hunger strike there to protest an attempt by some U.S. congressmen to cut overall aid for Panama. ``This isn't much, but it's a beginning,'' Hinton told Endara during the signing ceremony. ``Let's hope the rest comes as soon as possible,'' Endara replied. Under the agreement, the U.S. Agency for International Development will provide $25.1 million within 150 days for projects, mainly to repair damage caused by the invasion. Of that total, $13.6 million will be distributed in cash to about 1,500 families left homeless as a result of fires during the fighting in Panama City's El Chorrillo district. The money has been set aside so they can purchase new housing. About $7 million will provide temporary jobs to 3,000 people for up to three months repairing roads and other public facilities and for projects to protect the environment. The work includes repairing public schools, drain pipes, a building to house the Supreme Court of Justice and reforestation. Another $4.5 million will go for technical assistance and the purchase of government equipment. Among Panama's most pressing problems are a housing shortage and lack of jobs. Endara, 53, began his hunger strike March 1 at the Cathedral, announcing he was acting ``in solidarity with my fellow citizens in Panama who suffer malnutrition because of poverty.'' Although he made no explicit mention of U.S. aid, he hinted he was also protesting efforts led by Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., to cut sharply the $500 million in Panamanian aid requested by President Bush. For a few days in September, Endara, then a leading opposition member, also staged a hunger strike. At that time, he was protesting police brutality under Noriega, whom he replaced with the support of U.S. forces. Noriega is now in Miami where he faces drug charges. Endara was leading last May's national elections by a 3-1 margin when Noriega annuled the vote-counting.

DOC.HEAD: Nelson Mandela Honored in Tanzania
DOC.TEXT: Black nationalist leader Nelson Mandela thanked Tanzania on Wednesday for helping his African National Congress in its fight against South Africa's white government. More than 40,000 people gathered in a stadium to honor the ANC deputy president, who last month was freed after 27 years in prison in South Africa. Mandela arrived from Harare, Zimbabwe, on Tuesday. Thousands of exiled ANC members live in Tanzania and most are to return home by the end of the year. The Pretoria government recently legalized the ANC and other anti-apartheid groups, legitimizing them for the first time in 30 years. Mandela told the rally in Dar Es Salaam the ANC had asked Tanzania's ruling party for help with grass-roots organizing. He noted the party's organizational strength through committees and political leaders in each of the East African nation's neighborhoods and villages. ``We are hopeful our request will be met,'' Mandela said, indicating he hoped the ANC could build a similar organization in South Africa. On the second of his six days in Tanzania, Mandela also thanked former President Julius Nyerere for helping the ANC and other movements. He referred to the Front for the Liberation of Mozambique, the Zimbabwe National Union and Zimbabwe African People's National Union, Namibia's South-West Africa People's Organization and the Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola. All of the groups operated from Tanzania at one time or another. Mandela said the first ANC guerrillas to take up the armed struggle for black majority rule in South Africa were trained in Tanzania nearly 30 years ago and their camps remain in the country. He said Tanzania ``again opened its doors'' when the ANC was forced to evacuate its fighters from Angola following a U.S.-brokered agreement between South Africa, Angola and Cuba that called for Namibia's independence. The South African territory is scheduled to become independent on March 21. Tanzania has never publicly acknowledged the existence of the guerrilla camps, saying only that South African refugees were in its territory. On Thursday, Mandela was to fly to the semi-autonomous island of Zanzibar, then return to the mainland town of Iringa, where Western diplomats say there are between 3,000 and 4,000 ANC guerrillas in five secret camps. The rally at the national stadium began with Prime Minister Joseph Warioba bestowing on Mandela the Order of the Torch of Kilimanjaro, 2nd Class. The medal is named after Africa's highest peak, which rises to a height of 19,200 feet in northern Tanzania. The only other foreigner to receive the honor was the late Mozambique President Samora Machel, who waged a guerrilla war against the Portuguese colonists in his homeland from southern Tanzania. Earlier, local authorities in Dar es Salaam made Mandela an honorary citizen of the city and renamed one of its major thoroughfares Nelson Mandela Expressway.

DOC.HEAD: Methane Leading Suspect In Fatal Bank Explosion
LaserPhoto Staffing
DOC.TEXT: A buildup of methane gas emerged Wednesday as the suspected cause of an explosion that leveled a bank, killing three employees and injuring 14 other people, authorities said. Preliminary autopsy results released earlier Wednesday discounted a bomb as the cause of the explosion Tuesday at the Crested Butte State Bank in this Rocky Mountain ski resort town. Seven people remained hospitalized in Grand Junction and Gunnison, three in serious condition. Montrose pathologist Dr. Mike Benzinger said he discounted a bomb as a cause after examining preliminary results of autopsies on the three dead women. There were no marks on the victims' bodies to indicate explosives were involved, Benzinger said. The blast, which occurred as the bank was opening for business, leveled the two-story brick building, reducing everything except the vault to rubble. The victims were identified as Donna Smith, 33; Jade Woelk; and Monica Henning, all of Crested Butte. The ages of the other victims were not available. State and local investigators would not speculate further on the cause of the explosion until federal investigators began examining the site. U.S. Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms personnel began arriving Wednesday. Methane as the cause ``is my most fervent hope,'' said Hank Smith, police chief in Mount Crested Butte. ``We'll wait for confirmation from ATF and then we'll call the mine inspectors.'' Methane is odorless and colorless, detectable only by hand-held instruments, said Bill Denning, an inspector with the U.S. Mine Safety and Health Administration in Denver. Denning said it was possible that coal beds beneath or around the town might be producing methane, as could an abandoned and sealed mine in the vicinity. Methane also is found in landfills because it is the product of decomposing organic material, Denning said. A spark is needed to ignite methane, said Denning, and ``there would be an abundance of potential spark sources'' in the bank. ``Sometimes all it takes is a light switch,'' he said. Workers on Wednesday opened a temporary bank next door to the explosion site. The staff included an injured executive vice president and a retired bank employee. The rest of the town tried to resume normal business operations. ``It's hard to watch people on vacation when you're in a tragedy,'' said Hope Ostheimer, a clerk in an office supply store. ``It's hard to hear them complain about not getting their checks cashed. Some are real sensitive, but others aren't, and then there are the ones who dug through the rubble with all the rest of us yesterday trying to find our friends. ``I guess I'm just angry. You feel so enraged because you don't know what happened yet. You just know they're dead and hurt,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Gunmen Slay Prominent Liberal Journalist in Turkey
DOC.TEXT: Two masked men Wednesday shot and killed a prominent liberal journalist who was an outspoken critic of terrorism and Moslem fundamentalists. Hours later an unknown Islamic group claimed responsibility for killing Cetin Emec and his driver. Emec, 55, was a board member and columnist of Turkey's largest circulation newspaper, Hurriyet. Witnesses said the assailants opened fire as Emec was getting into his car near his home to go to work. The driver, Sinan Ercan, started running but was fatally shot in the back, said Istanbul police chief Hamdi Ardali. He said Emec was struck by seven bullets. In his last column, published Wednesday, Emec expressed alarm at the resurgence of terrorism in Turkey. He accused Syria of supporting terrorist groups in the region and claimed Syrian leaders were behind the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 over Scotland in December 1988. A group calling itself the Union of Turkish Islamic Commandos telephoned Hurriyet and two other Turkish dailies to claim responsibility for Emec's slaying. The caller, speaking Turkish, said: ``We killed Emec and now it is your turn. We will kill you one by one,'' according to Hurriyet editors. The caller to the newspaper Gunaydin said: ``We killed him because he was an enemy of Islam.'' President Turgut Ozal denounced the attack. ``The assailants and the treacherous people behind them should know that they will not succeed in ruining the calm and stability of our country with terrorism,'' he said. Turkish journalist associations said Thursday editions of Istanbul's major dailies would be printed with black mastheads, instead of the usual red, in mourning. Emec, the son of a newspaper publisher, was known for his liberal and secular views and often criticized the Moslem fundamentalist minority in Turkey. Close friends, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Emec had received threats and hate mail recently from Islamic groups.

DOC.HEAD: Dunne Questioned on Club Memberships, Stock Holdings
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's nominee to the nation's top civil rights enforcement job came under fire Wednesday, but a Democratic senator said it appeared likely John R. Dunne would be confirmed. ``I'm not sure President Bush would appoint anybody better than you,'' Sen. Howard Metzenbau, D-Ohio, told Dunne. ``Regardless of how I vote, you're going to be confirmed.'' Dunne, 60, was tapped in January to be assistant attorney general for civil rights. The post has been vacant since December 1988 when William Bradford Reynolds resigned. The former New York state senator was questioned Wednesday about his long membership in two private clubs that barred women and about his investments in companies that do business in South Africa. ``If you had it to do ever again, in retrospect, do you think you might have taken a different course of conduct?'' Metzenbaum asked in regard to joining the all-male clubs. ``I believe I would have,'' Dunne replied. Dunne became a member of the Long Island Garden City Golf Club in 1957, quitting when his nomination to the civil rights post appeared imminent. The second club, the Fort Orange Club in Albany, N.Y., began admitting women in 1988. ``I think on balance, maybe even more than balance, you'll find someone who is sensitive to the needs of women, as well as any other group that requires protection,'' Dunne said. Nominee William C. Lucas was rejected in August on a 7-7 committee vote. Lucas, a black, was opposed by many civil rights groups because he sided with Bush on recent a Supreme Court ruling that expanded opportunities to challenge affirmative action policies. Dunne, who was a state senator for 24 years, has been criticized by civil rights groups for having very little civil rights experience. He is white. Sen. Paul Simon, D-Ill., who chaired the hearing, asked Dunne to explain his position on apartheid in light of the fact that he and his law firm hold stock in companies that do business in South Africa and that he voted against a measure requiring New York state to divest such holdings. ``Let me put right up in the front: I hate, if one can hate, the principle of apartheid,'' Dunne replied. ``The three items ... are unconnected and not indicative of an attitude that favors that system.'' The Associated Press reported last week that Dunne holds almost $20,000 worth of stock in Schlumberger Ltd., a New York-based company engaged in oil field services and oil products manufacturing. Benjamin Hooks, executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, has said his group would neither endorse nor oppose Dunne. Simon aide John Travesina said the committee would probably vote March 22.

DOC.HEAD: Medical Assocation Calls for Expanded Medicaid, More Insurance
DOC.TEXT: The American Medical Association on Wednesday proposed expanding Medicaid and requiring employers to provide medical insurance to full-time employees to help fill the gaps in the nation's health care system. The AMA also called for the creation of state risk pools to provide group insurance policies for those who cannot afford coverage under the current system _ including small businesses and the self-employed _ and for individuals whose illnesses make them medically uninsurable. The changes are aimed at providing access to health care for all Americans, including the estimated 33 million who have no medical insurance, regardless of income. AMA officials, who unveiled the plan at a news conference, declined to put a total price on the package, but said the Medicaid expansion would probably cost about $30 billion a year. An AMA source, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said a ``fair estimate'' for the whole package was about $60 billion a year. Dr. Alan R. Nelson, AMA president, did not suggest specifically how the plan would be financed. But he said, ``almost certainly this would require some increased taxes.'' James S. Todd, acting executive vice president of the AMA, said talking about the cost of the package would detract from the plan itself. ``We don't want to see the concept deep-sixed because someone put a price on it,'' he said. ``We don't think you should make health care decisions based on what it will cost'' but rather on what is ``appropriate and needed.'' The AMA said the plan corrects weaknesses in the current system while building on its strengths, including patients' freedom to choose their health-care provider. ``The individual's freedom of choice remains a cornerstone of the American system,'' Nelson said. Though revision of the current system is ``badly needed ... it would be counterproductive to `fix' aspects of our system that are not broken,'' he said. The AMA's proposal is similar to a $66 billion plan recommended last week by the U.S. Bipartisan Commission on Comprehensive Health Care, known as the Pepper Commission for its first chairman, the late Rep. Claude Pepper, D-Fla. The nation's health-care bill is expected to reach $600 billion this year, more than 11 percent of the gross national product. The highlights of the AMA plan include: _Expanding Medicaid to all people below the poverty level and establishing uniform benefits. Medicaid now covers fewer than half of those living below the poverty line, and eligibility and benefits vary from state to state. _Requiring employers to provide health insurance for all full-time employees and their families and eliminating state-mandated benefits. Employers would be allowed tax deductions to help with costs. _Establishing state risk pools funded with tax revenues or insurance company contributions to make coverage available for those who can't afford or can't get insurance. About 15 states currently have such pools. _Expanding private sector coverage of long-term care with tax incentives. _Revising medical malpractice laws to reduce liability insurance costs for physicians and the practice of defensive medicine, such as ordering tests and procedures that otherwise might not be ordered. Also Wednesday, the Institute of Medicine recommended changes in the current monitoring of Medicare services to increase emphasis on quality of care. ``The current system is viewed by nearly all concerned as ineffective,'' said Kathleen Lohr, who directed the study for the institute, which is chartered by the National Academy of Sciences. The report recommends a plan that would be phased in over 10 years to shift the focus of the monitoring program from containing costs to tracking and evaluating the care of patients.

DOC.HEAD: Poindexter Trying to Limit Testimony by Leadoff Witness North
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 3rd graf pvs `Many of ...' to ADD details on some jurors' background. Picks up 4th graf pvs `At a ...'
DOC.TEXT: A jury of seven women and five men was sworn in Wednesday for the Iran-Contra trial of John Poindexter, whose lawyers were attempting to sharply curtail any damaging testimony from Oliver North, the government's leadoff witness. The jury was sent home for the day, after being selected from a pool of 45 people, as U.S. District Court Judge Harold Greene considered the question of whether to limit North's testimony. Jury selection took just three days, as opposed to more than a week in the North trial last year. Many of the jurors said they had heard of North but knew little about Poindexter, his former boss who many failed to recognize in the courtroom. The jurors include a bridal consultant, a university accountant, a postal worker, a retired food-service worker and a housewife. One of the six alternate jurors is a retiree who got the Watergate scandal confused with the Iran-Contra affair. At a hearing, prosecutor John Barrett argued that North should testify that he saw Poindexter destroy a presidential finding on Iran and that Poindexter forced North to lie about the Contras to Congress. Poindexter lawyer Stephen McNabb said North testimony on those two subjects should not be permitted because it was based on earlier testimony Poindexter gave Congress in 1987 under a grant of immunity from prosecution. At his trial last year, North testified that he witnessed Poindexter destroy then-President Reagan's finding, which depicted the Iran initiative as a straight arms-for-hostages deal. North recently said his knowledge of the destruction was based on Poindexter's immunized testimony. But ``North is a witness who doesn't want to testify for the government,'' Barrett said, suggesting North's was merely trying to avoid harming his former boss. Regarding the Contras, Barrett said that North's and Poindexter's stories contradict each other about a crucial Aug. 6, 1986, meeting with congressmen at the White House. At that meeting, North falsely denied assisting the Contras militarily. Poindexter has testified to Congress that North assured him he could handle the meeting with the congressmen. North has said the opposite, that he was reluctant to talk with them because he would have to conceal a number of matters, but that Poindexter directed him to do so. North admitted that he lied at the meeting. Greene denied one motion by Poindexter's lawyers to prevent all or part of North's testimony and said he will rule on the other one limiting by the time North takes the witness stand. ``I gather'' that North ``will be the first government witness'' in the case against Poindexter, Greene said in revealing that Poindexter had filed the sealed motions. Lawyers in the case later confirmed that North would indeed be the first witness. Opening statements are planned for Thursday. Greene said he would consider a Poindexter motion seeking to limit North's testimony, based on Fifth Amendment rights against self-incrimination. The judge denied the other motion, which he said was based on ``perjury'' that North ``allegedly committed.'' The government alleged at North's trial last year that he had given unreliable testimony when he took the witness stand in his own defense, Richard Beckler, a lawyer for Poindexter, later explained. In closing arguments at North's trial, prosecutor John Keker said the former White House aide ``had gotten in the habit of lying'' in the Iran-Contra affair and that he ``wasn't stopping now'' once he took the witness stand in his own defense. North made a number of statements at his trial last year that could be extremely damaging to Poindexter if repeated in the new trial. For example, he said he told Poindexter that it would be unwise to have a meeting in August 1986 with House members inquiring into whether North was assisting the Contras militarily. Poindexter insisted that North brief the lawmakers anyway, telling his subordinate that ``you can handle it ... you can take care of it,'' North testified. North admitted on the witness stand that he had lied to the lawmakers. Poindexter later sent him a message saying, ``Well done.'' The incident forms part of the indictment against the ex-national security adviser. North is appealing his convictions on three felonies: aiding and abetting an obstruction of Congress in connection with a November 1985 shipment of Hawk missiles to Iran, altering and destroying classified National Security Councl documents pertaining to North's assistance to the Contras and accepting a $13,800 home security system from Richard Secord. Poindexter is accused of obstructing and lying to Congress in five felony charges concerning the missile shipment and allegations that he covered up North's secret resupply network to the Contra rebels in Nicaragua. Greene in December placed limitations on North's testimony at Poindexter's trial. The judge ruled that prosecutors may only elicit evidence based on statements North made before July 15, 1987, the day Poindexter began giving testimony to Congress on national television under a grant of immunity from prosecution. North has said he is unable to differentiate what he knows from Poindexter's immunized testimony and what he knows from his own experiences in the Iran-Contra affair. Under federal law, no part of the prosecution's case may be derived from a defendant's immunized testimony.

DOC.HEAD: New Rights Commission Chairman Has Heart Surgery
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS one graf after 2nd graf pvs, Fletcher, who, to UPDATE with surgery completed; also SUBS 3rd graf pvs, The 65-year-old, to show previous surgery in Yakima
DOC.TEXT: Arthur Fletcher, the newly appointed chairman of the U.S. Civil Rights Commission, on Wednesday underwent his second triple bypass heart surgery in less than six months, an agency spokeswoman said. Fletcher, who was named chairman by President Bush last month, entered George Washington University Hospital on Monday after doctors concluded previous bypass surgery ``didn't take,'' said Barbara Brooks, spokeswoman for the commission. Hospital spokeswoman Claudia Dominitz said the surgery Wednesdsay ``went well. He's doing fine.'' The 65-year-old Fletcher underwent emergency open-heart surgery last November in Yakima, Wash., after traveling to Washington state for a speaking engagement. Brooks said he went to the George Washington hospital for a follow-up examination and went into surgery again Wednesday morning. ``According to his wife, the other surgery didn't take,'' said Brooks. She said doctors told family members ``his three bypass grafts occluded and the arteries are blocked again.'' Fletcher, who served as chairman at his first commission meeting last week, is expected to be out recuperating for six to eight weeks, Brooks said.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Leader Predicts Communist Defeat in Bulgarian Elections
DOC.TEXT: The leader of the democratic opposition predicted on Wednesday that Bulgaria's ruling Communist Party will suffer a crushing defeat in free elections he hopes will take place this year. But Zhelyu Zhelev, chairman of the Union of Democratic Forces, cautioned that the Communists, led by Premier Andrei Lukanov, are still a force to reckon with. ``We will win the elections without underestimating the Communist Party, which is still strong, though demoralized by now,'' Zhelev said. ``But if we have just, democratic and honest elections I think we will win, and for us it is not only a question of winning but doing so by a large, crushing majority.'' On Jan. 15, Parliament abolished the guaranteed leading role of Bulgaria's Communist Party in the wave of reforms sweeping Eastern Europe. Zhelev said a big win was imperative to establishing a strong government supported by the people ``to carry out the required reforms in the future.'' ``This type of administration will have to take unpopular measures, which underscores the need for a strong authoritative government ... (which) can ask people to make sacrifices and bear with restrictions for a period of time,'' he said. Zhelev said his alliance wants two rounds of elections this year. A preliminary round, already scheduled for June by the Communist government, would choose a National Assembly to draft a new constitution, to be followed by full-scale democratic elections toward the end of the year. ``I think we can fight for this,'' Zhelev said. ``But if the Communist Party tries to torpedo the plan we will turn to the people'' with rallies, demonstrations and perhaps a referendum. Zhelev said his proposed two-stage election process was crucial for the opposition ``because we have no experience whatsoever, no material base, no people well-known to the public.'' He said he hoped talks between the Communists and opposition groups would resume Monday and that the Communists would sign a crucial agreement on the country's democratic future. Meetings were suspended Feb. 12 after the Communists refused to remove party cells from the workplace and sign a political accord considered vital by the opposition. The Communists have since said they are willing to disband the cells. The political agreement he wants signed would provide for the clear separation of party and state and the end of state financing for the Communist Party, Zhelev said. Bulgaria also is beset by an economic crisis. It owes the West $10.8 billion and is experiencing a worsening shortage of consumer goods, including inadequate food supplies in parts of the country. Bulgarian reforms began in earnest last Nov. 10 with the ouster of Todor Zhivkov, the longtime, hard-line Communist Party chief. Large demonstrations for democracy followed that led to many of the old guard leaders being expelled from the party. The rallies in Sofia were the largest since the Communists consolidated power 43 years earlier. By December, the party's Central Committee was yielding to demands for reforms. Parliament passed an amnesty for political prisoners and erased ``anti-state activity'' and ``crimes against allied states'' from the penal code. On Dec. 27, the government and the Union of Democratic Forces agreed to hold talks.

DOC.HEAD: Senators Manuevering for Changes
DOC.TEXT: Groups of senators maneuvered behind the scenes Wednesday hoping to toughen controls on automobile and industrial pollution as well as to require automakers to produce more fuel efficient cars. As a stream of minor amendments to the clean air bill was debated on the Senate floor, industry lobbyists and the Bush administration sought to blunt attempts to stengthen the bill. Transporation Secretary Samuel Skinner said in a letter to key senators that a proposal that would require automakers dramatically to improve fuel economy would ``have a devastating impact'' on the auto industry and consumers, forcing automakers to concentrate on making smaller cars. The fuel economy provision, which was in the orignal bill approved by a Senate committee, was strongly opposed by the administration and the auto industry and was deleted during the negotiations between Senate leaders and the White House that produced the bill now being debated. But several senators said Wednesday they will try to revive the proposal, which would require automakers to curb carbon dioxide emissions because of concern about global warming. The auto industry said such curbs would require them to produce cars with a fleet average of 40 miles per gallon compared with the current requirement of 27.5 mpg. ``It would cost thousands and thousands of jobs ... (and) decimate the domestic automobile industry,'' said Sen. Don Nickels, R-Okla. But other senators including Sens. Timothy Wirth, D-Colo., Bob Kerry, D-Mass., and Richard Bryan, D-Nev., have argued that controls on carbon dioxide are needed to deal with global warming. ``Carbon dioxide is responsible for nearly half of the greenhouse effect,'' said Sen. Albert Gore, D-Tenn., ``and motor vehicles are the largest single source of carbon dixoide emissions.'' Carbon dioxide is an inevitable product of all combustion of fossil fuels. It also traps heat that would be radiated by the earth into space, leading many scientists to predict that its buildup in the atmosphere will mena a warming of the earth. The less gasoline burned, the less carbon dioxide produced. The compromise bill calls for sweeping regulations on smog-causing pollution from automobiles and industry, requires controls on 191 toxic industrial chemicals and would require cuts in acid rain pollutants from coal-burning electric utility plants and factories. Some Republican senators complained late Wednesday that the complex pollution control bill was being pushed through the Senate too quickly. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, told his colleagues he wanted to complete action on the legislation by the end of the week when the Senate goes on a week-long recess. He threatened to keep the senators in session into the weekend if necessary. That prompted complaints from Sen. William Armstrong, R-Colo., that the legislation was being ``rammed down our throats'' without enough time to examine details. Sen. Ted Stevens, R-Alaska, said he had only seen the bill on Monday. ``We've got to complete this bill,'' responded Mitchell, adding that the more time that is spent the more proposed amendments are likely to appear. Delays beyond the upcoming recess could ``result in very lengthy delays, perhaps defeat of the bill,'' said Mitchell. In addition to auto emission controls, senators also said they planned to offer amendments that would restore a provision under which the Environmental Protection Agency could impose a pollution control plan on a city if state and local officials do not act. That authority, which is in current law, was deleted during the closed-door negotiations.

DOC.HEAD: One Manufacturer Says Pillows Voluntarily Removed from Shelves
DOC.TEXT: One manufacturer of infant pillows and cushions the government said was involved in the suffocation of 10 babies in two years said Wednesday that it voluntarily removed its product from stores earlier this year. Leo Hollander, owner of Hollander Home Fashions of Newark, N.J., said the company stopped making its ``Mother's Helper Cushion'' in January and told distributors to remove them from stores. Sen. Alfonse D'Amato, R-N.Y., urged the Consumer Product Safety Commission on Tuesday to recall all the infant pillows that have been linked to the deaths, inlcuding seven since June. ``It's time to get get the product off the shelves and out of the hands of consumers before any other children are put at risk,'' D'Amato said. Hollander said his company ``does not believe that its product is responsible for the death of any infant. ... The product labeling warns parents never to leave their children unattended.'' He said infants under 5-months-old should never be placed face down and left alone to sleep on any type of pillows. ``Furthermore no pillow should be used for very young infants in their cribs,'' he said. CPSC spokesman Dan Rumelt said the company voluntarily recalled 400,000 cushions Wednesday. But Hollander said the company did not recall cushions bought by consumers and only took the action with its distributors ``awaiting CPSC determination.'' ``The CPSC has not determined that this product is the cause of this problem,'' he said. The agency on Tuesday warned parents not to let infants sleep on the miniature bean bags because 10 babies using the items have suffocated since December 1987. ``As a result of our investigation we know that at least 10 companies manufacture a similar product,'' Rumelt said. The agency said negotiations for a recall were continuing with other companies, which it declined to identify.

DOC.HEAD: Welfare Agencies Struggle with Crack Babies
DOC.TEXT: State child welfare agencies are struggling to meet the needs of a growing number of babies born to crack-addicted women, the Department of Health and Human Services said Wednesday. Many experts said that providing protective services, social services or foster care for such children is more complex than for other child welfare cases because there is more abandonment and violence. ``Case workers can spend days tracking mothers who give false addresses to hospitals and then abandon their babies,'' the report by the inspector general said. In some cities, caseworkers are so overwhelmed that hospitals are stepping in with their own efforts to recruit foster parents, the report said. Child welfare administrators and caseworkers, hospital social services staff, foster parents and state and local officials in 12 cities were interviewed. Only eight of the cities were able to provide the number of crack babies reported to the child welfare system. These eight handled 8,974 such children during the previous year. The report estimated that hospital delivery, medical care and foster care for these babies through age 5 would be about $500 million. The inspector general said the estimates for the eight cities, along with adjustments for underreporting of crack babies, are consistent with the president's National Drug Control Strategy report estimate that 100,000 babies are born to cocaine-using women each year. Prenatal exposure to cocaine can lead to premature birth, low birthweight, birth defects and respiratory and neurological problems, the report said. Some experts say that when these children are older, many will have severe learning disabilities and will need special education. Caseloads for child welfare workers in the 12 cities studied averaged 49 children for foster care and 161 for protective services, the report said. From 50 percent to 95 percent of the crack babies in the cities studied went home with their mother or a relative. The rest go into foster care or some other placement arrangement. The cities studied were: Chicago; Fort Wayne, Ind.; Los Angeles; Miami; New York; Newark; Oakland, Calif.; Philadelphia; Phoenix; San Francisco; Tacoma; and Washington, D.C.

DOC.HEAD: Religion Prize Goes To Australian Scientist and Hindu Friend Of Lepers
LaserPhoto NY21
DOC.TEXT: An Australian scientist who sees divine values in nature and a Hindu lawyer who started communities for lepers in India were named Wednesday as co-winners of the 1990 Templeton Prize for progress in religion. The $580,000 prize, the largest in any field, went to biologist-geneticist Charles K. Birch of Sydney and Murlidhar Devidas Amte, who established five centers for lepers in the area of Nagpur, India. The prize was founded in 1972 by financier John Templeton, a Presbyterian, who keeps the amount higher than the Nobel Prizes in the belief that religion is more important. An international panel of judges picks the winners. Templeton urged more research into spiritual realities when he named the winners at the Church Center for the United Nations. ``The accelerating discovery rate in natural sciences needs to be matched by man's spiritual progress and discovery,'' he said. ``Much evidence has been found that God's ongoing creative process is accelerating.'' The prize winners reflected two aspects of religion _ its intellectual ramifications in science and its altruistic impulse in serving the weak. Birch, 71, a University of Sydney biologist from 1960 until his recent retirement and veteran of science-religion conferences, maintains that the interrelationship of nature, humanity and God finds support in physics. He wrote that this has been emphasized by the ecological crisis, which has shown the negative results of a mere mechanistic view of nature. ``All actual entities have an inner reality as well as an outer reality,'' Birch said. For example, he said, ``Nothing will save the whales ... unless we attribute to whales intrinsic value in themselves and to God.'' Birch, who has been a research fellow at several U.S. universities, was cited for his ``reconciliation of the biological and the religious understanding of creation.'' Amte, 75, is called ``Baba,'' or ``father,'' by colleagues and patients. His largest leper center covering 450 acres accommodates 1,400 lepers and includes a cottage hospital, library, cooperative shops, bank, workshops, training schools, theaters, homes for aged and infirm lepers and technical college with 7,500 students. Amte was born into a wealthy Brahmin family, educated at a Christian college and became an attorney, but rebelled against caste barriers to help untouchables set up cooperatives and unions. An experience resembling that of St. Francis initially turned Amte to serving lepers, he said. He was so repelled at his first encounter with one that he fled, then returned to befriend him. Amte, like his friend the late Mahatma Gandhi, extolled the example of Christ but remained a Hindu. ``Everyone should attempt to walk in the shadow of the Cross,'' he wrote. ``That means you are in the company of that life which scuttled itself to save others.'' Australia's U.N. ambassador, Peter Wialenski, and India's, C.R. Gharekan, attended the news conference with several religious and public leaders. The prize is to be presented May 8 in London. Templeton said the prize ``is intended to help people see the infinity'' of ways God acts in the world and reveals himself to different cultures, adding, ``Exciting new advances are being made in every religion.'' Noting that millions are spent annually for research in natural sciences, he said, ``Similar manpower and resources devoted to research in spiritual subjects could lead to greater blessings for mankind.'' Previous winners of the prize include Mother Teresa of Calcutta, evangelist Billy Graham, science philosopher Thomas Torrance of Scotland and Russian exile writer Alexander Solzhenitsyn.

DOC.HEAD: Education Secretary `Saddened' By Angry Texas Lawmakers
DOC.TEXT: Education Secretary Lauro Cavazos said Wednesday he was saddened by a confrontation with Texas lawmakers whose fury erupted after he told them more money would not solve the problems of Texas schools. Cavazos told a joint session of his home state Legislature in Austin on Tuesday that fundamental changes _ not merely ``pitching money'' _ were the answer to improving education. Three Hispanic legislators left the chamber during his speech. Another confronted him afterward and then disrupted the secretary's news conference to raise heated objections to his views. The Texas Legislature is under court order to reform a school-financing system that short-changes poor districts. The order resulted from a lawsuit brought by the predominantly Hispanic Edgewood School District in San Antonio. Cavazos said it's the first time he has been attacked by fellow Hispanic leaders since he became the first Hispanic Cabinet appointee in September 1988. ``I wonder if they would have been as angry if the person who delivered that address as secretary of education had not been Hispanic,'' he said. ``It saddens me _ not because it was a personal attack _ but because people I have so much respect for take that kind of tactic, in front of television cameras and reporters. ``What I got yesterday in Austin ... was people who felt the solution was more dollars. It was quite a confrontation down there. I was very disappointed that the whole issue had to be focused on resources.'' Sen. Carlos Truan, D-Corpus Christi, interrupted the secretary's news conference. ``I feel betrayed and I feel embarrassed that the secretary of education _ a minority and from Texas _ would not take a more aggressive position regarding the needs of education,'' Truan said Wednesday. Truan, chairman of the Hispanic Caucus in the Texas Senate, said Cavazos is ``lacking in commitment to the children of our state and of this country by the comments he made here yesterday, and I regret that.'' Al Kauffman, attorney for the Mexican American Legal Defense and Educational Fund, said Cavazos' comments will not help those working on behalf of the property-poor school districts. Kent Pogue, superintendent of the Kingsville Independent School District, where Cavazos went to school, said he disagreed with Cavazos' contention that more money is not needed for public schools. ``By disagreeing, I'm not saying that money is the answer, but money is needed to provide a quality education,'' said Pogue. Gov. Bill Clements, a Republican who has repeatedly vowed to veto any new taxes for school finance reform, applauded Cavazos' comments. ``He's a great educator, he's a great Texan, he's a fine guy,'' Clements said. ``I liked everything he had to say.'' Cavazos said he has made the same speech dozens of times and taken his message before several congressional committees, yet ``no one has been angry with me until this came up the other day.'' As examples of the fundamental changes he would like to see, Cavazos said professionals should be able to teach with easier certification, parents should have more choice of schools for their children and principals and teachers should have more control over the schools where they work.

DOC.HEAD: Spanish Fishermen Maintain Port Blockade
DOC.TEXT: Spanish fishermen maintained a weeklong blockade of four major southern ports on Wednesday to protest Morocco's decision to increase fines for illegal fishing in its waters, a government official said. They used their fishing craft to close the ports of Algeciras, Puerto de Santa Maria, Almeria and Alicante, forcing a deep cut in ferry service and stranding a total of 3,500 people on both sides of the Strait of Gibraltar, said Alfonso Garrido, central government representative in Andalusia region. He said the protest has led to clashes between police and fishermen and to food and medicine shortages in Spain's North African enclave of Ceuta. Garrido said it also caused a shortage of fish and a steep increase in fish prices in southern Spain as well as financial losses to ship owners. The blockade began last Thursday after Morocco announced it was increasing maximum fines to more than $150,000 for infractions of fishing regulations outlined in its 1988-92 fishing accord with the European Economic Community. The fishermen also oppose the accord's obligatory one-month-a-year ban on fishing to prevent overfishing of Moroccan waters. An EEC commission agreed Wednesday to meet to discuss the issue.

DOC.HEAD: 107 Towns Support Referendum To Decrease Military Spending
DOC.TEXT: Residents in 107 of 141 towns across Vermont voted to urge President Bush to cut military spending by 5 percent a year for the next five years, officials said Wednesday. ``This is a pioneer effort to bring a grass-roots message that we want our spending priorities changed,'' said John Berkowitz, organizer of the Sane-Freeze petition drive that got the referendum on town meeting agendas. ``Vermont is a bellwether state in these issues, just like New Hampshire is in presidential primaries,'' Berkowitz said at a news conference to announce the referendum results.
