Of the 141 towns that held meetings Monday and Tuesday, 107 voted to press the federal government to redirect surplus defense money to such programs as education, environmental protection, housing and health care, he said. Ten towns shot down the referendum, and 11 more towns postponed it indefinitely, Berkowitz said. In a few other towns _ including Chelsea, Dummerston and Hancock _ residents amended the article. They supported the 5 percent reduction until it ultimately reaches 50 percent, provided that all the excess money go toward reducing the federal deficit. ``They felt that in solving that problem, it would solve many others,'' Berkowitz said. ``President Bush's budget is totally out of sync with new realities,'' he said. The proposed 5 percent drop in military spending would be after inflation increases in the military budget and would result in essentially level funding. He said Sane-Freeze, which was set up to push for nuclear arms reductions, has expanded to become ``a national organization working for peace and social justice and environmental issues.'' The president's $1.25 trillion budget proposes $303 billion for defense, including $10.4 billion for nuclear weapons. Administration officials have said overall defense spending will increase, but will not keep pace with inflation, leading to an effective 2 percent reduction. ``The referendum was passed in urban and rural areas, by Democrats and Republicans and young and old,'' said Rep. David Larsen, a Democrat who is vice chairman of the House Education Committee. ``This is not a partisan issue.'' ``We have our priorities mixed up,'' said Rep. Toby Young, a Democrat who is chairwoman of the state House Health and Welfare Committee. ``Vermonters have seen that the federal priorities are mixed up and have done something about it.''

DOC.HEAD: Battered Woman Who Shot Husband Over Dinner Sentenced to Five Years
DOC.TEXT: A battered woman who killed her husband after he criticized her cooking was sentenced Wednesday to five years in prison despite testimony that she suffered years of abuse. Virginia Eagan, 53, of Omro was convicted Jan. 31 of homicide by negligent use of a weapon. Psychiatrists told jurors that Mrs. Eagan suffered from an abuse-related emotional disturbance known as battered wife syndrome. Winnebago County Circuit Judge William E. Crane said he imposed the maximum sentence because ``battered women syndrome doesn't warrant killing someone.'' ``Virginia Eagan took a gun at close range while both of them were drinking, and shot him through the heart and killed him,'' Crane said. ``People have to face up to responsibility.'' Mrs. Eagan shot her husband of 32 years, Eugene Eagan, 56, during a July 2 argument over boiled potatoes and beets at the couple's rural town of Omro farm in east central Wisconsin. During the trial, both prosecution and defense attorneys characterized Eagan, who was disabled and used a cane to walk, as an abusive husband who would strike his wife with his canes and beat her during drunken outbursts. Defense Attorney George Curtis said after sentencing that sending Mrs. Eagan, a gray-haired factory worker who is going blind, to prison was cruel and compounded the family's tragedy. ``I feel this lady has gone through hell and doesn't deserve another minute of it. She was a helpless victim,'' Curtis said. ``I'm really sorry Virginia Eagan is going off to a new prison.'' District Attorney Joseph Paulus said Eagan's death ``seems to have fallen to the wayside in these proceedings.'' ``The jury's verdict certainly did not excuse the defendant's behavior,'' he said. Mrs. Eagan was originally charged with first-degree reckless homicide, which carried a maximum 20-year prison sentence, but the jury convicted her on the lesser charge, which carries a maximum five-year penalty.

A bipartisan panel called for flexible spending limits on congressional campaigns Wednesday but did not address many of the alleged abuses that have put the issue on the front burner in Congress. The panel of experts sided with Democrats to support a voluntary spending ceiling with discount TV and mail rates as an incentive for compliance. But it rejected Democratic calls for public financing and instead endorsed Republican desires to limit corporate and labor political action committees, or PACs. GOP desires to loosen rules on indiviudal contributions, to reduce a perceived advantage by incumbents and to make the political parties the engine for raising and spending funds also won the panel's endorsement. Senate Democratic Leader George Mitchell of Maine hailed the panel's 41-page report as ``breakthrough recommendations'' for untangling a bitterly partisan struggle. Senate Republican leader Bob Dole of Kansas called it a ``potential breakthrough,'' saying the panel of six experts _ three each picked by Dole and Mitchell _ at least ``touched on some of the hot buttons.'' Democrats, nonetheless, planned to push through the Senate Rules Committee on Thursday their version of a bill that has both spending caps and provisions for taxpayer financing. Mitchell acknowledged that the bill he is co-sponsoring with Sens. David Boren, D-Okla., and Robert C. Byrd, D-W.Va., has no chance to get past a presidential veto, but he said it provides a vehicle for negotiations between the parties. Meanwhile, Rep. Beryl Anthony of Arkansas, chairman of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, said House Democrats are nearing completion of a bill that would set a voluntary ceiling of $550,000 on what a House candidate could spend. Democrats previously had wanted a $400,000 ceiling. The task force called for ``reasonably high'' and flexible voluntary spending ceilings reflecting the extra costs of running in states where advertising in adjacent high-cost media markets is required. But it would not count limited contribtions by in-state residents to in-state candidates. The panel ignored many issues raised by the savings and loan crisis. For example, it did not touch so-called leadership political action committees or PACs, PACs run by members. It also had no recommendation on tax-exempt foundations. Of the $1.3 million that Phoenix S&L operator Charles H. Keating Jr. contributed to five Senate candidates, $850,000 was through a tax-exempt voter registration foundation headed by the son of Sen. Alan Cranston, D-Calif. The panel called for prohibtions on the ``bundling'' or gathering of many contributions by business and labor PACs but endorsed as ``little obvious cause for concern'' such activities by individuals. Keating, whose failed S&L may cost the taxpayers $2 billion, bundled more than $200,000 in individual contributions from members of his family and business associates for the re-election campaigns of the five senators. The five _ Sens. John McCain, R-Ariz.; Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz.; John Glenn, D-Ohio; Donald W. Riegle, D-Mich., and Cranston _ are now under investigation by the Senate Ethics Committee for interceding with regulators on behalf of Keating's Lincoln Savings and Loan Association. Recommendations by the task force include: _Giving parties authority to raise and spend unlimited amounts on voter registration drives, phone banks, get-out-the-vote campaigns and direct mail. _Raising the $25,000 limit an individual can make to a party committee. _Providing a 100 percent tax credit, up to a specified amount, for any indivual who contributes to a candidate in the contributor's state. _A ``modest increase'' in the current $1,000 limit an individual can contribute to one candidate and the $25,000 ceiling on all contributions by an individual. _Reducing from $5,000 to $2,500 the contribution PACs can make to a candidate for each of the primary and general elections, but only after total PAC contributions reach one-third of the candidate's spending limit. _Prohibiting PACs from making post-election contributions for two years after an election to reduce a candidate's campaign debt. _Requiring radio and television stations to provide eight hours of free time each year to candidates. Parties would allocate the time.

DOC.HEAD: British Group: Moscow Fails Conditions for Human Rights Conference
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union has failed to meet conditions Britain set for attending a 1991 human rights conference in Moscow, including those concerning Jewish emigration, a British group reported Wednesday. The group of lawmakers, journalists and a student leader said that despite progress on human rights, the Soviet Union has met only one of the six conditions laid down by Britain _ freedom to monitor human rights. ``We found evidence of real fear on the part of very many of the Jews we met ... that there would be physically violent manifestations of the anti-Semitism they find in their work, their living environment,'' said legislator Paul Boateng, a member of the opposition Labor Party. The eight-member group visited Moscow Feb. 23-26 on a trip organized by Britain's Student and Academic Campaign for Soviet Jews. The report was presented Wednesday evening to a meeting of about 750 members of the predominantly Jewish organization and was then handed to a government representative. The British fact-finding team said human rights abuses continued against Soviet Jews in the five other areas cited by Britain _ emigration, discrimination, freedom of religious and cultural expression, prisoners of conscience and laws covering emigration rights. The Soviet Union, which is eager to host the conference, has received acceptances, some conditional, from most Western countries. Britain announced its heavily qualified acceptance last year. ``We should keep up the pressure,'' said Sir Anthony Kershaw, ex-chairman of the House of Commons Foreign Affairs Committee, another member of the group. ``Not until later should we decide on 1991.'' Kershaw, of the governing Conservative Party, said that by official count there are 1.2 million Jews in the Soviet Union, but the number is probably 3 million to 4 million including people who do not register. Last year 105,000 Soviet Jews left, he said, and about 2,000 have emigrated this year. Many are going to Israel as a second choice after the United States tightened its entry visas when Moscow began allowing significant numbers of Soviet Jews to leave. During its trip to Moscow, the British group met with Soviet officials, representatives of refuseniks and Jewish organizations, and Andrei Sakharov's widow, Yelena Bonner. Kershaw said the number of long-term refuseniks _ people who applied a decade or more ago to leave _ dropped by 10,000 to 60,000 the past year. Those refused permission on grounds they have sensitive information included a 76-year-old former professor of plant breeding, said Kershaw. She retired 16 years ago and her family is now in Israel, he said. ``The Jews of the Soviet Union have had a long and bitter time,'' said lawmaker Sir Russell Johnston of the centrist Social and Liberal Democratic Party. ``That time is not over, but ... there is hope.''

DOC.HEAD: Czechoslovak Hero Hailed on 140th Birth Anniversary
DOC.TEXT: Czechoslovakia celebrated on Wednesday the 140th anniversary of the birth of its founding father, Tomas Garrigue Masaryk, in an outpouring of national pride and gratitude for newly gained freedom. ``He was not only a man who did good for the state ... but he was a man who breathed the idea of morality and truth into its foundations,'' President Vaclav Havel said at a ceremony in Hodonin, Masaryk's hometown 180 miles east of Prague. Masaryk and Gen. Milan Stefanik, a Slovak hero, gained U.S. President Woodrow Wilson's support to realize their dream of independent Czechoslovakia in 1918. Masaryk was erased from history books first by the Nazis and then by the Communists after they took power in 1948. He was depicted as a bourgeois capitalist who meant little for Czechoslovakia. In the face of police harassment, Havel and other dissidents supported Masaryk's image as the founder of independent and free Czechoslovakia during the years of harsh Communist rule that ended with last year's revolution. The Communists despised Masaryk not only as a symbol of pre-World War II democracy, but for being an intellectual beloved by Czechoslovaks and respected worldwide. Masaryk, a philosopher by profession, entered politics in his 60s. He was a strong advocate of the unity of Czechs and Slovaks, the country's two main ethnic groups. ``Just now, in the times of new programs, and perspectives, let us remember Masaryk striving for silent, practical and active inner qualities, proceeding from words to deeds,'' Petr Pithart, the prime minister of the Czech lands, said at a parallel ceremony in Prague, the official CTK news agency reported. Celebrations of Masaryk's anniversary were held throughout the country. Earlier, Havel and Czechoslovak Prime Minister Marian Calfa laid wreaths at the Masaryk grave in Lany, 30 miles west of Prague.

DOC.HEAD: Manley's Party Sweeps Local Elections, Violence Mars Voting
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Michael Manley on Wednesday said his party's landslide victory in local elections was a mandate for his government, which has faced growing attacks for its austerity program. In Tuesday's vote, Manley's left-of-center governing party defeated the opposition led by former premier Edward Seaga, a conservative and staunch U.S. ally. The balloting was marred by a low turnout and isolated beatings, shootings and ballot thefts. Election results released late Tuesday night indicated Manley's People's National Party kept its hold on 11 of the 12 parish councils and the Kingston-St. Andrew metropolitan area. Seaga's Jamaica Labor Party retained its St. Thomas parish council. Local elections are seen here as a gauge of the government's popularity. Manley said his party's victory meant Jamaicans recognized ``that we are grappling with the problems.'' His popularity recently dropped after the government enforced the austerity measures to rescue the debt-ridden economy. The moves included an increase in food prices and higher taxes. During Tuesday's vote in downtown Kingston, policemen shot in the air to disperse a crowd that threatened Seaga, threw ink in his face, and punctured his car tires. In the capital, police said one unidentified voter was shot to death and another remained in serious condition after he was stabbed by several men. Witnesses and state radio said thugs beat up a polling station chairwoman in Kingston and reported several cases of hoodlums and gunmen stealing ballot boxes. However, voting was mostly peaceful in the countryside. The government deployed 6,500 police and 4,000 soldiers to prevent violence in the Caribbean island, where elections have often been marred by violence. With most votes counted, the governing party had won 109 of the 187 seats being contested in the 12 parish councils, with the opposition receiving 38 seats and independents winning the rest. In one of the lowest voter turnouts in Jamaican history, only 45 percent of the electorate went to the polls. Manley's party trounced Seaga's in a national parliamentary election in February 1989. ``The shine is still on the ball as far as the PNP is concerned,'' Seaga said of Manley's party after the latest vote. ``As time wears on, the ball is not going to have the shine any longer.''

DOC.HEAD: Next Summit Could Come Weeks Early
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Retransmits a0775 to CORRECT cycle designator to AMs.
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration said Wednesday it is flexible about the timing of a superpower summit with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and is willing to move up the meeting from late June. ``We're always willing to change,'' said White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater. ``We can do it anytime.'' President Bush and Gorbachev had agreed to hold the summit the last two weeks of June, probably in Washington. That would put it right before a seven-nation summit of Western allies Bush is to host in Houston July 9 to 11. ``We'd like to do it as early as possible because of the economic summit,'' Fitzwater said of the next Bush-Gorbachev meeting. The Soviets also may have a desire to meet earlier because of a major Communist Party meeting now scheduled for late June or early July. Gorbachev has ``agreed in principle'' to be a commencement speaker at Brown University in Providence, R.I., and those ceremonies are scheduled for May 28. Some officials think it is unlikely he would make two trips to the United States in such a short period. Moreover, there has been speculation that some of the Bush-Gorbachev meetings would be at the president's vacation home in Kennebunkport, Maine. Bush is tentatively scheduled to be in Kennebunkport from May 25 to 28. Fitzwater said he was certain that if Gorbachev speaks at Brown ``it would be associated with the summit in some fashion.'' To prepare for the summit, Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze will hold his next round of talks with Secretary of State James A. Baker III in Washington April 4-6, U.S. officials said. Baker went to Moscow last month to see Gorbachev and Shevardnadze. The trip produced a narrowing of differences on a strategic arms reduction treaty the two leaders would like to sign at the summit. The two sides also moved closer on provisions for agreements being negotiated also with other nations to ban chemical weapons production and to reduce troops, tanks and nother non-nuclear arms in Europe. Baker also is in the midst of making arrangements for a meeting with the 15 NATO foreign ministers, probably in Brussels, after Shevardnadze visits next month, officials said Wednesday. This is in addition to a meeting Baker will hold with the NATO ministers in Ayreshire, Scotland, June 7-9. The new session, which has not been announced, was disclosed by the officials on condition of anonymity. Baker has held five rounds of talks with Shevardnadze so far _ in Vienna last March, in Moscow in May, in Paris in July, in Jackson, Wyo., in September, and in Moscow Feb. 7-10. They also could meet in Namibia while attending ceremonies marking the new African country's independence from South African rule Feb. 21. Baker's schedule reflects stepped up efforts to hasten arms control agreements, lend U.S. support to political and economic reforms in the Soviet Bloc and consult NATO allies more on U.S-Soviet relations. Also, Baker has pledged to consult regularly with the West Europeans about German unification. The U.S. formula gives special roles to Britain and France, as well as the Soviet Union, as the Big Four allies of World War II. A number of smaller countries, however, feel left out. Many are victims of German aggression in World War II and some are worried about the situation in Europe after West Germany merges with East Germany. Italian Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti carried these concerns to President Bush and to Baker on Tuesday. It was then decided to have Baker meet with the foreign ministers after Shevardnadze's visit.

DOC.HEAD: Karpov, Timman Start Battle to Decide Kasparov's Challenger
DOC.TEXT: Former world chess champion Anatoly Karpov faces only one obstacle _ Jan Timman of the Netherlands _ on Karpov's comeback path to a rematch this fall with the game's other king, fellow Soviet Garri Kasparov. Timman, the third-ranking player in the world, takes on Karpov beginning Thursday. Their 12-game contest in the Malaysian capital, Kuala Lumpur, is scheduled to end April 4. The winner gains the right to play the 26-year-old Soviet titleholder in a 24-game marathon in the fall. Karpov, 38, world champion for 10 years before losing to Kasparov in 1985, is strongly favored to win and challenge Kasparov for a record-breaking fifth time in a title bout. Timman's supporters are hoping he can exploit Karpov's relatively poor form over the last year and pull off an upset. ``Of course Karpov is the favorite, but if Timman is in good condition, the situation is unclear,'' said Kasparov, speaking by telephone from Spain. If both players are nervous or off their form, then Karpov will win, the champion said. ``But if Timman plays well, he could produce some surprises.'' Kasparov said he might enjoy facing a new opponent, but there were also advantages in taking on his archrival again. ``It would give me a chance to beat Karpov convincingly.'' he said. Timman, 38, is a celebrity at home. He frequently appears on Dutch talk shows and has appeared in a television commercial as well. The prize fund of $450,000 at the World Chess Championship Candidates' Final in Malaysia will be split, with five-eights going to the winner. However, a West German computer company is offering a prize of $1.5 million to the first Westerner to challenge Kasparov. ``Most Dutch writers have been saying Timman will be destroyed by Karpov,'' said Kik Shouten, an editor at the Dutch magazine ``New in Chess.'' ``But one or two commentators say Timman has some chances because of Karpov's recent form.'' In recent years, Kasparov and Karpov have dominated world chess. But in a January world ranking, Kasparov established a crushing lead, while Timman closed on Karpov. In a competition last June, Karpov lost his last three games, allowing Timman to slip into first place. Karpov had never before lost three in a row in an international career stretching 20 years. Karpov defeated his heavily outranked Soviet compatriot, Artur Yusupov, 4.5-3.5 after winning the eighth and final game in the Candidates' semifinal in October. But Karpov almost fell behind in the sixth game. And in January, Karpov finished third behind two Soviet grandmasters in a competition in Italy. ``If Timman ever had any chances to beat Karpov, he has them now,'' said Dutch chess historian Rob Verhoeven. But British Grandmaster Raymond Keene pointed to Karpov's overwhelming superiority over Timman in their past encounters. According to Keene, Karpov has defeated Timman 14 times and lost three with 27 games drawn. He said Timman hasn't beaten Karpov since 1980. The details of the showdown with Kasparov are not yet clear. The International Chess Federation has awarded the title duel to Lyon, France. However, Ted Field, a Los Angeles businessman and film producer, said he wants to stage the final in a leading American city. Kasparov has indicated a strong preference for holding at least half the contest in the United States, most likely New York.

DOC.HEAD: Renegade General Defects to Moslem Guerrillas
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with comment from U.S. official in Washington; EDITS thereafter to conform, tighten. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The former Afghan defense minister who led a coup attempt defected Wednesday to the Moslem guerrillas he fought for more than a decade, sources said. Gen. Shah Nawaz Tanai fled Afghanistan on Wednesday with his wife, two daughters and son, then returned with the U.S.-backed insurgents, according to rebel and Pakistani government sources. President Najib again claimed that the coup Tanai launched Tuesday had ``absolutely been broken. Of that there is no doubt.'' Tanai's flight seemed to indicate this, but Western diplomats and guerrilla leaders based in Pakistan said fighting continued, although on a smaller scale. In Washington, Assistant Secretary of State John Kelly told a congressional panel that the fighting had spread from Kabul, the capital, to the towns of Jalalabad, Kandahar and Kost. Western diplomats and guerrilla leaders in Pakistan, all of whom spoke on condition of anonymity, also said they had reports of fighting in Kandahar and in the city of Herat. Rival factions in the Afghan forces were reported battling for control of Bagram, the country's largest air base. Guerrilla sources and Western diplomats in Islamabad said Tanai's forces had won control of the base. Najib ordered warplanes to bomb it, and several Soviet-supplied Scud missiles were also fired, they said. ``Bagram is completely destroyed,'' said one guerrilla source, speaking on condition of anonymity. Afghanistan's charge d'affaires in Pakistan, Qudratullah Ahmadi, denied the base had fallen to the mutineers, who had the support of the Moslem guerrillas. The diplomats and rebel sources also told of sporadic street fighting in Kabul. Najib said ``a number of people,'' mostly civilians, had been killed or injured during nearly 20 hours of fighting. He gave no specific figures, but guerrilla sources said there were hundreds of casualties. Before the coup began, Najib said Tanai, who had been defense minister, threw away his identification card from the ruling People's Democratic Party of Afghanistan and his military uniform. Tanai escaped with ``valuable government documents,'' Najib said. Tanai, a battle-hardened soldier popular with the rank-and-file military, has been accused of engineering three coup attempts against Najib's government. Guerrilla sources said Tanai contacted guerrilla leader Gulbuddin Hekmatyar before leaving Afghanistan and that one of Hekmatyar's commanders had been with Tanai since the coup attempt was launched. Such an alliance would be more one of convenience than ideology. Tanai, a Marxist hard-liner, has long advocated a harsh stance against the U.S.-backed guerrillas and opposed Najib's methods of dealing with the war and his peace efforts. At the same time, the radical fundamentalist Hekmatyar has become increasingly estranged from his fellow Moslem guerrilla leaders, rejecting their political leadership and executing some of their followers. The latest bid to bring down Najib's government began Tuesday afternoon when Afghan air force planes bombed the presidential palace in the heart of Kabul and widespread fighting was reported in the capital. On Wednesday afternoon, Tanai boarded a military helicopter that flew flanked by two fighter jets to a military base in northern Pakistan, guerrilla sources said. After landing, they said, Tanai talked with several guerrillas engaged in the 11-year war against the Afghan government. ``Later, he returned with them to a point deeper in Afghanistan to continue the struggle against Najib,'' said Foreign Secretary Tamveer Ahmed of Pakistan. A Soviet-made transport plane carrying 12 people, including three Afghan brigadier generals, also landed Wednesday near the border town of Parachinar, government and guerrilla sources said. Among the generals was Gen. Abdul Qadar Akka, a former air defense commander who was implicated with Tanai in a coup attempt in December. Neither officer was ever charged, they said. The identities of the other two generals were not disclosed. Radio Kabul accused another high-ranking party member, Asadullah Sarwari, of involvement in the coup plot. Sarwari was a former interior minister accused of hundreds of killings following the 1978 revolution that installed a Communist government and sparked the civil war. The Soviet Union withdrew its troops from Afghanistan in February 1989 after nine years of direct military intervention but continue to ship billions of dollars in arms to the Afghan armed forces. The United States, Pakistan and Saudi Arabia support the guerrillas. Although one of the most anti-Western of the seven guerrilla groups, most of the U.S. weapons have gone to Hekmatyar's Hebz-i-Islami, or Party of Islam. Tanai belonged to a faction of the ruling party that is a bitter rival of Najib. He had opposed Najib's peace overtures to the guerrillas to try to end the civil war, which has claimed more than 1 million lives, destroyed tens of thousands of villages and ruined the country's economy. Since the Soviet withdrawal from Afghanistan, Najib's troops have held their ground against the insurgents, but guerrilla leaders in Pakistan and army officers in Afghanistan have said at least seven other plots to overthrow Najib have been uncovered.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Launches Appeal for Romanian Orphans, AIDS Victims
DOC.TEXT: A former government worker began a campaign Wednesday to raise $16.4 million for Romania's orphans and children with AIDS. Romanian health authorities say their country is suffering from the first known epidemic of childhood AIDS from infected blood transfusions and repeated use of contaminated needles. Mary Gibson, an aide to former Defense Secretary George Younger, said the new Romanian Orphanage Trust hopes to pay for more staff for each of Romania's 64 orphanages. About $165,000 already has been raised following Mrs. Gibson's appearance on a British Broadcasting Corp. television program. She told a news conference Wednesday she was so stunned by television pictures after the Romanian revolution in December that she decided to visit Romania and its orphanages. ``I was appalled by what I found,'' she said. ``These children are not loved. Nobody has time to talk to them, hold their hands or cuddle them. Very often they are kept naked as this is the only way to keep them clean.'' Mrs. Gibson said play group leaders, nurses and helpers for each orphanage were needed, along with thousands of diapers, blankets, educational toys, dried milk, mattresses, vitamins, medical equipment and drugs. Medical teams to visit the children regularly are also needed, she said. Three members of the trust left for Bucharest on Wednesday to assess the immediate needs of the orphans and children suffering from AIDS. In a separate appeal, theatrical producer Thelma Holt said British theaters should donate a night's take to help Romanian children with AIDS. ``Babies are dying, and they don't have simple things like disposable nappies (diapers) or syringes. It is just awful,'' said Miss Holt, who just returned from Bucharest. The producer said she hoped to donate one night's box office take from Chekhov's ``The Three Sisters,'' which she will produce in London later this year. AIDS, or acquired immune deficiency syndrome, breaks down the body's immune system. There is no known cure. Romanian health officials said in February there were 50 confirmed AIDS cases in children. However, other reports have suggested there are many more.

DOC.HEAD: Suspected IRA Bombers to be Extradited from France
DOC.TEXT: Three suspected IRA members wanted in West Germany in a bombing that killed a British military officer will be extradited to stand trial, a French appeals court ruled Wednesday. The extradition of Patrick Murray, 45, Donagh O'Kane, 29, and Pauline Drumm, 23, will be the first from France under an anti-terrorism convention passed by the European Community in 1977, the French news agency Agence France-Presse reported. France ratified the convention last year. AFP said West Germany charged the three with assassination, destruction by explosives, criminal association and arms violations in warrants issued Sept. 13. Authorities believe they were involved in attacks against British military targets in West Germany as members of the Irish Republican Army. Among the attacks was a car bombing last July 2 in Hanover that killed a British soldier and injured his wife and three children. French counterespionage agents arrested Drumm, Murray and O'Kane two weeks later, AFP said. The IRA has waged a campaign to force the British from Northern Ireland and unite the Protestant-dominated province with the overwhelmingly Roman Catholic Irish Republic.

DOC.HEAD: Swenson Takes the Lead, Buffalo Block Trail
DOC.TEXT: Four-time winner Rick Swenson regained the lead Wednesday in the Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race, while a musher miles behind him was trying to scare off curious buffaloes. Lavon Barve and three-time champion Susan Butcher were minutes behind Swenson about a third of the way through the 1,158-mile race from Anchorage to Nome. ``There's a lot of strong teams this year,'' said Butcher, warning that there's still plenty of time for surprises. ``We've got a long way to go yet.'' Swenson led the race Monday topping the Alaska Range at 3,500-foot Rainy Pass, but was overtaken by defending champion Joe Runyan at Rohn on Tuesday. He had a cut on his face and a cracked plastic runner on his sled as he mushed away from this Athabascan Indian village of 110 people at Iditarod milepost 367. Swenson said the damage wouldn't stop him from reaching McGrath, the next checkpoint 48 miles from here, where he either would repair the runner or change sleds. Behind Swenson on the trail through Farewell Burn, eighth-place racer Tim Osmar of Clam Gulch fired shots into the air to clear the trail of several buffaloes. The Iditarod Trail is named for a tiny ghost town it passes through. The race commemorates the 1925 emergency delivery by relay dog teams of life-saving diphtheria serum to Nome. Butcher won the race in 1986, 1987 and 1988 and took second place last year. Swenson won in 1977, 1979, 1981 and 1982. He has finished in the top 10 every year since 1973, when the Iditarod was started.

DOC.HEAD: South Korea Stops Searching North Korean Tunnel
DOC.TEXT: Booby traps and leaks forced South Korean and U.S. teams to stop searching a border tunnel dug by the Communist North as a possible invasion route, military officials said Wednesday. At least 10 booby traps have been dismantled since a dog working with inspection teams was killed Sunday when it apparently set off an explosion, officials said. No soldier has been injured. The teams were draining the shaft of water after plugging it with sandbags for protection, Defense Ministry officials said Wednesday. The tunnel was drilled open Saturday through an intercept tunnel from the southern sector of the Demilitarized Zone separating the capitalist south from North Korean. It was the fourth tunnel discovered since 1974 beneath the zone, but North Korea has denied digging any tunnels. An American officer and a South Korean soldier searching the first tunnel discovered in 1974 were reportedly killed, as were 10 others in 1975 and 1978 while searching two other tunnels. South Korean officials believe North Korea dug more than 20 border passages under the heavily fortified border to allow commando units to bypass South Korea's frontline soldiers in the event of an invasion. A military report, presented Tuesday to a National Assembly committee, said about 250 U.S. specialists are working to help discover other tunnels.

DOC.HEAD: Congressmen Protest Effort to Revoke Scholarship
DOC.TEXT: A group of congressmen protested Wednesday the Army's decision to retroactively revoke an ROTC scholarship given to a star recruit who later admitted he is gay. In a letter to Brig. Gen. Charles R. Hansell, head of the ROTC second regional command at Fort Knox, Ky., 23 members asked the Army to abandon its attempt to recover $25,000 in scholarship money given to James M. Holobaugh. The Army was set to award a commission last May when Holobaugh, 24, at member of the Reserve Officer Training Corps at Washington University in St. Louis, disclosed his homosexuality. After a preliminary hearing in December, a hearing officer recommended in January that the Army order Holobaugh to repay the four-year scholarship. ``We believe that to compel him to repay this money would not only be fundamentally unfair; it would also reflect an appalling mean-spiritedness which has no place in the ROTC,'' the lawmakers said in a two-page letter. There was no answer at Hansell's office early Wednesday evening. Last week, Lt. Col. John Calvin Blake, an Army ROTC spokesman, said the case was probably the first of its kind. ``The investigation is still ongoing and whatever the hearing officer recommended has to go through a careful review before there is a final decision,'' Blake said. The Pentagon regards homosexuals as unsuitable for military service. The U.S. Supreme Court recently dealt opponents of that policy a blow by refusing to hear two appeals of the Pentagon policy. U.S. Rep. Gerry Studds, D-Mass., who is gay, drafted the letter. Most of the signers were Democrats although two Republicans, Reps. Bill Green of New York and Christopher Shays of Connecticut, also signed. Another who signed the letter was Rep. Barney Frank, D-Mass., the only other member of Congress who has publicly stated he is gay. ``Throughout his career as a cadet, Mr. Holobaugh has compiled an enviable record of performance, with ROTC evaluations describing him as `possessing outstanding leadership potential,' the letter said. The legislators also noted that the Army had held Holobaugh up ``as a public model of excellence'' in ROTC recruitment advertisements. Holobaugh, who expects to graduate in the spring, said he was dating women when he began college in 1984 and that it wasn't until late 1988 or early 1989 that he realized he was homosexual.

DOC.HEAD: Slain Man Reported to be Sinn Fein Member
DOC.TEXT: A man reportedly identified by IRA supporters as a member of the group's political wing Sinn Fein was slain by a gunman in a Belfast suburb Wednesday night. Belfast police headquarters did not immediately identify the man but said he had just left a police base in Lurgan, where he had reported as a condition for bail, when a man in a car opened fire. Police said the car believed to have been used by the gunman was later found on fire on a road near Lurgan, 20 miles southwest of Belfast. The British domestic news agency Press Association quoted unidentified IRA supporters as saying the slain man was Sam Marshall, 31, who was out on bail on a charge of illegal possession of ammunition. The news agency quoted the supporters as saying Marshall had been warned by police in recent days that he was on a Protestant paramilitary hit list. Press Association said that in the 1980s Marshall served a lengthy prison term for illegal possession of firearms. The IRA supporters said Marshall was a member of Sinn Fein, a legal group. The outlawed IRA is fighting British rule in Northern Ireland. The mainly Roman Catholic group wants to unite the predominantly Protestant province with the Republic of Ireland under socialist rule. The republic is 95 percent Catholic.

DOC.HEAD: Spill of 100,000 Gallons Fouls Waterway, Investigators Probe Blast
DOC.TEXT: Coast Guard crews fought to contain more than 100,000 gallons of fuel oil spreading Wednesday from a barge that exploded and burned in a busy waterway between New Jersey and New York City's Staten Island. Investigators speculated that Tuesday's blast may have been caused by either static electricity, machinery sparks or friction between the barge and a tug towing it away from a Citgo Petroleum Corp. docks in Linden. Two explosions ripped through the barge Cibro Savannah within 15 minutes, cracking the vessel and spilling part of its 4.2 million-gallon cargo into the Arthur Kill waterway. One person, the captain, was injured. It was the third time in a week crews had to place containment booms around a vessel to prevent further pollution in the shipping channel, which connects through the Kill Van Kull to New York Habor. ``We're looking for ignition sources, anything that could have caused a spark,'' said Coast Guard Lt. Cmdr. Jay Hess, the senior investigating officer. The explosions left two gaping holes in the center of the 400-foot, 8,150-ton barge, which is owned by Cirillo Brothers Petroleum Corp. of New York. Capt. Robert North, the Coast Guard's officer in charge of New York-area waters, said part of a four-mile slick reached open waters but most of it had been contained by booms around the barge. Carol Ash, commissioner of the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation, said containment booms still in place after smaller spills last week prevented Tuesday's slick from reaching Prall's Island, a wildlife refuge in the Arthur Kill where migratory birds and marine life spawn. Ms. Ash said workers found one oil-soaked seabird and attempts were being made to save it. ``I'm getting a bit tired of coming out to these things,'' New Jersey Gov. Jim Florio told reporters at the Citgo docks. ``The law is either not being complied with, or, if it is being complied with, it is not sufficient.'' The Arthur Kill was the site of a 567,000-gallon oil spill on Jan. 1-2 from a ruptured Exxon underwater pipeline. Last Thursday, 3,500 gallons of heavy crude spilled from a barge into the Arthur Kill at Exxon's refinery in Linden, a day after 30,000 gallons of heating oil spilled into the Kill Van Kull from a barge anchored in Bayonne.

DOC.HEAD: Justice Raises No Objection to Latin American Routes Transfer
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3rd graf: ``Completion of,'' to note creditors must approve; INSERTS antepenultimate graf: ``Pan Am,'' to note Pan Am claims to some of the routes. Also on financial circuits
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Eastern
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department has no objections to the planned purchase of Latin American routes by American Airlines from Eastern Airlines, the department said Wednesday. The proposed $471 million transaction still must be approved by the Transportation Department and the bankruptcy court in New York overseeing the reorganization of Eastern. Completion of the route sale is a necessary condition for final approval of a reorganization agreement between Eastern and its unsecured creditors. Under that accord the unsecured creditors, who are owed $980 million by Eastern, would receive about $490 million in cash and notes. Joe Krovisky, spokesman for the Justice Department's antitrust division, said the division informed the two companies and the Transportation Department that its review of potential antitrust ramifications of the sale had yielded no reason to object. Pan American has filed objections to the route transfer with the Transportation Department, arguing that it would eventually make American the dominant airline in Miami. Pan Am asked for a public hearing on the issue. Eastern and American have until March 13 to file replies to Pan Am's objections. Transportation Department spokesman Hal Paris said a decision on the sale probably would be made in three or four weeks. Under the proposal, American, the nation's largest airline, would take over Eastern's routes to Ecuador, Peru, Colombia, Bolivia, Panama, Guatemala, Costa Rica and Paraguay. Pan Am told the Transportation Department that it, rather than American, should be awarded service from Miami to Guayaquil and Quito, Ecuador; Lima, Peru; and Bogota, Colombia. Included in the transfer would be Eastern's Miami-Toronto route, which Pan Am said it should be awarded. If Eastern sheds the routes, it would be about two-thirds its present size.

DOC.HEAD: Gas Explosion, Fire Raze Restaurant, 11 Killed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with cause of explosion pinpointed, sexes of the victims, details. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: A gas explosion and a fire killed 11 people and injured six Wednesday night in an Asian restaurant in downtown Frankfurt, officials said. Fire brigade chief Guenter Burbaum, who gave the casualty figures, told reporters at the scene the blaze broke out about 8:40 p.m. (2:40 p.m. EST) and gutted the Koryo Chinese-Korean restaurant on the second floor of a five-story building near Frankfurt's Cathedral. Police spokesman Kurt Kraus said a gas leak in the kitchen apparently caused the blast, but that experts were still investigating. ``The explosion probably occurred in the kitchen,'' he told The Associated Press. Kraus said four victims were in serious condition. He said among the injured were diners who leaped from windows to escape the flames. He could not say if any foreigners were among the victims, which included five men, five women and a child. ``We have not identified anyone. The identification of victims will take at least until tomorrow,'' Kraus said. ``At the moment, we have no idea about their nationalities.'' Rescuers said two of the injured were in critical condition. ``I heard a loud noise and I looked out of my window. All I saw was black smoke and a woman hanging from the window who appeared to be dead,'' said Wilhelm Sehrt, who lives across the street. ``I also saw a girl, about seven or eight years old, lying on the street, bleeding. I don't know what happened to her. I also heard people screaming, `Fire, fire!''' Witnesses saw the body of a man covering that of a young child. Kraus said authorities were trying to determine how many people were in the restaurant at the time of the blast. Police said most of the victims appeared to be restaurant guests. Burbaum said the explosion apparently preceded the fire. The blaze was extinguished less than an hour after it broke out. No other buildings in the area suffered damage.

DOC.HEAD: Occhetto Urges Italy's Communist to Unite Behind New Party
DOC.TEXT: The leader of Italy's Communist Party late Wednesday urged members to support radical changes in the party in hopes of uniting the nation's fractured left. Achille Occhetto spoke at an extraordinary congress that will decide on his proposal, which could lead to the rebirth of the party _ with a new name and without its hammer and sickle symbol. ``The problems facing communism not only affect the countries of Eastern Europe but also our very own country,'' Occhetto said. Occhetto, secretary of the West's largest Communist Party, stunned other party leaders in November when, three days after the opening of the Berlin Wall, he called for overhauling the party in line with reforms sweeping the East bloc. The party's Central Committee endorsed Occhetto's proposal but called for an extraordinary congress to decide the issue. About 67 percent of the 1,092 delegates are loyal to Occhetto, more than enough to assure the success of his proposal in voting on Saturday. The proposal has been opposed by members of the Old Guard, which wants much more limited reforms. Longtime members argue that the party can be proud of its traditions. They also say the party has criticized abuses by Soviet-bloc governments and should not panic and endorse dramatic changes just because communism has collapsed in Eastern Europe. Italian Communists have long proclaimed their independence from Moscow, pledged their support for Western parliamentary democracy, suppprted Italy's membership in NATO and criticised Moscow's interventions in Czechoslovakia in 1968 and in Afghanistan in 1979. The Communists have been kept out of power for 45 years. But Occhetto said Wednesday night that a new party could help forge socialist unity in Italy, bring the country's fractured left under a single umbrella and pose an alternative to the Christian Democrats, who have dominated or led every post-war government. He said the Communists can move closer to the Greens, Radicals and liberal Catholics within the Christian Democrats. The Socialists, Italy's third-largest party after Christian Democrats and the Communists, have been coalition partners with the Christian Democrats in the last decade. They also hope to surpass the Communists in the polls and become the de facto leader of the Italian left. Over the last 20 years, Italian Communists have seen a steady decline both in membership, now about 1.4 million, and in their strength at the polls.

DOC.HEAD: Three Famous Australian Beaches Closed After Oil Spill
DOC.TEXT: Three of Australia's top beaches were closed Wednesday after a 2{-mile oil slick swept ashore in Sydney. The Bondi, Tamarama and Bronte beaches were closed by Waverley Council inspectors, dead sea birds and fish washed ashore after being caught up in the thick oil, which started staining the sands late Tuesday. The New South Wales State Pollution Control Commission began an inquiry Wednesday into the cause of the spill, which a spokesman said was believed to come from a passing ship. Bondi, six miles east of the city, is one of Sydney's leading tourists attractions and famed for its scantily-clad sunbathers.

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Agency to Investigate Haiti for Human Rights Abuses
With AM-Haiti
DOC.TEXT: The U.N. Human Rights Commission agreed Wednesday to begin a special investigation into allegations of abuses in Haiti and to continue monitoring the situations in Iran and El Salvador. In recognition of recent democratic elections in Chile, the 43-nation commission agreed to drop Chile from the countries meriting close attention because of consistent and gross violations. The commission voted not to act on a mildly worded resolution that would have secured an official role for the United Nations in a planned visit by human rights experts to Iraq. Iraq was cited last month for its ``abyssmal'' human rights record in a U.S. State Department report. The commission adopted without a vote a resolution sponsored by France and Peru to appoint a special investigator on Haiti, saying the situation under Gen. Prosper Avril ``remains disturbing and even seems to have deteriorated since July 1989.'' It said it was ``alarmed by the proliferation of acts of violence in Haiti, particularly against arrested or detained persons, and by the apparent inability of the judicial system to put an end to such acts.'' The commission is the United Nations' highest human rights body. It said in agreeing to continue the annual investigation into the El Salvador situation, started in 1981, that it was concerned at the spiral of abuses committed by both extreme right-wing death squads and leftist rebels. A resolution voiced ``deep concern at the continued unsatisfactory capacity of the judicial system'' to track down those responsible for violations. The commission also agreed by consensus to continue its investigation on Iran, expressing concern at complaints of unlawful executions and torture cited in a recent report by U.N. expert Reynaldo Galindo Pohl. It welcomed Tehran's ``favorable reception'' to suggestions by Galindo Pohl after his brief visit to Iran in January, the first by a U.N. investigator. The Salvadoran lawyer will make a second trip there, at Iran's invitation, prior to his report to the commission's 1991 session. Galindo Pohl's recommendations included one that the International Committee of the Red Cross be allowed to visit prisoners throughout Iran. The mildness of the resolution drew fire from the United States. ``We regret how little evidence there is that Iran has sought to moderate its grave human rights violations,'' said U.S. representative Beverly Zweiben. ``Summary executions of prisoners continue as does imprisonment for political purposes.'' Iranian Ambassador Sirous Nasseri attacked the U.S. stand as ``arrogance.'' In the only vote of the day, the commission voted 18-14 to take no action on a Western-backed proposal that the Subcommission on Prevention of Discrimination and Protection of Minorities report back to the commission, its parent body, on a planned visit to Iraq. The proposal said the United Nations should sponsor the visit. The decision means the subcommission's 26 legal experts will be free to visit Iraq as individuals, but will be bound to report back to the commission. The commission agreed without a vote that no further need existed for a special U.N. investigator on Chile now that the recently elected government of Patricio Alywin promised restoration of human rights. Under the military rule of Gen. Augusto Pinochet, Chile joined South Africa and Israel in being regularly criticized for grave human rights violations at the commission's annual session. The six-week meeting ends Friday.

DOC.HEAD: East German Premier Criticizes Kohl for Evasion on Border
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf after 8th `Kohl on...' to UPDATE with White House statement; pickup graf 9 pvs `The premier...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BER6
DOC.TEXT: Premier Hans Modrow said Wednesday that East Germans are ready to sign a border treaty with Poland, and he criticized West Germany for trying impose a hasty unity plan on his people. The Communist premier and other top East German officials have lately displayed irritation with West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl and the fast pace of unification sought by their Western neighbor. In Bonn, opposition Social Democrats, who also charge that Kohl is pushing too hard for a speedy unification, insisted on a Germany-wide referendum over the issue. Modrow's concerns over unification echoed those of Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who on Tuesday urged a slow and careful approach and said NATO membership for a united Germany was ``out of the question.'' At the last parliamentary session before East Germans go to the polls on March 18, Modrow sought to assure Poland that his nation lays no claim to German lands forfeited after the Nazi defeat in 1945. About one third of modern-day Poland was German land under the Third Reich. Kohl has been ``evasive and ambiguous'' in statements on the border, Modrow said. Kohl on Tuesday agreed to support a West German parliamentary declaration of respect for the current border, but did not make clear whether he thought the two Germanys could jointly recognize the border before they are reunited. In Washington, the White House on Wednesday praised Kohl's latest stand as a positive and important step. ``As the president has made clear, the U.S. recognizes the current German-Polish border,'' said White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater. The premier said he and Kohl had received a letter signed by 32 U.S. senators calling on both German states to negotiate separate border treaties with Poland into one single accord. ``East Germany is prepared to do this immediately,'' Modrow said. West German government spokesman Hans Klein repeated that Bonn would begin negotiations on such an accord only after the East German elections seat a new government. Modrow said an accord recognizing the Oder and Neisse rivers as the permanent border could be negotiated by the two Germanys. The accord could be ratified immediately after unification, he said. Kohl and the Social Democrats differ not only on the pace of unification but on the means. The Social Democrats have sought unification through creation of a new constitution by the German people. The chancellor has said he favors unification under a section of the constitution permitting individual East German states to decide for themselves whether to join their western neighbor. Such a procedure would likely be the quickest route. On the issue of a unified Germany's role in NATO, the Social Democrats said the organization and the Warsaw Pact should at some point be replaced by ``a European security system'' including the Soviet Union, the United States and Canada. British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd said Wednesday Britain believed strongly that a united Germany should remain in NATO. ``It would be sensible for the stability of Europe,'' he said, answering questions in the House of Commons. Modrow also criticized central bankers with the West German Bundesbank for leaking details of a working paper on how the two Germanys could merge economically. Der Spiegel magazine and other media have reported what they described as a secret agreement among financial officials from both nations to make the West German mark legal tender in both states and to exchange much of the $10 billion in East German savings accounts at a one-to-one rate. Reports of a pre-arranged monetary union have been denied by officials in both Germanys, who contend no decisions will be made before the East German election. But the rumors have hurt the West German mark's value on international markets, prompting some fearful East Germans to withdraw their savings, and have inflated the exchange rate for non-convertible East marks among black-market traders. ``It must be clearly said which side is pushing for excessive haste and spreading rumors,'' Modrow told Parliament. ``It's clear a monetary union can't be built in a day. It must be thoroughly prepared.'' He said speculation stirred by the monetary union leaks are further damaging East Germany's economy. The Social Democrats, trying to woo citizens of both nations as the unification process continues, also proposed immediate measures for the ``social security'' of East Germans who could face hardships as their nation undergoes major economic changes. Parliament Speaker Guenther Maleuda also lashed out at West German politicians for interfering in the East German election campaign. Kohl, Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher and former Chancellor Willy Brandt are among those public figures who appear to be using the East German campaign as a dress rehearsal for December elections in West Germany, as well as to expand their party's voter support in anticipation of reunification. ``Let the candidates from our country take over the campaign rostrum for the first free, fair and secret elections to Parliament,'' Maleuda said. Also on Wednesday, the East German Defense Ministry responded to reports from Washington alleging some Soviet SS-23 missiles based in East Germany were a ``possible violation'' of the 1987 superpower treaty on eliminating intermediate-range nuclear forces. Defense Ministry spokesman Col. Uwe Hempel said the rockets were not covered by the INF accord, but that their destruction had begun by agreement with the Soviet Union.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutor Brands Him Liar Who Tried To Use Influence
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 14 grafs to UPDATE with defense's closing arguments, quotes, details; picks up 9th graf, `He is ...'. EDITS to tighten.
DOC.TEXT: U.S. District Judge Robert Aguilar was a liar who tried to use his influence to sway criminal cases and thwart investigations, a federal prosecutor said in closing arguments in the judge's trial Wednesday. But Aguilar's lawyer described the judge as a ``kind, sweet, generous man,'' who had done some ``foolish'' and ``improper'' things to reassure his friends but had not tampered with justice. ``Don't let the federal bench lose a man of this quality,'' defense lawyer Patrick Hallinan urged the jury. He contended that the FBI, after interviewing Aguilar's fellow judges and finding no improper influences, ``proceeded to try to create a crime'' by entrapping Aguilar in secretly taped conversations. The arguments were to conclude Thursday, and the case was to go to the jury. In his closing argument to the U.S. District Court jury, Justice Department lawyer William Keefer said Aguilar lied to the FBI, told a witness to lie to the grand jury, and lied repeatedly as a witness in his own defense. Keefer said Aguilar made a ``corrupt endeavor'' to influence two fellow judges in criminal cases, falsely told a deputy marshal he was unaware of a fugitive's whereabouts and tried to manufacture a coverup when the FBI closed in on him. The prosecutor said possible motives were a house purchase on generous terms from the woman who was a fugitive, an interest-free loan from a defendant in one of the criminal cases, and another defendant's help in getting a job for a brother of the judge. Keefer said Aguilar was a man who thought he could get away with breaking the rules because of his office. Aguilar told an ``unequivocal lie'' to FBI agents and fabricated a story to get a grand jury investigation sidetracked, confident that ``when a federal judge shuts the door, the door's usually shut,'' Keefer said. ``The greatest failure of the prosecution is the absence of any motive,'' Hallinan countered in his closing argument on Aguilar's behalf. The ``foolish things'' he said Aguilar had done included some lies and exaggerations to co-defendant Rudy Tham's lawyer and others, secretly recorded and played for the jury, and a continued association with co-defendant Abe Chapman, an elderly relative by marriage with a long criminal record. ``But ladies and gentlemen, we are not in a church, we are in a court,'' Hallinan said. The 58-year-old judge from San Jose, who was appointed in 1980 by President Carter, is charged with eight felonies punishable by up to 55 years in prison and $2 million in fines on conviction. He also could be removed from office by Congress, regardless of the verdict. Aguilar is accused of approaching two fellow judges to seek favorable treatment for Tham, a former Teamster leader who was seeking a new trial on an embezzlement conviction, and businessman Ronald Cloud, a longtime friend of Aguilar's convicted of bank fraud in a Nevada casino sale. He is accused of helping his former legal secretary, Vera Hoff, conceal her presence in Mexico, where she fled in 1979 to avoid a two-year sentence for tax evasion. Aguilar is also accused of twice disclosing a wiretap to Chapman, asking Tham's attorney to conceal their discussions about the case from the grand jury, and lying to the FBI about the Tham case and the Chapman wiretaps. Aguilar testified that he spoke briefly to U.S. District Judge Stanley Weigel, asking about the status of Tham's case, and to U.S. District Judge Samuel Conti, mentioning that Cloud was a friend as a preface to a request to appear as a character witness. Weigel and Conti both said they didn't think Aguilar was trying to influence them.

DOC.HEAD: Committee to Drop Probe of Gingrich; Admonish Him Over House Purchase
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS grafs 11-13: ``Members do not,'' to explain reporting not required for members own homes, which this is not
DOC.TEXT: The House ethics committee decided Wednesday to drop its investigation of Republican Whip Newt Gingrich but will criticize his failure to disclose the purchase of a home, the lawmaker who filed the complaint against him said. ``The ethics committee has resolved the Gingrich matter by deciding not to investigate further, but by deciding to admonish Gingrich'' for not reporting his purchase of a home with his daughter, said Rep. Bill Alexander, D-Ark. A House source, speaking only on condition he not be identified, provided the same information about the committee decision on the Georgia Republican. The panel _ formally the Committee on Standards of Official Conduct _ met behind closed doors Wednesday but made no announcement. Gingrich's case has generated keen interest because he filed the ethics complaint that triggered the investigation _ and eventual resignation last year _ of former Speaker Jim Wright. A Chicago law firm hired to provide the committee advice on the Gingrich case reportedly told the panel late last year that there was insufficient evidence to pursue the investigation. Alexander, who filed two separate complaints against Gingrich, called the committee action ``a practical resolution of the Gingrich matter. Futher disciplinary actions against Mr. Gingrich are therefore not needed at the present time.'' Gingrich spokesman Tony Blankley said his boss would not immediately comment on the committee decision because there had been no formal notification from the panel. In a complaint filed with the committee last October, Alexander said that Gingrich failed to make the required disclosure of the purchase of the home with his daughter in Fulton County, Ga. in June 1986. The complaint said that Gingrich's annual financial disclosure forms beginning in 1986 failed to report the home purchase, failed to list the property as an asset and failed to list the $77,800 mortgage as a liability. Members do not have to disclose financial information about homes they live in, but Gingrich said last year this home was for his daughter. At the time, Gincrich said he was ``incensed that the fact that I helped my daughter by co-signing, or signing the note, or whatever one calls it, gets drug out and becomes a story.'' He said Alexander's decision to include his daughter's mortgage in the complaint ``carries politics in the House to a new low level. I mean it just strikes me as madness.'' Alexander triggered the Gingrich probe last April with a complaint that the No. 2-ranking House Republican violated violated House rules and federal campaign finance laws in the operation of a limited partnership created in 1984. The ``COS Limited Partnership'' promoted ``Window of Opportunity,'' a book written by Gingrich and two others. The partnership was made up of 21 individuals who each put up $5,000 to promote the book. Gingrich was not an investor, but his wife, a co-author, was paid more than $10,000 for running the operation. The complaint contended the $105,000 raised by the partnership could be considered income to Gingrich, in violation of House limits on members' outside earnings, or it could constitute a gift to Gingrich, in violation of House rules that prohibit members from accepting gifts worth more than $100 from anyone with a direct interest in legislation. The compliant also contended that if the money were considered to be campaign contributions, Gingrich would be in violation of reporting obligations and restrictions under campaign finance laws. The second complaint, filed in October, charged Gingrich with a long list of alleged campaign finance and financial disclosure violations.

DOC.HEAD: W.Va. Hit by First Teacher Strike
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 8-10, `Teachers in...' with 3 grafs to UPDATE with more counties scheduled to strike; ADD that one county voted not to, show that Mississippi teachers are lowest paid in the country; picks up 11th graf pvs, `The walkout...'
DOC.TEXT: The nation's second lowest-paid teachers traded pens and pencils for picket signs Wednesday in nine counties in a dispute with the governor and legislature over a pay raise. West Virginia's first school strike was expected to be joined by teachers in more counties Thursday. Gov. Gaston Caperton, who earlier this week said negotiations with the teachers were over because of the strike threat, told a joint Senate and House of Delegates session Wednesday night he is willing to resume talks if the teachers return to the classroom. ``When calm and reason are restored and the teaching force returns to the classrooms, I will begin again to meet with the educational community to plan for the improvements of education on every level, including teacher pay,'' Caperton said in his six-minute address. But Caperton also reiterated his refusal to ask for a teacher pay raise in the face of a strike threat. ``Let me say again: This state government will not conduct its affairs under intimidation,'' he said, receiving a standing ovation from senators and delegates. West Virginia Education Association President Kayetta Meadows said after Caperton's address that her group is willing to meet with him but isn't ready to call off the strike ``at this point.'' Teachers in at least 18 more counties planned to strike Thursday, said WVEA spokeswoman Jackie Goodwin, but educators in one county voted to stay on the job. ``We're committed to keeping it up as long as we have to,'' said Connie Taylor, an English and speech teacher on picket duty at Oak Hill High School in Fayette County. The association, which represents 16,000 of the state's 22,000 public school teachers, says average teacher pay in the state was $21,904, 49th in the nation behind Mississippi, before a 5 percent pay raise last month. An additional 3,000 teachers are represented by the West Virginia Federation of Teachers. The walkout began after Caperton and legislative leaders on Tuesday withdrew their offer of an additional 5 percent pay raise, beginning in July, for teachers and higher education employees. In exchange, they wanted an end to strike threats by the two teacher unions. The agreement collapsed 14 hours after it was announced after the WVEA refused to call off the strike, saying instead it would defer action until after Saturday's end of the legislative session. House Speaker Chuck Chambers and Senate President Keith Burdette said the continued strike threat made it impossible for them to win passage of the pay raise, which would have been financed by a new $1 per ton tax on coal mining. Some teachers blamed the walkout on Caperton. ``We did not want to strike,'' said Ted Dixon, co-president of the Fayette County Education Association. ``But he's put the teachers in West Virginia in this posture.'' About 1,000 students from five Monongalia County secondary schools left classes Wednesday in support of their teachers. The walkouts lasted less than an hour. School staff employees in Monongalia County were urged not to cross teachers' picket lines beginning Thursday. ``We support our teachers,'' said Janice Wilson, president of Monongalia County School Service Personnel. ``We don't think they should be 49th in the nation in pay. But we don't think a walkout is the answer.'' At Back Creek Elementary near Inwood in Berkeley County, parents plan to join teachers on the picket line Thursday to show their support, said parents' organizer Debbie Dunnigan. ``We want to send a message to Governor Caperton that we're mad as hell, that we're not going to put up with this anymore, and if we don't invest in our children's future today, there's not going to be a future for them tomorrow,'' Dunnigan said. County school boards canceled classes Wednesday in many counties hit by the strike. In Boone County, 17 of 433 teachers reported for work. State law does not permit teachers or other employees to engage in collective bargaining, and Attorney General Roger Tompkins said he has found nothing in the law to permit a strike. The teacher unions, however, contend a 1980 Supreme Court decision gives all public employees the right to engage in work stoppages.

DOC.HEAD: Activists Say Stage Set for Lithuanian Independence Vote Sunday
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 14 grafs to raise reference to report that $34 billion bill being presented if republic seceeds, minor editing to conform. Picks up 15th, `Siaurusavicius said Sajudis...'
DOC.TEXT: Lithuania's parliament will meet this weekend to declare independence from the Soviet Union, activists in the Baltic republic said Wednesday. Sweeping victories in recent elections have given backers of Sajudis, the pro-independence popular movement, dominance in the Lithuanian parliament, and Sajudis leaders have decided to force the issue of secession, activist Audris Siaurusavicius said. Vilnius Radio reported that Lithuanian President Algirdas Brazauskas met with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Monday to discuss secession, and was presented with a bill for $34 billion that the republic supposedly owes the Soviet Union for resources invested there. ``But Lithuania has not presented its bill yet to the Soviet Union,'' for losses incurred by 50 years of Soviet rule, Siaurusavicius said. Brazauskas, speaking Wednesday night on Lithuanian television, said there was no need ``to frighten ourselves and others'' about the economic consequences of secession. He said the republic would be so much better off on its own that the advantages would offset its debt to Moscow, according to Eduardas Potashinskas, another Sajudis activist. According to a draft law currently under consideration in the Soviet legislature, a republic that wants to secede faces a series of lengthy procedures, including a five-year cooling-off period and required approval from the 2,250-member Congress of People's Deputies. The Soviet constitution guarantees republics the right to secede, but the procedure has not been spelled out in Soviet law. The parliament is sure ``to come out with some form of declaration of independence'' when it meets Sunday, said Potashinskas, an editor at Lithuanian TV, in a telephone interview from Vilnius, Lithuania's capital. Pro-secession sentiment in Lithuania has been swelling for months, but Sajudis decided to move now to pre-empt Gorbachev's plans for a vastly more powerful presidency with the right to crack down on restive republics. The national Congress is to meet Monday to consider the presidency proposal. ``Why so fast? I think Gorbachev himself created such a reaction,'' said Siaurusavicius, a reporter for Rebirth, the Sajudis newspaper. ``If there were no such proposal on the presidency, we wouldn't have done this now.'' Gorbachev has repeatedly denounced ``separatists'' and asked activists to give Moscow time to work out the terms of a new Soviet federation before moving to secede. The Lithuanian Supreme Soviet will meet Saturday night to settle procedural questions and address independence on Sunday, said Siaurusavicius. Siaurusavicius said it was not clear what changes would immediately follow the declaration. ``We just have to say it. This is not secession but it's saying they must end their annexation _ they should leave.'' All three Baltic republics, Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia, were independent nations between the two world wars. They were annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940 while under occupation by the Red Army. Siaurusavicius said Sajudis leaders were expecting Moscow's response to the declaration of independence to be restrained, and did not anticipate use of force. But he said the republic of 3.7 million people could already feel the effects of a mounting Soviet economic blockade, with many factories hurting for raw materials and expecting the pinch to get worse. He predicted the Soviet Union would probably not be among the first to respond to Lithuania's planned appeal to the countries of the world to recognize it as a full-fledged sovereign state. The declaration will technically be merely a reconfirmation of Lithuania's declaration of independence in 1918, Siaurusavicius said. Last month, the Lithuanian parliament passed a measure declaring as ``unlawful and invalid'' the 1940 act that incorporated the republic into the Soviet Union. It called for talks with the Kremlin on restoring Lithuanian independence. An article in the government newspaper Izvestia on Wednesday complained that ``Lithuania is getting public opinion used to the fact that it `is leaving,''' without thinking through the economic and political difficulties secession will create. ``God, can we really imagine what pain, suffering, clashes and insults this break threatens?'' wrote L. Kapeliushny, Izvestia's correspondent in Vilnius. He listed among expected problems trade imbalances, the difficulty of deciding what to do about various Soviet-built factories and the fate of Lithuanian residents who want to retain their Soviet citizenship. About half the Soviet Union's 15 republics now have popular groups pushing for independence or greater sovereignty, including Moldavia, Georgia, Armenia, Azerbaijan, Estonia and Latvia.

DOC.HEAD: Sandinistas in Provinces Passing Out Weapons in Wake of Defeat
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERT 2 grafs after 7th graf, The Sandinistas ... to UPDATE with Cuba cutting off military aid. Picks up 8th, `Officials of ... and CORRECTS election date in 12th graf, `Officials of the United ... to Feb. 25
DOC.TEXT: Sandinista leaders say they'll hand over the government on April 25, but their local forces don't appear ready to hand over their guns. The army, a party organ, is delivering truckloads of assault rifles to civilians in Jinotega and Matagalpa provinces who live in the poor neighborhoods the leftist Sandinistas regard as their ``social base.'' ``All the barrios have guns. They are all defending their land,'' said Francisca Castileblanco, a 52-year-old tortilla vendor, showing off her new AK-47. High-ranking Sandinista officials in Jinotega and Matagalpa at first denied civilians were being armed. When confronted with evidence, the officials asserted they were creating a self-defense network to fend off possible attacks by Contra forces that the Sandinistas have been battling for years. But they also acknowledged that guns are going to people living on land confiscated after the 1979 revolution, areas the party regards as its grassroots. The Sandinistas have said they will ``defend the conquests of the revolution,'' including opposing any efforts to return land to previous owners and possibly other aspects of the conservative economic policies of the new government of President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro. Cuban President Fidel Castro said Wednesday he is cutting off all military aid to Nicaragua before the Chamorro government takes office on April 25, Cuba's official news agency Prensa Latina, monitored in Mexico City, reported. It quoted Castro as saying that Cuban assistance in housing construction and health care could continue if the new government desires. Officials of the United National Opposition say they won't dislodge peasants from land that is being worked, even if it was expropriated under Sandinista rule. ``There is a little tension,'' acknowledged Col. Manuel Salvatierra, the regional military commander. ``There is a lot of uncertainty about what will happen when the new government takes over.'' International observers, diplomats and opposition officials are worried about the large-scale distribution of weapons at a time when tensions are so high. ``It's a time bomb,'' said Luis Serrano, part of the Organization of American States observer team monitoring Matagalpa and Jinotega provinces. Officials of the United National Opposition, the conservative coalition that defeated the Sandinistas in the Feb. 25 elections, say they have reports of arms being distributed in several other provinces and that the issue is on the agenda for transition negotiations between the Sandinistas and UNO. UNO representatives have also met with top-ranking regional officials of the Sandinista party and the Sandinista army, said Santiago Rivas, UNO's legal adviser in Matagalpa, 78 miles north of Managua. ``We've argued that they shouldn't give arms to civilians. It could provoke a civil war,'' Rivas said in an interview. Their rallies resound with political battle cries such as ``One Single Army,'' a slogan expressing the revolutionary goal of melding the people, the party and the military into a united armed force. ``They are trying to intimidate,'' said the Rev. Eliar Pineda, a Roman Catholic priest in Jinotega whose family backed UNO. Sandinista gangs known as ``turbas'' have demonstrated in Jinotega, 100 miles north of Managua, and in Matagalpa since the election. Intimidated UNO supporters have stayed at home rather than celebrate the coalition's resounding victory at the polls. ``They are afraid of provoking the Sandinistas,'' Pineda said. Rivas said UNO fears an attempt to destabilize the country during the delicate transition from a leftist Sandinista government to the UNO, with its free-market philosphy. ``The top Sandinista leadership seems disposed to hand over power, but at the midlevel, there are those who want to create a coup at the base of the party,'' he said. President Daniel Ortega has said there will be a peaceful transition of power. But he and other Sandinista leaders have made it clear the smoothness of that transition depends in large part upon negotiations to demobilize the U.S.-backed Contras and an agreement on the armed forces. Property is another critical issue in the transition. UNO policy is to privatize as much as possible of the state-run economy without evicting people from confiscated lands. But Sandinista campaign rhetoric and the party-controlled media have spread fear and doubt among the poor. ``The people here are afraid of losing their land,'' said Mrs. Castileblanco, the tortilla vendor and a party organizer in Barrio Roger Angin, a slum of 400 homes without water and electricity on confiscated land on the edge of Jinotega. She went into her house, a ramshackle shell of mismatched planks and tin over a dirt floor, and pulled out her new AK-47. It is one of 400 assault rifles she and her neighbors said the army delivered on Feb. 27, two days after the election. Mrs. Castileblanco and her neighbors say the AK-47s were distributed to anyone age 15 and over. In Matagalpa, residents of the Pancasan neighborhood told a similar story. When asked what the guns were for, 16-year-old Jose Alexis Guido Gonzalez said: ``If the Contra comes or if the UNO comes to kick on our door. We can use these arms against anyone who is against us.'' Sandinista officials say they are arming people against the possibility of a Contra offensive.
