DOC.HEAD: Frank Greer: This Year's Hot Political Consultant
LaserPhoto WX13 of March 7
DOC.TEXT: On the wall by Frank Greer's office door is a Doug Wilder campaign poster, signed by the nation's first black elected governor with thanks ``for making this possible.'' The space next to the poster Greer hopes to fill this year with a picture of the nation's second black elected governor: his client and candidate in Georgia, Andrew Young. Greer, a 43-year-old political consultant, says Wilder's election last fall was ``probably one of the most rewarding experiences politically and personally in my life.'' A white southerner, Greer adds, ``More than anything else, I was proud of the South. I always thought the South would lead the way in race relations.'' Born and raised in Alabama, Greer designs campaigns for liberal and moderate Democrats. His consulting firm has $15 million in billings a year from a Pennsylvania Avenue office overlooking the Potomac River. Greer is widely regarded as the hot consultant this campaign season. In part, that's on the strength of Wilder's 1989 campaign: its groundbreaking use of abortion rights as an issue, and tough, rapid responses that defused his opponent's attacks. ``It was brilliant,'' said Republican consultant Roger Stone. ``He sold abortion as a conservative position.'' Wilder may have won only narrowly, but a win is a win, and others already are copying his methods. As a result, Greer finds himself at the center of the two most significant political developments of the post-Reagan era: the election of blacks to statewide office and the power of abortion as an issue. Another Republican consultant, Eddie Mahe, also praised Greer's work for Wilder but cautioned that Greer may be following a risky course. ``He clearly believes the future is pro-choice,'' Mahe said. ``He's putting all his chips on that.'' Greer gained the notice of his colleagues in 1986, when three Democratic Senate challengers he was handling each won upsets: Brock Adams in Washington, Kent Conrad in North Dakota and Wyche Fowler in Georgia. He'd worked for some losers: Fred Harris's 1976 presidential campaign; Walter Mondale's in 1984. In between, he was the Labor Department's spokesman in the Carter administration. His firm, Greer, Margolis, Mitchell and Associates, also helped democrtic forces in a 1988 plebiscite in Chile that defeated Gen. Augusto Pinochet. Greer has another important client: the National Abortion Rights Action League. On the day last summer when the Supreme Court ruled that states could impose some limits on abortion, Greer had TV ads ready. That night, NARAL began airing them in selected cities, trumpeting abortion rights as the issue to come. The work coincided with Wilder's decision to base his campaign in large part on abortion rights. Before, candidates who supported abortion rights had done their best to avoid public debate, regarding the influence of abortion opponents as too great. Greer's clients this year include Young, the former mayor of Atlanta and veteran of the civil rights struggle who is running in the Democratic primary for governor of Georgia. Young faces longer odds that did Wilder, Greer acknowledges. One big reason is that Georgia law requires a candidate to have 50 percent of the vote in a primary or runoff to secure the nomination _ long an obstacle for blacks in southern states. His other candidates this year include Senate challenger Harvey Sloane in Kentucky, Montana Sen. Max Baucus and Paul Hubbert, a candidate for governor in Alabama. What Greer has done so far, and his clients hope he will continue, is to find a way to victory for Democrats whom some might conclude were more liberal than the voters electing them. More ``progressive,'' Greer prefers. ``That is what we do,'' he said. ``I think we do it fairly well. It's what I grew up with in Alabama, in terms of the legacy of Franklin Roosevelt and the grassroots populism of southerners.'' One measure of Greer's success came recently in Kentucky. Republican Sen. Mitch McConnell's re-election campaign went on the attack _ not against Sloane, the challenger, but Greer, the consultant, calling him a master of misleading advertising. Earlier, Sloane had switched positions and now supports abortion rights. Greer says he didn't force or prompt the change. ``I don't have a litmus test,'' Greer said. ``I let them make that decision.'' In Wilder's campaign, Greer designed ads that presented abortion as an issue of civil liberties _ a question of who decides, the government or the woman. Greer used lots of waving flags and pictures of Virginia's Thomas Jefferson. Greer says it was his success with Fowler's Georgia campaign, not Wilder's, that prompted Young to hire him. Already, though, there are echoes of Wilder's approach in Young's campaign. Young, announcing his candidacy, said abortion is a woman's decision. ``I would rather trust the women of Georgia,'' Young said, sounding a lot like Doug Wilder's ``I trust the women of Virginia.'' Framed that way, Greer argues, support for legal abortions is a powerful wedge that Democrats can use to divide Republicans and win back voters who were attracted to the GOP on economic issues. Republicans dismiss that as wishful thinking. But Greer argues it goes even further, too, in symbolism. ``It's a very much an age issue,'' he said. ``That's why Lee Atwater (the Republican naitonal chairman) is scrambling.'' ``I think the Democratic Party is perfectly positioned to raise the issue and use it to win back younger voters,'' he said. ``It symbolizes compassion, concern about day care, issues of concern to working families. ... The question is what the Republicans do. Right now, they're positioned on the wrong side of the issue, the wrong side of history.''
DOC.NOTE: End advance for March 11

DOC.HEAD: Perrier Back Next Month; $25 Million Marketing Campaign Planned
With PM-Coke II Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Parched for Perrier? The U.S. importer of the sparkling water that became a status symbol in the 1980s and the object of a worldwide contamination recall to start the 1990s says relief is a month or more away. Newly bottled Perrier bearing a special marking is being shipped for the first time since last month's recall, Source Perrier SA officials said Tuesday. Meantime, Perrier Group of America plans to launch a $25 million marketing campaign starting today with advertisements in 22 newspapers in an effort to keep the brand's name before the public during shipment and to rebuild sales of what had been the top-selling imported bottled water once it arrives. The new bottles are expected to reach shelves in the eastern United States early next month and the rest of the country within three months. They will carry the mark ``Nouvelle Production'' on the label to distinguish them from the 160 million bottles pulled off the market last month. Source Perrier said Tuesday in Paris that shipments to distributors resume today. But Perrier Group officials said it will take until early April for the bottles to travel overseas, pass through customs and be distributed to the more than 1 million U.S. outlets from supermarkets to bars where Perrier is sold. ``Perrier. Worth Waiting For'' is the theme of ads slated to appear today in USA Today, The Wall Street Journal and 20 major market newspapers. Perrier also plans a series of humorous radio ads in the 15 largest U.S. markets, featuring actors posing as newscasters for the Perrier News Network reporting on Perrier ``sightings.'' In one ad, fictional correspondent Jill Purity interviews a man who had spotted a bottle of Perrier. Jill notes the bottle is missing, and the man explains that Elvis Presley came and drank it. Ronald V. Davis, president and chief executive of Greenwich, Conn.-based Perrier Group, told reporters at the French consulate that humor was appropriate because ``no one was hurt'' and no health risk was posed by the contamination incident. Perrier was recalled Feb. 9 in the United States after traces of benzene, a cancer-causing chemical, were found in some Perrier bottles. The recall was broadened five days later to all 160 million bottles in 120 countries when contaminated bottles showed up in several other countries. Company officials claim the benzene, a naturally occurring gas that dissolves in water, entered Perrier's bottling line when workers failed to replace a filter used to screen impurities from the carbon dioxide gas that is mixed with the water to provide more fizz. They said new quality control procedures have been installed at the plant in Vergeze, including double filtration of the gas and more careful monitoring. Perrier should start appearing on shelves in New York in early April, Davis said, and across the country within three months. He said it may take until the end of the summer to get all Perrier varieties back in full distribution. An ad campaign to be used after the relaunch is being developed by Hal Riney & Partners, a San Francisco-based ad agency that created the old ``It's perfect. It's Perrier'' campaign. Davis said no decisions have been made on using that slogan again. Hellen Berry, market research director for the industry consultant Beverage Marketing Corp., said, ``I suspect the consumer will come back to them.'' Perrier's Davis said consumer surveys the company has taken indicate 95 percent of Perrier users feel the company acted responsibly in ordering the recall and 84 percent plan to purchase it in the future. He said he could not estimate the costs of the recall in the United States. But he said the Perrier brand would have sold about $30 million in the months that it will be off the shelf or in limited supply. Offsetting that, however, would be gains in sales of Perrier Group's other brands, including Arrowhead, Poland Spring and Calistoga. Davis said at least 50 percent of Perrier brand's shelf space in major markets is being filled by other Perrier Group brands. The Perrier brand was the third best-selling bottled water brand and the top-selling imported water in the United States in 1988, accounting for about 5.7 percent of the $2.2 billion in industrywide sales, according to Beverage Marketing. Davis said the Perrier brand accounted for about $119 million in sales in 1989, or about 19 percent of Perrier Group's estimated $640 million in sales.

DOC.HEAD: What's In A Name? Coca-Cola May Change Name of New Coke
With PM-Perrier Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Didn't like new Coke? Try Coke II. The taste promises to be the same. The Coca-Cola Co., which learned the hard way about consumer loyalty when it changed the formula of Coke five years ago, apparently isn't worried about tinkering with the product that replaced it. The company said Tuesday it will try changing the name of new Coke to Coke II in an attempt to bolster sales of the product that in 1985 replaced the world's best-selling soft drink and sparked a consumer revolt. Randy Donaldson, spokesman for Atlanta-based Coke, said the formula of new Coke will not be altered and that no changes are planned for Coca-Cola Classic, the name for the restored original formula. Donaldson said Coke II will be test marketed initially in one city, which he would not identify. ``After five years, new Coke is no longer new, though it's still called new Coke,'' he said. ``We just want to make it easier to distinguish between Coke II and Coke Classic.'' Soft drink industry analysts speculated that if the change to Coke II is adopted, the brand name Coca-Cola could be returned to the best-selling Coke Classic. Coke officials denied such a name change was being considered. Jesse Meyers, who publishes the Greenwich, Conn., industry newsletter Beverage Digest, said the Coke II test meant Coca-Cola was ``taking off the gloves'' in its cola war with rival Pepsi Cola. ``They've had a namby-pamby approach to new Coke vs. Pepsi,'' Meyers said. ``They're going from namby-pamby to the machine guns.'' Recent Coke advertising has pitted diet Coke, rather than the sugared new Coke or Coca-Cola Classic, against Pepsi. Meyers said the Coke II test indicates a plan to match the newer product against Pepsi Cola. Meyers said the proposed packaging for Coke II has a red, white and blue design with blue lettering that closely resembles that of Pepsi. But Donaldson said that unlike Pepsi the Coke II can has a red background with white letters and a blue outline. Coca-Cola announced in April 1985 that after extensive taste tests it was changing the formula of Coke, the world's best-selling soft drink. Consumer reaction was so strong against the new product that the company two months later apologized and brought back the original formula under the name Coca-Cola Classic. Coke Classic regained the position as the No. 1 soft drink. The sweeter-tasting new Coke also remained, but its market share now is 1.4 percent compared to Coke Classic's 20 percent. Second-ranked Pepsi had an 18.3 percent market share, according to Beverage Digest's 1989 year-end figures. Emanuel Goldman, who follows the soft drink industry for PaineWebber Inc. in San Francisco, said the Coke II label, if chosen, would remove the perception that new Coke is a failure. ``You don't want something called Coca-Cola that doesn't work, so you call it Coke II,'' Goldman said. ``I think it's not such a bad thing to do. The name of the game is Coca-Cola.'' Meyers said the proposed changes could lead the company to change Coke Classic back to Coca-Cola. ``The name Coke Classic may be on the way out,'' he said. Donaldson said the change to Coke II would not leave the company without a product called simply Coca-Cola. He said the company had several products incorporating the name. Pepsi spokesman Tod MacKenzie said Coke's so-called ``megabrand'' concept could backfire. ``It raises some questions in our minds. ... At what point does this megabrand confuse consumers?'' MacKenzie said. ``How does the consumer keep track?'' Pepsi has maintained that new Coke was an attempt to make a drink that tastes more like Pepsi Cola. ``Whether it's Coke II or new new Coke, it's another validation of Coke's interest in the great taste of Pepsi,'' MacKenzie said from Pepsi headquarters in Purchase, N.Y.

DOC.HEAD: Inflation in Peru: What Once Bought Truck Now Buys Cigarettes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report and on general news wires
DOC.TEXT: Their currency is named for the sun, but with inflation of nearly 3,000 percent last year, Peruvians got little warmth from it. ``The first truck I bought, 15 years ago, cost me 10 million soles; now that won't even buy me a pack of cigarettes,'' said Miguel Guzman, who owns a trucking company in Lima. Guzman quoted prices in the old currency, the sol _ Spanish for sun. In 1986, when the sol had fallen to 14,000 to the dollar, the government lopped off three zeros and renamed it the inti _ sun in Quechua, the Indian language spoken by nearly half the population. Four years later, a dollar buys 14,000 intis, which means it would buy 14 million soles if they were still around. To Peruvians, like nearly everyone else, jokes are spiritual life preservers against disaster. The latest one in Lima is that the government will chop off three zeros again and call its money the lupaca _ sun in Aymara, Peru's second major Indian language. The inflation rate for the past year, which meant prices ended the year 30 times higher on average than 12 months earlier, was surpassed only by Argentina's 4,924 percent. Doris Mandujano, 27, one of three daughters in a working-class family of 16, including grandchildren, says the last year has brought fundamental changes in the way they live. ``Sometimes at dinner there isn't enough food to go around,'' she said. ``We used to have milk and marmalade for breakfast; now it's bread and oatmeal. ``We've given up trying to provide clothing and medicine for everyone.'' Her family is squeezed into a three-bedroom, cement-block house Miss Mandujano's father built in Villa El Salvador, a shantytown on the outskirts of Lima. Miss Mandujano's parents and seven of the children, including herself, have jobs and contribute to meeting the family's needs. She has the additional job of trying to make and follow a budget. ``Our pay doesn't keep up with prices,'' she said. ``Sometimes by the fourth day of the month, we've already spent what was budgeted for two weeks, and so the crisis begins.'' Most economists blame government policies that favored consumption over production while creating a huge deficit that fed inflation. They say populist President Alan Garcia's administration has subsidized basic goods and services to the point of bankrupting the very state companies that provide the services. A gallon of gasoline costs the equivalent of only 40 cents, but the state oil company, Petroperu, is on the verge of bankruptcy. Electricity and water are among the world's cheapest, but both are rationed to Lima's 7 milliion people, largely because of the dilapidated systems. Some parts of the city have been without water for weeks. Ernesto Amans, president of the state water company, said nearly half the water leaving treatment plants was lost through leaking underground mains and the company could not afford the $18 million needed for repairs. While subsidized prices remain low, food and clothing rose more than 2,500 percent last year, entertainment soared more than 10,000 percent and education nearly 20,000 percent, according to official statistics. The magazine Analisis Laboral predicts that by the time Garcia leaves office July 28, accumulated inflation during his five-year term will reach 1,383,120 percent. Novelist Mario Vargas Llosa is favored to win the April 8 presidential election as the candidate of a center-right coalition. He has pledged to reduce annual inflation to 10 percent within a year, but says it will demand great sacrifice. After five years of Garcia, who campaigned as ``the president of hope'' and won by a landslide, many Peruvians are skeptical of politicians' promises. ``All that's left to believe in is ourselves,'' Miss Mandujano said.

DOC.HEAD: Eastern Asks Court To Speed Approval of Texas Air Settlement
With PM-Eastern-Override Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Eastern Airlines has asked a federal bankruptcy judge to accelerate approval of a $280 million payment by its parent Texas Air Corp. to settle claims that Texas Air had drained assets from Eastern. Eastern President Phil Bakes said Tuesday the airline made the request because news reports about the settlement had wrongly suggested Eastern was plundered and duped by Texas Air, creating a bad image in the industry and flying public. Bakes told a news conference that quick approval by the court would help clarify the settlement. A report by court-appointed examiner David I. Shapiro filed last week suggested Texas Air had victimized Eastern by underpaying for the airline and some assets by hundreds of millions of dollars. Eastern and Texas air denounced the report, partly because it appeared to vindicate longstanding claims by Eastern unions, which struck the airline last March. Eastern sought bankruptcy protection a few days later. The pilots and flight attendants quit the strike in November but union hostility to Eastern and Texas Air remains strong. In response to Eastern's request for the accelerated settlement with Texas Air, Air Line Pilots Association spokesman Don Skiados said: ``We're all for that. We know their arguments can't hold up under the light of day.'' A hearing on the settlement has been set for April 6 before U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Burton R. Lifland in New York. Normally, approval wouldn't occur until Eastern's final bankruptcy reorganization plan was confirmed by the court. Shapiro disclosed the settlement last Thursday, the same day he filed with the court his extensive report on financial dealings between Texas Air, Eastern and sister carrier Continental Airlines. Bakes said the report had left ``a most, most unfortunate impression'' that could negatively affect Eastern's relationships with travel agents, suppliers and the flying public. He said the settlement between Texas Air and Shapiro has been misinterpreted by the news media as an admission of wrongdoing by Texas Air for the asset purchases. Texas Air agreed to make the payment to Eastern only to bolster the airline, he said. Bakes was accompanied by five outside directors of Eastern, who each made brief statements reinforcing the company's position. ``The report disturbed me as a director and even more so as a lawyer,'' said Thomas Hale Boggs, Jr. ``To imply, as the report does, that we (Eastern directors) sort of rubber-stamped these actions is erroneous.'' In a similar move Monday, Shapiro told congressional leaders his report had been misinterpreted by the media as a finding that Texas Air was liable for the money. ``I did not find that Texas Air had improperly diverted assets from Eastern,'' Shapiro wrote in a letter to House Speaker Thomas S. Foley and House Minority Leader Robert H. Michel. ``Instead, I set forth the grounds on which such a claim could be asserted.'' ``The settlement is not an admission of liability by Texas Air,'' the letter read. ``Rather, it is an agreement between Texas Air and the examiner as to what is needed to assure the economic viability of Eastern Airlines.''

DOC.HEAD: Securities Executive Says Letting Drexel Fail Was Right
DOC.TEXT: The head of a securities industry group says government regulators were right in not stepping in to save Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. Investment banker Robert N. Downey told a Senate panel Tuesday that Drexel's failure ``reflects how self-reliant the industry is'' compared to the multibillion-dollar government bailout of the savings and loan industry. Downey told the finance subcommittee of the Senate Banking, Housing and Urban Affairs Committee that ``when Drexel no longer could stand on its own, it collapsed. The government did not rush in to save it, nor should it have.'' Drexel's parent company, Drexel Burnham Lambert Group Inc., filed for bankruptcy code protection from creditors last month after defaulting on $100 million in short-term loans and failing to secure additional financing. Drexel Group listed more than 2,000 creditors and nearly $3 billion in liabilities. Drexel's fall marked the largest securities industry bankruptcy filing ever and one of the first exceptions to a long-held, but unwritten, regulatory policy that some institutions are just to big to be allowed to fail. Downey, a partner in the investment banking firm Goldman, Sachs & Co., put in a plug for a plan _ still being developed by the SIA _ to allow commercial banking organizations to enter the securities industry and securities firms to enter consumer banking. He said the plan would stand ``without forcing the deposit insurance system to shoulder the securities risks and without triggering `too-big-to-fail''' status that led to the saving and loan bailout. Downey was among a panel of securities industry leaders testifying about the health and future of their industry in the wake of Drexel's demise, the collapse of the junk bond market and a stock market plunge last October. The panelists included John H. Gutfreund, chairman of Salomon Inc.; Philip J. Purcell, chairman of Dean Witter Financial Services Group; and W. Lucas Simons Jr., managing partner of J.C. Bradford & Co. of Nashville, Tenn. All four called for a single federal agency to regulate all aspects of the securities industry rather than the current division of power now among the Federal Reserve Board, Securities and Exchange Commission and Commodity Futures Trading Commission. While Gutfreund wasn't specific, the others said the SEC should take up the super-regulator role. The SEC should then ``regulate both equity and stock index futures markets, with a recommendation that its first order of business be devoted to rationalizing margin requirements,'' said Simons of J.C. Bradford, an investment banking partnership concentrating on the Southeast. Margins, the amount of money investors must put down to buy securities or futures contracts on credit, are much lower in the futures industry than in stocks. Critics say that encourages speculation in stock options through index arbitrage, leading to sharp ups and downs in stock prices.

DOC.HEAD: Breeden Tells Senate Panel About SEC's Needs
DOC.TEXT: Regulating a securities firm like Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. without financial data on its parent company is like being a doctor who can only examine part of the body, the head of the Securities and Exchange Commission said. SEC Chairman Richard C. Breeden used a budget hearing before the commerce subcommittee of the Senate Appropriations Committee on Tuesday as an opportunity to lobby for additional authority. Questioned about the recent collapse of Drexel, Breeden said one difficulty for the SEC was lack of data about the parent holding company, which filed for bankruptcy code protection last month. The SEC regulates broker-dealers but not their parent companies, which don't have to disclose their financial status. Legislation pending in both the House and Senate would give the SEC access to such financial data. Breeden likened the limitations on such information to being a physician ``who can only look at the right arm from the elbow to the wrist. It's very unrealistic.'' The Bush administration is seeking $192.4 million for the SEC in 1991, a 14 percent increase over the 1990 appropriation of $168.7 million. Breeden noted that Congress should be mindful that SEC revenue production through filing fees ``have significantly exceeded its appropriations.'' He pointed out that in 1989, while receiving only $142.6 million in appropriations, the SEC generated $213.8 million in fees.

DOC.HEAD: Drexel, Creditors Near Deal on Managing Company
DOC.TEXT: The lead creditor to Drexel Burnham Lambert Group Inc. withdrew a request for a court-appointed examiner in the bankruptcy case as the two sides neared a deal on who will manage dissolution of the Wall Street firm. The firm and its creditors negotiated over a proposal to allow a triumvirate of Drexel board members to oversee the firm, with input from creditors, as it liquidates under Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings. The move Tuesday by lead creditor First City Bancorp. of Texas to withdraw its request for an examiner was a sign the Drexel board members were likely to continue directing the liquidation. Creditors had sought an examiner in the case because of concerns about the rapid liquidation of billions of dollars in securities holdings and other assets by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the brokerage subsidiary. The brokerage firm is not subject to bankruptcy court proceedings but the asset sales, the movement of capital from the subsidiary to the parent company prior to the collapse and other links prompted anxious creditors to seek an examiner. In a bid to prevent the appointment, which Drexel officials contended would hamstring the company's day-to-day management, Drexel asked U.S. District Judge Howard Buschman III to allow three board members led by Chairman John S.R. Shad to oversee the dismantling of the parent and all subsidiaries. Drexel attorney Alan Miller told Buschman the two sides had made ``considerable progress'' toward resolving the issue. But he said unanticipated differences arose during Tuesday's negotiations. Miller and other attorneys refused to disclose the nature of the stumbling block. Buschman postponed a hearing on the appointment of the Drexel board members until Friday. Buschman has said such an arrangement would not require court approval. An individual involved in the talks said that under a plan being discussed, the three-member Drexel team would manage the liquidation but give creditors ``real input' into the process. Drexel already has sold off more than 85 percent of its portfolio of about $47 billion in securities since the parent filed for bankruptcy protection from creditors Feb. 13. But the firm still is trying to dispose of most of its $1.1 billion in high-yield bonds, which could take months because of a downturn in the market and the risky financial state of many of the companies for which Drexel issued and now owns junk bonds. The individual, who asked not to be named, said Drexel management would handle transactions and creditors could attend senior level meetings and have ``the ability to scream if they see something they don't like.'' Responsibilities of the oversight panel would apply to the parent and the subsidiaries, the individual said. Lawyers said in court they would continue meeting on the matter. The three-member panel consists of Shad, who is a former SEC chairman; Roderick Hills, a Washington lawyer and former SEC chairman; and Ralph Saul, a business executive and former American Stock Exchange president. The group was named as an outside oversight committee to Drexel as part of the firm's agreement with the Securities and Exchange commission last April settling wideranging securities fraud charges.

DOC.HEAD: Kidder, Peabody Loses $23 Million in 1989
DOC.TEXT: Kidder, Peabody & Co. lost $23 million in 1989, its parent General Electric Co. reported in another sign of Wall Street's troubles. The loss at the firm compared with a $46 million profit in 1988. Like other Wall Street firms, Kidder has suffered because of a decline in stock market and investment banking activity. A General Electric spokesman said Tuesday that Kidder reported an operating loss of $53 million last year but that its net loss was lower because of accounting adjustments by GE. ``Kidder's financial performance improved in the last half of the year from the first six months,'' GE said in a statement. ``Kidder's streamlined management team is making progress in a difficult environment.'' Kidder is not required to disclose its earnings because it is a subsidiary company, but figures on its performance were included in GE's annual report. Kidder's $53 million pretax operating loss compared to an operating profit of $64 million in 1988 and a loss of $23 million in 1987, when the stock market crash wreaked havoc on the securities industry. Kidder had revenue of $2.9 billion in 1989, up from $2.3 billion a year earlier. But revenue from investment banking fees and brokerage commissions declined 17 percent to $518 million last year, nearly 30 percent lower than in 1987. The securities firm was the only segment of GE's business to show an operating loss last year. Overall, GE had pretax earnings of $5.7 billion in 1989. GE, the electrical products, broadcasting and financial services company based in Fairchild, Conn., paid $600 million to acquire an 80 percent stake in Kidder in 1986. But Kidder has proven costly to GE since its acquisition, above and beyond its operating losses. About a year after buying Kidder, GE paid $26 million to the Securities and Exchange Commission to settle insider trading charges involving the firm. Kidder underwent a major restructuring shortly after the crash, laying off employees and cutting expenses. The firm recently has been focusing its retail brokerage business on wealthy clients and small companies, rather then all individual investors. Kidder has 5,600 employees, down from a peak of 7,500.

DOC.HEAD: Rockefeller Heir Poses for Jockey Underwear Ad
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report
DOC.TEXT: Some heirs to great family fortunes dabble in art collecting. Others become renowned philanthropists. Ola Stillman Rockefeller is posing for underwear ads. Rockefeller, 30, is the newest pitchman for Jockey International Inc. The company unveiled the magazine ad campaign at a news conference Tuesday with the aid of baseball great Jim Palmer, who is perhaps the best-known Jockey model. Rockefeller, according to material provided by his public relations agency, has a ``recent penchant for art.'' He has collaborated on collages with Mark Kostabi, a New York artist who has mounted public relations stunts to promote his artworks. Rockefeller said Jockey came to him with the idea of posing for the ads. ``I kind of hemmed and hawed,'' he said in an interview. ``I really wanted to do it but then I thought, `Is my grandfather going to kill me or cut me off or something?' But I eventually decided to do it. I'm just sort of winging it.'' He said his grandfather, James Stillman Rockefeller, former chairman of First National City Bank of New York, opposed the plan until the younger Rockefeller said he would give the proceeds to Memorial-Sloan Kettering Hospital, a family charity. ``In some ways I am trying to create my own identity,'' Rockefeller said. ``Sometimes it's hard if you're the son of or descendant of _ you're expected to play a certain role.'' Rockefeller said he hopes the exposure he gains through the ads _ in which he is tastefully garbed in plaid undershorts and a T-shirt _ will help further his art aspirations. Rockefeller, whose great grandfather was a brother to John D. Rockefeller, the founder of Standard Oil Co., said he's been wearing Jockey underwear since he was 14. One of Rockefeller's cousins, James Stillman Rockefeller Rose, said Rockefeller's plan to pose for the ad ``sort of came out suddenly.'' ``The only reason the family let him get away with it is that he's donating the procedes to Sloan-Kettering,'' Rose said in a telephone interview. Several years ago, Rockefeller announced he would launch a line of men's clothing featuring the family crest. The clothes never materialized, ``thank God,'' Rose said, adding that the family was dismayed by the intended use of the crest. Rose, 30, described his cousin as the non-traditional member of an otherwise low-key family. Rose, who helps manage a family-run investment company, said that despite the trust funds _ the total of which dwindles with each generation _ most members of his generation of the Rockefellers are employed. ``We've have a much stronger work ethic than a lot of our cousins on the other side of the family do, out of necessity and training,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: May Department Stores Earnings Increase
DOC.TEXT: May Department Stores Co., one of the nation's largest retailers, reported a slight fourth-quarter earnings increase but a mild loss for the year, mostly from the cost of discarding two discount chains. Earnings for the quarter ended Feb. 3 totaled $283 million, or $2 a share, up 2 percent from $276 million, or $1.88 a share, for the same period a year earlier. The earnings from continuing operations were much brighter, however, at $283 million vs. $230 million, because last year May had $46 million in earnings from discontinued operations in the fourth quarter. Revenues for the quarter increased 5 percent to $3.2 billion, up from $3 billion from the same period a year ago, May said Tuesday. May Department Stores Co., based in St. Louis, operates 14 regional department store chains around the country along with a national chain of discount shoe stores. The company, best-known for its Lord & Taylor stores, is in the midst of an aggressive expansion plan in an industry that has been experiencing some difficult times. For the year, the company's earnings declined about 6 percent, primarily because of a $23 million charge for the cost of discarding discount chains Venture and Caldor. Last year the company made $498 million, or $3.52 a share, compared with $534 million, or $3.62 a share. Revenues in 1989 were $9.6 billion, up 8 percent from $8.8 billion for the year before. May plans to open a record 21 department stores in 1990 and 244 new Payless ShoeSource stores in 1990. The company also will remodel 29 stores.

DOC.HEAD: De Beers Plans To Split South African Operations From Foreign
DOC.TEXT: De Beers Consolidated Mines Ltd. plans to split its foreign operations from its South African business in an apparent move to shelter the huge diamond mining company from political turmoil in South African. De Beers said Tuesday the plans were intended to focus attention on the company's international nature and its true business value. ``Basically it's going to lose some, if not all of the discount of being a South African share,'' said Rob Davies, a mining analyst at Shearson Lehman Hutton International in London. De Beers also announced its net profit soared 37 percent last year. Chairman Julian Ogilvie Thompson denied there were political reasons for the company's split. Speaking at a Johannesburg news conference that was relayed to London, he said the split would give De Beers better access to international capital markets; enable shareholders to better identify earnings, dividends and assets attributable to the South African and foreign sides of the business; and allow the two sides to develop their businesses better. Analysts said the move would insulate the company _ which in 1989 made 80 percent of its profit from foreign businesses _ from its South African ties and from moves to end white-minority rule in that country. The African National Congress party has said it would nationalize South Africa's mines and other major sectors of the economy, if it comes into power. Furthermore, many investors are reluctant to invest in South African companies because of its government policies of racial separation. In the United States, government sanctions prohibit Americans from making fresh investments in South African equities. ``It should open up the share to a wider market,'' Davies said of the De Beers plan. Ogilvie Thompson also denied that the plan was linked to Minorco SA's failed hostile takeover bid for the British mining company Consolidated Gold Fields PLC last year. The bid by Minorco, which is controlled by De Beers and the associated Anglo American Corp., was seen as an attempt by South Africa's Oppenheimer family to diversify its gold and diamond mining empire further outside South Africa. Under the proposed split, De Beers' South African company will continue to be called De Beers Consolidated Mines. De Beers' foreign businesses would be grouped under a Swiss company, De Beers Centenary AG, although both companies will be headed by the same board of directors. De Beers said it would give existing shareholders one share in Centenary for each De Beers share they own. The two shares will be tradeable only as a single unit on the nine exchanges where De Beers shares are traded, the company said. De Beers said it would retain a 9.5 percent stake in Centenary. John Taylor, an analyst at the London investment firm James Capel and Co., said, ``Essentially, it's an extremely cheap share. People were giving it a low rating because of the politics of investing in South Africa.'' The split means ``the political risk to a certain extent has disappeared,'' Taylor said. De Beers can just allow shares in the companies to trade separately if the situation in South Africa deteriorates, he said. The plan is subject to final approval by South African regulators, who have approved in principle. It also must be approved by shareholders. Support already has been given by Anglo American, which has a 33 percent stake, and De Beers Botswana Mining Co. (Pty) Ltd., which holds 5 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Pathe to Buy MGM-UA Studios
DOC.TEXT: MGM-UA Communications Co. said today it has agreed to be acquired by Pathe Communications Corp. for $20 a share, or about $1 billion. Pathe, an international film producer, distributor and exhibitor, will begin a tender offer for all of MGM-UA's common and preferred shares within five days, the companies said in a joint statement. The deal is expected to be completed in late June. MGM-UA's principal shareholder, Tracinda Corp., has agreed to tender to Pathe all of its MGM-UA shares, the statement said. Pathe, which will operate MGM-UA separately, agreed to put up $100 million in ``earnest money'' within the next few days. MGM-UA Chairman Jeffrey C. Barbakow will retain his position. Europe-based Pathe also granted MGM-UA certain distribution rights and an interest in up to $75 million of net distribution proceeds of certain motion pictures. Further details were not disclosed. ``We believe that MGM-UA's unique library and strong distribution capabilities complement Pathe's existing business worldwide,'' said Giancarlo Parretti, president and chief executive officer of Pathe. ``We are confident the transaction will result in a strong, dual company structure which will be strongly competitive in the industry,'' he said. Barbakow said the deal allows MGM-UA employees ``to continue their efforts to build our film, TV and home video operations.'' He said MGM-UA ``will also benefit from Pathe's control of over 1,000 theater screens in Europe and its ownership of an extensive library of 1,200 feature films, including Cannon's well-known library.'' On Monday, the companies announced that MGM-UA had reached a five-year deal to distribute films from Pathe. MGM-UA said the deal would boost the number of major films it releases in theaters to at least 15 this year. MGM-UA virtually shut down its film production efforts for nearly two years while controlling shareholder Kirk Kerkorian looked for a buyer. It has started up its own production again but has depended largely on distributing movies from independent production companies like Pathe. Australia's Qintex Group outbid Rupert Murdoch's Fox Studio for MGM-UA last year, but the deal collapsed when Qintex failed to line up financing. Merger talks with cable TV baron Ted Turner ended in January, and Kerkorian said he would go back to the business of making movies.

DOC.HEAD: Sony To Introduce ``Palmtop'' Computer
DOC.TEXT: Japan's Sony Corp. said Wednesday it soon will begin selling a small keyboardless computer that can read words written with a special pen on its flat screen. ``We consider this an epoch-making product, like the Walkman tape player,'' a Sony official said. Sony officials said the 2.8-pound book-size computer has the same screen resolution, or clarity of detail, as Apple Computer Inc.'s Macintosh computer. It comes with built-in software that displays a row of easily recognizable symbols on the screen like a Macintosh, and has extensive graphic capabilities. ``This is a real computer, but unlike other computers, anyone can begin using it the minute they take it home,'' said another Sony official, who also spoke on condition of anonymity. Instead of a mouse, the hand-operated device that manipulates the cursor on the screen and executes commands with a push button, the computer is equipped with a special pen that is used to point to the desired function diagram on the built-in flat screen, which folds open to create a writing surface. Similar pens that emit a light beam have been used for years with larger computers. But the Sony computer, named the PalmTop PCT-500, takes the pen concept a step further. In word processing, the pen is used to write text on the screen, which the computer recognizes through a handwriting recognition system that uses ``fuzzy logic,'' Sony said. The computer is capable of recognizing English letters and more than 3,500 complex Japanese characters, the company said. ``Fuzzy logic'' allows computers to reason more like humans. Instead of being limited to ``yes or no'' answers, the computer can process information like ``shorter'' or ``wider.'' The computer has a 16-bit processor and 320 kilobytes of built-in RAM memory, which can store about 110 pages of information, Sony said. Additional memory cards will be available. With an optional adaptor, the PCT-500 can send and receive fax messages to any fax machine, a funtion available on many other computers, Sony said. The computer also comes with a built-in auto phone dialer and can digitally record up to eight seconds of sound. In addition, it has a standard computer interface. Sony said the computer will be introduced in Japan on April 1 for 198,000 yen, the equivalent of $1,320 at current exchange rates. ``We plan to sell it overseas, but the current software is written entirely in Japanese, so we need to develop a new software system for the foreign market,'' an official said.

DOC.HEAD: Rules Taking Effect Two Years After Hawaii Accident
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 4th graf, The anti-corrosion ..., to delete extraneous word `between'
DOC.TEXT: Nearly two years after the roof ripped off an aging Boeing 737 jetliner over Hawaii, the government is imposing the first set of parts-replacement rules for older planes. At the same time, the Federal Aviation Administration announced plans worked out with the aviation industry to require a detailed cycle of inspections for corrosion in Boeing airliners. The final rules announced Tuesday are aimed at correcting metal-fatigue problems in airliners that have gone through thousands of takeoffs and landings. They require replacements of parts and will cost airlines an estimated $142 million over the next four years. The anti-corrosion measures are estimated to cost $38,720 for each Boeing 737 over the six-year inspection cycle, $80,000 for each Boeing 727, $80,640 for each Boeing 707 and $188,800 for each Boeing 747. Foreign regulatory agencies generally follow FAA requirements for U.S.-built planes. The rules come as no surprise to the industry, which set up the task force that proposed them. The aging airliner effort was started after the roof of an Aloha Airlines 737 ripped off at 24,000 feet over Maui, Hawaii, in April 1988. A flight attendant was swept to her death and 64 passengers were injured. The plane was 19 years old and had made nearly 90,000 flights. The accident was caused primarily by metal fatigue, but corrosion also was found, the FAA said. The new fatigue rules, which take effect in 30 days, give airlines four years to comply with all the requirements and will immediately affect 115 older, U.S.-registered Boeing aircraft. Tony Broderick, FAA regulations chief, said the agency believes that if the regulations are followed, there will be no need to retire airliners at a given age. Final fatigue rules for McDonnell Douglas airliners are to be issued in a couple of months, with rules for other airliners to be issued before the end of the year, Broderick said. Corrosion rules also will be proposed for other jetliners, he said, and will become final after airlines have an opportunity to comment. Broderick said that although most airlines have programs to detect and repair corrosion, the proposed rules would impose detailed FAA requirements for inspections of 19 specific areas of each airliner. Under the proposal, inspections would have to be performed most often under lavatories and galleys, where corrosive liquids might collect, and in wheel wells. Broderick said the program could pose ``a relatively big burden'' on some small airlines, but that if carriers find themselves overburdened it probably means they have not been conducting adequate corrosion inspections on their own. The goal is for each airline to set up a program that will find only harmless corrosion that can be corrected quickly with each inspection. More serious corrosion, which would require repair or replacement of parts or which might endanger the safety of the airliner, would have to be reported to the manufacturer. The FAA has based its rules on Boeing service bulletins and the experiences of domestic and foreign airliners that participated in the task force.

DOC.HEAD: Singapore To Buy $2.2 Billion Of American Engines For Its New Planes
DOC.TEXT: Singapore Airlines has decided to fit the 30 Boeing 747-400 and 20 McDonnell Douglas MD-11 aircraft it is buying with American-made Pratt & Whitney engines worth about $2.2 billion, the company said Wednesday. In a news release, the airline said it spent four months evaluating three engines, including General Electric CF6-80c2BIF and Rolls Royce RB211-524H, before deciding on the Pratt & Whitney PW 4056 for the Boeing 747-400. Pratt & Whitney engines are made by United Technologies Corp. of Hartford, Conn. For the MD-11s it evaluated General Electric CF6-80C2DIF and Rolls Royce Trent 650 before selecting the PW 4460, the airline said. The deal, which includes spare engines, covers 234 engines, 152 for the B747-400 and 82 for the MD-11. The total cost of the engines amounts to $2.2 billion and was included in the estimated outlay of $8.6 billion for the aircraft orders announced in January, the company said. The PW 4056 is the same engine the airline uses on its existing B747-400s, five of which are in service, with another 15 to be delivered by 1993, the release said.

DOC.HEAD: US Could Lose Lead in Computer Software to Other Countries, Study Says
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Top 10 grafs new to include testimony; Picks up 8th graf pvs, The congressional study.
DOC.TEXT: The United States has 70 percent of the world's computer software market but could lose its lead without better legal protection as other countries develop their software, a congressional study says. With continued innovation, the United States can keep outshining its foreign competitors, the congressional Office of Technology Assessment said in a study released today. It said intellectual property protection encourages innovation by providing incentives for creation and security for investors. Last year, software and related services were a $60 billion industry in the United States. Software refers to sets of instructions for computers, whether they are stored in punched cards, magnetic tape, disks, or on chips. The term can encompass data as well as programs. Mitchell D. Kapor, the creator of Lotus 1-2-3, told a House subcommittee that over-protection of software ``is as pernicious as under-protection in its stifling effects on innovation.'' He said his industry has made an ``unsteady but stubborn march'' to extend copyright protection of computer software. But, he said, it is possible to go too far. ``I honestly believe that this industry isn't mature enough to cope with a barrage of new laws,'' Kapor said. ``Congress could help both the software industry and its customers if, when it passes laws their legislative histories tell the courts that, when they consider a copyright case, they should err on the side of innovation over protection.'' The Software Publishers Association, a worldwide trade association representing 575 microcomputer software developers and publishers, said in a statement that patent protection for their product is not universally endorsed, partly because publishers are concerned that the government's Patent and Trademark Office can't adequately review applications. ``Publishers believe that the PTO is understaffed, underfunded, and so is not equipped to evaluate most software patent applications in a timely and effective fashion,'' the association said. There is fear of foreign competition, especially from the Japanese, who reportedly plan to spend $125 billion over 10 years for programming research and development _ especially in the field of artificial intelligence, where the goal is to make computers think more like humans. The congressional study said there are basic questions about providing too much, as well as too little, legal protection for software. New technologies have long challenged existing protections, but usually accommodations are made. ``For instance, the first copyright statute dealt only with maps, charts and books, but copyright has been able to deal with hard questions posed by works like engravings, musical compositions, photographs,'' the study said. With software, however, the items needing protection are not clear. As writing and checking lines of program instructions _ so-called code _ becomes more automated, some software producers want to protect ``the logic and idea'' of a program, not just the effort required to write the code and check it. Others worry that computer-aided software development will make copying easier to disguise. The study says drawing the line between derivative works and new creations, and determining authorship, is likely to become more difficult. But it also points out that lawyers and many in the software industry believe existing copyrights and patents adequately protect software. ``At the same time that some are calling for major revisions in software protection,'' says the study, ``others are arguing that the current system is not broken and does not need fixing _ or, at least, can be fine-tuned within the existing framework.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Promises to Work for Electronics Leadership
DOC.TEXT: President Bush promised today to work toward helping the U.S. electronics industry ``regain and retain'' its lost leadership in world markets. The president, speaking to the American Electronics Association, proposed no new trade strategies but said congressional enactment of many of his lanquishing initiatives would help make U.S. high-tech goods more competitive. Without passage of his proposed reduction in the capital gains tax rate, ``every business in America _ of every size _ is at a competitive disadvantage abroad,'' Bush said in prepared remarks. He said some of the nation's biggest competitors, including Japan, South Korea, Taiwan and West Germany, did not tax capital gains at all. ``So we're fighting hard, with your continued support, for that crucial tax cut,'' he said. Capital gains are the income from the sale of stocks, real estate and other assets. It is currently taxed at the same rate as other income _ up to 33 percent. Bush's proposal would lower the rate, in effect, to about 19.5 percent. ``We intend to work with you _ closely, constantly and consistently _ to see that American electronics and technologies regain and retain a pre-eminent position in world markets,'' Bush told the trade organization that represents U.S. chip manufacturers. He praised the industry for becoming ``the nation's largest manufacturing employer, creating jobs for over 2.5 million Americans.'' The president also said he was optimistic that his meeting last weekend in California with Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu would help pry open more markets in Japan. He said he and Kaifu ``specifically discussed satellites and telecommunications, super computers, forest products and...semiconductors. I hope, on the basis of our talks, that Japan will be moving toward early resolution of these problem areas.'' There has been a longstandng trade dispute between the United States and Japan over semiconductors, or computer chips, that resulted in temporary sanctions against Japan in 1987 for ``dumping'' chips in U.S. markets _ deliberately selling chips at below-market prices.

DOC.HEAD: Georgia Pacific Announces Completion of Tender Offer for Great Northern
DOC.TEXT: Georgia-Pacific Corp. said today that 97.3 percent of the outstanding shares of Great Northern Nekoosa Corp.'s stock have been tendered under the Atlanta company's $5 billion takeover plan. Georgia-Pacific said 53.8 million shares of Great Northern stock were tendered as of midnight Tuesday, the deadline for the $65.75-a-share tender offer. ``Georgia-Pacific intends to complete the acquisition of Great Northern as soon as practicable by merging NM Acquisition into Great Northern in accordance with the merger agreement,'' Georgia Pacific said in a statement. Great Northern's management agreed last month to the unsolicited buyout after 3{ months of bitter resistance to the deal. The merger is expected to result in the nation's largest forest products company. Atlanta-based Georgia-Pacific had $10 billion in sales last year, while Great Northern, headquartered in Norwalk, Conn., had $4 billion in sales.

For Release PMs Thurs March 8
DOC.HEAD: DINKs Have Troubles Too
DOC.TEXT: When the time comes for doling out financial encouragement and moral support, DINKs often must wait at the end of the line. The millions of modern American households nicknamed for their double-income, no-kids status are widely presumed to be doing just fine on their own, with economic advantages few others enjoy. Social commentators have gone so far as to portray DINKs as egomaniacs hooked on instant gratification. If a layoff or other reversal hits either half of a DINK partnership, sympathy may be slow in coming, even from close friends and relatives. The accuracy of such generalizations, of course, varies widely from one two-income, zero-dependent living unit to the next. Even in households where the cash flow never seems to stop, say experts in matters of personal finance, DINKs face problems of money management and planning that are just about unique to their species. ``While two incomes can give couples a financial edge, that edge is often blunted by poor planning,'' says Candace E. Trunzo in her book Financial Planning For The Two-Career Family, recently published under the auspices of John Hancock Financial Services. ``Not only financial stability but family stability can suffer if there is no management or compromise in a two-career family.'' The steady flow of multiple paychecks in a DINK household can overcome any impulse to develop disciplined habits or plan for the future, making such regimens harder and harder to adopt and adjust to with the passage of time. If a two-career family has something of a cushion against a disruption in the life of either worker, it also may be doubly exposed to the risk of changing economic circumstances. With such considerations in mind, many advisers urge DINKs to save a greater percentage of their income than others might deem prudent _ as much as 25 percent, or even more. ``Sock it away before you spend it on restaurants, clothes and cars,'' says John Erb at the accounting firm of Deloitte & Touche. Society's presumption that DINKs are more capable than most of bearing the cost of government shows up clearly in the tax code. ``Because they lack most of the deductions that reduce taxable income, they stand virtually defenseless before the tax man,'' Erb observes. To reduce the tax bite, Erb recommends that DINKS make the maximum contributions possible to such things as individual retirement accounts and employer-sponsored retirement savings programs. He also suggests that when they save, they give extra emphasis to growth investments such as stocks and mutual funds, seeking out long-term capital gains over current income from their nest eggs. Tax rates are now the same for both capital gains and dividend and interest income. But tax bills on capital gains don't arise until you decide to sell an investment. For unmarried DINKs, planning is complicated by questions of what rights lawmakers, the courts and society are willing to accord them _ for example, on the death of either partner in the household. Married couples are urged to consider special strategies as well. For instance, they may be prime candidates to save on tax deductions for medical or miscellaneous expenses by filing their returns separately rather than jointly. Advisers also suggest that two-career families give their employee benefit programs close scrutiny to eliminate overlaps. When it comes to things like insurance, Trunzo writes, the goal is to be ``adequately but not overly insured, particularly if you are paying for benefits from your own pockets.''
