DOC.HEAD: Senate Debates Amendments to Clean Air Bill
DOC.NOTE: EDS: LEADS with 7 grafs to reflect today's floor activity and postponement of House hearing; picks up 6th graf pvs, The House ...
DOC.TEXT: Groups of senators worked behind the scenes today to toughen a compromise clean air bill, trying to craft amendments that would place additional pollution controls on automobiles and industry. Floor debate on the clean air bill moved ahead slowly with several controversial amendments _ including the tighter controls on automobile emissions _ yet to come up for consideration. Both Senate leaders and the Bush administration were trying to keep intact a compromise bill fashioned during three weeks of closed-door bargaining, opposing amendments that would either weaken or strenthen the legislation. In the House, the Energy and Commerce Committee's energy and power subcommittee, which had planned later today to consider a proposal to help Midwest utilities pay for costly sulfur dioxide emission controls, put off its hearing until Thursday. Rep. Philip Sharp, D-Ind., chairman of the House energy and power subcommittee of the Energy and Commerce Committee, has argued for a special fee to help the Midwest utilities. Congressional sources said it was unclear whether Sharp had enough votes, even in his subcommittee, to tack onsuch a provision. A cost-sharing fee has been opposed by the Bush administration as well as many lawmakers from areas where utilities already have relatively clean-burning electric power plants. The Senate bill contains no such provision, although some allowances to help the Midwest are included. In the Senate, a number of noncontroversial amendments were approved by a voice vote Tuesday and today. The House and Senate clean air measures call for tougher controls on smog-causing pollution from automobiles and industrial sources, curbs on toxic chemical releases by industry and, for the first time, cuts in acid rain pollutants from coal-fired utility plants. The House bill remains in committee. Last week a Senate compromise with the Bush administration sent that body's measure to the floor for debate. For most of Tuesday, the Senate debated an amendment brought by Sen. Steve Symms, R-Idaho to change the toxic chemical section of the bill. But by late afternoon the proposal was withdrawn, and the Senate later approved by voice vote a number of noncontroversial amendments. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, complained that senators were slow in producing amendments and vowed to keep the legislation on the floor ``until we see some progress'' even if it means working into the weekend. ``We can't permit legislation of this magnitude not to proceed because no senator wants to come forward with an amendment,'' Mitchell declared in an almost empty Senate chamber late Tuesday. Despite the lack of floor action, there was considerable activity behind the scenes. Various groups of senators worked on proposed amendments, including one to strengthen auto pollution controls by reinstating automatic enactment of a second round of tailpipe controls. Another would reinstate a requirement that automakers improve the fuel economy of their car fleets and control carbon dioxide emissions. Both provisions were taken out of the bill during private negotiations with the Bush administration, which considered them too expensive to the auto industry.

DOC.HEAD: Greyhound Says It's Rebuilding `Slowly But Surely'
With PM-Greyhound Strike-Training, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with four grafs to UPDATE with Tuesday ridership and negotiators talking briefly by phone. Picks up 5th graf, `The union...'.
DOC.TEXT: Greyhound says it is ``slowly but surely'' restoring service at the strikebound bus company with replacement drivers and breakaway union members. Greyhound Lines Inc., America's only nationwide bus system, said today its ridership Tuesday was 37.1 percent of the number carreid on the same day last year, an increase from Monday's 33.8 percent and Friday's 30 percent. ``The trend is up. There is no erosion in our service,'' said George Gravley, a spokesman for GLI Holdings, parent company of Greyhound. ``It's getting better slowly but surely.'' The company's 6,300 drivers and about 3,000 office and maintenance workers are on strike. The union has asked for new talks, but none are scheduled, although the chief negotiators spoke briefly by telephone Tuesday. The union issued a bulletin to its members Tuesday, urging them to use their cars to take blood to hospitals where supplies may have been disrupted by the strike. But Red Cross officials said they were unaware of any serious disruptions, although blood usually delivered by bus was being carried by alternate transportation in some cases. The company has been operating with about 700 replacement drivers plus what it says are 350 union members who crossed picket lines. Union officials said their own checks show that only 95 union drivers have been behind the wheel. Gravley said the replacement drivers are being paid under the contract terms the strikers rejected. The contract does not change base pay but allows drivers to reach higher pay levels sooner by setting up a system based on experience rather than seniority, Gravley said. It also rewards accident-free driving, he said. The union has rejected pay increases linked to productivity. Greyhound drivers made an average of $24,743 last year, according to the company.

DOC.HEAD: Reports: Feds Decide To Sell SASA To First Gibraltar Bank
DOC.TEXT: The federal Resolution Trust Corp. has decided to sell San Antonio Savings Association to Houston-based First Gibraltar Bank, possibly as early as Friday, according to published reports today. Resolution Trust, the federal agency that took over the failed thrift last year, also reportedly adopted a policy ensuring San Antonio Savings independent operation at least until the RTC reviews the plan that formed First Gibraltar. A decision to sell the savings and loan to First Gibraltar was made Tuesday afternoon in Washington, and First Gibraltar officials were notified soon afterward, the San Antonio Light and Dallas Times Herald reported in today's editions. RTC spokesman Steve Katsanos, First Gibraltar spokeswoman Ruth Lack and SASA chairman W.W. ``Bo'' McAllister III all declined to comment on whether an agreement had been reached. SASA, one of several was seized on March 2, 1989 and at that time had $2.6 billion in assets and $1.9 billion in deposits. SASA was offered for sale in the RTC's initial package of Aug. 30, 1989. As of Sept. 30, SASA had total assets of $2.31 billion and a negative net worth of $415.07 million. The sale is expected to include at least $415 million in federal assistance to eliminate the negative net worth. Specific terms of First Gibraltar's deal could not be determined late Tuesday. The sale was not expected to affect the thrift's customers, and SASA would remain open for business as usual. Sources close to several bidding groups confirmed that First Gibraltar Bank, which actually operates as a savings and loan, has been told it won the bidding for the thrift, the Light reported. Other bidders included NCNB Texas National Bank and Bank One Texas, the Times Herald reported. ``The deal propels (First Gibraltar) into a leadership role for all three of Texas' major cities _ Houston, Dallas and San Antonio,'' said Robert Rieke, banking analyst at Rauscher Pierce Refsnes in Dallas. With $9.8 billion in assets, First Gibraltar is the largest savings and loan in Texas. The thrift reported $7.1 million net income in the first nine months of 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Pratt & Whitney Worker File Age-Discrimination Lawsuit
DOC.TEXT: Nineteen salaried Pratt & Whitney workers who were dismissed from jobs in Connecticut have filed an age-discrimination lawsuit in federal court against the jet-engine manufacturer. Two of the laid-off employees from Pratt's plant in North Haven, also filed a separate suit alleging racial discrimination played a role in their layoffs. Both lawsuits were filed Tuesday in U.S. District Court in Hartford. They seek to reinstate most of the employees, all over age 40, with back pay, plus punitive damages. If the court were to find a willful discrimination and award double back pay to the employees, Pratt could face potential payments of $3 million to $5 million. The lawsuits filed Tuesday are similar to ones filed last year by Pratt workers laid off at the company's engine plant in Florida. Those lawsuits, by 56 white-collar workers, are pending in federal court in West Palm Beach. Pratt's layoffs followed what is called an ``activity value analysis,'' or AVA, in which it examined all administrative functions to eliminate those that overlapped. Curt Linke, Pratt vice president of communications, declined to discuss the specifics of the lawsuits, which he had not read. But he defended the layoffs. ``Overall, we conducted the AVA process as fairly and thoroughly as possible,'' Linke said. ``And we believe we conducted the whole process without discrimination.'' Pratt, the East Hartford-based division of United Technologies Corp., has eliminated 2,650 salaried jobs in the past two years. Layoffs accounted for two thirds of the cuts; the remainder came through resignations and retirements. Igor I. Sikorsky Jr., a Rocky Hill attorney representing the former employees, said Pratt's layoffs abandoned a longstanding policy that used seniority as a key factor in determining who gets laid off. He had said last March that layoff discrimination lawsuits were imminent, but the suits were delayed as Sikorsky first sought, and last fall entered into, out-of-court negotiations with Pratt's lawyers. The talks, aimed at reinstating employees wishing to return, collapsed last month, Sikorsky said.

DOC.HEAD: Shares Rise
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing stock prices. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Share prices finished higher Wednesday on London's Stock Exchange, helped by the strength of the dollar and several healthy earnings reports. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index rose 14.3 points, or 0.65 percent, to close at 2,230.3. The Financial Times 30-share index was up 11.3 points at 1,757.0 at the close. The Financial Times 500-share index rose 6.21 points to close at 1,208.80. Volume amounted to 415.3 million shares, compared with 404.2 million shares Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Polygram Earnings Rose 27 Percent in 1989
DOC.TEXT: The Dutch recording company Polygram NV said Wednesday its earnings rose 27 percent in 1989 as its sales increased 20 percent. Polygram, based in the Netherlands, said it earned 333 Dutch guilders, or $173.5 million, last year, up from 262 million guilders in 1988. On a per-share basis, the company's earnings translated to 2.08 guilders, up from 1.64 guilders a year earlier. Sales totaled 4.11 billion guilders, up from 3.43 billion guilders in 1988. Polygram acquired A&M Records and Island Records last year. The company said it expected to have 18 percent of the world market for recorded music once it completed its absorption of the two companies. Polygram maunfactures Deutsche Grammophon, Philips Classics and Decca-London classical recordings. Besides A&M and Island, its pop labels include Fontana, London, Mercury, Polydor, Vertigo, Verve and Wing. The company is also involved in music publishing; film, television and music video production; and direct marketing of recordings.

DOC.HEAD: Pratt & Whitney Receives Order Worth $2.2 Billion
Precede SINGAPORE-dated BC-Singaporer Airline Engines
DOC.TEXT: In a deal potentially worth $2.2 billion, Singapore Airlines has placed orders and options for 234 PW4000 Pratt & Whitney engines, the jet-engine manufacturer and the airline announced Wednesday. The orders come on the heels of a record-breaking $12 billion year for Pratt in 1989 and represent ``the largest single order for the PW4000 on record,'' said Pratt spokesman David Long. Long said the engines would be used to power both Boeing 747-400s and McDonnell Douglas MD-11 widebody aircraft. Pratt received firm orders for 99 engines, including spares, worth about $900 million. If the airline follows through with its options, Pratt would supply an additional 135 engines, including spares, worth nearly $1.3 billion. Deliveries will begin in 1994 and carry through the end of the decade, Long said. To put the magnitude of the order in perspective, all airline orders for Pratt's popular PW4000 engine in 1989 combined totalled 700 engines worth about $4.7 billion, Long said. Selwyn Berson, president of Pratt's Commercial Engine Business, said he was pleased that Singapore, which has an exclusively Pratt-powered fleet of aircraft, intends to continue its relationship with the jet-engine maker. In a prepared statement on the orders, Singapore Airlines said the decision to remain with Pratt engines came after ``four months of exhaustive evaluation.'' The company said it also had considered engines produced by Pratt's major rivals _ General Electric's CF6-80C2 and Rolls-Royce's Trent 650 _ but concluded that while all three companies offered high-quality, high-technology products, Pratt's engines were preferable. ``Taking into account all factors, including financial and technical, SIA decided that Pratt & Whitney ... engines had the edge over the other engines,'' the airline's statement said. Airline officials also said the new aircraft will permit the company to compete better and ``take advantage of growth opportunities provided by the changing global environment.'' In addition to providing modern power, the airline said, the new Pratt-powered fleet will be more fuel efficient and help reduce pollution as well as costs.

DOC.HEAD: Booming Auto Industry Gathers For Geneva Show, Korean Premiere
With AM-Auto Outlook Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Thursday's opening of the Geneva Motor Show, one of the world's biggest, comes against a backdrop of increasing U.S. and Japanese efforts to set up plants inside the integrating European Community. Worldwide auto sales grew again in 1989, reaching record levels for the fifth straight year, but industry watchers expect competition in major markets to increase further and growth to slow slightly this year. Many of the new models to be featured at the Geneva show's 60th annual edition reflect how the industry is relying on powerful, sporty cars with designer bodies to meet that competition. Ninety-nine automakers are displaying latest models at the 10-day show, which is aimed mostly at the tastes of non-American car buyers. Switzerland is considered a highly competitive market because it is highly motorized but has no domestic auto industry. Hyundai, which launched into the U.S. market in the 1980s, is a new entry at Geneva this year. The South Korean maker is showing its economy Pony model and the top-of-the-line Sonata sedan, which listed at up to $19,660 in Switzerland. With manufacturers increasingly fighting for the medium to high-priced sports car bracket, each of Japan's big three makers is offering a new model. Nissan's 300 ZX, listed at $50,000, features a 280-horsepower V6 engine and four-wheel steering. New sporty offerings from Mazda and Toyota sell for about $20,000. Italian makers Alfa Romeo, Fiat and Lancia, plus France's Peugeot, are showing substantially revamped sedans. World passenger car production rose 3.8 percent last year to 35.5 million units, with Japan gaining market share mainly at the expense of U.S. automakers, industry figures show. But non-European manufacturers, particularly the Japanese, are increasingly signaling fears about losing out in the giant European market the EEC is due to complete by the end of 1992. Officials of Honda and Nissan called on the EEC Wednesday to abolish restrictions on Japanese car imports as soon as possible after 1992. In interviews in Geneva, Osamu Iida of Honda Motor Europe Ltd. and Yoshikazu Kawana of Nissan Europe NV, rejected a charge made this week by the French minister for European affairs, Edith Cresson, that Japanese automakers want to destroy their U.S. and European competitors. Kawana said Europe's consumers and its auto industry will suffer if France succeeds in efforts to extend EEC curbs on Japanese imports for 10 or 12 years after 1992.

DOC.HEAD: Times Mirror Subsidiary Buys Five Weeklies
DOC.TEXT: Five weekly newspapers in southwestern Connecticut and southern New York have been sold to Southern Connecticut Newspapers Inc., publisher of The Advocate and Greenwich Time. SCN will buy Acorn Press Inc., which publishes The Ridgefield Press, The Wilton Bulletin, The Redding Pilot, The Bethel Home News in Connecticut and The Ledger of Lewisboro, N.Y. The papers have a combined circulation of 21,800. Terms of the agreement were not disclosed. Acorn, based in Ridgefield, has been owned and operated since 1937 by the Nash family, headed by Karl S. Nash, president and principal stockholder. SCN is a subsidiary of Times Mirror Co. of Los Angeles. The Advocate has a circulation of 30,912 daily and 38,724 on Sundays; Greenwich Time has a circulation of 13,276 daily and 13,295 on Sundays. ``The acquisition of Acorn Press is a strategic one for Southern Connecticut Newspapers because it allows us to expand in the market and the business we know best _ publishing high-quality newspapers specializing in local news coverage, serving demographically strong Fairfield County,'' said William J. Rowe, publisher and chief executive officer of The Advocate and Greenwich Time. ``I am confident that Times Mirror's Fairfield County dailies will ably guide the further growth of our little oaks, and I'm proud of the devoted, hard-working and competent people who produce our newspapers,'' Nash said.

DOC.HEAD: Wheat Futures Prices Rise
DOC.TEXT: Futures prices for wheat were stronger while corn and soybean prices were slightly lower at the close Wednesday on the Chicago Board of Trade. ``The corn market backed off, with a forecast for rain moving into the corn belt,'' said Rich Feltes, an analyst with Revco Inc. Soybeans changed direction several times during the session due to a lack of export and other news, although there was an increase in farmers' selling overnight, traders said. Professional and fund-type buying supported wheat. At the close, wheat was } cent lower to 1\ cents higher with the contract for delivery in March at $3.80{ a bushel; corn was { cent to 1{ cents lower with March at $2.43 a bushel; oats were 1{ cents lower to \ cents higher with March at $1.44} a bushel; and soybeans were } cent higher to 1\ cents lower with March at $5.77} a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: French Publishing Giant Enters Eastern Europe
DOC.NOTE: For Release 6 p.m. EST, time set by source
DOC.TEXT: The French group Expansion, which publishes 25 economic periodicals in Western Europe, announced that it was breaking into the East European market through a joint venture with a Polish publisher. Expansion's Eurexpansion unit is linking up with Zarzadzanie I Bankow, publisher of the financial weekly Gazeta Bankowa, to jointly produce Gazeta. The Polish magazine will make use of Expansion's editorial and marketing expertise and tap into the French group's information network, according to a statement for release Thursday by the Paris-based company. The publication hopes to double the 16 pages it prints each week and will continue to carry foreign exchange and commodity prices, analyses of government policies, and profiles of emerging Polish companies. The agreement marks the first time the publishing industry has taken advantage of a new Polish law allowing foreign companies to hold a majority in joint ventures. Under the terms of the accord, Eurexpansion will hold 51 percent of the venture, while Zarzadzanie will have 49 percent. Zarzadzanie President Josef Sniecinski said that with help from Eurexpansion he hopes to double Gazeta Bankowa's current estimated circulation of 22,000. Sneicinski, jailed for four years for his political beliefs, founded Gazeta in 1988, the Eurexpansion statement said. The Gazeta name is taken from a similar business tabloid founded in 1926, which didn't survive under Communist rule. Expansion created Eurexpansion last year, and its shareholders include Belgium's Mediafina, Class Editori of Italy and Dow Jones & Co. of the United States. The Eurexpansion accord follows news Tuesday that French publishing giant Robert Hersant, a unit of Socpresse, will launch two business periodicals in a joint venture with two Soviet companies. Hersant's new publication, entitled ``Businessman,'' will be published in Russian, while the other, ``Business in the USSR,'' will be in English. Hersant is seeking circulation of 100,000 for the former and 40,000 for the latter, according to French press reports. Sources, who spoke on condition they not be identified, said Eurexpansion also is looking into possible ventures in the Soviet Union.

DOC.HEAD: Al-Fayed Brothers Lied in Harrods Takeover, Government Says
DOC.TEXT: The Al-Fayed brothers, who waged a bitter $1 billion battle for Harrods in 1985, exaggerated their wealth and background to win the famous department store, a government report said Wednesday. Mohamed, Ali and Salah Al-Fayed were thought to have come from a wealthy and established Egyptian trading family that exported cotton to Lancashire in the 19th century and built up a shipping empire, when really they were the sons of a teacher from a poor quarter of Alexandria, Egypt, the report said. The Al-Fayeds denied Wednesday that they misled anyone in connection with the battle for Harrods owner House of Fraser PLC. Lonrho PLC, which lost the fight for Harrods and has continued to battle the Al-Fayeds for the past five years, launched a fresh multi-pronged assault Wednesday. Lonrho Chairman Edward du Cann said the government, Parliament and the British financial community must act quickly on the report or the credibility of all three would be undermined. The government released its previously withheld report after the Serious Fraud Office and the Director of the Public Prosecutions said last week they would not pursue a criminal prosecution stemming from the takeover. The government has repeatedly declined to refer the bid to the Monopolies and Mergers Commission and did so again on Wednesday. Trade Secretary Nicholas Ridley said in the House of Commons he had referred the trade department's report to authorities to determine whether there should be any prosecution for giving false evidence to investigators. However, he said he would not seek to have any House of Fraser directors disqualified. Documents produced by the Al-Fayeds as evidence for the trade department's investigation, including their birth certificates, were false and they knew they were false, the government report said. The report said it was likely the brothers used their association with the Sultan of Brunei raise funds toward the 1985 purchase of the department store chain. The Al-Fayeds did not have enough money of their own to buy House of Fraser, trade department inspectors Hugh Aldous and Sir Henry Brooke said. The Al-Fayeds said in a statement they bought House of Fraser chain with cash of their own. The trade department's investigation was unfair and the accusations ``worthless,'' they said. Roland ``Tiny'' Rowland, Lonrho's chief executive, has waged a long, expensive and very public campaign to have the takeover reversed, repeatedly alleging that the Al-Fayeds misrepresented themselves to win Harrods. The Al-Fayeds repeatedly have denied those allegations. Over the years, Rowland has developed a reputation for obsessively pursuing a bitter, unsuccessful vendetta. Lonrho is pursuing its own claims in civil court, du Cann said Wednesday. Mohamed Al-Fayed, who serves as House of Fraser chairman and is visibly proud of owning the crown jewel of British retailing, has vowed that ``only God'' would take Harrods away from him. Founded in 1849 by tea merchant Henry Charles Harrod, Harrods boasts that it provides everything from baby clothes to funerals, from furnished palaces to fresh pheasants. Its five-story red-brick building in fashionable Knightsbridge is a major tourist attraction and a shopping haunt of Britain's royal family.

The stock market edged ahead today, getting a bit more mileage out of its late-winter rally. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, up 112 points from Feb. 24 through Tuesday's close, rose another 1.80 to 2,678.60 by 3 p.m. on Wall Street. Advancing issues slightly outnumbered declines in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 767 up, 702 down and 486 unchanged. Analysts said hopes persisted that the economy could keep growing at a sluggish pace, avoiding the recession that many feared might have taken hold by now. There are some expectations that that view will be bolstered on Friday with the government's monthly report on the employment situation, which will provide one of the first gauges of economic activity in February. The data are expected to show an increase of 200,000 to 250,000 in nonfarm payroll employment, compared with a 275,000 gain in January. Stocks also got a boost Tuesday from a downturn in open-market interest rates. In today's trading in the market for U.S. Treasury securities, rates showed only slight and mixed changes. MGM-UA Communications jumped 3| to 17| on word of a $20-a-share takeover offer from Pathe Communications. Compaq Computer rose 2] to 91 and Businessland was up 2 at 10}. Compaq gave Businessland the right to sell its products in the United States, renewing a business connection severed more than a year ago. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks gained .07 to 186.24. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was up .46 at 359.27. Volume on the Big Board came to 136.11 million shares with an hour to go.

DOC.HEAD: House Upholds Veto of Bill to Let Government Intervene in Eastern Dispute
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs, with new material, editing. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The House today upheld President Bush's veto of a bill to let the government intervene in the year-old Eastern Airlines dispute. The 261-160 vote was 7 votes short of the two-thirds needed to overturn the veto. Bush vetoed in December a measure creating a special panel to investigate and recommend solutions to the bitter dispute between Eastern and 8,500 mechanics and other ground service workers. He said Congress had no business intervening in a labor-management dispute. Override supporters said it was the last chance to save the bankrupt carrier and jobs for the machinists who walked out last March. But members who sided with Bush said a congressional panel would not be able to solve the dispute and the matter belonged in bankruptcy court. During debate on the override attempt, Rep. Bud Schuster, R-Pa., accused Democrats of having an ``uncontrollable urge to bash the president'' on the issue. But Rep. James McDermott, D-Wash., said ``our government is turning its back on the working men and women of this country. The president said there is no emergency, but he doesn't have to fly on an airline that's on the verge of collapse.'' The vote dealt a huge blow to organized labor and gave Bush a victory in his second veto confrontation of the election-year session. Bush also won the first showdown in January, when the Senate narrowly upheld his veto of a measure protecting Chinese students. Union officials contend Bush has sided with Frank Lorenzo, head of Texas Air Corp., Eastern's parent company, in the dispute and therefore is supporting what they consider union-busting practices by Lorenzo. ``Some Republicans are going to support the president on this, but I think they're going to do it holding their nose and walking the plank for a person they don't particularly feel good about,'' Oberstar said, referring to Lorenzo. Eastern sought bankruptcy protection in March 1989 shortly after the International Association of Machinists walked out. The machinists were later joined by pilots and flight attendants, who ended their strike late last year. The machinists are still out. Eastern has hired replacements for some of the strikers and has tried to reorganize itself as a smaller carrier. White House spokesman Stephen Hart said the administration still thinks the Eastern strike ``is something that we should not be involved in.'' In a letter to House members Tuesday, Machinists President George Kourpias said an override would ``send a loud clear signal that it is time to stop labor-bashing.'' On Monday, bankruptcy examiner David Shapiro sent a leader to House Republican leader Robert Michel of Illinois urging Congress to stay out of the dispute, saying its intervention might jeopardize the remaining 17,000 jobs at Eastern.

DOC.HEAD: Automakers Review Sales Estimates
LaserPhoto DT1
DOC.TEXT: The nation's Big Three automakers are reviewing their estimates for 1990 sales amid signs that sales early this year have been stronger than they had expected. ``I think that as the year begins to unfold, that the more optimistic forecast of more like 14.5 million cars and trucks is more likely,'' Chrysler Corp. Vice Chairman Gerald Greenwald said in an interview Tuesday. Late last year, Chrysler was the most pessimistic of the Big Three companies, forecasting car and truck sales industrywide of 14.2 million for 1990, down from 14.85 million in 1989. ``Backing up three months as the fourth quarter of last year unfolded, there was a lot of concern that this year could really be tough,'' Greenwald said. Since then, Chrysler and General Motors Corp. have delayed factory shutdowns and layoffs, January and February sales were running less than 1 percent behind last year's rate and the spring buying season is getting under way. On Monday, when February sales figures were reported, Robert Rewey, Ford Motor Co.'s North American sales vice president, indicated that the No. 2 automaker may revise its estimate. ``Looking at the first two months of the new year, sales are not only much improved from the fourth quarter, but somewhat ahead of the pace we anticipated when establishing our industry forecast of 14.5 million units in 1990,'' he said. GM Chairman Roger Smith predicted as recently as last week that sales for the year will come in between 14.5 million and 15 million with a bias toward the upper end of the range. However, auto analyst Joseph Phillippi of Shearson Lehman Hutton of New York City, who is holding to his sales prediction of about 14.3 million cars and trucks, said even though the sales rate may be higher than originally projected, the increase is coming at a price. ``When you have a thousand dollars a unit (in incentives) in the marketplace for all the manufacturers on average, you should be able to sell anything, even ice to Eskimos,'' Phillippi said. ``We're pumping units out the door, but it's essentially profitless prosperity.'' Each of the Big Three companies reported sharply lower profits for the fourth-quarter and all of 1989, partly because of incentive costs, and there are predictions that the earnings downturn will continue. Yet there are indications that automakers aren't as worried about the next few months as they were during the last months of last year. GM has put off for a few months the closing of its Lakewood car assembly plant in Atlanta. Late last year, that shutdown, which will result in about 2,200 workers being laid off, was scheduled for mid-March. Now, GM says, it won't happen until April or May. Chrysler also indefinitely suspended some planned reductions in assembly line speeds, which also would have resulted in indefinite layoffs. Ford plans no changes in production that will result in layoffs. The reductions are aimed at bringing production levels more into line with sales levels. But, as Rewey said, sales for the first two months of the year seem to be running a bit above anticipated levels. In January and February this year, automakers sold 2.19 million cars and trucks, down just 0.8 percent from last year, when companies were offering attractive incentives. Typically, March and April are strong car and truck sales months as Americans get ready for spring and summertime road trips. Last year, the sales pace during those two months lagged mainly because of the attraction of incentives offered earlier in the year. This year, things could be different. Automakers and dealers are ready to let their inventories of unsold cars creep up in anticipation of an increased buying pace. Chrysler recently extended an incentive program through March for all of its vehicles except minivans, and Ford and GM cash-back and low-interest financing offers run into April or May. ``What would we do if we didn't have that?'' Phillippi wondered about incentive-enhanced sales. ``It's pretty clear that we are going to have that all the way through the 1990 model year. ``I can't see incentives coming down appreciably unless there's a heck of a lot more strength in the economy.''

DOC.HEAD: Help-Wanted Index Down 3 Points in January
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Hold for Release at 6:30 p.m. EST
DOC.TEXT: The Conference Board said Wednesday its help-wanted advertising index, which measures the local, regional and national supply of jobs, fell 3 points in January. The business research group said the seasonally adjusted index fell to 146 in January from 149 in December. In January 1989, the index was at 155. Advertising volume in major newspapers rose in four regions of the country, declined in four and remained unchanged in one, according to the monthly survey. The East South Central and Mountain regions posted the steepest declines, 10 percent and 9.9 percent respectively, while the West South Central area had the sharpest increase, 7.7 percent. ``The nation's unemployment rate has been holding steady at 5.3 percent for five months,'' said Ken Goldstein, a Conference Board economist. ``There is widespread anticipation of sustained moderate growth, which could easily lead to some pickup in labor demand. ``Presently, there is little concern about a recession. However, labor demand is not softening, which may spell problems later this year,'' he said. The monthly survey examines help-wanted advertising in 51 major newspapers across the country. In the East South Central region, the newspapers are located in Birmingham, Ala.; Knoxville, Memphis and Nashville, Tenn.; and Louisville, Ky.; the Mountain region includes papers in Denver, Colo.; Phoenix, Ariz.; and Salt Lake City, Utah. In the West South Central area, the survey included Dallas, Houston and San Antonio, Texas; New Orleans, La.; and Oklahoma City and Tulsa, Okla.

DOC.HEAD: Slide Continues
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures continued to slide Wednesday, with refined oil products posting steep losses. Analysts said fundamental supply and demand factors plus technical market forces encouraged selling on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The contract for April delivery of West Texas Intermediate, the key grade of U.S. crude oil, lost 37 cents to close at $20.93 per 42-gallon barrel after shedding 28 cents on Tuesday. Later contracts finished lower by slightly smaller amounts. The April contract of unleaded regular gasoline tumbled 1.06 cents to 56.73 cents a gallon, bringing its decline over the past two sessions to 2.57 cents. On Monday the contract spurted 2.83 cents. Contracts for delivery further in the future also declined, with the May contract off 1.08 cents. Among other refined products traded on the New York Merc, No. 2 home heating oil for April delivery dropped 1.03 cents to 56.19 cents a gallon on top of Tuesday's loss of 0.77 cent. The April contract soared 2.12 cents on Monday. Later contracts also finished lower. James Steel, an analyst at Refco Inc., said traders sold in response to weekly figures from the American Petroleum Institute showing crude oil stocks expanded slightly more than expected. The increase in gasoline stocks was more in line with market expectations. The API report was released Tuesday after the market closed. ``Everybody thinks there are adequate stocks right now,'' Steel said. West Texas Intermediate also has been considered overpriced relative to comparable grades of crude traded on foreign markets. Recent selling has pushed the April WTI contract below $21 a barrel, breaking through what had been a technical support level. Heating oil prices have begun their normal seasonal weakness due to lower demand during warm weather months, Steel said. ``From a trading point of view the winter's over,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Georgia Pacific Announces Completion of Tender for Great Northern
DOC.TEXT: Georgia-Pacific Corp. said Wednesday it has completed its tender offer for Great Northern Nekoosa Corp. stock and plans to begin buying the 53.8 million outstanding shares of the Connecticut paper products maker this week. The $65.75-a-share tender offer expired at midnight Tuesday, and Atlanta-based Georgia-Pacific said 97.3 percent of Great Northern's outstanding shares had been tendered by the deadline. ``We expect to start purchasing the 58 million shares tomorrow,'' Georgia-Pacific spokeswoman Sheila Weidman-Farley said. After a bitter 3{-month holdout, Great Northern's management agreed last month to a sweetened buyout bid from Georgia-Pacific. The $5 billion merger is expected to produce the nation's largest forest products company. Georgia-Pacific had $10 billion in sales last year, while Great Northern, headquartered in Norwalk, Conn., had 1989 sales of $4 billion. Ms. Weidman-Farley said the company was satisfied with the 97.3 percent tender and had not expected to get 100 percent. Stockholders who did not tender their shares will be issued stock certificates worth $65.75 each which can be cashed in at any time, she said. Shares which were not tendered include those held in trusts, by people who are out of the country or by opponents of the takeover. ``It's impossible to get 100 percent,'' Ms. Weidman-Farley said. ``So everyone was pleased with this number.'' She said Georgia-Pacific is compiling financial disclosure material required by the Securities and Exchange Commission before the buyout can be completed. The SEC filing, to be made within 30 days, will be followed by a shareholders meeting required by the takeover laws in Maine, where Great Northern is chartered. No date has been set for the shareholders meeting, she said. Initially, Great Northern will operate as a wholly owned subsidiary of Georgia-Pacific, Ms. Weidman-Farley said. Company officials have declined to say specifically what their plans are for Great Northern's mills.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Rules For American Tobacco In Smoking Liability Case
DOC.TEXT: A federal jury decided Wednesday that American Tobacco Co. should not be held liable for the death of a lung cancer patient, rejecting claims that the company failed to warn the public about the dangers of cigarette smoking. The six-member jury deliberated about two hours before returning its verdict, culminating a three week trial. Lawyers representing the plaintiff, the cancer victim's widow, said they would consider an appeal. ``This just puts a further chill on anyone having the audacity to take on one of the empires of industry,'' said Eric Nissen, one of the plaintiff's attorneys. Andrew Lane, an attorney for American Tobacco, declined to comment on the verdict. Earlier in the day during his closing arguments, Lane stressed that the lung cancer victim, George Kotler, had ample opportunity to quit smoking but chose to continue his habit. The suit against American Tobacco, a subsidiary of American Brands Inc. in Greenwich, Conn., marked one of the rare smoker death cases to reach the courtroom. The first case to have a damages judgment came in 1988, when a federal jury in New Jersey awarded $400,000 to Antonio Cipollone, whose wife died of lung cancer. But an appeals court this year overturned the jury award and ordered a new trial. The Boston suit was filed by Joanne Kotler, whose husband began smoking when he was 11 and died in 1986 at age 55. The case focused on his smoking habits and American Tobacco's actions prior to 1966, when Congress required warning labels on cigarette packs. Lane told the jury that the first credible evidence linking lung cancer to smoking surfaced in the 1950s, but the studies were not definitive and some medical experts disagreed with the findings. Lane also argued that warnings would not have made a difference for Kotler. He said that during the 1950s, the debate over cigarette smoking became more widely reported, culminating with a highly publicized report from the U.S. surgeon general in 1964 warning of the health risks. But Lane said Kotler, who regularly read newspapers and likely was aware of the controversy, did not heed the warnings. The first time Kotler quit smoking was in 1975, when advised to do so by his doctor, and he resumed several months later when his health improved. ``Forty million people have stopped smoking,'' Lane said. They made the decision. That's what this case is really about _ choice.'' But Garry Inge, another attorney who helped present the case against the cigarette company, argued that American Tobacco had a duty to alert the public of the risks so Kotler could make an informed choice. Studies in the 1940s warned about the dangers of smoking, but American Tobacco's response was to encourage people to buy its products, he said. ``Burying your head in the sand is not a defense,'' he said. ``When you're talking about people dying, you cannot wait for scientific proof.'' Inge also said the addictive nature of nicotine contributed to Kotler's smoking habit. But Lane said when Kotler first tried to quit smoking, he showed no symptoms of withdrawal. ``This was not a man compelled by the outside,'' he said.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 15th graf to include Wilshire Index.
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices posted some spotty losses Wednesday after the market ran into an afternoon flurry of selling. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, up more than 8 points at midmorning, closed with a 7.21 loss at 2,669.59. Declining issues held a slight edge on advances in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 740 up, 762 down and 482 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 163.58 million shares, up from 143.64 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 194.78 million shares. Analysts said hopes persisted that the economy could keep growing at a sluggish pace, avoiding the recession that many feared might have taken hold by now. There are some expectations that that view will be bolstered on Friday with the government's monthly report on the employment situation, which will provide one of the first gauges of economic activity in February. The data are expected to show an increase of perhaps 250,000 in nonfarm payroll employment, compared with a 275,000 gain in January. Stocks got a boost Tuesday from a downturn in open-market interest rates. By contrast, in Wednesday's trading in the market for U.S. Treasury securities, rates showed a modest increase. MGM-UA Communications jumped 3} to 17} on word of a $20-a-share takeover offer from Pathe Communications. Pathe shares gained { to 4}. Compaq Computer rose 3| to 92\ and Businessland was up 2 at 10}. Compaq gave Businessland the right to sell its products in the United States, renewing a business connection severed more than a year ago. Nynex, which said a proposed rate agreement for its New York Telephone subsidiary was rejected by state regulators, dropped 2} to 80{. Among other regional telephone issues, Pacific Telesis fell 1\ to 44\; Bell South ~ to 53], and U.S. West 1[ to 70[. Losers among the blue-chip industrials included Exxon, down | at 46{; International Business Machines, down \ at 105{, and General Motors, down } at 45\. Home Depot gained 2\ to 43~, trading at record highs. The retailer of home improvement and do-it-yourself merchandise said profits for its latest fiscal quarter were up about 57 percent. Esterline Corp., which posted higher quarterly operating earnings, added } to 12. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market lost $5.408 billion, or 0.17 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks dropped .40 to 185.77. Standard & Poor's industrial index slipped .52 to 389.02, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was down .98 at 336.95. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market edged up .14 to 432.47. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 359.03, up .22.

DOC.HEAD: NEC, AT&T To Cooperate in Semiconductor Technology, Production
With AM-Computer Software, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Japan's NEC Corp. and American Telephone & Telegraph Co. said Wednesday they would cooperate in developing and making a wide range of semiconductors and other computer technologies. The agreement should enhance the U.S. company's access to Japan's world-dominating electronics market. NEC, the world's largest maker of semiconductors, agreed to cooperate with AT&T's Microelectronics division on various projects for at least five years. Under the agreement, AT&T Microelectronics will receive a license to market, design and produce NEC's advanced gate-array computer chips, which are used widely in computers and other electronics devices. AT&T did not have the technology to produce these chips on its own, spokeswoman Barbara Baklarz said from AT&T Microelectronics headquarters in Berkeley Heights, N.J. ``An important feature of this agreement is that customers of both companies will enjoy the advantage of having two stable sources of identical gate-array products,'' William Warwick, president of AT&T Microelectronics, told reporters in Tokyo. In return, NEC will receive AT&T's most sophisticated computer-aided tools used to design computer chips, Warwick said. He said the two companies also are working on accelerating the placement of AT&T semiconductor products into a variety of NEC products, such as communications systems and computers. In addition, AT&T Microelectronics will help manufacture certain NEC chips widely used in consumer electronics products. ``This will allow Japanese customers to obtain products made by an American firm, and will give AT&T a greater presence in the Japanese market, especially with consumer electronics companies,'' Warwick said. ``This agreement shows that one single company cannot stand alone and needs more resources to survive,'' said Tomohir Matsumura, an NEC executive vice president and director of its semiconductor division. ``It makes sense for AT&T as a big semiconductor user to go to NEC, a big semiconductor producer,'' said Charles Elliott, an electronics analyst with the investment firm Goldman Sachs & Co. ``But AT&T is also a big semiconductor developer, and it makes sense for AT&T to design and NEC to produce.'' Millard Phelps, an analyst with the San Francisco brokerage Hambrecht & Quist Inc., said the agreement is part of a global cooperation trend among electronics companies. AT&T Microelectronics announced two weeks ago that it will produce semiconductor memory chips for the international market in a joint venture with Mitsubishi Electric Corp., another major Japanese chip manufacturer. International Business Machines Corp. said in January that it would set up a joint venture with Siemens AG of West Germany to develop advanced memory chips. Neither AT&T nor NEC would attach monetary figures to the accord, but Warwick said he was confident it would be continued after five years. Gate-array chips are the logic chips that customize computers according to their use. They are a key component of a computer, along with its microprocessor, or ``brain,'' and its memory. AT&T lacked the technology to produce complementary metal oxide semiconductor, or CMOS, gate-array chips, Ms. Baklarz said. These are considered the most advanced gate-array chips. The agreement also will aid NEC's policy of increasing purchases of foreign semiconductors to ease trade friction. U.S. officials, angered by what they claim is a closed Japanese market to foreign semiconductors, say Japan agreed to boost the foreign share of the semiconductor market here to 20 percent by July 1991. But foreign chips' share stood at only 12.9 percent in the final quarter of 1989, according to the Ministry of International Trade and Industry. NEC expects to purchase $5.3 million worth of AT&T semiconductors in 1990, and more in 1991, though there is no target figure for next year, NEC spokeswoman Akiko Sato said. The manufacturer plans to raise its internal use of foreign computer chips from the current 20 percent to 23 percent by July 1991, when the U.S.-Japan semiconductor accord expires, and to about 24 percent by the end of next year, Miss Sato said.

DOC.HEAD: Orange Juice Futures Climb
DOC.TEXT: Futures prices for frozen concentrate orange juice climbed higher Wednesday at New York's Cotton Exchange on speculation that the U.S. Agriculture Department would revise downward its estimate of Florida's orange crop. On other futures markets, pork bellies rose the faily limit, energy and gold prices tumbled and grains were mixed. The USDA had earlier estimated 68 million boxes of oranges would be harvested, but apparently came up 3 million short, said analyst Judith Ganes of Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. A revised report is due out Friday. Futures prices have gone up about 80 cents since December's freeze, peaking at over $2 a pound in mid-Janaury. On Wednesday, frozen orange juice settled .40 cent to 2.15 cents higher, with the contract for delivery in March at $1.91 a pound. Prices for frozen pork bellies soared while other livestock prices drifted mostly higher on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. March, May, July and August contracts for bellies closed up the daily limit of 2 cents. Light hog slaughter and firm cash prices supported prices in the pork complex, said Dale Benson, an analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. ``The market also saw the U.S. giving the Soviet Union preferred nation status and Canada sending beef carcasses to the Soviets. Traders see any exports going elsewhere as exports are not coming here. That's good,'' said Benson. Cattle settled .03 cent lower to .50 cent higher, with the contract for April at 76.67 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .05 cent lower to .12 cent higher, with March at 81.47 cents a pound; hogs were unchanged to 1.10 cents higher, with April at 51.42 cents a pound; and frozen pork bellies were 1.55 cents to 2.00 cents higher, with March at 50.27 cents a pound. Energy futures tumbled on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Crude oil prices were pressured by an American Petroleum Institute report Tuesday that showed larger inventories than anticipated. Heating oil had opened higher on news of a decline in the API distillate stock and a New Jersey barge explosion that dumped 100,000 gallons into the water. Crude oil settled 4 cents to 37 cents lower, with the contract for delivery in April at $20.93 a barrel; heating oil was .55 cent to 1.03 cents lower, with April at 56.19 cents a gallon; and unleaded gasoline was .55 cent to 1.08 cents lower, with April at 56.73 cents a gallon. Futures prices for corn were down, while soybeans and wheat were mixed on the Chicago Board of Trade. ``The corn market backed off, with a forecast for rain moving into the corn belt,'' said Rich Feltes, an analyst with Refco Inc. Soybeans changed directions several times during the session, due to a lack of export news or other developments concerning that commodity, although there was no increase in selling by farmers overnight, traders said. Professional buying supported wheat futures prices. Wheat settled \ cent lower to 1\ cents higher, with the contract for delivery in March at $3.81 a bushel; corn was 1 cent to 2 cents lower, with March at $2.43 a bushel; oats were unchanged to 1\ cents lower, with March at $1.44{ a bushel; and soybeans were 2 cents higher to 1\ cents lower, with March at $5.76} a bushel. Gold fell sharply on the Commodity Exchange in New York, due to a stronger U.S. dollar. Silver was boosted by some overnight buying in Zurich by Middle East interests, traders said. Gold settled $3.40 to $4.30 lower, with the contract for delivery in March at $400.20 a troy ounce; and silver was .3 cent to .6 cent higher, with March at $5.12 a troy ounce.

DOC.HEAD: Electronic Pricing Errors Found in State Probe of Store Chain
DOC.TEXT: Product pricing errors at a large discount store chain that used electronic price scanners has prompted the state to probe other stores for similar problems, Attorney General Donand Hanaway said Wednesday. State investigators announced Wednesday that a November investigation of ShopKo Stores Inc. outlets in Wisconsin found scanned prices at the checkout counter sometimes failed to match the advertised sale price on store shelves. Shopko, a Green Bay-based retailer with more than 90 outlets in Wisconsin and the Midwest, cooperated with the probe and has agreed to offer rebates of $1 to $5 to customers who discover future overcharges, Hanaway said. Gene Bankers, vice president of ShopKo, said the company had taken steps to prevent future overcharges. Hanaway said the investigation found 33 electronic pricing errors out of 270 items checked at 12 ShopKo outlets. Twenty-one of the errors involved overcharges, ranging from 2 cents to $9.99, while undercharges ranged from 2 cents to $5, he said. Hanaway said most of the pricing errors resulted because the electronic price scanners were immediately reprogrammed after a sale but the sale signs not removed from shelves. The attorney general said the overcharges ``were human errors and not an attempt to defraud customers,'' but the 12 percent error rate still was unacceptable. ``It's my suspicion that it's not just ShopKo,'' Hanaway said. ``It's much bigger than that. ``I am broadening the investigation to other general merchandising stores and food stores in the state to determine if pricing errors are occurring elsewhere,'' he said. John Gary, spokesman for the National Retail Federation in New York City, said he did not know of any nationwide problem with electronic scanning of sale items. ``This is the first time I've ever heard of this kind of thing,'' Gary said. Bankers said to avoid future problems ShopKo planned to put the expiration date of sales on all in-store advertisement signs. Hanaway said he believed the ShopKo probe was ``the first in Wisconsin and, we believe, the nation,'' he said. ``We know of no one else who has undertaken such an extensive investigation.'' Steve Nicks, director of the state Consumer Protection Agency, said similar checks may have been conducted on the local level at individual stores.

DOC.HEAD: Farmer Mac Ready to Pump Up Ag Credit Market
DOC.TEXT: Farmer Mac is a new kid on the financial block but is almost ready to start building muscle in the nation's agricultural credit market, officials said Wednesday. The Federal Agricultural Mortgage Corp. _ Farmer Mac _ was created a little more than two years ago by the Agricultural Credit Act of 1987 as a secondary market for agricultural real estate loans. Start-up procedures, which included the initial sale of $20 million in voting common stock to banks and other lenders, and the naming of a 15-member board of directors, are expected before Farmer Mac is ready to become active in the financial market later this year. John R. Dahl, chairman of the board, said after the corporation's second annual stockholders' meeting that underwriting standards and other guides must be developed meticulously to ensure integrity. Dahl said Farmer Mac has a ``very strong foundation'' and that all the deadlines specified by Congress have been met. The aim of Farmer Mac, he said, is to `` ... to increase the availability of capital, to allow agricultural borrowers and rural housing borrowers an opportunity of more places to go to look for credit.'' Hopefully, Dahl added, these borrowers also ``will have the benefits of competition and competitive interest rates.'' But Dahl and Henry D. Edelman, the corporation's president and chief executive officer, said they could not estimate a firm timetable or identify those in line for actual ``pooling'' operations. Banks and other lenders can convert long-term assets _ in this case real estate mortgages _ by selling the loans on the secondary market. At that point, those who buy the mortgages package or pool the loans and then sell loan-backed securities to the general public. Meanwhile, the original lenders are able to increase their cash and use it to make more loans to agricultural borrowers. Farmer Mac will share the risk of the farm real estate loan business by guaranteeing returns on the securities. Other federal agencies such as the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. (Freddie Mac), Federal National Mortgage Association (Fannie Mae), and Government National Mortgage Association (Ginnie Mae) serve a similar function for their clientele. Dahl, a rancher from Gackle, N.D., said in an interview after the meeting that ``we've come a long way'' in getting Farmer Mac on solid ground. But he said there is no way to estimate the corporation's eventual impact on the nation's agricultural credit market. ``There's no history involved here,'' he said. ``There's a lot of enthusiasm for Farmer Mac, and I wish I could tell you that we're going to do a billion dollars in business, or something. But there's no way we can predict this.'' But what can be predicted, Dahl added, is that ``we're going to to everything we possibly can to come up with the kind of program that Congress envisioned agriculture needed.''

DOC.HEAD: Bolar Ex-President Settles With SEC, Talks Continue with Company
DOC.TEXT: Former Bolar Pharmaceutical Co. president Robert Shulman has settled securities fraud charges but negotiations are still underway with the generic drug maker itself, federal regulators said Wednesday. The Securities and Exchange Commission announced that Shulman consented _ without admitting or denying wrongdoing _ to a court order barring him from further alleged securities law violations. Despite a Bolar statement to the contrary earlier this week, ``the case against the company has not yet been settled,'' said Merri Jo Gillette-Meadows, an attorney with the SEC's Philadelphia regional office, which brought the case against Bolar. Ms. Gillette-Meadows confirmed that negotiations with the company were underway but would say no more. Last month, the SEC charged the drug maker with making misleading and inadequate statements to the investing public about an agreement with the Food and Drug Administration to suspend shipment of its products. Copaigue, N.Y.-based Bolar came under fire after allegations by a congressional panel that it appeared to have falsified lab test results on its generic high blood pressure medication. Bolar has said it will close most of its manufacturing operations while the FDA conducts an audit. The SEC said Shulman, who resigned from the company's board last month, settled with the SEC on Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Pathe to Buy MGM-UA Studios
LaserPhoto staffing
DOC.TEXT: After two years on the auction block, MGM-UA Communications said Wednesday it had accepted a $1.2 billion buyout offer by Italian financier Giancarlo Parretti's Pathe Communications Corp. Parretti also will take over $400 million in junk bond debt as part of the deal, which may be the final scene of a long-running drama in which a virtual cast of thousands considered buying all or part of MGM-UA. The proposed marriage would join companies holding extremely diverse film properties. Pathe's Cannon Releasing is a leading purveyor of exploitation films, with upcoming releases like ``American Ninja 4'' and ``Lambada: The Movie,'' while MGM is is one of Hollywood's jewels, responsible for everything from ``The Wizard of Oz'' to ``Rain Man.'' A $1.5 billion buyout of MGM was aborted last year when the suitor, Australia's Qintex Group, missed a $50 million down payment. MGM-UA Chairman Jeffrey C. Barbakow said MGM already had commitments from Pathe worth $100 million to distribute Pathe movies. The deal also requires Parretti to come up with $200 million ``earnest money,'' with the first $50 million deposit due Friday. ``If for whatever reason this doesn't close, then we have the money for damages,'' said Barbakow. He said he was confident Parretti could arrange financing for the deal, but declined to say where. Parretti was traveling Wednesday and could not be reached for comment. In the past, he has financed deals with help from Credit Lyonnais Group, the international financial giant. The deal is the latest step in the globalization of Hollywood. Sony Corp. acquired Columbia Pictures last year, Australia's News Corp. owns Fox, and the CBS, RCA and A&M record labels are owned by Japanese, German and Dutch companies. England's Television South PLC owns television's MTM Productions. MGM-UA has profitable TV and home video divisions and a film distribution system in place. It has been trying to start producing films again recently after a two-year fallow period while its controlling shareholder, Beverly Hills billionaire Kirk Kerkorian, sought a buyer. MGM-UA Communications has lost money in four of the last five years. The studio's only major release of 1990, ``Stanley & Iris,'' with Jane Fonda and Robert De Niro, was a critical and commercial disaster. Pathe, which grew out of Parretti's purchase of Cannon Group in 1987, produces and distributes movies worldwide and controls more than 1,000 theater screens in five countries. It has film production facilities in Italy, a processing lab in France, and the rights to 500 movies and 2,000 newsreels. ``MGM-UA's unique library and strong distribution capabilities complement Pathe's existing business worldwide,'' Parretti, Pathe's president and chief executive, said in a statement. ``We are confident the transaction will result in a strong, dual company structure which will be strongly competitive.'' Pathe is making a tender offer of $20 per share for MGM-UA's common stock, worth about $1 billion if all the shares are tendered. Kerkorian will tender all his common shares, 82 percent of the total, and also will sell his preferred stock to Pathe for about $200 million. The transaction was expected to close by June 23. MGM-UA's stock jumped $3.75 to $17.75 a share on the New York Stock Exchange. The companies said they would operate separately for the time being, but the actual management structure remained unclear. Barbakow said he and other officials intended to stay on at MGM. Many of them have worked with key Pathe officials in the past at MGM-UA and other studios. For example, Pathe's film chief, Alan Ladd Jr., once held that position at MGM-UA before he quit in 1988 over the company's lack of direction. ``As far as putting the management team together, that will have to be resolved in the next three to four weeks,'' said Richard Berger, MGM-UA's head of film production. Berger said MGM-UA already had committed $185 million to restarting movie production, and said he assumed more would be forthcoming from the new buyers. Analysts have estimated it would take $500 million for $600 million over two years for MGM-UA to re-establish itself as a major movie producer. On Monday, the companies announced MGM-UA had reached a five-year deal to distribute films from Pathe, a coup for MGM, which is dependent on movies from independent producers until it gets its own product back in the distribution pipeline. Parretti, whose $8.9 million Beverly Hills mansion is filled with masterpiece paintings, owns a large European travel agency and acquired the Cannon Group in summer 1987. He used Cannon as a platform to make unsuccessful bids on several smaller entertainment companies, including De Laurentiis Group, New World Entertainment and Kings Road Entertainment. Besides Qintex, other potential buyers for MGM at various times included Rupert Murdoch's News Corp., which was outbid by Qintex last year, cable television magnate Ted Turner, Sony, producers Jon Peters and Peter Guber, Warner Communications, financier Marvin Davis, Weintraub Entertainment Group, PolyGram, The Walt Disney Co., C. Itoh and Co., and a variety of other industry players.

DOC.HEAD: Justice Raises No Objection to Latin American Routes Transfer
With AM-Eastern, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department has no objections to Eastern Airlines' proposed sale of its prized Latin American routes to rival American Airlines, the department said Wednesday. The proposed $471 million transaction still must be approved by the Transportation Department and the federal bankruptcy court in New York overseeing the reorganization of Miami-based Eastern. Joe Krovisky, a spokesman for the Justice Department's antitrust division, said the division informed the two airlines and the Transportation Department that its review of potential antitrust problems of the sale had yielded no reason to object. Earlier this week, Pan Am Corp. filed objections to the route sale with the Transportation Department, arguing that it would eventually make American the dominant airline in Miami. Pan Am asked for a hearing on the issue. Eastern and American have until March 13 to file responses to Pan Am's objections. Transportation Department spokesman Hal Paris said a decision on the sale probably would be made in three or four weeks. Under the agreement, American, the nation's largest airline, would take over Eastern's routes from Miami to Ecuador, Peru, Colombia, Bolivia, Panama, Guatemala, Costa Rica and Paraguay. Pan Am told the Transportation Department that it, rather than American, should be awarded service from Miami to Guayaquil and Quito, Ecuador; Lima, Peru; and Bogota, Colombia. Also included in the sale would be Eastern's Miami-Toronto route, which Pan Am said it should be awarded. A sale of the routes would reduce Eastern to about two-thirds its pre-strike size.

DOC.HEAD: Simmons Vows to Ban Lockheed `Golden Parachutes'
DOC.TEXT: Texas billionaire Harold Simmons said Wednesday he would seek to change Lockheed Corp.'s by-laws to ban management ``golden parachutes'' if his slate wins election to the company's board of directors. Simmons disclosed in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that Lockheed has rejected his bid to put the issue of large severance payments to management before shareholders at the annual meeting March 29. Such agreements are known as golden parachutes, specifying the payments due to executives of a company if they lose their jobs after an ownership change. Simmons holds an 18.9 percent stake in the Calabasas, Calif.-based defense contractor through a group of companies headed by his NL Industries Inc., a Houston chemicals company. Simmons, of Dallas, said he will seek to change the company's by-laws if his slate of candidates is elected to Lockheed's board.

DOC.HEAD: Farm Credit System's Profit Down 33 Percent in Fourth Quarter
DOC.TEXT: The Farm Credit System reported Wednesday that its fourth-quarter profit fell 33 percent from a year earlier. The system said it earned $181 million in the three months ended Dec. 31, down from $270 million in the fourth quarter of 1989. The decline in net income was due largely to a reduction in provisions for loan losses, reflecting an improvement in credit quality, said Daniel Bienz, a vice president of the Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corp., the financing arm of the farm credit system. He said net interest income rose while most expenses remained stable. Per-share figures do not apply. The Farm Credit System is a nationwide system of federally chartered agricultural lending institutions serving the rural economy and cooperatively owned by their borrowers. The system took several steps last year to streamline its structure following 1987 legislation that included the issuance of up to $4 billion in government-backed, low-interest loans. For all of 1989, the system earned $695 million, down from $704 million the previous year. ``For the second consecutive year, the system has achieved favorable results suggesting continued progress in returning to financial soundness and strength,'' said James A. Brickley, president and chief executive officer of the Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corp. Net interest income totaled $275 million for the fourth quarter, up from $216 million in the year-earlier quarter, and $1.01 billion for the full year, up from $787 million in 1988. The system said net interest income increased as a result of continued improvement in the credit quality of its loan portfolio stemming from a reduction in nonaccrual loans. When loans are placed on nonaccrual status they are accounted for only as they come in rather than when they are due.

DOC.HEAD: Argentines Sentenced in Lycra Extortion Scheme
DOC.TEXT: An Argentine convicted of trying to extort $10 million from the Du Pont Co. in exchange for stolen documents detailing the company's production of Lycra was sentenced Wednesday to 6{ years in prison. Two co-defendants received prison terms in U.S. District Court in a scheme involving sensitive documents taken from Du Pont's Lycra manufacturing plant in Mercedes, Argentina. Lycra is Du Pont's trade name for spandex, an elastic fiber used in clothing such as swimsuits and leotards. The Wilmington-based chemicals manufacturer controls more than 50 percent of the world spandex market, with more than $600 million in sales in 1988. Bruno Skerianz, 52, the alleged mastermind of the extortion plot, also was placed on three years' probation by U.S. District Judge Joseph Longobardi. Co-defendants Raul Armando Giordano, 37, and Antonio Ruben Inigo, 40, received 3{-year prison sentences and three years' probation. Attorneys for the defendants said they plan to appeal. The three were convicted in December of one count each of conspiracy to extort and attempted extortion. Each count carried a maximum penalty of 20 years in prison, a fine of up to $250,000 and a maximum five years' probation. Prosecutors said during the trial that Du Pont had to agree to pay for the documents or Skerianz would have sold them to a competitor. Du Pont also made an agreement with the three men that they would not work in spandex production for five years and that Du Pont would sell spandex yarn to a company chosen by Skerianz during the period, the government said. Defense lawyers maintained that Skerianz had not attempted extortion because he and the others had planned to manufacture spandex for Radicci, an Italian textile manufacturer. Skerianz had worked for Du Pont more than 20 years ago. The others resigned in the fall of 1988 from the Mercedes plant. The three defendants and Lorenzo de Bianchini were arrested in February 1989 in Geneva, Switzerland, after an aborted attempt to return the documents for $10 million. Petrosino was arrested at the beginning of last summer. Longobardi ordered the three defendants to pay $100 to a victims' compensation fund. He said he did not impose a fine or order restitution to Du Pont because of the defendants' bleak financial situations. The men were sentenced to concurrent terms on each count. A fourth defendant, Jose Petrosino, is fighting extradition from Italy. Charges against Maria I. Lorenzo de Bianchini, who testified for the prosecution, were dropped. Du Pont spokesman R. John Malloy said the company was pleased with the sentences, which he said would be ``a strong deterrent for those who might consider doing similar things.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Closes Mixed After Central Bank Intervention; Gold Declines
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf pvs, `We haven't... to CORRECT spelling of Levine; PICKS UP 8th graf pvs, `Despite the...
DOC.HEAD: Precede LONDON BC
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was mixed in foreign exchange trading Wednesday as it struggled against a concerted effort by central banks to bring the U.S. currency lower. Gold prices fell, closing below $400 an ounce in London. Traders reported the Federal Reserve and other central banks entered the currency markets to sell dollars, and a published report in Tokyo said the members of the Group of Seven industrial nations had agreed to intervene jointly to try to stop the dollar's climb. But the attempt was only partially successful. The dollar rose sharply in Europe and was mixed in New York, where it still managed to advance against the Japanese yen, the currency which the G-7 is trying the hardest to prop up. In New York, the dollar rose to 150.35 yen from late Tuesday's 149.85 yen. In Tokyo, the dollar advanced to 150.75 yen from 149.50 yen Tuesday. It was quoted in London at 151.15 yen. Richard Levine, vice president for foreign exchange at Elders Futures Inc., said the dollar appeared to be rising on commercial and investment demand, and not just on speculation. ``We haven't seen this kind of demand for dollars since the end of 1989, and probably going back to the summer of 1989,'' Levine said. Despite the efforts of the central banks, the increased demand for the dollar was likely to lift it even higher, he said. Overseas traders said the continuing lack of confidence in the Japanese yen and the West German mark, as well as a brighter view of the U.S. economy, is also supporting the dollar. The dollar fell against the mark in New York after rising in Frankfurt. In New York the dollar closed at 1.69815 marks, compared to late Tuesday's 1.7035, and in Frankfurt it closed at 1.7075 West German marks, up from 1.7005 marks. The dollar gained against the British pound. In New York, sterling slipped to $1.6465 from 1.6475 late Tuesday. In earlier London trading, the pound fell to $1.6388 from $1.6495. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's prices, included: 1.4995 Swiss francs, down from 1.5000; 5.7400 French francs, down from 5.7565; 1,252.75 Italian lire, down from 1,257.00; and 1.18305 Canadian dollars, down from 1.18565. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Tuesday's quotes, included: 1.5075 Swiss francs, up from 1.4985; 5.7665 French francs, up from 5.7450; 1.9155 Dutch guilders, up from 1.9105; 1,259.00 Italian lire, up from 1,254.75; and 1.1853 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1866. Gold dealers blamed the high dollar and a stronger Wall Street for the precious metal's decline. Advances in the U.S. currencies and the stock markets have made gold a less attractive investment. A troy ounce of gold fell $3.40 to $400.20 on the Commodity Exchange in New York. Republic National Bank of New York later quoted a bid of $400.60 a troy ounce, down $2.85 from late Tuesday. In London gold slipped below $400, closing at a late bid price of $399.25 a troy ounce, down from $405. In Zurich, the metal fell to $400.75, down from $405.50 late Tuesday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell $1.83 to close at a bid $402.90 an ounce. Silver prices were mixed. The metal gained 0.6 cent to close at $5.122 a troy ounce on the Comex in New York after falling in London to a late bid price of $5.13 a troy ounce, down from $5.15.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Rebound; Dollar Lower Against Yen
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with morning Nikkei, comments
DOC.TEXT: The key index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange rebounded sharply Thursday morning, while the U.S. dollar dropped against the yen. The dollar ended morning trading at 150.13 yen. It started the day at 150.25 yen, down 0.50 yen from Wednesday's close at 150.75 yen, and ranged between 149.85 yen and 150.35 yen. Reassured by the yen's recovery, the price of the benchmark 10-year No. 119 Japanese government bond inched up to 86.91 points, up from the previous day's close of 86.67. The bond's yield was 7.15 percent, down from 7.20 percent late Wednesday. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average gained 470.98 points, or 1.41 percent, ending morning trading at 33,833.32. The index, which had lost 428.74 points Wednesday, plunged further in early morning trading as arbitragers sold issues to collect profits out of the spread between the stock and futures markets, said Kazuhiro Nomura, a dealer with New Japan Securities Co. Program trading sell orders pushed the Nikkei below the 33,000-point mark temporarily, but the index made a dramatic recovery, recouping more than 860 points by the end of morning trading. ``... the index kept coming back even with frequent arbitrage sellings,'' Nomura said. ``The market seems to have hit its bottom.'' So far this year, the Tokyo Stock Exchange's key index has at its worst lost more than 5,500 points, or 14.3 percent. Yasuda Trust and Banking Co. and the department story Mitsukoshi have joined other major companies that have canceled or postponed new equity issues because of the market's weakness, Japanese news reports said Thursday. Foreign exchange dealers said the yen opened higher in Tokyo following dollar-selling intervention by the Bank of Japan in the Sydney market, which opens earlier than Tokyo. The extent of the central bank intervention in the Sydney market was not immediately known. The bank in recent weeks reportedly has sold billions of dollars in both Japanese and overseas markets to stem the yen's decline. Overnight intervention by the Federal Reserve Bank in New York also helped support the yen, dealers said. Discouraged by active intervention by central banks, market players were reluctant to push the dollar higher, a dealer with a major Japanese bank said.
